When he recovers from this Trance, he is able to tell what passes in that Place, and what those People transact there, of which Enquiry was made . Here no mention is made either of a Drum, Song, his Companions, or any Tokens of the Performance of the Business; which difference must be attributed to this, that each Author gives an Account of what seem'd most worth taking notice of to him, without excluding the rest, mentioned by others; so that from what has been said already, the use of the Drum can scarce be call'd in question; but what Olaus Petri relates of the Drums, made for this particular use, viz . That they have a Handle shaped like a Cross, deserves our special Observation. The Drum they make use of, says he, is the same as I deseribed to you before, with this difference only, that the lower part of it is divided into four Parts, by a Cross, by which the Sorcerer bolds it with one Hand . Here you find a Handle made in the shape of a Cross, of which make is the Drum, which I told you was prefented to me by my Lord Henry Flemming , Colonel of a Finland Regiment of Foot, the Draught of the lower Side of which you see in the next following Figure.

The Second is to find out a proper Remedy, viz . what Sort of Sacrifice will be most pleasing to their Gods, but especially to Storjunkare , without whose peculiar Favour they never hope to recover their Health. The beforementioned Author proceeds thus: This done, the Patient must make a Vow of a certain Sacrifice, of a Raindeer, Buil, He-Goat or Ram, or something else of this Kind, to be offered to some certain Storjunkare, dwelling in some certain Mountain or other . Neither is it left to the Choice of the Patient, but to the direction of the Drum-beater; it being his Province to prescribe, what they ought to do. Whatever the Drummer orders the Patient to do , says the same Author, he must perform, and either Sacrifice immediately, or at least promise to offer such a Sacrifice at a certain appointed Time . For it is the Business of him, who beats the Drum, to enquire (as I told you before) which of the Gods the Sacrifice is to be offered to, and what kind of Sacrifice will be acceptable to him; for the same Sacrifice is not pleasing to every one of their Gods, neither is the same God satisfied with one kind of Sacrifices at all times; so that the choice of it depends on the Manager of the Drum, whose direction the sick Person is to follow. The manner of performing it, is thus described by Samuel Rheen: When they pretend to Cure any Distemper by the help of the Drum, it is done in the following manner: The Patient must present the Drummer with two Rings, as a Reward for his Pains, one of Brass, the other of Silver; both which he tyes to his right Arm. The Drummer, after having put those two Rings in the same Bunch, which commonly is made use of, as often as the Drum is employed for those Purposes, beats the said Drum, singing all the while, as do likewise all the Men and Women there present, the first with a loud Voice, the latter somewhat lower . From the Motion and Position of the Rings, the Drum-beater makes his Conjecture, as we told you before. Lundius gives the following Account concerning this Method: If a Laplander happen to fall Sick in the Lapmark of Uma , they send for the next Neighbour, whom they think most expert in the management of the Drum. The first Thing to be done after his coming is, to Sacrifice one of the best Raindeer, belonging to the sick Body, or to his best Friend; then he begins to beat his Drum, and falling on the Ground, remains there for some time unmoveable, his Body being as hard as a Stone. In the mean while the rest there present sing a certain Song, which they have been taught by him beforehand, till he recovers his Senses, arises, takes up his Drum, and holding it up to his Head, beats it softly for some small time. After which he sits down very pensive, and begins to give them an Account of his Transactions; he tells them, that he has passed thro' the Body of the Terrestrial Globe, where he has met with the Antipodes, being conducted by his Genius, among a People of a very handsome and venerable Aspect; those People, he says, being advertised of his coming, had shut their Gates against him, but that by the affistance of his Genius, he had got among them thro' a Hole, where he had seen something belonging to the Sick Person, either his Hat, his Shoes, or perhaps his Mittens, or some such like Thing, which he was either able or unable to bring away. Their gencral Opinion is, That if the Drummer did bring it away, there is great Hopes of the Patients recovery, but if not, that he will Dye, and endure a great deal of Pain. And because they are fully persuaded, that the Soul of the Drummer does actually leave his Body and is carried to the Place he Names to them; they say that his Soul is brought back by his Genius over the highest Rocks and Mountains, with such swiftness, that the Sand and Stones doe flye about like Hail. Mr. Paul Venetus relates something not unlike this of the Tartars of the Province of Areladam . And these are the Things commonly performed by this Drum.

The Laplanders , notwithstanding they undergo a great deal of Hardship, yet enjoy a great share of Health. The Natives , says Olaus Petri Niurenius, are so healthful, that they neither have nor want any Physicians . And Samuel Rheen, The Laplanders are of a strong Constitution, being seldon afflicted with any of those Distempers which are frequent among other Nations . They scarce know what Sickness is, not so much as those Epidemical Distempers which sometimes afflict whole Nations. There is no such thing as putrid or burning Fevers, or the Plague in Lapland. In Lapland, says the same Author, you meet with no burning Fevers or the Plague ; nay if any Contagion be transferred thither, it loses its Virulency. Qlaus Petri Niurenis says, Some years ago a Pestilential Contagion was transported into Lapland, but no body was kill'd by it, except the Women that in Spinning choused it; for the coldncss of the Northern Climate soon disperses the viralent Vapours . Their only Epidemical Distemper is sore Eyes, which are often the Forerunners of Blindness; this is attributed to their constant sitting in their Huts, from their Infancy, which are both Winter and Summer pestred with Smoak. Their ordinary Disease , says he, is Sore Eyes; for the continual Smoak in their Huts, is so offensive to them, that most lose their Eye-sight as they grow old. Eric Plantin attributes the cause of it, besides the Smoak, to the light of the Fire. The Laplanders, says he, grow for the most part Blind at last, without question, because from their very Infancy they sit constantly in the Smoak and near the Fire . The same is confirmed by Olaus Petri Niurenius the Elder: Their greatest Trouble and Misery is, that they lose their Eye-sight when they grow old; this being a Disease more to them than any other Nation. This proceeds from their continual looking upon the Fire from their Infancy, which burns Day and Night, in the Winter and Summer, in the midst of their Huts . a Lundius is of Opinion, that the Mountaineers are Blinded by the Violent reflection of the Sun Beams upon the Ice and Snow of the Mountains. They are also sometimes troubled with the Plurisy, Inflammation of the Lungs, Pains in the Back, and Giddiness in the Head. Mr. Eric Plantin , in his Answer to my Letter says, Their most common Distempers are, the Pleurisy, Pains in the Brest and Back, and Dizziness in the Hend . And sometimes also the Small-Pox; for he adds, Sometimes they are inflicted with the Small-Pox . As they are subject but to few Distempers, so they àre Strangers to Physicians. Their universal Remedy against Internal Distempers are the Roots of a certain Moss call'd by them Jerth , or for want of those, the Stalks of Angelica. Their general Medicine, says Plantin, against any Internal Distempers is the Root of Moss, call'd Jerth; instead of which they substitute in those Places where it grows not, the Angelica, call'd by them Fadna, which is to be found every where. Lundius adds the Beavers Kidneys steep'd in Brandy. They boil the Angelica in Whey of Raindeers Milk, as I told you it was their Custom in that Chapter of their Diet. Samuel Rheen says of this, They use it likewise for a Medicine. Against the Scurvy , says Lundius , they drink Raindeers Blood; when they are afflicted with the Tooth-Ach (which is but seldom) they make a Tooth-Pick of the Wood of a Tree, which has been struck with Lightning, with this they pick their Teeth till they Bleed. Against the Pain in the Back, they anoint themselves with Grease of Serpents, or wear Beavers Teeth on the back-side of their Girdle; others have a Superstition, that if they turn themselves round extended upon the Ground, the first time they hear it Thunder in the Spring, this Cures all the Aches in the Back. When they are afflicted with Pains in their Limbs, they apply fired Chips, which occasioning an Ulcer, they pretend by that means to draw the viscous Humour thither, and to mitigate the Pain. Their common Remedy is , says Plantin, to take fired Chips, or the Moss growing on the Birch-Tree; this they apply to the Place where the Pain lies; if they hit it right, the Moss will fall off, of it self, and the subsequent ulcer removes the Pain. To their Wounds they use no other Plaisters, than the Rosin, which the Trees sweat out. If they are wounded , says he, they apply Rosin instead of a Plaister . If their Limbs are benummed with Cold, their Raindeers Cheese supplies them with an Infallible Medicine; they thrust a red hot Iron into the Cheese, and with the Oil, that distils from thence, anoint the affected Part, with incredible Success. Some apply the Cheese it self, cut in thin Slices; If their Limbs be spoiled by the Cold , says Olaus Petri, this Cheese they cut in thin Slices, and appyed warm is a present Remedy . They likewise boil this Cheese in Milk, against a Cough, and all other Distempers of the Breast and Lungs, arising from Cold; they drink it Hot. It is also a good Stomachick to rectifie the Indigestion of the Stomach, occasioned by drinking too much Water. This Cheese, says Olaus Petri, is good for the Stomach, when it is spoiled with taking too much Water . For the rest, as they are seldom troubled with any Distempers, so they commonly arrive to a great Age. As the Laplanders, says Samucl Rheen, are not subject to any dangerous Distempers, so they grom old, even to a great Age . He says some live above a Hundred, but most Seventy, Eighty or Ninery Years; notwithstanding which, they lose not much of their natural Vigour, being able to traverse the highest Mountains, and thickest Woods, and manage all other Affairs as before, neither get they any gray Hairs till they are very Old; They seldom grow Gray, says he. So that most of the Laplanders Dye rather for Age, than by any Distemper. But when ever any one is dangerously Ill, either by Age, or some Distemper, they have recourse to their Drum, to know whether he will recover or die, as I have told you before concerning their Drum. Mr. Matthias Steuchius, in his Letter written to me, has these Words: I remember, that a certain Laplander told me, that they can by their Drum, know the Hour and manner of Death of the Patient . And Eric Plantin says; They pretend to enquire by their Drum, whether the Patient will Live or Dye . After they are satisfied, he cannot live long, if any Pious and good Christians are prelent, they exhort the dying Person, to think of God and Christ. I was told, says Eric Plantin, by an old gray Headed Laplander, who formerly went to School at Pitha, that those who are well instructed in the Christian Religion, used to exhort the Patient to remember God . But such as are no great Admirers of the Christian Religion, are careful only about the Funeral Feast, which they begin sometimes, before the Patient is expired. One Thomas, says Steuchius, a rich Laplander, being desperately Ill, beyond all Hopes of Recovery, sent for his Friends and Relations. These finding him to draw near his end, went to an Inn, where those that travel to Norway and Jempterland, used to lodge; there they stay'd a whole Day, which they spent it drinking of Strong-Beer and Brandy, the best Sacrifice they could make him, whilst yet alive, and then returning to the Hut, found him Dead . This being an Instance of a later Date, gives us sufficient reason to make due Reflections upon the just Complaints inserted in the introduction to the Grant of K. Gustave Adolph for creating a Lapland School, where among other Matters he says of the Laplanders: Those which live in the remotest Parts, among the Mountains of Norway, if they are Sick, and destitute of all Comfort, there being no Body, who administers the Sacrament to them, but they Dye without Consolation or Absolution. He alledges the Reason; Because the Devil at that nick of Time makes use of all his Tomptations, to become Masier of their Souls , viz. The Devil insinuates into them, to neglect all these Things, as vain Inventions, so that instead of those of their Friends that are good Christians, they send for such, as take more Care of their Belly's, than the Salvation of the Sick Person. But whenever any of them Dies, let the Distemper be what it will, they all forsake the Hut, where the Dead Carcass lies; it being their Opinion, that there is something remaining still of the Dead (as I told you before) such as the ancient Latines call'd Manes , and that not always of a Benign, but sometimes of a malignant Nature, which makes them dread any Dead Carcass; They are fearful of the Dead, says Samuel Rheen, for no sooner does any Body dye, but they leave the Place the same Day .

Formerly the neglect these miserable Wretches shew of their Salyation, was in a great measure attributed to the Ignorance and Carelesness of the Country Clergy; but since by the Care of the Swedish Kings, a Yearly Synod has been Convocated at Rival , for the regulation of Church-Affairs, and Examination of the Clergy-Men; it has been found by experience, that besides their unfitness for Devotion, by reason of the constant Fatigues they are forced to undergo, their antient Idolatry and Superstition, has taken so deep root among them, as not to be quite extirpated by the Art of Man; for such is their Inclination for Sorcery, that they are of Opinion their Cattel cannot thrive without it; for which reason, Fathers and Mothers, among these Peasants, are as careful to instruct their Children in it, as we do in the Cathechism and other good Morals. To elude the Effects of Charms, they never kill a Beast, or make a Slaughter, but they throw some part away, upon which the effect of the Charm is to fall; nay, they are so far entangled in Superstition, that if within a few Weeks after Baptism, the Child happen to fall ill, or pine away, they Rebaptize it, alledging, that the first Name was not agreable to its Constitution, tho' very severe Laws have been enacted against it. The worst of all is, that they are so Tenacious of these Superstitions, and so obstinate in the perseverance of their antient Customs, that nothing is able to divert them from it. Of this there have been several Instances of late Years; for these Peasants, as I told you before, being not permitted to purchase any Lands, but obliged to live upon the Allotments granted to them by their Lords, for the bare sustenance of their Families, will sometimes cut or burn down some Woods, and Manure the Ground, which produces good Wheat; this they hide for Sale; but if they happen to be catch'd, they are strip'd to the middle, and ty'd to a Post, where they are soundly whipt with a Switch, till the Blood issues forth on all Sides; I say, there are many Instances of such among the Livonian Peasants, who rather than redeem this Chastisement by a small pecuniary Mulct of about 18 or 16 Pence, have chosen to submit readily to the Punishment, alledging, that rather than introduce any Novelty of this Kind, they would suffer the same Chastisement their Fore-fathers used to do before them.

Some of the relatively unsuccessful cases are perhaps easiest to analyze first. Poor health seems very clearly involved in several instances of men who have remained economically marginal. Since physical ability has been so closely related to success in reindeer herding and other economic activities, several individuals with uncertain health are among the emerging category of “techno-economic marginality.”

In the treatment of the sick, too, practical measures are intermingled with superstitious beliefs. There are believed to be three kinds of sicknesses: (1) sickness sent by God, which cannot be cured; (2) sickness sent by another person, usually by a sorcerer, which in some cases may be cured, but which can end with the death of the patient as well; and (3) ordinary sickness, which is not fatal.

Among the Inari-Lapps, m annud a-att se n is the old moontarring man, or rahko (> Norwegian Lapp and U.). “ M annud a-att se n 's heel is already worn out,” the Lapps say when the moon is in its latter phase. According to Fellman, At sen-nieida was in bygone days a covetous and haughty maiden, who nowadays is hanging in the moon, which is the reason why the moon looks spotted. Att seń-kál'gu (I.) was a female spirit well known for its witchcraft. The Lapps also say that att seń (I. reind. h ahttsed zân , K. ahttsé h k' ) is pulling the veins, when someone has cramps. The Kola-Lapp word adz is of the same origin and signifies a wicked female being that exchanged its daughter in secret for the son of an old Lapp woman. In the Kolt-Lapp dialect ahttsé h k' means, besides an evil-minded female spirit (whose daughter was called ahttsé h k'-nei'd a ), also marsh-cricket, while the Enontekiö-Lapp ahtsi s-eäbmi and the Norwegian Lapp hacced zân mean carrion beetle. In Enontekiö a witches'-broom (in the trees) is ahtsi s-eämi-lav'd se-kih-pu (= ahtsi s-eämi 's bunch of straps).

N'ivitt sen-kál'g u (I.) was an old woman-fairy mentioned in connection with Attsen-ka'g u . Fellman names the Navitsen-galggo of Utsjoki. Hattisen-galggo (= h ahttsed zân ?), mother of the frog, had given her misshapen daughter as foster-child to Navitsen-galggo . When the girl later learned that her real mother had been killed, she felt so grieved that she wanted to drown herself in a well. Her foster mother gave her a severe scolding, but when the girl nevertheless plunged into the well, she struck her on the back with an iron shovel. The girl became a hunchback and turned into a frog. In Enontekiö a n avi s-eäbmi was “mother of mankind.” Among the reindeer-Lapps of Inari, ń ave-d zân signifies a slow person.

Rutto ( roht'tu ) (= plague), accompanies man in the shape of a black cat. Once a merchant was driving along the river Uts towards Tana, and by the house of Leppälä he opened his sled, containing textiles. There he saw the black cat in the sled and guessed what was the matter. Quickly he rebound the sled with the ropes and set off again. When the merchant had reached the shore of Keniskoski (according to another version: Alaköngäs by Tana), he stopped the caravan, cut the “drawing strap” and pushed the sled into the rapids, which engulfed it under the ice. The plague did not get out. Some years later the sled was found in the water and pulled ashore. It had moldered, the textiles were rotten and in between them was some slime, believed to be the remains of the plague; it no longer moved. -- If a traveler spends a night in a plague-stricken place, the plague will hide inside his reserve shoes and will travel in the sack with dried sedges. If the traveler finds out what has happened, he must light a fire and burn such shoes. When the plague can be burned or drowned, all the infected people will recover.

According to Haruzin, the Suonikylä Kolt-Lapps had the reputation in Kolttaköngäs of being sorcerers. They were supposed to be able to provoke lumbago, + = a play on words: the Finnish word “noidannuoli” means lumbago and sorcerer's arrow. (Transl. note.) and when they approached, some people fell ill. Similarly, an Inari-Lapp who lived nearby always fell ill when the Kolt-Lapps came, until he happened to be told that he could preserve his health if he would put a piece of steel under his doorsill. In the beginning of the present century, a Kolt-Lapp from Hirvasouta cured a man in Suonikylä with the condition that he be allowed to take reindeer from his patient's herd every year and have sexual intercourse with his wife whenever they happened to meet. -- According to the Kolt-Lapps, a sorcerer sees his evil-spirit ( nóaid-kád'dz e ) at night. Some of them appear in human shape; they chat and have a meal in the master's hut, although no food is consumed. If the sorcerer treats his evil spirits badly, they may even attack him. When the sorcerer dies they are freed, unless he has had time to leave them to someone else. The Kolt-Lapps of Paatsjoki narrate the following: Formerly when Lapps set off on a trip, e.g. to visit a distant village, they sent ahead a mouse or a magic arrow + = a play on words: the Finnish word “noidannuoli” means lumbago and sorcerer's arrow. (Transl. note.) ( ńuoll a ) in the event that the seers of the other place would send animals to meet them. If these villagers discovered the mouse and managed to kill it, this meant that the man in the guise of a mouse would “get a correction,” i.e. lose his life. A particular kind of sorcery was the practice of enchanting ( lommad ), especially into a heavy sleep, during which the sorcerer could subject the other person to whatever he wanted. The leaders of the enemies ( t s udd e ) were, for example, able to enchant people so that they were unable to put up opposition. While in a trance the sorcerer would sing in a humming voice ( k ihkkvd , original meaning = “to hiss, to imitate the call of a wood grouse at mating time”).

Indigestion or colic may be due to consumption of “kero,” vuös'mäs id (leavings of a pregnant woman). One's food will not stay down and the heart is weak; the Lapps say: “the ruöv'de-k arânâs shot at the heart.” This is cured by catching a large black beetle , “iron-raven” ( ruöv'de-k arânâs ), on a chip, giving it the vomitus of the patient or his leavings, and saying: “eat, you who are strong enough to kick out these troubles.”

A human being will become run down ( kóarädih ), if he does not observe the customs of his forefathers. Everyone knows in his conscience whether he has disobeyed their will. Then the fairies of the wood will get a “claw-hold” on his dwindling property. Nightmares will make him flaggy and indifferent. Such a person dresses in an unusual way, his face is full of dark and light spots, his eyes are bloodshot and dull and blink strangely. There is no cure for such a state -- not even sorcerers had any remedy (northeast I. reind.-L.).

The Lapps never sit on ground-stones ( eänâ-keäd'gi ), only on loose stones ( podus-keäd'gi ). A large ground-stone should not be used to sharpen edged tools, or the person who does so will fall ill. A stone should not be struck at with another stone so that there is a smoke, as this may set a plague going (I. reind.-L.). It is forbidden to move stones at night on a former hut-yard; one who does so may die on the spot. It is also better not to dig in the ground at night during dew, as this may bring disease, e.g. itches (K.).
There are three kinds of diseases ( tav' â, puohttsovuohtâ ):

1) God's disease ( Ibmel-tav'dâ ), which are incurable 1 MANNINEN, Die aämonistischen Krankheiten, p. 206: “God's disease” is known among the Finnic, Teutonic and Slavic peoples. -- The Lapps have probably adopted this conception from the Finns. ,

2) diseases brought about by magic ( pijâh-tav'dâ ), provoked by another person, usually with the aid of a sorcerer. They are generally internal and appear as attacks: the victim's bowels are subject to cramps and twists; he may recover after a long period, but the disease may also end fatally. The patient has done some injury to another, e.g. stolen a reindeer. If they settle the matter the patient may recover; the disease cannot be sent back to the contriver.
3) Ordinary diseases ( t avälâ s tav'dâ ), which are not mortal.

Some diseases hover in the air. Some Lapps seem to be able to see a disease moving in the sky above the clouds or on a level with the high arctic mountains such as Rastekaisa, in the form of a yellow mucus ( tav'd-aibmu or j abm-aibmu = “dead air”). At times it comes down spreading plague ( rohttu ). Formerly the sorcerers are said to have caught it perhaps by sucking - in order to prevent it from spreading. The plague also hides in melting springwaters. Therefore the Lapps prefer to drink well-water. In summer the Lapps usually blow along the water's surface before they drink, as this is where the disease is believed to dwell. The Kolt-Lapps believe that many diseases, e.g. 2 A Lapp never makes coffee with water from tarns or lakes without outlet. They have “dead water” (E., Aili Leinon kok. 1947). smallpox, wander with the wind, particularly in the spring and on mild, cloudy winter days; diseases can also be caught in the water and on the ground. 1 PAULAHARJU, Kolttain mailta, p. 179. The Kolt-Lapps never remove earth at night when dew is falling, as it is believed that this may cause diseases such as itchings.

Plague is also believed to accompany human beings in the shape of a black cat . When a contagious or epidemic disease ( ńóam'mu-tav'dâ or kol'gu-tav' â ) is on the move, the Lapps burn dry juniper sprigs when the person they believe is carrying it has left the house. The room or hut should be filled with smoke. Having shaken hands with such a person, some Lapps wash their hands with water in which they have boiled juniper., If one has frequented someone suspected of being contagious, it is wise to chew pine-pitch or to drink a decoction of juniper berries or juniper bark. An efficient method is to drop tar on a red-hot flagstone several times a day.

“Diseases are subordinate to man.” (If the disease finds out that a man is afraid, it will kill him.) “He does not know how to be ill,” the Lapps say, when someone is suffering from a long illness. One should not lie down in bed for a trifle ailment, so long as one's legs will carry one. -- Diseases appear one at a time, and when there are enough of them, death will ensue. “He tumbled down immediately, as a Kolt-Lapp, when he got ill.” (The Kolt-Lapps are supposed not to know how to be ill, they die at once.) “Unless the patient dies when the Tana river is freed from ice, he will still recover.” According to others, a sick person will not die in the spring, if only he hears the cuckoo sing.

The Lapps believe that the father's physical and mental diseases are not inherited, only those of the mother. Thus “the mother's trouble” (= eädne-vihkki ) is an incurable, congenital defect, eädne-skier'bmi means “crippled since birth,” eädne-keähppes-vihkki or eädne-keähppes-tav'dâ is “a hereditary consumption” and eädne-miellâ-vihkki signifies “hereditary mental disorder.” Hereditary diseases are also called “family diseases” ( s oyâ-tav'dâ ) (northeast I. reind.-L.).

Even a minute amount of mercury, “the size of a white-fish-eye pearl” ( tsal'me-kakk a ), may be good in certain cases; if there is no trouble, it will come out “even through the eye” (I. fisher-L.). 1 About mercury, see QVIGSTAD, m.t., pp. 146-47. Mercury drives out tapeworms and kills “ruffs” (= diver-beetles) that have entered the stomach with the drinking water. The Kolt-Lapps use mercury to cure headaches, pains, sharp pains and jerks. -- Wearing a copper ring or bracelet is supposed to prevent the arm from becoming numb auring sleep or stiff from hard work. A person who touches a dead corpse should also keep such an object in his hand (western Lapland). -- A piece of woolen yarn wound around a limb or the body will help to cure aches, sprains, abscesses, blood poisoning and even strabismus. 2 Compare ELGSTROM, Karesuandolapparna, pp. 332-3 and Fataburen, 1922, p. 37: A piece of red yarn is wound as tightly as possible around a sore finger. In blood poisoning, a piece of woolen yarn with 9 knots is tied around the hand; the power of God's lamb will make the yarn effective. -- About the use of yarn among the Finns see Kotiseutu 1911, pp. 118-9; Hembygden 1910, p. 109; 1911, p. 55; Budkavlen 1923, p. 49. -- “The male beaver's testicles formed a thick ball under its tail; they were used to prepare an efficient medicine.” Castoreums were kept around the neck in a small bag as a preservative against all sorts of diseases. 1 J.F., III, p. 164; PAULAHARJU, Lapin muisteluksia, p. 19. The great seer Päiviö is said to have cured the daughter of the Swedish king with beaver testicles. -- Live frogs ( tsuobpu ) have a prominent position in healing. During the winter, when frogs are needed, the Lapps dig with shovels in the mud at the bottom of springs. The animal is placed on the abscess, the suppurating wound or the aching point; in heart diseases it may be placed in the armpit. A Lapp who keeps a frog in his fist until it dies will get a “medicine hand” ( t alkâs-kiehtâ ), with which he will be able to cure his fellow beings. 2 Similarly QVIGSTAD, pp. 16-17. -- In western Lapland (E.) certain wells contain water that is believed to cure eye diseases, herpes caught in soil and water, and all sorts of external diseases. In some springs the water is to be drunk, in others one must dive into it three times. To certain springs the Lapps offer coins and metallic objects, such as pins. 3 PAULAHARJU, Lapin muisteluksia, pp. 205: compare TURI, Muittalus samid birra, p. 212. -- The belief in mineral springs may be of Finnish-Scandinavian origin.

There is a general rule in Lapland that a person who has an injury or a disease in some part of his body should not eat the corresponding part of a slaughtered reindeer; thus, for example, anyone with a liver disease should avoid eating liver, and a person with an injured leg should not eat reindeer feet.

P ostâ-tivri is a small, poisonous insect (yellow ant) that lives in swamps. Its bite is painful and may cause swelling ( pos'tâyâh , iduh ). The Lapps particularly avoid the tussocks by the edges of swamps, which are covered with strange-looking, stunted grass; they should not be used as pillows when sleeping outside. -- In summer, when the water begins to dry up in the pits, the soil is considered very poisonous; one should never lie down on bare ground at that time. 1 PAU AHARJU, Taka-Lappia, p. 1-9. Compare QVIGSTAD, pp. 175 ( sta ). If the “soil breathes” on a person's skin, he will become covered with pimples ( ru s'm os , I.). “An infection of the soil” shows up in the form of pimples that itch and burn like fire; it may be caught by a person who arinks water from an “unselected” place. It is cured with the aid of soil (E.). 2 Aili Leinon 1947. Swellings on the skin are treated with salt water or the water of boiled wild rosemary. It is also good to scrape the swollen spot with a knife; massage is not recommended. Bites of mosquitoes ( Culex ) and gnats ( Simulidae ) may similarly be scraped with a knife, although the Lapps' skin seems to be quite indifferent to them. Scraping a wasp's sting with a knife until the spot becomes white will prevent it from swelling.

Wounds ( h avvi ) are treated as follows: A small wound is covered with liquid pike-bile or with a fresh birch leaf. The borders of an iron wound are pressed first on one side, then on the other, and at the same time it is blown upon. It may also be soaked with urine and covered with a thin piece of inner birchbark. Some Lapps boil nails in water, then wash the wound with this water three times. 3 The Lapps also used alum-water (ANDE IN, Oulun Lehti 1881, n:o l; U.). Others heat a birchbranch until a sticky, brown liquid begins to ooze forth and then apply this liquid to the wound (U.). The Inari-Lapps put the aried chest-fat of a bear or “settled” reindeer or sheep fat on such a wound; a mixture of pitch and melted reindeer or dog fat may also do. In case of a rupture of the vein in a hand, the wound is closed with a heated knife. In the summer, the Inari reindeer-Lapps wash a larger wound with water; in the winter they wash and rub the wound itself with snow. They take salt in their mouths, then press the wound with their tongue, at the same time sucking out blood, which is spat out. Blood is not sucked out of large wounds, they are covered with salt or salt water. The wound may be sprinkled with the spore-dust of a puffball ( Lycoperdon bovista ), 1 Similarly QVIGSTAD, Lapp. Heilkunde, p. 105. -- Enontekiö: the puffball ( st alu-pur'sâ , kied'de-spab'bâ ) is placed on the wound (Aili Leinon kok. 1947). mixed with pitch-water ( pihk'kâ-t s ahttsi ); the latter is obtained when boiling pinepitch in a small quantity of water. The mixture is put on the wound and covered with a bandage (I. reind.-L.). Fresh pine-pitch is an excellent remedy on wounds; it is usually covered with a thin piece of inner birchbark (U.). The Kolt-Lapps also use pine-pitch or a mixture of boiled spruce-pitch (or tar) and candle-wax. -- The wound may also be covered with a mouse-skin, hair inwards, which has previously been sprinkled with the spore-dust of a puffball; it is tied with rags. An injured finger may be covered with a leather sheath spread with spore-dust. If a wound will not stop bleeding it has to be strewn with ground coffee. Another method is to let some blood drop onto a red-hot cobblestone; the emerging steam will stanch the flow of blood (I. reind.-L.). The Utsjoki-Lapps had still another method: a hole was drilled in a tree and some blood from the wound was poured into the hole, which was then obstructed with a peg. -- The wound may also be covered with a thin membrane from a hide 1 Similarly QVIGSTAD, p. 99. or with a film of birchbark. 2 Similarly DRAKE, p. 260. Twenty-four hours later the membrane begins to tighten, and it is then changed. A large wound, e.g. one made with an ax in the foot, which will not stop bleeding, may in winter be healed with a thin, still-warm slice of meat or the lights of a recently slaughtered reindeer. In some regions such reindeer are slaughtered by being stabbed in the neck and not in the heart as is the usual way; the patient should in addition eat a piece of meat, raw and unsalted. Cold meat is heated in warm water. The wound is then covered with a piece of rag (northeast I. reind.-L.). The Utsjoki-Lapps place a slice of frozen lights on such a wound. Stanching the flow of blood is called v arâ pis'se h teäbme . 3 There is a Lapp woman in Enontekiö who is able to stanch the bleeding of a person living in another locality, if only she is informed of his/her name (Aili Leinon kok. 1947). -- A live frog is pressed against a suppurating wound (e.g. for as long as it takes to make coffee). A fresh or suppurating wound may also be healed with boiled tar. 4 For suppurating wounds also pitch oil (E.). The Kolt-Lapps use the thin membrane underneath the birchbark (“julmu”) on such a wound. The wound can also be soaked with lye obtained from ashes. -- Bleeding wounds occasioned by the bites of dogs or other animals are stanched with salt; the wound is then smeared with sour fat and bandaged. If a hunter is bitten by a bear, the wounds have to be rubbed with the bear's bile, and the rest of the bile is drunk by the bitten hunter (Sodankylä-Lapps). -- Scabs are smeared once a day with reindeer-marrow or sour fat to prevent them from chapping. This is probably what Fellman refers to when he writes that wounds and abscesses are healed with reindeer-marrow or tar and pine-pitch melted in fat. 1 J.F., III, p. 163; compare DRAKE, pp. 261-2: Fat or pitch. Scabs may also be smeared with rotten eggs. -- If a small child's navel discharges pus, it is smeared with marrow taken from the tibia of a reindeer or a sheep (I.).

Burns ( puölläm ) are healed in the following ways: if a finger is slightly burned, it should be kept in the mouth for a while. Larger burns are 1) bathed with hot (U. cold) water, after which the burn is covered with a hot-water compress or is kept as near a fire as possible: “cold to cold, hot to hot”; 2) stroked with strong saltwater with a feather; 3) covered with rotten eggs (I. reind.-L., E.); 4) rubbed with the glue-like water of boiled, finely cut willow leaves; 5) smeared with fish-oil (taken from the surface of the broth) or any other fat, e.g. the marrow of a reindeer-tibia. The most effective remedy is old, sour reindeer-tallow; 2 ANDELIN, p. 189: The wound is kept in cold water, and is then smeared with 1-year-old reindeer-fat. if the skin has burned so much that it begins to ary up, it should in addition be covered with a hot compress until the latter cools down. An ordinary burn is, in summer, bathed with hot water; at times the patient's own hand is tied to the burn for the night. In winter the burn is covered with a thin slice of fresh, warm reindeer-meat or -lights. The scab is treated as with ordinary wounds (northeast I. reind.-L.). -- The Kolt-Lapps have a magic remedy for burns: the burn is smeared with blood taken from a cut in a dog's ear. The Inari-Lapps use the same method for skin burned by boiling water.

Toothaches ( p adne-veär'kâ ) are treated as follows: 1) The mouth is filled with hot (I. reind.-L.) or cold water; when it has warmed up it is spat out and a new mouthful is taken (U.). 2) The aching tooth is rubbed with tar or with pitchoil. 3) The patient chews liquid or dry pine-pitch 3 Similarly J.F., III, p. 163. -- The patient may also chew wild rosemary leaves ( kuohtsâ-r assi ; I. reind.-L.). ( käs'si ). In winter the pine-stick is kept near the fire, in order to make the pitch flow out. Any hole in the tooth is filled with melted pitch. 4) The outer end of a pipestem is pressed against the aching tooth and the smoke will relieve the pain; pipe-oil will also do. 4 And also salt (ANDELIN, m.k.). 5) In winter the Lapps fetch a chrysalis from a birch-branch, warm it up, take out the larva and press it into the toothhole. 6) Pike-bile is dripped on the painful spot (I. reind.-L.). 7) A small piece of a hide-membrane is cut off, filled with a small amount of a child's excrement and formed into a little ball. A small hole is made in the ball with an awl, and it is pushed inside the tooth with the hole turned inwards (U.). 8) A good method when the ache is setting in is to bite a piece of birchwood until the pain disappears; this method is also used by aged Lapps to refasten their falling teeth (I. reind.-L. and U.). 9) A piece of red broadcloth is placed on the tooth and bitten for a while (I. reind. and fisher-L.). 10) The Kolt-Lapps sometimes place a piece of smoldering tinder on the cheek, by the aching tooth. 1 PAULAHARJU, Kolttain mailta, p. 174. Similarly the Enontekiö-Lapps (Aili Leinon kok. 1947). 11) Formerly, the aching tooth was pressed with the tooth of a beaver or a bear (in Utsjoki the latter is still used today). 2 J.F., III, p. 169; IV, p. 37. 12) The gum is stuck with the point of a knife and some blood is pressed out. 13) Heated sand or a heated flat stone wrapped in a rag may be applied to a cheek swollen by a toothache; a dough made with very salty water will also do (K.). Hot ashes inside a woolen stocking or mitten are also applied (E.). 14) The hot water of boiled, wild rosemary is poured into a bowl and the patient keeps his head over the bowl, covered with a cloth (K.). 15) A frog is wrapped in a thin piece of cloth and kept on the cheek until it dies (I. reind.-L.). The paws of a black cat are bound with four pieces of rag, to prevent it from clawing. The animal is then kept on the patient's cheek until the pain has moved over to the cat's paws. 16) A stick is cut from a beautiful, lonely-growing aspen. It is heated on the fire and then pressed on the cheek by the aching tooth. 17) The tendon by the shoulder-blades in the back is pressed hard (U.). The painfull spot is pressed with the thumb and the forefinger, thereafter the fingers follow the tendon in the same way below the ear and to the neck, until they reach the spinal column (I. fisher-L.). 18) Another method is to bloodlet the hand by the thumb (and also the neck) on the same side as the toothache (E.). -- Bloodletting was formerly done with a large knife, which the Lapps struck with another knife. 1 ANDELIN, Oulun Lehti 1881, n:o 1. Teeth are not extracted in general, and old Lapps have better teeth than young ones. One may encounter aged Lapps who have all their teeth left; the teeth are certainly very worn, but the person may never have suffered from any tooth-disease. The Inari-Lapps believed that eating bark kept the teeth in good condition.

The eyes get extremely tired from staying awake for long periods tending the herd ( t sâlmih leä ked'dom or t sâlmih muorrâluvveh ), particularly if the herdsman has constantly to watch the reindeers' earmarks. Then “the world is stricken as with mist,” the eyes blink much less frequently than usual and the person easily becomes tired ( rav'gâluvvä ) -- to such an extent that he will have nose-bleeds and be unable to sleep. He should be given a cold compress (snow inside a piece of cloth) on his eyes and should lie down in the shelter or at home for at least 24 hours. To prevent snow blindness ( t sâlbme-sud'dom ; t sâlmiht suovgâ h tuvveh , I. t salm eh koddojeh ) in early spring, the Lapps remain in a dark stable or look inside through a steaming sheep-barndoor until their eyes begin to fill with tears. If there are no sheep, they will wash their eyes with their own, warm urine, as many as three or four times a day. Other Lapps dye a piece of cotton fabric black and make a cap ( peäi've-suo 'gâ ) which they press down to the nostrils on bright days. The ordinary cap is placed on top of the black one (I. reind.-L.). Snow blindness may also be avoided if the eyes are not washed between February and Midsummer (I. fisher-L.), or if the lower eyelid is covered with soot (E.). The Utsjoki-Lapps used alum water. 1 ANDELIN, Oulun Lehti, 1881, n:o 1. -- A few drops of mother's milk are dripped into a sore eye, after which it is covered with a woolen cloth and blown upon. Another method is to throw cold water in the patient's eyes unexpectedly, e.g. when he opens a door (U.). If the disease of the eyes is due to cold, they should be rubbed with the water obtained by boiling white, black and red stones. 2 ANDELIN, Oulun Lehti, 1881, n:o 1. A kind of cataract ( tsâlmi l anstârduvveh ) may form in the eyes in clear spring weather. When the patient enters a smoky hut, the cataract will break as a result of the flow of tears, and it is licked away (I. reind.-L.). The real cataract ( smäi'ti ) is healed by boiling birchashes in water. When the dregs have settled a pin is dipped into the surface layer (= lye) and one drop is let fall on the cataract. A minute amount of mercury has the same effect (U.). Formerly a louse was placed in the eye; it was believed to wear out the cataract when it moved. 3 Oulun W.-S. 1857, n:o 34. Tobacco-spittle may also be put in an eye afflicted with a cataract. 1 OINONEN, Kolmen valtaku nan ota-Lappia, p. 169. If the eye was injured while looking at a solar eclipse, it was healed by looking into a well or a copper kettle in moonlight, where the reflected image of the moon was shining. 2 PAULAHARJU, Taka-Lappia, p. 164. Some Lapps suffer from night blindness . The Kolt-Lapps believe that this is due to the fact that newborn children are brought at once close to the dazzling hearth. 3 Idem. Kolttain mailta, p. 175. A bit of dirt in the eye is taken away by blinking the eye in lukewarm water. At the worst, some skillful old woman will turn the eyelid inside out ( forgu h tih ) and take away the particle with the tip of her tongue. Some Lapps have tweezers to remove dirt particles; they may also be taken out with a golden ring. The Utsjoki-Lapps aripped mother's milk in the eye. When eyelashes had irritated the eye, the lid was turned inside out, sucked, squeezed between the thumb-nails, or even scraped with a knife, after which it was smeared with milk heated in the mouth. 4 ANDELIN, Oulun Lehti, 1881, n:o 1. -- Fellman believed that eye diseases were often due to smoky huts and to snow-blindness. 5 J.F., III, pp. 162, 300; I.F., 1, p. 212; similarly EL STRÖM, Karesuanaolapparna, p. 14.

When a piece of food is swallowed “ the wrong way ” ( póas'to-t sod'dây i ), the person should be beaten on the shoulders with the fists. Children are taught not to think while they eat, because as the thoughts emerge from the stomach, they will come face to face with the food and the latter will get into the windpipe. When a child cries almost to break his heart, it is wise to slap it on the shoulders.

A painful or strained tendon (I. vienn a -suonâ ) in the hand or foot is healed by tying above the painful spot (= by the wrist or the ankle) an unwashed, black woolen thread (I. and K. = with 9 knots). This will keep the pain from spreading. Another method is to tie a fresh, nine-inch-long foot-tendon from a reindeer around the wrist or the ankle. A small bone of the hock-joint will remain attached to the tendon. The Kolt-Lapps of Suonikylä proceed thus: They press the back of a knife on the painful, “growling” spot; the patient asks: “what do you cut?” The healer answers: “I cut the vienn a (= pain).” “Has it already broken?” “Not yet.” This is done twice. The third time the healer feigns to cut off the tendon and answers: “It broke.” The injury will now heal in 24 hours. Another, apparently more perfect method is to place two thin wooden splints on each side of the sore place, after which the healer cuts off the splints, turns the ends three times around the painful spot, and then throws them on the fire. The tendon of a reindeer's hind-leg ( vienn-suonn a ) is also used. One places it untied on the painful place, while pressing with a knife on both sides and reading “words;” thereafter the tendon is cut in two. A painful tendon is also cured by cutting off a birch-twig in three points above it, while the patient asks each time: “what do you cut?” The healer answers: “I cut off the vienn a ( = pain).” This is done on three consecutive days. 1 Notes of E.A. Virtanen. SeePAULAHARJU, Vanhaa Lappia ja Peräpohjaa, p. 251: “Stroking tendon”; ELGSTRÖM, Karesuandolapparna, pp. 331-2, 347. The fourth method is to tie a black piece of yarn around the wrist, where the vienn a usually is. -- If a limb is wounded with no injury having been done to the bone, tinder may be burned on both sides of the painful spot, while the skin is pinched all around (U.). 2 ANDELIN, Oulun Lehti, 1881, n:o 1.

Sore muscles ( póat'koduvvâm ) are treated as follows. The feet may get sore from too much walking, particularly when wading in soft autumn snow. The patient should give up work for a couple of days, but he should, however, move slowly from time to time, so as not to get “foot-less” ( juölgi h tuvvâh ). The soreness may be avoided by lying down during the walk and keeping the legs in a diagonal position against a tree. -- A painful limb used to be rubbed with bear-suet kept in the intestine of a bear; men should be treated with the suet of a male bear, women with that of a she-bear. 1 Suometar, 1857, n:o 30. -- The flanks may get sore from carrying a heavy burden, from too much lasso-throwing, from excessive wood-chopping, from punting a boat upstream, from cutting hay, etc. In this case too, the best treatment is to be quiet for a few days, moving about slowly from time to time. The old Inari-Lapps cured sore flanks with beaver testicles ( majj u-pah' s ).
A wrench ( reht'tem ) is the result of lifting too heavy a burden too abruptly. There is no cure; the person must simply be careful henceforth. Three wrenches mean death (northeast I. reind.-L.).

Lumbago ( vuoisâ h tâh ) may be healed only by lying down in bed. Sudden sharp pains were cured by placing a live frog on the stomach by the painful spot or by sucking the skin until it began to bleed. The sore place might also be cupped or a thimble-measure of dried, pulverized pike-teeth might be drunk either with liquor or with water. 2 J.F., III, pp. 163-4, 300; GRAPE (1803), p. 207. -- ANDELIN: the painful spot was sucked until the skin got black.

The following method is still in use among the Inari-Lapps: They boil a large head of pike, take off the teeth, dry them by the fire and then reduce them to a powder which is drunk with water. A small amount of liquid bear-bile or a powder scraped from dry bear-bile and dissolved in water, will have the same effect. Sudden sharp pains ( palâs , ńuoll a = “arrow”) are treated by the Kolt-Lapps by having another person pinch the painful spot -- he takes the pain in his own finger-tips, as it were, then blows it away. 1 HÄMÄLÄINEN, Koltta-Lappia, p. 87: The healer spits on his finger-tips, then pinches the sore place as if gradually pulling out the pain. After each pinching he feigns to throw something over his left shoulder, while repeating: “you miserable, who attacks a decent person! Why didn't you go elsewhere, to a dog or a cat? You should be ashamed.” Compare LÖNNROT, Matkat II, p. 35: The Finnish peasantry massages with the thumb and the other fingers and pinches the various limbs. A skillful healer has ńuoll a -k'iehtt a = “sharp pain-hands.” Castrén tells of a similar sprain in 1841. The healer passed his fingers over the sore place, as if looking for something, then he got hold of the pain, squeezed it with his nails, bit it with his teeth and finally spat it away. This was repeated several times. 2 CASTREN, Nordiska resor och forskningar I, p. 137; see also MANNINEN, Eräs lappalainen parannusmenetelmä (Kalevalaseuran vk. 14). -- Prolonged, sharp pains ( vuái'sâ ) are treated with mercury “the size of a fish-eye-grain” (I. fisher-L.).

A sprained limb ( veätt se h teäbme , E. nilkâsteäbme ) is rubbed with and bathed in saltwater. If the limb is dislocated ( l addâses lihk'kä ), another person will give a quick pull at the hand, ankle or knee, until it snaps. If the hip is dislocated, it will be pulled back by several men.

Lâdâs-tavdâ or lâdâs-vuöl' si means that a joint swells up and pus forms inside. It is treated with compresses of wild rosemary-water; burning with tinder is another method. A withering hand or foot ( âs'tân-tav'dâ ) is treated in the same way, but rarely heals.

As a protection against back-aches , the Lapps carry a bear tusk tied to the back of their belts. This method has also been used by the Finns since heathen times, as is proved by certain gravefinds (see illustrations 241 and 441). 1 Some Siberian peoples also use bear-claws as amulets (HARVA, Altain suvun uskonto, p. 274).

If some part of the body (fingers, toes, face, ears) gets frostbitten ( suvt sâyih ), the spot has to be rubbed with snow. During a trip one may also rub the face with snow. I. Fellman writes that frostbitten limbs were smeared and rubbed with the heated fat of reindeer cheese. 2 I.F., I, p. 321; similarly DRAKE, p. 262. The Kolt-Lapps smear the frostbitten spot with liquor, mixed with the dried core (yolk?) of a goose egg. 3 Paulaharju, manuscript.

When a person feels chilly ( kóalluh ), he should warm himself by a fire and then go to bed. An effective medicine for chills is gunpowder-liquor, or coffee or water in lack of the former. It should be drunk in abundance and as hot as possible. If it cannot be drunk, the patient should at least breathe the steam through his mouth. Blood cooked in water or broth about half an hour is a good sudorific; 1 Similarly QVIGSTAD, p. 28. it should be taken as hot as possible and in great quantities (I. reind.-L.). Another method is to slaughter a reindeer, then let the person with a cold drink blood directly from the wound, as much as he can stand, after which he goes to bed (I. fisher-L.). 2 Compare ANDELIN, (Oulun ehti 1881, no. 1): Colds are cured by drinking the warm blood of a newly slaughtered reindeer (U.). -- If a Lapp does not get sweaty when skiing or walking fast, it is a suspicious symptom and he should drink something hot. The Kolt-Lapps believe that colds can be avoided by taking a swig of hot liquor or by breathing the smell of excrements or passed gas. 3 PAULAHARJU, Kolttain mailta, p. 173; QVIGSTAD, p. 27.

There is no medicine for smallpox ( póahk'ku ). A preventive remedy is juniper-smoke or -water. Andelin wrote that during epidemics of smallpox the reindeer dwindled, as the Lapps sacrified between three and ten animals for each patient. In the beginning of the 19th century almost one-tenth of the Enontekiö-Lapps had been ill with smallpox. This disease was so greatly feared that a Lapp could leave his or her sick spouse alone in the woods. 1 GRAPE (1803), p. 206. Measles ( m anä-póahk'ku , E. par'ku-tav'dâ ) is another incurable disease. The patient is given liquor mixed with bear-bile. Contagion is avoided by keeping juniper-bark under the cradle-pillow and by fumigating the hut or cottage, as often as twice a day if there are visitors. Children's washwater is mixed with juniper-water, in equal amounts. Small-pox and measles were formerly very fatal. 2 J.F., III, p. 162. Oulun W.-S. 1855, no. 58: There was a severe pox-epidemic in Inari. Chicken pox is cured among the Kolt-Lapps by cooking alderbark in water, straining the water, then washing the children with it. 3 QVIGSTAD, p. 97. In Enontekiö the Lapps put live frogs in boiling water; when the water has cooled down it is used to wash the children; the scabs will fall off. 4 Aili Leinon kok. 1947.

If a herdsman has to run too fast behind the herd, so that his lungs get strained and he emits blood from the throat ( luos'kânih ), he will never again recover his former condition. He will get a kind of node under the chest that is incurable (northeast I. reind.-L.).

Even some animals are believed to bring on certain stomach diseases. If a mosquito-larva ( tiv'ri ) gets into the mouth with drinking-water, it will eat its way into the tongue and the throat; in the stomach it is not particularly dangerous. Liquids should be taken through a straw ( poht'tsi ) made of a goose- or swan-tibia, in order not to swallow insects. The Inari fisher-Lapps believe that the “malluainen” ( kubb o lid z ) (= a snout-insect living in water) swells up in the stomach and eats the blood vessels. T sierges-seävi (I. reind.-L.) is a beetle living in water, which has two white rings around its neck. If this insect is drunk with the water, it will grow and make the stomach swell, eating the intestines down until death ensues. The animal is expelled from the stomach by making the patient eat as much boiled fish as he can stand and then raw fish until it makes him vomit; the insect may come out along with the vomit. A lizard may enter through the mouth of a person sleeping outside, and similarly the eggs of a frog with the drinking water; they will grow in the stomach and may even croak from time to time, and finally they will bring about the person's death. 1 Compare QVIGSTAD, Lapp. Heilkunde, pp. 63-5; PAULAHARJU, Kolttain mailta, p. 174. -- The Lapps believe that every person carries inside himself a curled worm, which straightened out might be several meters long; they mean, of course, the tapeworm (I. reind.-L.). The tapeworm may be induced to come out if the person first fasts and then sits down in a container filled with lukewarm milk. Pinworms disappear if the person eats Angelicareeds in the early summer for a few days, five or six stalks at a time (U.).
Tumors ( lii'gi , E. kuor'ti ) appear mainly in the stomach; they are incurable.

A hernia is called monne-t sóalli or vuölle-t sóalli ; also k usk idâm-vad'du . A Lapp suffering from a hernia ( l eskidâl'li ) is suspended from the feet in such a way that his shoulders touch the floor, and is then shaken to make the intestines slip back. If the patient is alone, he will lie down on his back, lift his legs up in the air and kick a tree or a stone (northeast I. reind.-L.).

Fractures ( täk'te-tsuov'kâneäbme ) are treated as follows. If a finger-bone breaks, it should be splinted on both sides and bandaged ( nuovhtu ). Whenever a larger limb-bone breaks, its ends are put together and the thin inner membrane of a hide is placed on the spot, followed by a soft, and finally a stiff, piece of tanned leather. A woolen shoelace is tied quite tight around the limb. A broken arm is put in a loop tied around the neck. The bandage should be opened daily. An arm heals in about three months, whereas the healing of a tibia might take half a year. -- A patient with a fracture is given mercury or tiny carved silver chips. 1 J.F., III, p. 163; ANDELIN, p. 189 (likewise in Inari until recently). The Enontekiö-Lapps swallow a small drop of mercury, “it takes away the pain and makes the bones grow.” Even the reindeer are given mercury in similar cases (Aili Leinon kok. 1947). The Kolt-Lapps scrape minute particles of a copper coin and eat them with bread (Paulanarju, manuscript).

A arowned Lapp ( t s ahttsäi hav'kâm or t s ahtts- olmo s = “water-man”) will have his mouth cleaned, then he is turned on his stomach and carried in that position. His ears are opened, after which he is shaken and massaged. A good sign is when water begins to flow out of his mouth and his skin fills with white and red spots. Reviving takes about an hour. Those present must be silent all the time, in order not to frighten the returning life, but they must think that the drowned person will be restored to life.

The general impression given by the Finnish Lapps' original methods of curing is that they are comparatively manifold. Most cases are treated now with rational, now with magic remedies, even if the results are far from always being in accordance with expectations. Established Lapps have better opportunities to take care of the sick than do the nomadic Lapps in their inadequate cloth-huts. The reindeer-Lapps, owing to their migrations, are obliged to move their sick long distances in sleds, even when the ground is bare. Patients suffering from chronic diseases, as well as weak, aged people, are often placed by the reindeer-Lapps in families with permanent dwellings. -- Nowadays, when doctors, hospitals and pharmacies are closer than before, the old methods of curing are more and more tending to give way to modern therapeutics. 1 The Chapter “Diseases and Methods of Curing” is based, in addition to the sources in the afore-mentioned foot-notes, mainly on notes of the writer (see Die Heilkunde der Finnlandlappen, Mitteilungen des Vereins für Finnische Volkskunde, 1944-5) and on articles by P. HEILALA (Valojuova 1946, Farmaseuttilehti 1946, Lapin Kansa 23/8 1946 no. 130, Yliopiston Farmaseuttikunta r.y:n vuosijulkaisu (MDC 1946, 1947), Semina 1948, no. 5.

Children must be quite still in the evening or illnesses will descend upon them. Illnesses are pictured as human figures which are afflicted with the disease and infect mortals. They use the paths of mortals, so a hut must never be built too near the road. If you sleep on the naked ground you may fall ill unless you first spit on the place where you are going to lie.

For a broken leg they used quicksilver, which was early known to the Lapps. They also dropped quicksilver into the eyes for abscesses and so-called styes. For headache they tore the hair wherever the pain was.
Against snake bites they had a more reliable treatment: they cut the bite deep and squeezed the poisoned blood out. Against ant bites and wasp stings they apply certain mosses to the place even now.

Erik Knoljokk told us how once a little boy was brought unconscious to a noiade . He had suddenly collapsed without visible cause and was now wrestling with death. The noiade explained that the boy had been “struck by a whirlwind”. It was believed that, if one happened to get into a whirlwind, one would die or at least fall grievously ill. The colour of the boy's face had gone quite yellow. The noiade smeared his whole body with earth, pronounced his spell, and finally said, “I now feel the disease mounting my arms. They are aching up to the shoulders.” The boy grew well and the yellowness vanished completely from his face.

Another story that Erik told was of the miraculous cure of a blind girl who had often been treated by a doctor without success. When she came to the noiade he uttered incantations over her eyes, gave her an ointment and told her to stay for some time in darkness. A fortnight later she was able to see.

As appears from the above statements, the god of thunder was worshipped among the Lapps as among many other lower peoples under a twofold aspect: partly he was regarded as a good and benevolent, partly as a[unavailable] bad or malevolent divine being. It is not difficult to understand that thunder and lightning, which sometimes kills men and animals, sets fire to trees and splits mountains, in these respects must be regarded as a malevolent being. But on the other hand the thunder which is followed by the fertilizing rain, important for the growth of grass and reindeer-moss, and purifies the heavy and oppressive atmosphere, from these points view appears also as a being benevolent to mankind. He expels the bad spirits or trolls which according to primitive belief fill the air and cause sickness. All the Samek seem to have agreed on this point. According to Leem there was a saying among the Norwegian Lapps that “if there were no thunder the trolls would ruin the world”. They also said that during a thunderstorm the trolls were seen running about in the forest for fear until they found a hollow tree, where they tried to conceal themselves; but the tree was thereupon set on fire by the lightning 15 14 Fellman, I, 599. . The Russian ethnologist Charuzin, who in the first place gives us information about the ideas of the Russian Lapps, tells us much the same about them as Leem, Rheen, Högström and Fellman do about those of the Scandinavian and Finnish Lapps. “Thunder is”, says Charuzin, “both a good and a bad god; he is good because he persecutes the evil wizards in whom a bad power is concealed.” Aijeke is honoured by the Lapps, he continues, because, as they relate, he has in his hands power over the life and death, the good and ill health of men. He pursues the evil spirits who are ill-disposed to the Lapps, shooting his arrows at them where they live in the rocks and mountains, or in the depths of the lakes. The Lapps have recourse to him when they believe that wizards have bewitched their reindeer herds, in order to revenge themselves. Aijeke pursues the evil-doer; sometimes he finds the wizard and then he kills him. Aijeke dwells in the air, he hears the utterances of men even when the Lapps believe that he will not hear them. He punishes them for their crimes. In addition to the belief that the thunder itself is a divinity, we find even among the Russian Lapps the idea that the peals during a thunderstorm are due to the arrows which the god of thunder shoots against the wizards 16 15 Leem, 506. .

As to spirits causing sickness, Samic mythology developed an idea of a personal demon of disease, called Rutu or Rota, who, however, was known only to the Scandinavian Lapps. Different theories have been presented as to the origin of the name rutu . Above all, Rutu seems especially to have been worshipped as a personification of epidemic diseases--etymologically rutu is akin to Finnish rutto , “plague” or “pest” --and the underworld, Rotaimo or Jabmeaimo, is mentioned as his proper abode, which is due to the fact that the Lapps localized diseases at the underworld. Later on Rotaimo or Jabmeaimo, developed under the influence of Christian ideas, into the hell of the Lapps, and Rota or Rutu himself became an evil, tormenting god, a devil. In spite of this the Lapps in some cases, when no help was to be expected from other gods, were wont to offer sacrifices to this devil, the sacrifice always consisting of a horse 82 81 Itkonen, Heidnische Religion , 71-115. . Not only the sacrificial animal but also the way of performing the sacrifice was peculiar. According to Sidenius the victim had to be buried in the earth in order that Rutu might ride away and down into the underworld on the horse. The Lapps have found, the same author adds, that Rota brings diseases and plagues both to men and reindeer, and if there has been no other remedy they have bribed him with sacrifices to get rid of him. 83 82 Reuterskiöld, Källskrifter , 36 (Forbus), 59 (Sidenius). .

The primitive speculation relating to the noidendirri and practices connected with it, however, is only one side of the Samic theory of discase. Different illnesses of course are believed to have somewhat different causes according to their symptoms. The most common explanation given of illnesses, the cause of which appeared mysterious, among the Lapps was the same as among other Finno-Ugrian peoples: they were believed to be sent by their own relatives who wished to take the survivors with them to the realm of the dead. The departed in the Hades of the Lapps, and the female ruler over it, who in the more developed Norwegian mythology is called Jabmeakka, generally were anxious to make their surviving relatives follow them there, either as a punishment or merely because they were longing for their company. Now if someone fell ill with a serious malady, the Lapps presumed that the soul of the patient had gone alone to the abode of the dead, and if the soul could not quickly be released and brought back, the body also would soon follow it. What the noidi had to do in such a case was to make a journey to the under-world for the purpose of liberating the soul by placating the departed with conjurations, prayers, and offerings. It was during this dangerous journey that he, among other things, needed the help of the saivo-guelle , the mysterious fish or snake the mission of which it was to protect him and help him to reach his destination. If, assisted by his tutelary spirit, he succeeded in bringing back the errant soul to the earth and reuniting it with the body, the patient was considered cured. If on the other hand the noidi failed to bring the soul back, he came into deadly peril himself during his sojourn there 62 61 Leem, 483 sq. The ideas held by the Lapps about the “bewitching fly” are examined in detail by Nils Lid in an article Gand og Tyre , published in Festskrift for Prof. Falk (1927). .

263 As seen above, almost all the parts of the reindeer are used for food. Most of the parts are divided equally among the eaters, but with regard to certain parts certain regulations are observed. Only a few of them are generally common throughout the whole Lappish area; their great number, however, proves that the custom itself is very old. Internal family relations play an important role in this custom. The master of the household reserves for himself the first vertebra, the tail, and the lower bone in one hind leg. With his wife he eats the tongue, lower jaw, eyes, kidneys, and rectum. The mistress gets the sacrum ( k adnis ) and the upper bone in one hind leg. The bones in the forelegs are given to the children (the boys eat the lower bones, the girls the upper bones). The parents and the children eat the fat front part of the back. The lower bone in the other hind leg belongs to the manservant, the upper bone to the maid. The servants get the sausage made in the large intestine, the back part of the back, the neck, liver, hoofs, muzzle, and ears. The children are urged to eat eyes of reindeer and pikes so that they may see better. “Who eats the spleen, gets good reindeer” (I. rein.). The Skolts do not give the spleen to children, since it tends to make them lazy. The slaughterer eats the biggest /piece of/ marrow and the biggest sausage in the soup as his pay. A woman who is about to give birth cannot eat sausages, otherwise she will “die in her blood” (in a hemorrhage). A sick person avoids eating the corresponding part of the body. Thus, a person with a diseased liver does not eat reindeer liver, and a person with a bad leg does not eat marrow.

The Lapps in Iijärvi prepare even oil ( t s oar'v-ol'ju ) from reindeer antlers. They use antlers which are dropped or cut off in the fall (called t sâlâ-t s oar'vi ), and remove the forks and the upper part ( speä u ). One-half of the remaining part of the antler is placed in the fire, and as it burns, dark, sticky fluid begins to gather in the unburned section. It is collected in a small cup. After it has congealed it is boiled in fat and poured into a bottle. The oil has a pungent smell. It is used 1) to chase the wolves away, by tying a rag dipped in the oil around the reindeer's neck, 2) to prevent a reindeer from chewing its strap, by rubbing the strap with the oil, and 3) to repel mosquitoes, by rubbing the face with a feather dipped in the oil. -- Even glue can be made of reindeer antlers. Glue probably has been made from time immemorial, as indicated by the Skolt Lappish designation for glue t su ar'v e -demm (- dem & tamm e , I. tame , Finnmark Lappish (Friis) dabme ~ Finnish tymä “glue”). Originally the Lapps made glue from fishskin 1 Leem, p. 374: Glue is made by boiling fishskin; antlers are also used , but according to 503 cont'd Figure 284. An old powder container, carved of horn. Length 15 cm. Suenjel (N.M.) J. Fellman, a few Lapps in Inari and Enontekiö also made glue from anders. 2 J.F., Vol. III, pp. 335, 512; glue was made by boiling antlers in a pot. In Swedish Lapland the Fisher and Forest Lapps made glue (Drake, pp. 207-8). According to Drake, making glue from antlers was learned from the Scandinavians. Finnish farmers also made glue and sold it to burghers in Tornio. A man by the name of Hellant owned a glue factory in Tornio toward the end of the eighteenth century and / sic / tried to increase the production of glue. 3 Boström, Anders Hellant , p. 55 According to Grape, glue is prepared in the following way. The antlers are cut and split in small pieces. 504 /Figure 285 appears here./ They are boiled without interruption for two and a half days. Water is added during the first 12 hours as it evaporates; after that no water is added. The mixture is poured in low troughs to cool, cut into sheets, and dried. The same antlers can be boiled again for another amount of glue. Three and one-half to four leiv 1 [see cateqory 104 -- Glossary. -- Analyst] of antlers yield one leiv of glue, 504 cont'd Figure 285. Awl made of horn, 15 cm. long. (N.M.) less if the antlers were those of old animals. 1 Grape (1803), p. 269. The best glue is obtained from the antlers of wild reindeer, which often weigh two lbs. each. 2 Deutsch, p. 306: (at the beginning of the nineteenth century) a farm in the Tornio valley would prepare as much as ten L of glue a year. -- The antlers are stored under a storehouse or upon a roof, and sold in Finnmark.

Tattooing has a purely magical significance, as may be inferred from the fact that the Mataco and the Choroti women regard it particularly as a protection against disease. Analyzing the custom, we can distinguish at least three factors in it, all of which are associated with magical ideas: first, the scarification or bleeding itself; second, the matter (soot, ashes) rubbed into the wounds; and third, the patterns and marks incised which remain when the wounds have healed. Bleeding and scarification are common practices of purely magical significance among all Indians of South America, and as far as the Pilcomayo tribes are concerned I shall have occasion to mention this custom again in a later chapter. The very scars left after such operations are regarded as a protection against evil spirits. Further, that tattooing is done by means of ashes or soot is certainly not an accident. The use of ashes for superstitious purposes is of frequent occurrence among the Indians, the general idea being that ashes are a prophylactic against evil spirits. The custom of mixing ashes or soot with saliva is significant from the same point of view, for magical virtues are commonly ascribed to the saliva.

The theory which the Choroti have formed about sickness and disease has appeared from some of the above statements. Sickness, like epidemic disease, is always due to supernatural operation. It is caused by a demon, a mohsek, directed by a human sorcerer. Wizards cause sickness by throwing spells embodied in certain material objects, small stones, cactus thorns, bones, certain insects, etc. We should say that it is the stone, thorn, etc. that causes the pains felt by the victim, but its real cause is the mysterious demon embodied in the object. This appears most clearly from the conjuration with which the medicine-man tries to remove the evil and in which the demon is directly addressed.

Every grave disease is due to a special nahút . Thus for instance, the intermittent fever which attacks people during the cold season, is caused by a nahút teláh . The Mataco, however, are of opinion that it is possible for a medicine-man to cure the patient by incantations in four or five days. The worst nahút of all is the small-pox, otoahtyá, a disease which has caused terrible ravages among the Mataco at different periods. The art of the medicine-man is powerless against this dreadful demon. Therefore, when an epidemic of small-pox breaks out in a Mataco village the inhabitants know of no other remedy against the evil than to burn the whole village, to abandon the place and the sick ones, and to depart to another place. When an Indian is attacked by the small-pox, the Mataco told me, the nahút seizes the patient at the throat and presses it together with such violence that the tongue hangs out from the mouth, the eyes are thrust out from their orbits, the face swells up, and the patient dies.

If in a village, during a certain time, several deaths have occurred, especially if an epidemic has been raging, the Mataco are in the habit of saying: That place has been visited by many naút yil . On the other hand, if in a certain village there has been no death and no disease for a long time, the Indians say: In this place there are, at present, no nahút yil . There is practically no disease and no illness which is not directly or indirectly ascribed by the Indians either to an aittáh slamsa or a nahút yil . Slight disorders and illnesses which are cured in a couple of days are ascribed to the aittáh, mortal diseases to the nahút . If a Mataco for instance breaks his leg, or if some other misfortune happens to him which does not end fatally, he is of opinion that he has been attacked by a small aittáh . Similarly, there are aittáh operating in stupendous natural phenomena, in hurricanes, in torrential rains, in thunder and lightning, A Toba woman spinning wool. Bolivia. The house of the Toba chief Niradyak (Alligator). Bolivia. in drought in eclipses, etc. Thunder and lightning, for instance, are caused by the demons called aittáh tavakái p[unavailable]lai (the thunder demons). which pass in great numbers through the air or above the clouds. Eclipses of the moon, on the other hand, are attributed to a demon called aittáh hayáh which is supposed to prey upon the moon. The Mataco try to frighten away both the thunder-demons and the demon eclipsing the moon by shouting loudly and making a noise, and by beating drums.

The medicine-men of the Mataco also have a good spirit ( aittáh is ), of which much the same holds true as has been said of the good spirits of the Tobas and the Choroti. The aittáh is of the Mataco is however surnamed aittáh talák, i.e. the Old One, and to that extent seems to be more strongly personified than the corresponding tutelary genius of the Tobas and the Choroti. The Old One of the Mataco is not a Supreme Being of the kind which is supposed to exist among certain primitive tribes; he is neither a creator of the world nor a guardian of morality. He is the particular guardian spirit of the medicine-men and plays his most important rôle in connection with the conjurations by means of which the latter try to cure disease. The Mataco ascribe disease to the operation of evil spirits. The cure, as usual, is effected by the expulsion of the evil intruder, but the medicine-man’s own art is insufficient for that. He needs supernatural aid, and this aid is afforded him by the aittáh talák .

We know already the general theory of disease held by the Chaco Indians. Most bodily evils from which the Indians suffer are, according to their belief, due to witchcraft, which implies that the illness has been sent by a human enemy, generally a malignant sorcerer. In this way the Indian has arrived at the theory of possessions: an evil spirit has entered the body in the form of a material object of some kind. It is the medicine-man’s business to extract the evil intruder, and if he succeeds in doing so, the patient will recover. An epidemic, on the other hand, especially such as has come to the Indians from another part of the country, is believed to be directly caused by special disease- and death-demons of a particularly malignant character, who wander about in the village carrying off one victim after the other. Against these demons even the art of the medicine-man is powerless. The only thing the panic-stricken Indians can do in such cases is to abandon the haunted village as soon as possible and wander off to another part of the country.
There is, to these Indians, practically no such thing as natural disease and death. Every illness is attributed to supernatural causes, be the diagnosis in a particular case witchcraft or disease.
Therefore, in dealing with native methods of curing illness we are here only concerned with such evils as are set down to witchcraft.

There are certain ailments which are particularly characteristic of the Chaco Indians. Rheumatic pains, especially during the dry season, are very common, and both young and old people suffer from them. As we know, they usually come on very suddenly, and even civilized peoples still use expressions like fairy-dart,  Hexenschuss , etc. of such sudden ailments. Beliefs of this kind are held both by the Choroti and by the other Chaco Indians. The Indians have very concrete ideas as to the way in which the sorcerers and the demons who serve them operate. The mysterious pain suddenly afflicting a man is explained as due to an arrow shot by an evil spirit. The Choroti accordingly call this disease-demon mohsek ihitek, i.e. the arrow-shooting demon, and this is an idea which is quite common among the South American Indians in general. The expression seems to indicate that at least in some cases an evil spirit is supposed to operate alone. As a rule, however, he is sent by a human sorcerer. I have already mentioned that the arrow or splinter, discharged by the sorcerer or his assistant demon, is generally a small stone, a cactus thorn, a piece of bone, or a small insect (for instance a worm or a beetle). I have also stated that this seemingly insignificant material object is identical with a mysterious demonical being whom the medicine-man, in curing the patient, tries to extract from his body. The object is sent by a mohsek, or in a certain sense is a mohsek . Generally, however, the Choroti call the mysterious intruder by another name: sometimes it is called nihléle, in other cases again piní, words which have their equivalents in the Mataco and the Toba languages in the terms aláh and kaipák respectively.
