I promise to help rid these people of their passions by offering the said demons a black horse. “I shall profess, worship, and bow to the demon Altan-Sobiraj-Toen (the brazen basin), his wife Altan-Sobiraj-Chotun (the one with the bigger brazen arrow), their daughters Timir-Kuturuk (iron tail) and Kejulgan-Darchan (the important, great, lopping woman), who send mankind chronical abscesses. I shall help free the sick by sacrificing some (Arago) liquor, and offering the demons a motley seamew, as a gift of honor. “I shall profess and worship, and bow to the ancester of these demons who is known as Kjun-Zelerjuma-Sakryl-Chotun (the horrible foe of the sun) who has 52 tables full of holes, and 52 servants. She sends the people the passion of game and drinking, of robbery, plundering, abject deeds, and suicide. I shall try to heal those who are obsessed with these vices. I shall kill a red-spotted young mare who is an ambler, and twist heart and liver of the mare round my neck; I shall perform shaman magic to propitiate the goddess. “I shall profess and honor the demon above the demons of the six sibs who live in the place where the sinners’ souls are sent to; I will bow to the one who is known among the shamans as Talirdach-Tan-Taraly-Toen (he who drags into ruin), his daughters Sorocha-Chotun (the wind-driven female beauty, and San-Chotun, and his countless servants who send men and cattle epidemic diseases. To propitiate them I shall offer them a sorrell-spotted mare. “I shall profess, honor, and bow to the demon Bor-Malachaj-Toen (deformed earth) and his wife Bor-Malachaj-Chotun who send mankind various diseases and, especially, death. If in a family children should die, I will implore these demons for mercy, and 171 offer them a black cow with a half-white head. “I shall profess, honor, and bow to the demon Archach-Toen (the sick one) and his wife Archach-Chotun, who send mankind consumption. I shall heal the affected by offering a blackish brown cow. “I shall profess, and honor the demon Njas-Elju (cart-horse, death) and his wife Yeryk-Chotun (the sick one) who send the people falling sickness and Siberian pestilence. I shall try to heal those who have been affected by these diseases by offering an eelpout and a trout. “I shall profess, honor, and bow to the demon Kytaj-Baksy-Toen who gives the Yakuts resourceful smiths and powerful shamans. When Kytaj, angry with a smith, sends him a disease, I promise to kill a red cow in his honor, to spread the blood over all the forge tools, and to burn the heart and the liver to ashes in the chimney. If I should be affected by this disease, another shaman will sacrifice for me and propitiate the demon. “I shall profess, honor, and bow to the daughter of the demon, Tamyk-Chotun (the haughty one). She sends mankind mental diseases of various kind. Those who have been affected by such diseases I shall heal by sacrificing nine ermines, nine snow-weasels, nine fitchews, and nine pigeons; I vow to catch them alive, to adorn them, and to release them entirely. “I shall profess and bow to, I shall honor the shaman woman Tajaktach-Njacaj (the feeble one with the reed), her husband Atyr-Chataj (the eagle) and his countless family and descendants, who send the people oppression of the chest. Those who have been affected by this disease I shall try to save by sacrificing a light-red cow with but one horn. “I shall acknowledge, honor, and bow to the heavenly shaman Kybilyr Ojun (the white swan), his sister Kytalyktyr-Kyrbyky (the swan of the acute wings). and their mother Soruktach-Sodor (the charitable ruler), who send the people deafness and every kind of ear disease. Those who have been affected by it I shall try to save by offering a red cow with but one horn ( agar mostach kugas ).

Ajsyt (the distributor of goods). This female deity has her abode in heaven; she does benefits by sending the people children and facilitates delivery to the women. She is favorable in general and especially towards women; she makes menstruation return after a childbirth. After lucky deliveries she is offered sacrifices. The ceremony will be referred to below. These good deities are not offered bloody sacrifices, only victuals (corn).

Good deities of the second class are: (orolzuttar) 1) An-dojdu-itcitja An-darchan-chotun (the female deity who protects the earth); she lives on big trees and gives the plants growth and fertility. According to the shamans she appears to people once in a while; and he who has had such a vision is happy for his lifetime and will suffer no more from any distress. According to the shamans, they accept various kinds of offerings. 2) Sjugja-Toen, chara-begi-toen (the deity of the cattle); he sends children and claves to the people. According to the shamans he sends beleljach-kulun and mjanjach-ogon, i.e. a foal with a spot on his forehead, and a boy with a birth-mark. Those spots and marks are considered as fortunate signs. Proportions and qualities of the actual sacrifice are ordered by the shaman. 3) Uordach-dzjusjugjach-Aj, i.e. the angry deity who punishes a man for his crimes and transgressions. He is offered a horse or a bull. The teacher Pripuzov mentions that this god gives courageous men, fiery horses, and powerful bulls. 4) The same author also mentions a god, Chotoj-Aj, who gives a mediocre breed only, but in larger quantity, and with a prevalence of female individuals. 5) Eechsit, a female deity who always accompanies a wanderer on his way and supports him in his good deeds. She enjoys particular love and esteem among the Yakuts. Sacrifices are willingly made for her. She is regarded as the Yakut guardian angel. According to the shamans, there is no protection for him who may have offended Eechsit and is abandoned by her. He is exposed to the evil spirits. If someone escapes a peril, he says that Eechsit has aided him. She is offered a young mare. 6) Baj-Bajanaj is the deity who protects game-hunting. He accompanies the hunter everywhere and helps him in his undertakings. When a Yakut goes to hunt in order to get skins, he carves an idol of wood, and tinges it with the blood of an animal he has killed in his honor. The shaman and the guests eat the meat of the killed animal, and the statue of Baj-Bajan is put in the front corner on the oron of honor. Oron is the table of honor in the left front corner. Sometimes Baj-Bajan stays in his corner for many years. 7) Ukulan, the deity of the fishermen. He lives in the water and affords successful fishing. He is offered two-years-old black calf.

The following gods and good demons may still be mentioned: Kis-tanara, the deity of the stables. He is represented in human appearance, dressed with a sable-fur. His statue is kept in a bag of chamois leather which is adorned with motley pearls. On important occasions he is asked for help by throwing grease into the fire. 178
The demon of the fire, An-drachan-toen, or Al-ot-iccitja enjoys equal honors. He is offered part of the meal which is being eaten. It is thrown into the fire.

An-darchan is fancied as an aged man. He is the mediator between mankind and the evil spirits. No sacrifice is made without a secondary sacrifice for him. He is the door through which one can reach another demon.

The god of the fire is characterized by benevolence. He helps in all circumstances, he displays a sensible and vivid interest in the actions of the people, which is repaid by giving him part of the meal which being eaten and throwing it into the fire. The demon is an honest old man. He is known as Byrjachja-bytika-kyryl-tjusjumjat, i.e. the appearance with the white beard.

As demons, or evil spirits, are considered: 1) Z-chosgon-ojun-kinjas, i.e. Satanas, the prince of the monsters. He sends the people evils, diseases, causes deaths of the cattle, and sterility. To appease him a light-brown foal is sacrificed ( surzagyl ). 2) Bologur-chotuna, Dochsun-Dujan, and Bachsy-toena-al-ljachaj are demons, the former of male, the latter of female sex. According to the shamans, both of them once were human beings, but were changed into demons on account of their sins. They deprive men of their intelligence. They are offered a mare of spotted color ( cugur ). 3) Dzachtan-byradaj, or Jurjun-ogustach once was a shaman and possessed a white bull. The bull was stolen so the shaman became malicious. After his death he was punished by becoming a demon. He causes diseases, especially chest ailments in young children with fatal exit, unless he be offered a three years old calf. 4) Sordach-conach was a female shaman when she was alive. She causes several epidemics. According to the shamans her appearance is ugly, she has but one hand and foot, and one eye in the middle of the forehead. She is offered a red-stained cow ( kéchebiren ). 5) Makyny-kysa-tynyrachtach-kjadzjaj, a former shaman woman, causes madness and other diseases. She is offered a cow with water-bright horns and claws, a bald spot on the forehead, a motley tail, and generally red color. . . To honor her she is carved as an idol which is adorned with a giant fur. In this idol the fury is inevitably closed in, according to shaman notions. The idol is known as kys-tagara, virgin goddess. She is put in the angle of the central timber to the left of the fireplace, and remains untouched from generation to generation. It is venerated that much especially because the slightest touch may cause the ire of the Fury. 6) Buchar-dodar is the demon of death. Therefore he rides on the bull Bor-kurjun, i.e. the earth-pale panther. She lives in the nether world where like him, and with the exceptions of a few minor ones, there are eight demons of equal rank. 7) Syry-kysa is a woman shaman as to her origin. She seduces people to do wrong, to suffer evil. She is not offered anything. The shaman has no difficulty in exorcizing her. 8) Sjulljukjuter are the demons of the waters. They live the way mortal men do, and raise cattle. In the waters there is much moss. If the latter is brought on the dry ground, it changes to meney, though, after three days it will be moss again. 9) Sebeka is a little ugly girl with an enormous belly. She lives in a poor Kalmuk hut ( choton ) and brings mischief upon the cattle.

Because of their slovenliness , skin disea ses, such as rashes, various herpes, scabs, fistula, ulcers, and abscesses are extremely widespread among the Yakut. Cachexia and scrofula are common also, particularly in poor localities which are subject to frequent famines. In damp and marshy places, among lakes, where the population feeds primarily on the poorest kinds of fish, leprosy is found, although by no means to such an extent as has been proclaimed. The point is that the inhabitants confuse this disea se with some forms of chronic syphilis, which manifests itself in this severe climate with fearsome severity: the body and the bones rot away, and the sick man decomposes while he is still alive, just as he does from leprosy. The inhabitants have a great fear of both these disease and, as soon as they develop, banish the sick one mercilessly: they put the syphilitics into the okrug hospitals, and drive those suspected of leprosy into the woods, where they have houses built for them and where they bring the m food at definite intervals. When such a colony dies off, the Yakut burn down the buildings with everything that is inside them. 1 Their fear of infection reaches such apoint that they avoid speaking to the sick or approaching them, even at a distance of several sagenes. They consider that the fish of a lake where lepers have fished are also leprous, and once when I gathered some cloudberries growing not far from the ashes of a colony of lepers, long since destroyed, the Yakut, learning of this, considered that I was a doomed man (Kolymsk Ulus, Engzha, 1883). Another time, when on the road to Kolymsk on the Indigirka I and my Cossack fellow-traveler, lagging behind the caravan, got lost in a snowstorm and accidentally stumbled on such a house, my young fellow-traveler, learning that lepers lived there, jumped up like a madman and ran, literally at a gallop, far beyond the confines of the enclosure, without waiting for me or asking the direction. The lepers themselves, who met us very timidly, went out into the yard and shouted dierctions to us from afar. They call leprosy the big sickness (ulakhan olyu, and also syster), and call syphilis the Russian or French disease. The worst of the epidemic diseases for the Yakut is smallpox. Ninety percent of those that fall sick from this disease die; in the south it does not have as deadly an effect as in the north.

Almost nothing is known about the prevalence of other diseases; they are all treated with homemade remedies, incantations, and shamanism, and since they are accompanied by delirium and moaning, they ascribe them to the influence of hostile spirits. From the reports of medical acquaintances and my own observations, the following diseases are known to me: catarrhal, gastric, and rheumatic fevers, pneumonia, diseases o the heart, liver, and gall bladder, consumption, cancer of the throat, uterus, and stomach, and diseases of the eye... Slight inflammations of the eye are cured very successfully by licking the pus from under the eyelid with the tip of the tongue. Sometimes this is done by particular specialists who have a particularly soft and thin tongue. People come purposely to the houses of such people and pay as much as thirty kopecks for an operation. Despite the abundance of water, swamp fever is comparatively rare; sufferers are cured by frightening them, or pouring cold water over them; even oftener they are not treated at all. Fever belongs to that class of diseases against which shamanism acknowledges itself to be powerless. Rheumatism is extremely widespread; finally, the terrible disease, contraction of the throat, is not a rarity; its victims die a death from hunger. This malady is apparently found most often in those places where cattle raising is the exclusive occupation, where the supply of wild animals has been exhausted and they do not raise grain; I think it appears as a result of eating liquid foods exclusively. Besides this, it is a rare Yakut who does not suffer from tape-worm or round worm - a result of eating meat that is raw or not sufficiently cooked; the local cattle suffer equally severely from these parasites. From the observations of doctors, diseases and medicines alike act more quickly on the organisms of Yakut, than on Russians. Yakut live to a ripe old age: old men of seventy or eighty are far from rare among them.

322 In the way of meat the first place among the Yakut according to the number of poods consumed is occupied at the present time by beef. Mare's meat is more highly valued by the Yakut, it cost more, and is inaccessible to the poor. Even average households are not able to feast themselves on it very often. Less of it is used in general. - This is the food of rich men and horse thieves, says, not without foundation, a proverb. But on rare occasions even the poor manage to get hold of this meat, in the form of payment for work done, for hay, and so forth. In some localities the rich are very willing to settle accounts with slaughtered mares or two year old colts. Again, at weddings, even when the parties are not rich, the Yakut always slaughter horses and all the meat is eaten on the spot or taken home by the guests. The Yakut distinguish nine stages of corpulence in their horses and three stages of emaciation. They consider meat from a horse in the last stage of emaciation, yrbyt, injurious to the health. Matiushkin, who traveled with Vrangel, describes how when after many days of hungry wandering he offered to kill one of the horses, the Yakut, although famished and driven to desperation, refused: No, our horses are exhausted, covered with boils and wounds; their blood is inflamed and we will become ill if we start to eat their meat, - they replied. 1 Vrangel'. Vol. II, p. 267. I have myself heard these arguments more than once. Nevertheless in the Kolymsk Okrug in 1882, when great numbers of dead horses died along the road because of bad fodder, I saw whole caravans, of up to ten narts, of disgusting looking carrion with ragged skin and no meat at all. These dead horses were being carried to post stations, from where they were sold at a cheap price to poor Yakut. In general the Yakut do not scorn eating carrion and even rich men, using the pretext of opoy , uruttabyt , will not miss a chance to eat a dead mare or a cow, as long as it is fat. Opoy (heart failure) for some reason is not considered a dishonorable death. The Yakut are also willing to eat cattle which has died from malignant anthrax; they have even worked out a whole system of treating such horses. The sick horses are killed, which is something the Yakut always try to do with any hopelessly sick cattle; in no case, however, do they use the blood as food. Then the meat is quartered and hung up, to let it cool off and dry from any remnants of blood. Before eating it they boil it thoroughly, contrary to their usual practice with meat. The intestines and the fat are not eaten. They dress the cattle while wearing mittens and do all sorts of things so as not to get the disease themselves; nevertheless each year in the Yakutsk Oblast several families die from malignant anthrax. Often they fail to recognize this disease, and tempted by the sight of the fat meat attribute the cattle's death to the all-excusing heart failure

The souls of shamans, male and female, the souls of witches and wizards, abtakh, the souls of evil, envious, and angry people, or of all those set off from the rest in one way or another, all become er. These spirits remain er for ever and serve 624 as workers and assitants to the higher spirits; if they settle in a person's body they cripple it, ruin their eyesight and insides, break their bones, make them into hysterics, mannerik, and drive them insane. Sometimes they endow them with power and the arts of magic, turning them into shamans. (Namsk Ulus, 1888). Basically, every shaman's power rests on the omnipotent spirit mannerik, and is an hysteric. No one is born a shaman, but anyone can become one, sometimes even against his will. Here is the s tory of the above-mentioned shaman named Tyus'pyut, which means he who has fallen from the sky, of how he became a shaman:

All sicknesses are caused by evil spirits who settle in a person, and the methods of treating each disease are almost identical. They consist 637 of frightening or coaxing out the unwelcome guests. The simplest method is the fire cure. It is only used for treating certain illnesses, such as: swellings, broken bones, rheumatic pains, and malignant wounds. In the Kolymsk Okrug I saw a characteristic scene: a lad had accidentally bruised his finger. It was aching and an abcess had developed. He had however come to the conclusion, as did all his associates, that an er had settled in his finger. Wishing to drive him out the sick one took a hot coal and began to blow on it holding it next to his wound; when the burned skin began to blister and then broke with a slight cracking sound, the curious onlookers, gathered around in a circle, jumped back with a cry of fright, and the sick lad, smiling with self-satisfaction, said: See how he jumped out! The use of fire as a method of healing is very widespread among the Yakut, particularly in the north. In Verkhoyansk I saw an old man who suffered from shifting rheumatism; his body was literally eaten out with deep burns. He treated his illness in the following fashion: as soon as pain or swelling would appear he would immediately put a piece of lighted tinder or rag on the affected spot, and then wait patiently for the whole piece to burn. A choking smell of burning cloth and human flesh would permeate the hut, and the old man would sit, his head downcast, and merely moan quietly and pitifully from time to time. No arguments could convince him of the uselessness of the treatment he was employing; the Yakut ironically call this method the Yakut blister.

It is commonly believed that eagles are spiteful, but on occasion also grateful. One shaman told me how an eagle whom he had had an opportunity to kill but spared presented him with the stone sata, excreting it together with the magical excrement which causes bad weather. On the other hand, I was told that a certain Yakut of the Atamaysk Nasleg of the Namsk Ulus who had killed an eagle suffered heavily for it; he and his sister were twisted, he began to suffer from fits (manrier), and in three days they both died in horrible agony. (Namsk Ulus, 1887). A Yakut woman of the Namsk Ulus would not under any consideration eat a duck taken away from an eagle: It is a sin to make use of the labor of others; after all the eagle also suffers while hunting! she justified herself. I think that she was motivated by fear.

Together with Kagkhtan-Burey live many other spirits subordinate to him, who injure people's backs, making them hunchbacked or bent. In their honor are sacrificed horses with black backs and dark-red sides and thighs, and kochay are hung. Only in exceptional cases do Ulu-toen and Kagkhtan-Burey appear personally on the earth. 2 I should call the reader's attention to the word Kagkhtan in this divinity's title: occaisionally kagan is said instead. The Uigur called their tsars kagan.
Also in the south, on nine forest hillocks, lives Nemirie, a prince's daughter. This was once a young Yakut woman; she married far

from her house and lived with her parents for a long time after her wedding, in accordance with the ancient custom. Her husband took her away with honor. The bridal train consisted of nine horses; the husband treated her well, but when on the journey he stopped on the ninth forest hillock to spend the night under the open sky, the young wife went out of her mind during the night without any apparent reason. She killed her child, sucked out his blood and devoured his meat. Then 662 she attacked the sleeping cones and began to scratch and bite herself and the others. They quieted her forcibly and brought her back home. There they built a small and securely bolted shed, where they placed her and where she lived for many years. After he death she turned into the heavenly spirit which attacks people, particularly women, and drives them insane, turns them into hysterics, epileptics, and lunatics, all those who bite themselves and others. To her is sacrificed a grey mare with black spots on her shoulders (sur dzhagyl sylgy), which the shaman leads along nine forest hillocks, and then sets free. Along with Nemirie on the same nine-hillocks live her eight sisters, who also drive people to insanity; I was only able to learn the names of some of them:

In the north lives The Mistress with the long staff, Ken' tayakhtakh khotun,and with her her nine younger sisters. She is Russian; when she was alive she had fallen sick and died of syphilis. She visits on mankind: syphilis, scrofula, leprosy, and other contagious diseases. To her are sacrificed various kinds of cattle, mainly sorrel cows with blue spots and horses with red spots, kyuokh-ebirien (ebirdyakh) ynakh; kysyl chogur sygly. They also make presents of cookies, vodka, silver, money, furs, clothing, silk handkerchiefs, and so forth. Far in the north, before reaching the sea, there is a mountain with posts, on the bank of the Lena. There can be seen a stone house with stone household utensils; in this house lives a stone women in Russian clothing - this is that mistress with the long staff. 2 See p. 16.

In the direction to which the northern corner of the bilirik points, beneath the earth, lives the son of Satan, the old man who lives underground with a troop of helpers and sorcerers, Satana uola, allara ogonior khamardatakh (Komandalakh) etyugYa da oyuna. To him is sacrificed a six-year old bull with black and red stripes, with a white forelock and white eyes (tusaktalakh, yuryung kharakhtakh kyurdzhyuges). Together with the old man who lives underground lives Sor-khara Dzheng (black raven Dzherg), who goes to the houses of rich Yakut with a tambourine and drums on it. From his visits everyones in the house becomes sick, usually with headaches.

In the east lives the Mistress with a white colt Kere ubakhalakh khotun - once a Yakut woman of the Bayagantaysk Ulus, a relative of the nine sisters living in the south. To her is sacrificed a white colt, sometimes alive and sometimes slaughtered. In the latter case a table on four legs with four corners is placed in the center of the hut; on it are placed dishes with vodka, salt, and pieces of boiled meat, liver, heart, and fat, the boiled head of the sacrificed animal. When a certain time has elapsed they burn all this. This spirit causes headaches, pain in the intestines and bones, and so forth.

664 In the north, under the earth, also lives The old man Dampay-Braday with his white bull, Yuryung ogustakh ogonior, Dampay-Braday ogonior, once a Yakut shaman of the Bologur tribe, 1 Of the Bologur Nasleg of the Baturussk Ulus. which lived in the north; this old man was old and poor, and lived by begging. He had many children, seven, I believe, and one white bull on which his children rode when visiting neighbors, itimni. It happened that someone stole his bull and thus made it impossible for him to move about with his children. The children began to get sick and cry from hunger, and drove the old man to such a point that he dug a pit, put the children in it, and lit a fire over them. When the children began to choke and die he struck his tambourine and, walking around the fire, began to perform a shamanistic rite and utter his grieviances against mankind. In return for the injury he had suffered Ulu-toen gave him the right to take away a child for every hair on the bull. Since this time the old man, turned into an er , has gone about crippling and killing children. Not a single shaman could overcome him, but now he has received the full quota of children alloted to him and has become harmless, as a result of his old age and infirmity. When he now visits someone he is not given what he asks for, but simply taken by the neck and thrown out. (Namsk Ulus, 1887). It is characteristic of the Yakut shamanistic pantheon that for the most part the secondary spirits are former shamans or people who had somehow been injured, or in general suffered, while on this earth. To their titles is always added the clan name, which again indicates the tie between the Yakut cult of shamanism and their clan organization and their clan history. 2 In the Zapadno Kangalas Ulus I was even shown a tiny circular island in the middle of a small lake, on which the yurt of Dampay-Braday had once supposedly stood; this was not in the Bologur Nasleg, but in the Oktemsk Nasleg.

The Yakuts who live in the northern part of the Yakutsk government divide the diseases a man can have into two categories: such diseases which one may catch by chance and which soon are over, e. g. cuts sprains, &c, the healing of which is easily reached either by application of cow’s butter, excrements, herbs, &c, or by setting the limbs; other diseases of inner organs, chronical ailments, nervous illness or mental troubles are considered to be due to a demon or spirit. Outwardly applied remedies are useless in such cases; they cannot touch the disease. Only the shaman (ojun) who has the privilege of being in contact with the invisible world is in a position to provide healing or at least relief for the patient. Slight diseases of the second category such as eye ailments (outward inflammation, abscess of the eyelid) may be healed by a single short invocation of the spirit. The shaman will recite his exorcisms for ten minutes and stare at the patient’s eyes, until he suddenly spits into the letter’s eyes. When the patient now is starting with terror, the evil spirit (abagy, abassy) will be terrified and flee from the patient who gets his health back. Man just gets a disease because an evil spirit, a demon, has visited him.

It is, above all, up to the shaman, after being called to a patient to find out the name of the spirit in question, because every spirit causes only those diseases which are peculiar to his sib. He must, moreover, find out, what kind of sacrifice has to be offered in order to appease the spirit and make him abstain from his hostility towards the patient. For this purpose the exorcist performs a mystic ceremony before the couch of the patient. After having dressed in his official dress (kumà) he takes his drum (djugjur), which is his leader through the nether world and the seven heavens, and invokes the spirits of his dead ancestors and relatives, the spirits of mighty shamans. Through their mediation he goes down to the subterraneous world of the spirits, then climbs on strongly-turned ropes from one heaven to the other (which he reports in his mystic and ecstatic songs) asking whoever he is meeting: “who is the spirit that keeps my protégé in prison?” After a long migration he receives information on the permanent domicile of the spirit; finally, further devices are applied to get into negotiations with the found demon under the supervision of the protectors of the shaman.

The shaman’s endeavor is not always successful. He may not succeed in finding out the identity of the spirit who causes the illness, or once that he has managed to, he may not be able to locate him at a given moment, or, at last, the negotiations may have failed to bring about persuasion of the frightful, cruel demon, to appease him, to change his ire into indulgence. Unconditionally helpless is the shaman with pestilence and epidemics (d[unavailable]an) . The demon will not cease grasping the soul (kut) of the patient as a prey, takes possession of it, severs it from the body, and flees away with it. The patient’s body remains unmoved and stops breathing, and unless the dreadful demon is propitiated before long, the soul will fail to come back to its former abode, the bodily frame will cool down and be subject to decomposition.

Shamanism is not the faith or religion of the Yakut but a particular action carried on in certain defined circumstances as follows: 1) for all kinds of sick people, with an investigation first to determine what devil produced the disease and then entreaty to that devil to deliver the patient from the illness, with a sacrificial offering of a head of cattle, a dog, or something; indeed, through great faith in this, patients sometimes obtain relief. The Yakut consider a devil to be the cause of everything, for instance: if a person or head of cattle falls ill, or calves die, they day that a devil is torturing and killing them, without any understanding of the fact that all this has natural causes; healing through shamanism, which includes shouting over sore eyes, spitting on the sick part of the body, which is done not by a shaman but by ordinary Yakut and which sometimes succeeds, comes from sympathetic actions; 2) to repel cattle infection and especially the death of calves; 3) for entertainment, for in such cases the shamans do tricks and make prophesies; 4) for the delirious; because of great faith in shamanism, this illness formerly existed everywhere among the Yakut, especially among females, who can be stopped only by means of shamanism and otherwise continue to suffer. This custom, i.e., shamanism, has gradually almost died out since the Yakut adopted the Christian faith, and now most of the Yakut, enlightened by faith and the knowledge of the truth, recognize it as ignorance and superstition; however, many even of the converted Yakut, having bee brought up in the belief, practise it, but the Yakut do not consider this reprehensible, owing to the antiquity of the custom, and therefore no 219 strict measures are taken in this connection, the more so since: 1) the Yakut who practise shamanism do not forget that God exists and know that everything is done through His Almighty Power, for they have long become accustomed to saying, when a person dies, “He has gone to God”, without distinguishing whether the person was righteous or sinful; circumstances which favor them have God's help, and likewise events which hinder them and accidents are recognized as God's punishment for sins; 2) if shamans were given strict punishment, then it would be necessary to punish their spectators as well, for they induced them to shamanize and came mainly to eat the sacrificed livestock; there are four or five people every time, from which it follows that very few would go unpunished, investigations and denunciations would multiply so that there would be no business but cases about shamanism, with resultant neglect to useful domestic occupations. The Yakut are using the following means to destroy this custom gradually: a) all converted Yakut are strictly forbidden by the clan-chiefs to shamanize and to have shamanism performed. In case of conviction of this offence, the guilty shaman is deprived of the clothing and objects which he uses for shamanism, they are destroyed, and the shaman's hair is shaved off, as a sign of his calling; and those who caused him to perform are given reprimands in meetings of the communities; b) among the unconverted, a shaman who was supposed to heal a patient but who did not succeed must turn over the head of cattle which was sacrificed and pay all losses incurred by the patient; but if he is convicted of this several times, he is declared an impostor and becomes a permanent object of mockery and is quite without employment. As this custom is repugnant to the Christian religion, 220 the Yakut themselves, and frequently the eparchial priests have sent denunciations to the authorities because of particular complaints among the Yakut, there have been investigations by the zemstvo officials, and the guilty parties have given themselves up to the disposition of the discretionary court which caused the Yakut, and especially those who were affected by the action, much losses and distractions from their occupations.

The Aymara possess a wide variety of amulets ( ila ), many of which are purchased from the traveling doctors ( qolawayu ). Amulets in clude stone, clay, bone, metal, and bezoar stones removed from the stomachs of llamas and vicuñas. When not worn on the person, they are usually kept in coca bags. They are often greased with a mixture of llama fat, coca, and flower petals. Some amulets are worn by children to protect them from evil spirits (see p. 550), whereas others ward off disease and witchcraft. Little stone figurines representing men and women are tied together for love magic. Amulets the shape of a human hand prevent fatigue and give luck in weaving. Paredes speaks of amulets called “ conopa ” which are kept in houses as family guardians (Paredes, 1936, p.27). These are in human, fish, or phallic form and are smeared with the blood of sacrificed animals. Other amulets which represent animals are used in fertility rites (see Domesticated Animals, p. 520, and pl. 111, bottom, right ), but have no power in themselves, simply representing the class of livestock for which the ceremony is performed.

Diseases and medicines.--Curing is an absorbing interest of the Aymara . Its elaborate development is reflected in the extensive terminology of diseases, medicines, practitioners, and curing techniques. It is recognized that people of different ages are susceptible to special ailments. All adults have some knowledge of simple herbal remedies and treat slight injuries; a doctor is not consulted unless the ailment or injury is persistent and specialized knowledge required.

Diseases are thought to be due mainly to evil spirits and witchcraft, although a few are attributed to natural causes. All the latter are classified as hot or cold and require a remedy of the opposite temperature. These concepts of hot and cold may come from Spanish influence. The general procedure is for the practitioner to divine the cause of disease according to his particular method, and then to cure it by medical or magical techniques.

Beliefs about the cause of disease are numerous. They include seeing ghosts, the soul becoming lost or having been kidnapped by evil spirits or witchee, dreams, being looked at by evil spirits, intrusion of an object into the body, mutilation of one's effigy in witchcraft, and the “evil eye,” the last possibly being a Spanish concept. Most of these have been discussed earlier in connection with witchcraft and supernatural beings. Soul loss, an ailment particularly common among children, results from fright or shock. If the child's mother is unable to make the soul return by calling to it, a doctor makes an image of the child's clothes, entices the soul into it, and places the image in the child's bed (Paredes, 1936, pp. 116-17). The intrusion of a fragment of human bone into the body is the cause of “chullpa sickness,” which comes from witchcraft or malevolent spirits which inhabit ruins. The bone is extracted magically in a variety of ways, but is not removed by sucking.

The Aymara have never developed a rational medicine with tendencies to change into scientific medicine. The components of its practice are completely empirical and its practitioners pretend to become thaumaturgi. They divide the medical art into two big groups: in the first is what would correspond to the origin or cause of illnesses, or etiology; the second group, the more important, corresponds to therapeutics.

They have a simplistic conception of the etiology of diseases. Either the sick person has contracted his illness because nature so willed it, and the origin of the illness may be cold, fright, /245/ the air, rage, etc., and the medication /245 cont./ will be in accord with it, or the causes of the trouble must be that he is the recipient of some harm, a curse, or is the victim of a spell, either from supernatural beings or persons who show superior powers. In these cases therapy assumes magical characteristics.

They know how to identify the symptoms of many sicknesses, especially the infectious ones. As a result of direct observation they have succeeded in establishing the rudiments of a system that enables them to make prognoses in serious cases. This has allowed them to identify diseases, although in this they have adopted Spanish terminology, having almost totally lost the primitive names; among these we have:

sojo anemia chaje deforming articular rheumatism, (a cold disease) surumpi coniunctivitis sacha compadre typhus associated with death gentil chronic illness (the evil spirits of the gentilares enter the organism)

Animals are used frequently, either whole, eviscerated, mashed, one organ only, or the blood. On fractures they use snakes or vipers mashed with quinud , applying it /246/ over the affected area, but they do not try to reduce or immobilize the segment; live frogs are applied directly on the neck in case of sore throat; blood of a male lizard in liquid for the ear, eye and facial paralyses; hard-shelled /? lacatos / white worms, dried and ground with salt and brandy for pneumonis; large eviscerated roads by direct application in consumptive diseases imputable to witchcraft.
Surgery is completely unknown to them; in the traumatological aspect they limit themselves to trying to reduce dislocations by manual manipulations, aided by alcohol rubs on the affected joint.

The Aymara, in their fatalistic conception of life, accept sickness and pain as natural elements; they accept pain and support it with great stoicism; they try to fight it but resign themselves before the irremediable. With great modesty they try to conceal their imperfections, malformations, or sores; but this is never a cause for ridicule or jokes on the part of others. There are diseases that they accept as a condition of conquest, like gonorrhea, which in young men indicates that the adolescent has become a man; on the other hand they avoid others such as smallpox, using a method of empirical vaccination: inoculation with smallpox virus / variolización /.

There were large cats in the forest--large and gray. They were afraid of fire, so we used it to protect ourselves. Wild boars attacked us and tore up our fields. The mosquitoes were one of the worst problems; we put brine on our skin to keep them from biting us. Once we saw a water buffalo.

In elevated regions snow-blindness or surumi is not uncommon, and against this the natives appear never to have devised any protection. One ingenious but improbable modern explanation of the purpose of the characteristic hole in the native tupu or semi-lunar copper knife-pin is that this was used in lorgnette fashion by myopic persons, but of this there is no observational evidence which I could offer, since I never saw them so used by the Aymara. A kind of lymphatic swelling under the corner of the chin is called cupu, “frogspit,” or liuka , “rat-spit,” according to the native's decision as to which had been the cause. A disease lao-usu involving worms or maggots is also described. Epilepey is lak'u usu . Insanity is called cankapara , and the Aymara have the realistic explanation that they become insane “because we suffer.” In some regions, especially in Larecaja and Muñecas, east of the lake, went and goitre are common, so common in Quiabaya and Sorata that the inhabitants are called otusu (from otu , “goitre”) by their neighbors. Livestock is also goitrous in this region. And whatever the historical provenience of syphilis may be, both syphilis and gonorrhea are now well known among the Aymara.

Meriting special attention is the environmentally conditioned altitudesickness of the altiplano. Medically known as an acute or chronic anoxemia, or lack of oxygen, the native terms for this disease are various. “Sorroche,” the commonest term (also the name for a friable silver ore), and “veta” (also meaning a vein, seam, or lode of metal) reflect the local superstition that the infirmity is owing to “antimonios,” or metallic exhalations--for which reason some localities are considered to be more “asorrachado” than others. Sorroche is also called “marea,” after a supposed similarity to seasickness, from which, however, it is quite distinct. The sorroche sickness of the Bolivian plateau is of course identical with the symptoms of anoxemia in aviators or balloonists who navigate at high altitudes. Various individual differences (physique, condition of the heart, red blood-cell count, hemoglobin index, etc.) obviously determine the altitude at which one becomes susceptible to it, but anywhere from 9,000 feet above sea-level and upward is a common altitude at which to anticipate anoxemia.

There are many Aymara condiments. Most familiar of course is the “aji” or Capsicum frutescons Linnaeus ( Solanaceae ), which grows only up to 4,800 feet above sea level, and hence must be traded in; a piece of “aji” or hot chili in one's bolsa will also frighten away the rachitic yellow dwarf-spirit or cuhcu who causes malaria. Another familiar condiment is qoa or “póleo,” Mentha Pulegium Linnaeus ( Labiatae ). The miniscule, aromatic leaves of this plant are much used to flavor soups and stews, especially those made of fish. A tea made of oa is widely used for stomachache, or to take away hunger while travelling. A limited use is made of this plant as a fuel, and its ashes are thought to make a fine fertilizer for fields. The same native name may possibly also refer to a species of Borreria of the Rubiaceae . Forbes 65 Forbes, 1870, p. 286. describes “chacacoma” as

To the newborn baby spoonfuls of human urine are given, especially that of other children, until milk appears in the mother. After bathing and the cutting of the cord ( kururu ), the child is wrapped up and a “bolsita” or amulet is placed around its neck. This amulet bag contains substances like the following: a rosary, a piece of deer horn (“para que les dé el aire”), small knives, chunks of milu or alum, a piece of salt, hawikulilu or pips from the luhmilu (unidentified), ikinkulu (from ikiña “to sleep” and kulu “wood,” that is, “wood to cause the child to sleep”), a spiral yellow seed-pod from the yungas, waxi (a dried root), etc. M19:N19 (which is a serious disease in Aymara belief), from being affected “por el aire,” etc. Sometimes the child has larpa , anemia, and this they believe occurs because the mother when pregnant had seen a corpse, and for this reason a pregnant woman turns her head aside if there is a corpse in sight. The Aymara belief that souls are reborn in babies may have a reference to this notion.

The souls of children are not so firmly attached to their bodies as those of adults, so that great care must be exercised on this score. At the apacheta on leaving a town, the parents cry “[child's name] hutani hutakim haniu qeparatati!” (“Come! Come now! You must not stay”) so that the child's soul will not linger behind. Sometimes when a child is sick they believe that its soul has been “caught” ( katatau ) by the spirit ( kata ) of the road, a church, a certain field, river, lake, or mountain. If it is “caught” by the earth ( oraqen katatau ), there has to be a trukaqaña to “change the health.” This is an offering of colored wools, candy, coca leaves, etc., which is left at the spot by a yatiri or laliri doctor, and a traveller should avoid this offering if he sees it at a crossroad lest he be endangered thereby. Sometimes a child has a multa (“fright”) and falls at a certain spot; then they ask it “where did you fall?” and take some earth from that spot and give it to the child to eat so that it will not become sick. Another remedy is the milucana ritual. In this a piece of milu or alum is placed on the sick child's chest, left there two or three hours, and then rubbed all over its body. After this the alum is put in a large bowl or lamota of putrified urine, covered up with a cloth, and taken out at the end of twenty to thirty minutes. The alum swells up into a sponge-like mass which the yatiri studies for a diagnosis. Then he says: “The child was frightened at this spring,” or “It will get well,” or “It will die.” When the augury is bad the yatiri takes a knife and cuts the mass with exorcisms, makes a hole in the ground and buries the milu .

Bertonio tells of a practice called “aych jatha,” in which a hair is tied around a flea or louse so that darkness will come quickly and the child can return immediately to its home to eat or sleep. When children or babies have white hair (?albinism) the Aymara say it is tatitun munata or “beloved of the Lord.” When an adult gets the hiccough ( hiku ) ordinarily the reason is thought to be worms (from eating too many sweets, etc.) and they say laqu hitkatanitu , “The worm has shoved me upwards”; but when a child gets a hiccough they think it is a sign of growing and say hilaskiu , “He is growing.” A child's growth must be protected, however. Both anciently 170 Bertonio, 1612d, 1:426. and nowadays alike children of both sexes wear the sukulu urku , the “capa pollera” or “fandilla,” mentioned on p. 89. On this score Bertonio has the following interesting words to add:

Sucullu: The little boy that they bring out into the plaza in his cradle, or bring taken out [of the cradle], and then into the plaza come the young men of the house who bear the blood of vicuñas tied up in the paunches of the same, with which the uncle, or Lari, anoints the face of the little boy, crossing the nose from one cheek to the other, and afterwards dividing up the flesh of the vicuñas among the mothers who have brought their little boys there for this ceremony, because ordinarily they bring together for this all the little boys who had been born that year; and they are accustomed to do this when beginning to harvest their potatoes, when we Christians celebrate the fiesta of Corpus Christi. They add to all this the dressing of the little boys in a black camiseta, which has interwoven in it three colored threads, one in the middle, and two at the sides from top to bottom, in the front and in the back. They do the same with the little girl of that year, only they differentiate in the name, because they call them Huampaña; and in the colored threads, of which there are many, which are interwoven not from top to bottom but all around, and fall in the middle of the little skirt or sayta, a little below where grown women are girdled, although little girls of that age do not use the girdle or huaka, that they call. . . .

Sucullo vrco: The sayta or little skirt in which they dress the little girl at the time of said ceremony, the little boys being in a row in one place, and the little girls across this, all in their cradles.

Sucullu apsutha or Ichusutha: To bring out thus the little boy or little girl; and officiating here is the aunt on the side of the father, and in default of him the wife of ones Lari [maternal uncle]. They do all this with sacrifices to their guacas [ waka ] or demons, which have them tricked and deceived with this.

In any case, properly wielded, the sling can be a formidable and even a fatal weapon, and there is no dearth of suitable stones for it in most parts of the altiplano. Testifying to the efficacy of the Aymara slings and clubs as skull-crackers is the interesting fact that two per cent of the crania in the Muñiz collection, 213 Muñiz and McGee, 1897, pp. 14, 64. representing “vigorous and healthy young men, presumptively soldierly,” had been trephined. This is a broad hint that in Aymara medicine one of the major functions of trephining may have been to relieve compression fractures of the skull caused by these weapons. In defence against them the natives had a light shield, called “kherari” according to von Tschudi, which protected most of the body. The sometime function of women in warfare as a kind of supply train, bringing up heavy stones in their skirts held like aprons, may account for the persistent legend found in the early writers that there were “Amazons” among the Aymara.

Personal amulets are many in form. In the north of the Departamento of La Paz, young Aymara on their saint's day wear a necklace of beads with a qolqemunaci or little hand holding a “real.” This is to make one “beloved of money.” If the person is a young man, he may add a warmimunaci so that he may be loved by a woman, and if a young woman she will add a cacamunaci (from munaña “to love”) so that she will get a husband. In Calacota, Corocoro, Ayoayo, and in fact most of the altiplano they carry in their bundles a little yellow corkscrew-shaped seedpod called kuru from the yungas to protect them from bad luck. Sometimes they chew it and spit in the direction from which they believe the bad luck is coming; elsewhere they use kuru in the “corrida de toros” by chewing it and spitting it in the direction of the bull, so that he will keep his distance. It is also useful to keep off lightning. Cloves of garlic have a similar efficacy in bull-fights and in warding off bad luck on a journey. An amulet to attract money is the aux-actir-qala (“needle-clutching-stone”) or magnet, because of its ability to attract metal. The Aymara say that there are two kinds of magnets, a spiny, rough “male” one and a smooth “female” one. The kolawayu doctors use and sell them, for they are a favorite kind of qolqemunaci or money-raising amulet. In the region of Sicasica the Indians put a little amulet bag around the reck of a child, on its chest, to protect it from bad luck, falls, wounds, hurts, and sickness; for a child wearing this, even if it is sleeping, cannot be menaced by a qariqari or ancancu . The typical contents of such an amulet bag are as follows: a small knife, some rosary beads, a small cross, a little salt, a small yellow chili, a piece of milu stone or alum, hawikulilu (the pip of a tropical fruit), kiñulu root, a piece of indigo stone, and perhaps a pood or two of kuru .

In the Indian markets of La Paz all these amulets and many more can be bought. The ila brings abundance to a house, and is said to be the bezoar stone from the taraku or Andean deer ( Cervus antisiensis ). “Huakanquis” are love amulets. As a necklace, “mulla” preserves the wearer from witchcraft and all illnesses. The little molded figures of men and women, made of marl or a similar chalky substance, and widely used in love magic by both men and women have been mentioned elsewhere ( see p. 133). Cholos and white people in Bolivia also employ this irresistible technique.

The Aymara, in short, pay extraordinary attention to the “altatory” elements in life. We might recall here that even the great god eqeqo is basically, in modern times, only the most elaborate of all their good-luck fetishes.

But it is Thunder who most terrifies the Aymara. Electrical storms on the Bolivian plateau are at cortain seasons both frequent and spectacular, and one can well empathize a native's fright during one of them. Thunder is ilapa , a god throwing balls ( ilapaña ) at the earth. Lightning is exuexu , hurled from tata santiagun oraqapa , “Father Santiago's sling.” There is a confusion in the minds of the modern Aymara between the ancient sky-god Viracocha, the thunder-god Thunupa, the horseman god of the Spanish (Santiago), and the bearded white men with loudly explosive arquebuses of colonial times. If a person is struck by lightning and still lives, he is regarded as particularly favored by the god ( tatilun munatau ). ( See p. 170.) Amulets to avoid being struck by the lightning are qorilimpi, qolqelimpi , and ciarlimpi , “gold-, silver-, and black-glass” (mica in these colors) respectively. Objects are also frequently placed on Aymara houses to protect them from the lightning ( see p. 95). I have also seen little bowls with offerings to Thunder, placed near an animal shelter. It is interesting to note that the bearded “snake-” god of the earlier period at Tiahuanaco excavated by Bennett 278 Bennett, 1936, pp. 440-441. has carved on its head both pumas and zigzag “lightning,” and along its side a puma-headed lightning-snake, with partly curved and partly zigzag lines.

Ordinarily, of course, the Aymara recognize that blindness and deafness announce old age. They say “ nairakiu ” (or hincukiu ) nair sarxe ,” “The eyes (or ears) [of the person] have gone on ahead.” But when a young person becomes deaf or blind it comes from “el aire” or congestion. As an etiological factor this is somewhat obscure, as Nordenskiöld justifiably remarks: 297 Nordenskiöld, 1907, p. 168.

According to the statements of several Bolivians and Peruvians, “el aire” appears to be equivalent to a partial apoplexy. They say that the face is twisted by “el aire” in a certain fashion. However, I have not very well been able to arrive at an understanding of the meaning of “el aire.”

A corkscrew-shaped yellow seed-pod, as I have noted elsewhere, is a common prophylactic against this effect of “el aire”--the most obvious of “sympathetic” magical devices to counteract the twisting of the face--and the same plant, Prosopis strombulifera (Lamarck) Bentham, is said by Métraux 298 Métraux, 1934, 26:90. to be used for torticollis or wry-neck.

The skin disease q'araci they believe is caused by a person's being “caught by the earth.” They say “ oraq'en q'alxata ,” “He's been caught or taken by the earth.” The skin disease hamat' -“saliva,” on the other hand, which is characterized by itching red spots and granules, is thought to be caused by the spittle of a frog or some other animal. Urticaria, haucixapuri (“[human] skin, burning”) is similarly caused and similarly cured with fermented human urine and salt.

The sirkaq'amani is the Aymara surgeon, who treats fractures, luxations, and wounds. Very probably it was this practitioner who in ancient times 312 In any case, Bertonio lists “Sircacamana: Cirujano” [cf. “Sirca: El pulso; la vena del cuerpo, y mina de metal, o beta”]. The sirkoq'amani quite certainly performed the operation of bleeding, vide the entry, “Sisiratha ppacharatha ccarinocatha: Sajar como hazen los cirjuanos, o los indios con piedra affilada.” As usual, Bertonio is an invaluable check on the existence of modern culture-elements in colonial times. He lists the following: Tala, vel Layca: Hechizero, o Hechizera Tata: El Hechizero Layca: Hechizero o hechizera. Vtcani layca: Hechizero de officio, cathedratico enel arte. Toqueni hamuni: Hechizero, y adeuino. Toqueni hacchiri: El que adeuina co tomar vnpuñado de mayz, o de estiercol de carnero, y despues cuenta los granos si salen pares, o nones, y segun esse adeuina lo que sera, o por mejor dezir embauca a los indios que creen en sus embustes. [Cf. Hacchutatha, Hacchutarapitha, and Hacchini toqueni.] Vmu: Grande hechizero. Huchharatha, Lancaratha: Chupar la sangre, que es embuste de los hechizeros escondiendo el algodon empapado en sangre, y fingiendo que chuparidose la saco al enfermo mostrandosela diziendo que le quito el mal. Ttinccatha: Dar papirotes co los dedos en qualquiera parte, sangrar al modo indico. Ttinccarpaatha: Quitar algo a papirotes. Tapitha: Dexar enel camino ropa o lana, &c. para q el q la hallare se lleue la enfermedad de aquella persona cuya era la ropa. Es supersticion de indios. Tapita isi haytanithe, Idem, mas claro, vel Tapirpaanitha. performed the trephinings for which this region is famous among physical anthorpologists and archaeologists. Skulls have been found with as many as five successful trepanations--which argues for a certain skill in the surgeon, as well as for the vitality of the patient. Krogman 313 Krogman, 1939, p. 12; Ronhaar, 1930, passim . Without having examined the physical evidence which might prove this contention, I believe on other evidence (such as the frequent and severe migraine of the Aymara) that a very plausible case might be made also for the alternative purpose. There is every reason to believe, however, that both motives could have operated. In this connection it is interesting to recall the legend, reported by Vara Cadillo, of the Ichik Ol'qo or child-demon, which inhabits waterfalls and foundtains, growling angrily, and throwing out a rainbow from his navel, by which he exerts an evil influence upon men through the crowns of their heads. Note also the Aymara belief in a vampire-head which sucks blood from the occipital region. considers that the purpose of trephining was to relieve compression fractures of the skull caused by warclubs, but Ronhaar believes that trephining was performed most often for epilepsy or migraine (if the epilepsy were traumatic, it comes to the same thing). Trepanation was done by sawing, cutting, scraping, and drilling with chips of flint, obsidian, quartz, and possibly blades of copper. A gourd, shell, or plaque of silver controlled the herniation of the brain through the operation. Similar is the bleeding performed upon the root of the nose, although this may have been to relieve the swelling in this area caused by a disease called “Gundu.” Another surgical procedure was to tie off multiple lipomata with horse-hairs until they sloughed off.

This already protracted account of Aymara folk-medicine would still be incomplete without mention of a variety of native chiropractic called t'alantaña or c'uimaq'aq'oña . The theory of this Aymara science is that various internal organs, particularly the heart ( c'uimia ), may become physically dislocated kiucxata . By massaging the arms and the torso carefully, and by binding with a wide textile girdle, the visceral dislocations of the patient are reduced, and he is cured. In the t'alanta procedure previously mentioned the patient is also sometimes tossed gently in a poncho held by serveral people, until his organs return to their proper position. The processes of truq'aq'a and p'ic'aq'a involve rubbing certain substances upon the body of the sick person, but with a different motive: to absorb the evil spirit which has entered, so that it may be tempted away by libations and sacrifices. A similar practice is lumaq'a , or “purification.” Some diseases like tertian fever can be cured by frightening the patient severely, for then the evil spirit will abandon his body. One of the fevers, which has the appearance of a skeleton-thin woman with disheveled hair, can be so cured. Tuberculosis, however, which is caused by tall, thin, frozen beings who live by drinking the blood of their victims, is not cured in this way. Typhoid fever can be sidetracked by cutting open a black chicken and placing it on the stomach of the sick person, or by placing his legs in the stomach of a dead dog, or by putting black guineapigs on his body immediately after eviscerating them. The disease of culpa-usu , which is caused by the “penetration” of a bone from the tomb into the body of the victim, can of course only be cured by the removal of the foreign body itself.

The climate is quite cool (average yearly temperature about forty-five degrees) and the sun very intense both because of the altitude and the latitude (about sixteen degrees south). The vasiation in temperature on a warm day is between twenty-five and thirty degrees, the average low being around forty and the high sixty-five degrees Fahrenheit. Most sicknesses are attributed to the sun or the cold. Children are always dressed in wool clothing and hats or caps, usually without shoes. Herbs are the main medicines used for most childhood or adult sicknesses, and the list of herbs and possible combinations is a very long one. Aspirin is bought by some people as a cure-all, and most of the little stores in Chinchera carry this medicine. More serious sickness that does not respond to ordinary treatments may be referred to a local qollasiri (herbal doctor), the medical doctor who holds a clinic in Chucuito once a week, or in cases of real emergency the hospital in Puno.

There are two special sicknesses that children may have that call for extraordinary treatment. A child may be made sick by the dend, either because the child has stepped on a grave or betause a loose soul has decided to torment the child. There is a standard preventative that involves the purchase of a type of yellow rock. The rock is thrown on a grave and the child's body then rubbed with it. If the child does catch the disease (called orijja ), the meat of a guinea pig or a part of a dead human body is cooked, pulverised, and fed to the child. This is a family affair with no help nesded form a magician as intermediary to the supernaturals.

The second nickness mostly strikes children, is much more serious, and cannot be prevented. It is called susto (fright) and is considered to be caused by the child losing his soul. The symptoms are sasily recogaizable. The child can't sleep, the whites of his eyes are more apparent than usual, and he fusses a great deal. Norma's child was still nursing when she lost her soul. Norma says that she knew right away what was wrong since “she chewed at my breast like a dog.” Norma was especially werried since several years before a small child of here had died from susto . Norma, her husband, and his brother and wife were all there at night for the necessary ceremony. They said the Lord's Prayer, mixed herbal medicine and gave it to the child, said the Lord's Prayer, fixed hospital medicine and gave it to the child, and again said the Lord's Prayer. This took almost two hours to finish. The child was put to bed and then Norma and her husband called for the child's soul to return. They rang a bell and shook a piece of the child's clothing out the front door. Norma did this again the next morning. The ceremony cured the child, but if it hadn't it would have been necessary to repeat it. The Lord's Prayer was said instead of Ave Marias since this family is Seventh Day Adventist. A non-Adrentist would have used coca and alcohol in the cere mony as well. This sickness is probably the result of poisoning after eating earth.

From Tschopik's notes comes a description of an actual interment. The coffin was lowered into the grave, let down by two ropes slung under it, one at either end. A member of the funeral party jumped down into the grave, raised the lid of the coffin, and untied and removed the cord which had been knotted around the throat of the dead man. As he climbed out, first he and then others around the grave threw earth into the grave on top of the coffin. The paqo or man in charge of the ceremonies said a few worde of prayer before the grave was shoveled full. A mound formed by the earth displaced by the coffin was smoothed off over the grave and a crude wooden cross stuck into it. The wreath and flowers carried on the coffin during the procession were placed on top of this mound. In addition, coca and alcohol were placed on top of the grave, to be rescued later in the day for general consumption. Nothing was buried with the corpse, but people recognize that in the past household and other items were buried, too. They know this because they run into old graves during their construction work. Tschopik notes the practice in Chucuito of the widow putting a stone inside her blouse near her heart. The stone was taken from a ditch of running water and the rational was that she should forget her sorrow for her dead husband just as “the stone feels nothing when the water runs over it.” Tschopik further notes that the women mourners reverse their clothing after leaving the grave area, and any children present must step across the grave to avoid coming down with a serious sickness ( orijjo ) caused by the souls of the dead. The party leaves the grave area in a mixed group, and returns to the house of the deceased. Tschopik notes that a separate path is taken than that taken for the original procession. As the people leave they ask “pardon” of each other to insure a proper atmosphere of respect for the dead ard the occasion.

Among the Aymara, soul concepts are confusing. The soul and ghost are clearly defined and while the ghost is generally feared, the soul is not. On occasion the soul of a living person may leave the body and be lost or captured. After death, the soul survives in the afterworld, sometimes returning to its former habitat to protect its living relatives, or, if they merit it, to punish them. As noted above, ghosts are greatly feared. They may appear to the living as corpses or dogs. "Desiccated human flesh from old graves is sometimes eaten when prescribed by a doctor as a prophylactic against ghosts and sickness caused by ghosts" (1: Tschopik, p. 553).

Early infancy, known as “the dangerous years” is also plagued by illnesses such as whooping cough, diarrhoea, scarlet fever, bloody dysentery, grippe, tuberculosis, and susto or fright. These are ascribed both to natural causes, such as faulty care, and to supernatural ones. For example, fright is occasioned by seeing an apparition at night with the subsequent loss of soul. The treatment of these illnesses depends on the etiology of the disease: natural illness is treated by a variety of herbal teas whereas supernaturally-caused illness is magically treated (see Chapter 7).

Not everybody is considered capable of becoming a magician. Aymara magicians frequently claim that they had been struck by lightning and thus knew that they had been singled out by the spirits to become magicians. Quintin, a Capilaya magician, attributed his decision to become a magician to a prolonged illness. He became a maestro when he was well in his forties. He had been living in La Paz for ten years and had become ill. After entering a hospital his health improved somewhat. Soon afterwards his compadre , a maestro who could “read the coca” revealed to him that his illness was caused by supernatural forces, a sign that he should become a maestro , too. Quintin then returned to Compi and asked a yatiri from Jank'o Amaya to help him request the Achachila of Kakape, a Compi mountain, to give him permission to practice magic. During part of the trip up the hill Quintin rode on a donkey, still feeling too weak from his illness to walk; halfway up he suddenly felt better and was able to proceed on foot. He claims that from that moment on there has been no illness in his family. On top of Kakape the initiation took place with a sacrifice to the mountain's achachila . Later the wife of another yatiri suggested that Quintin affirm his position as maestro by making a pilgrimage to Oje, a community whose patron saint, an image of Saint Peter, is considered to be endowed with miraculous powers. Favorable circumstances, however, elevated Quintin to the position of section magician that very same year and thus the trip to Oje became unnecessary. In previous years there had been no magicians in Capilaya. Feliciano, a Compeno who was at the same time sot'a , or chief aide to the mayordome of the hacienda, an administrator hated in the community because of the unpopular measures he had introduced in Compi to gain the favor of the patrón, acted as magician of both Compi proper and Capilaya. The year Quintin became a magician the harvest in Capilaya had been bad because hail had fallen in that section alone, sparing the rest of the hacienda. This was attributed to Feliciano's disinterest in a section to which he did not belong. Thus the Capilaya colonos asked Quintin to direct the important hail ceremonies. According to the magician, the crops produced abundantly again during subsequent years forcing even the patrón to recognize him as section magician in spite of the intrigues of Feliciano.

Apart from the process of becoming a magician, Quintin's case also illustrates how modern medicine (represented by the La Paz hospital), Catholicism (the desirability of the magicians' endorsement by the image of Saint Peter in Oje), and magic are not considered to be incompatible but instead have complementary or reinforcing functions in an individual's life. Saint Peter may be called upon like any powerful mountain spirit to bestow magical powers on an individual. The fact that Quintin's health improved in the hospital did not lead him to doubt his compadre's verdict that supernatural forces had brought about his illness. Quintin's story also exemplifies both section rivalries and the relationship with overseers appointed by the patrón. Capilaya considered itself to be at a disadvantage vis-à-vis other sections because it did not have its own magician. The resentment against the Compi magician's unfavorable activities as a sot'a enhanced these rivalries.

Both natural and supernatural causes are ascribed to disease. Natural causes include faultu care, while supernatural ones may include the loss of soul or possession by an evil force. Flora told us the following tale: “When my child felt ill, they thought it was a place that caused her illness. So they went to a place where there is a stone in the shape of a horse which the child had mounted previous to the illness. We knelt and gave mesas , but the child died anyway. Maybe it was eaten.”

Illnesses may be caused by susto , or fright. Anytime during the day or night one may be frightened by an animal or an apparition of an animal such as a dog or a donkey. A person might fall ill with a headache or of an illness of the hands, feet, ears, or eyes. The yatiri , or curer, should be called in such a situation in order to recall the animo , 4 According to other yatiri the ayayu , a second soul, is the soul which is lost. The third soul is a person's coraje , (or “courage”). one of the three souls a person possesses. This is accomplished in the following manner. A piece of the patient's clothing is laid on the ground, a short distance from the patient's house by the maestro . He is accompanied by at least one friend or a relative of the patient. Near the patient's clothing is put the contents of llama entrails, gall stones diluted in holy water in a little cup, with St. Nicholas bread (a sort of wafer with the image of St. Nicholas) and chinchi chinchi (unidentified fruit). Then they both retreat to the house. After this, the curer calls to and libates the animo with alcohol. In the meantime, the patient is supposed to sleep in order for the soul to reenter its abode. (Sleep may be considered an intermediary between life and death.) While waiting for the soul's return during the patient's sleep, other animos may appear. These are the animos of persons who will fall ill in the near future, and can be clearly identified. When the patient's animo arrives it has to be enveloped immediately in the clothing. They (the curer and his assistant) then place the clothing beside the patient, making him drink some of the holy water and wash his face. Then they put the clothing on the patient. During the process of calling the soul, wool spun in reverse is also used. One tears small pieces and throws them to the wind, calling the soul as one throws. The next day this wool is burned and the patient must drink the ashes mixed with water. Yarn spun in reverse is also placed in the patient's hands and on the ground around him so that the soul may not escape. If the patient does not recover, this may be due to complications with other spirits, such as a lake, or other achachila , or rayo (lightning or site where lightning has struck). A mesa (burnt offering) has to be given on the site where the person experienced a susto , or at the site where lightning has struck. However, susto may also be cured by natural herbal remedies such as a brew of thapi (unidentified), chinchi chinchi or chhojjlla (grass).
As we have seen, illness is caused by both natural and supernatural phenomena. So it is treated accordingly.

Blood from various animals is widely used in the Aymara pharmacopoeia. The blood of the picitanka , a small sparrow-like bird, is drunk to keep sickness at a distance; this bird is believed to be able to see far into the distance, and to be able to prophesy future events. Lizard blood is drunk to obtain good eyesight. The blood of a chicken, especially that of a black one, is regarded as helpful in curing pneumonia. Fresh pig blood is used to anoint the face of a person spotted with jaundice; pig blood also is rubbed on the skin affected with kakali (severe chapping, in which the “hands and feet split open from the cold”). The fresh blood of a yungas bat is taken to cure epilepsy, and when this is not obtainable, they grind up the dried bat ( ciñi ) itself. The blood of the condor, kunturi , and that of a monkey, matiku or kusilu , is drunk to rejuvenate oneself; the Aymara regard the condor as a vigorous and strong bird, full of endurance. The blood of the amae , or altiplano fox, is believed to be good for tertian fever ( cuhcu ).
A species of Cecinus (Lacosomidae), a lepidopterous insect, is used to prevent children from falling sick; the coccoon is sewed to their clothing for this purpose (Métraux, p.90).
The skin from the inside of an egg is placed over a cut to protect and heal it.

The llama fetus is usually meant by the Aymara term sulu , though it is also applied to the fetus of the pig or the sheep. The Aymara keep and sell many of these for medical and magical purposes. The sulu of a pig is good to drive demons away; it is used with “dulces” and colored wools in a ceremony intended to drive the demon from a person who is sick or crazy. In Sicasica, Loayza, parts of Pacajes and Omasuyos (and perhaps elsewhere), the Aymara use the sulu of the llama to put beneath the house foundations, for they say oraerux waxtanau , “it is necessary to make sacrifice to the Earth.”
Owl feathers are put in their hats by the Aymara to protect themselves from rifle bullets.
Rabbit- and fish-oil (from the suci fish) is rubbed on the skin to aid the removal of a splinter or a thorn.

The urine of the cow, or that of a black she-burro, is taken to cure jaundice. The urine of the skunk is thought to blind human beings. Human urine has many medicinal uses among the Aymara. Newborn babies are given spoonfuls of human urine (especially that of young children) until the milk appears in the mother. Fermented human urine, tamata , is also widely used. Every house has its yuru ( tamatutu or tamat wakula ) or pottery jar for saving urine; compare Bertonio (Vol. 2, p. 81) “Chillami: Orinal como bacinilla o mate.” When a person gets the mange, they say that he is oraen katxata , “caught or fished by the earth”; washing with tamata or “orina podrida” is one of the best cures for this disease. For this term, compare Bertonio (Vol. 2, p. 238) “Ttamatayacca: Orines podridos.” Aymara women wash their hair in fer mented urine, as it is said to kill fleas, lapanaka , in the hair, as well as to “cut” the grease because of the ammonia in it; very dirty and greasy clothes are also sometimes washed in tamata . When a person has a fever, he is washed all over with fermented human urine; Garcilaso (bk. ii, ch. XXIV) says that when a suckling was feverish, it was washed in urine in the morning, and if they could obtain some of the child's own urine, it was given to it to drink. As has already been mentioned, urine is also mixed with other substances, notably with the viscous pounded mass of the berries of some of the American mistletoes ( Phoradendron spp., Loranthaceae) as an ointment. When a glandular or goitrous swelling is adjudged to have come from contact with the spittle of a frog, the place is washed with tamata and salt. When a baby is sick, the milucana ceremony may be performed by the yatiri (one type of Aymara medicine-man). A piece of milu or alum is put on the child's chest and left there three or four hours until night. The yatiri then rubs the milu all over the little patient's body, after which he puts the stone into a large bowl of tamata . This is then covered with a lihla or other woollen cloth and left for twenty minutes to half an hour. When the bowl is uncovered, the milu is seen to have swelled up like a sponge (from the chemical action), usually into figures which the yatiri is able to study for his diagnosis. Then he says: “This child was frightened at such-and-such a spring,” or “He will get well,” or “He will die.” When the augury is bad, he takes a knife, and cuts the spongy mass with appropriate exorcisms, makes a hole in the ground and buries it. This diagnostic technique is of course especially valuable for the ailments of children, who cannot be expected to verbalize about such abstruse matters with any fluency; the same technique, however, is also used in the case of adult ailments, when the cause of the disease baffles even the yatiri . Finally, urine has a therapeutic value in the apsuyasiña type of counter-witchcraft. In this the house of the sick man is carefully searched and sounded for hollow places with a weavingbatten, and when the place where the sickness is hiding is found, the camakani or camakiri (other kinds of Aymara medical practitioners) throws some of the sick man's urine on it together with salt, and sometimes with other substances. The sickness then enters the urine and salt, which is then gathered up and thrown into a river, or burnt at a cross-roads, where the next unfortunate passerby will become the “host” of the disease. Best of all is for the camakani to obtain by stealth some of the urine of the rival witch who is causing the disease. The sick man is bathed in this urine, which is then thrown surreptitiously outside the witch's door. In this way the witchcraft-induced disease “comes home to roost,” where it belongs.
Aymara medicines of mineral origin are quickly considered. They are as follows:

Alabaster, carved into amulets, has an occasional prophylactic function in native medical theory. The best alabaster comes from Arque and Berenguela.
