Compare Métraux (p.90): “The commonest good-luck pieces are fragments of alabaster cut into the shape of animals. The Indians keep these at their houses for good luck and so that their flocks may multiply. On the day of San Juan each one carries his good-luck piece to the church where they are blessed after Mass.”

Alum, milu is a white, frangible, crystalline mineral, apparently fairly pure. It is used as a mordant in dyeing, for divination, and in witchcraft, as well as in native medicine. Bertonio (Vol. 2, p. 222) lists “Millu: Vn genero de salitre bueno para teñir colorado, o azul o de otras colores, segu la que precede” --obviously as a mordant. He also lists (Vol. 2, p. 227) “Mullo piedra. o hueso colorado como coral con que hazen gargantillas; Y tambien vsam dellos hechizeros.” Nordenskiöld (p. 168) writes that “An Aymara of La Pax told me that the body is invigorated if one rubs the face with alum.” Métraux (p. 90) describes another therapeutic use: “To make a swelling go down. apply on the sore place a piece of alum wrapped in cotton. Burn this afterwards and throw it far away from the house.”

Amulets are widely used by the Aymara in medicine and magic. The Collawayus of Charazani make amulets of a somewhat friable calcareous stone for which they charge exorbitant prices and which are extensively used in the Andean region, for example, as love charms. The tail of a wolf is used in the cearar or “left-handed” ceremony with a reverse-twisted llama-wool thread, as an amulet to avoid bad luck. In the north of the Department of La Paz, on the day of his saint, a young Aymara puts on a bead necklace with a olemunaci (a little hand holding a Spanish real ), and if a male a warmimunaci (that he may obtain a wife), or if a female a cacamunaci (that she may obtain a husband); ole means “money,” warmi “woman,” caa “man,” and munaci is derived from munaña , “to love,” that is, such an amulet causes the wearer to be beloved of money, a woman, or a man, as the case may be. The olemunaci is often a “piedra iman” or magnet to attract (metal) money; hence it is also called auxactir ala (from Sp. aguja , “needle,” “lift” and ala , “stone,” or “needle-lifting stone”). The Collawayus say that there are two kinds of magnet, male and female. The “female” magnet has a smooth surface, the “male” is spiny and rough. The medicine-men both sell and use them themselves. In the south of the altiplano around Sicasica a compound amulet or “bolsita” is placed around the neck of a child on a string. This may contain such articles as a small knife, rosary-beads, a small cross, a little salt, a small yellow chili, milu or alum, hawatikilu (a fruit pit), kiñulu (a root) a piece of añil or blue stone, etc.--to protect the child from sickness, falls, hurts, wounds, and “bad luck” in general. While the child who wears one of these is sleeping, no ariari or ancancu (vampires or disease-producing demons) dare approach.

Mica in various colors is used by the Aymara to protect themselves from being struck by lightning. Specimens I collected from natives include mica colored orange ( qori limpi , “gold glass”), white ( qole limi , “silver glass”), and black ( ciar limpi , “black glass”). I do not know that these are used other than interchangeably.
Soot is drunk in some parts of the altiplano with water and herbs as a remedy for colds and for minor aches and pains, as well as used externally for small hurts and sores.

The arisiri seems, like the ancancu of which we will speak further on, to be a late personification of a special category of demons or evil spirits. The Indians of the Peruvian Sierra “also believe in another kind of mysterious beings which are incarnated in individuals with certain special characteristics: /72 cont./ old men, wicked or deformed men, and suspicious strangers, who bring on slow illnesses and who kill by stages but surely, through consumption. The Kicua call them Naccac and the Aymara, Khari Khari . They say that when you have abandoned yourself to sleep, these spirits come and draw certain juices and fat out of your body” 1 On the belief in the arisiri in Peru, cf. Mostajo, pp. 419-420. (Ordoflez, p. 42).

The kabilto are male spirits while the torrentes are female. They are shadows, phantoms who place themselves on the apaceta (pile of sacred stones) on Tuesdays or Fridays. The morsel of coca which travelers customarily throw on the apaceta is an offering destined for them. Woe to the absentminded passer-by who neglects this rite: these spirits will pursue him, will frighten him, and his soul will vanish from terror. Loss of the soul brings on immediate sickness and, if its absence is prolonged, death.

To cure a man whose soul has been stolen by a lari-lari or to ward off the attacks of these demons, recourse is made to a magical substance 1 It is a vegetable substance unidentifiable from the samples which the Indians sold me. called lari-lari-ak , or “ lari-lari's excrement.”

This substance, several samples of which I was able to procure, is found in rivers, at places along their course which enjoy a bad reputation. The larilariak is pulverized, mixed with wine or water, and drunk in this form.

The details that Paredes (pp. 148-149) provides us on the subject of the larilari have only a very distant relationship to those which I have just given. “In some cases,” he says, “the Indians attribute a child's illness to a certain evil spirit called Larilari , who appears to have succeeded in getting hold of its body. To put him to flight and cure the victim, some khoa or anis is burned in the sick one's room. The bitter smoke is considered to produce the retreat of the demon. The larilari , they believe, can appear in the guise of a cat with red fur who climbs trees and hisses from there to attract imprudent people. As soon as he sees them approaching, he rapidly descends and, in fleeing, brushes against them, thereby giving them a disease whose symptoms are bloodshot eyes, eruptions on the body, and general depression.”

“This monster is accused of killing children. His deed is recognized by the red spots which cover the small corpse which are the marks left by the larilari .” In Bertonio's dictionary (Vol. II, p. 191), the word larilari is translated by “People of the puna who do not submit to the jurisdiction of the cacique, runaways.” This definition could be applied to the spirits as they were described to me by my own informants.

To defend oneself against their sorcery, one must sacrifice to them two cocks which are drowned in a river, at a place looked on as baneful or haunted by phantoms, and, prior to this, one must rub oneself with kernels of maize belonging to three different varieties (for example, to black and white varieties). These kernels are ground and, like the cocks, thrown into the water 1 This practice has the end of dispelling the ill that one has in oneself. It was observed in the Inca empire especially during the great annual festival of the zitua or expulsion of diseases. “Finishing which they returned to their homes in order then to prepare a pap / macamora / of roughly ground maize that they called sanco and elba : which they put on their faces, placing it also in the openings of the doors and in the parts where they kept food and clothes, and they took the said sanco to the springs and threw it in them, saying that they might not get sick and that sickness should not enter that house, etc.” (Molina, p. 41). /Cited in Spanish./ . The current carries away the /74 cont./ disease. /75/ In order for these rites to be efficacious, the presence of a magician is required.

The ancancu have been fused during the present period into a single mythological character which represents the entire species, as was the case of the arisiri , who originally were determinate spirits. “The anchanchu ,” if Paredes is to be trusted (pp. 59-61), “is a corpulent dwarf with a large head who stays by preference at the bottom of rivers or in the middle of ruins. It is claimed that he attracts his victims by flattering words and by a very courteous welcome. When the unfortunates who have trusted him have gone to sleep, he kills them or inflicts a serious illness on them. He is a demon all the more sinister in that he sows ruin and desolation with a smile on his lips.
“When he crosses a path he produces tornados and whirlwinds. The Indians, bothered by these atmospheric phenomena, cry; ‘Pass, pass, Anchanchu , do not harm me, because the ma'ku is protecting me.’”

Any house in which the occupants die with some frequency is considered to be haunted by this demon, who profits from the sleep of people to suck their blood and infect them with some disease. He is also considered responsible for landslides and floods. Out of fear of the ancancu , the Indians avoid spending the night near rivers or unoccupied houses. They are even afraid to utter the name of this malevolent spirit, whom they designate through circumlocutions.

/76/ A number of illnesses are caused by the flight of the soul. He who has felt sudden fear falls ill, because his frightened soul has left for distant parts and does not dare regain its dwelling. A yatiri (learned man) or a amiri healer, diviner) must then be summoned immediately to prescribe a remedy for the patient, the composition of which is the following: a kind of consecrated wafer made from flour ( San Nicolãs tanta : “bread of Saint Nicholas”) is crushed and then mixed with mineral powers of 12 different colors. To this a mineral substance (a complex silicate) called bizarra and fossilized shells ( ãguila ) are added. The whole thing is served to the patient in the form of a drink, and at the moment when he drinks, the magician cries: Hanpui, hanpui, animu (Come, come, soul). The soul returns and the sick person recovers immediately. 1 The flight of the soul, frightened for one reason or another, is the most frequent cause given for illness by the Andean Indians. It is naturally assumed that this accident has occurred whenever an individual suffers from fainting fits or dizziness. One may consult on this subject: Quiroga, Ambrosetti, pp. 157-159; Boman, Vol. II, pp. 490-491; Muñiz, pp. 18-19, etc.

The word auqui recurs frequently in the accounts published by the University of Cuzco on the folklore of this region. So herds are under an auqui's protection and a sick person's soul is deemed to have been stolen by an auqui (Muñiz, pp. 18-19). The word apu, the meaning of which is similar to that of auqui and mal'ku , is also used to designate one or several demons.

If it has not been possible to procure a llama or sheep fetus, they substitute an armadillo shell over which they offer libations and decorate it with tufts of wool. If the newborn is a boy a festival is organized in the course of which the ceremony of the cala, i.e., offerings and libations in honor of the Pacamama , is carried out. The wish that all these rites may be efficacious is uttered with fervor: “ suma hora kacu ” “That this may be in a propitious hour”. 1 Paredes (pp. 142-143) notes apropos of birth other, very interesting practices on which my informants remained silent. A knife and a pair of scissors are hidden under the mattress of the woman in childbirth in order to keep evil spirits aside. The placenta is buried with objects symbolizing the profession which it is desired that the child will later adopt. A relationship exists between the woman and the placenta, which makes the womb become inflamed if it is exposed to the sun.

1) Pulverized bezoar stones are administered to frightened persons whose soul has fled. 2) A pulverized resin (copal) mixed with wine or dregs is taken against the air (a chill). 3) To prevent children from falling ill, the cocoon of a lepidopteron ( Cecinus sp. Lacosomidae ) is sewn to their clothing. 4) The seeds of a leguminous plant ( wilka , wilkacipa : Piptadenia ) or the fruit of the Prosopis strobolifera ( kutiwainito ) are taken against curses and the air (torticolis, for example). 5) Every Tuesday and Friday it is advisable to put in one's pocket with one's money a fragment of loadstone wrapped in red paper. A few drops of alcohol are previously poured over it. If the loadstone becomes covered with fine bristles, it is a sign that good luck will accompany you in your gains, /90 cont./ in your work, in your trade. The loadstone furnishes indications about the immediate future. 6) After an illness the house must be fumigated with rosemary leaves. 7) Very small mollusks ( cinicuru ) constitute an efficacious remedy for frightened people whose souls have fled. 8) To make a swelling pass an alum stone wrapped in cotton is applied to the affected part. It is then burned and thrown far from the house.

Doubtless there exist other sources of anxiety not mentioned by the Aymara; in all likelihood there are some of which they themselves are unaware. In addition, owing to projection, displacement, and other mechanisms of this order, it is equally certain that an Indian's manifest complaints did not in all instances reflect the precise anxiety he was actually experiencing. Other sources of error are likewise apparent, for the categories employed in the tabulations in no way reflect clear-cut entities. Thus disease, from the Aymara point of view, may be due to natural causes, to sorcery, or may be sent by demons or offended spirits, and the informant, in expressing his anxiety about illness, may not specify his conception of its source with clarity. Again, rain or its absence (an environmental consideration) may be the source of anxiety, but rainfall in turn is often believed to be affected by spirits or souls of the dead (supernaturals). Similarly, in certain cases of sorcery it is difficult to know whether the victim was more concerned about his health or the effect that impaired health would have upon his subsistence activities. The following analysis of threats in terms of sources and effects, therefore, must be regarded as suggestive and indicative rather than definitive and conclusive. It is, however, a step beyond mere impressions and “snap” judgments.

When a child does not sleep well, this means that he is being bothered by demons. So the mother makes a small bag and puts in it a small knife, salt, aif peppers, and q'opa [see p. 247]. Then this is put inside the belt in which the baby is wrapped until he is about a year and a half old. This protects the baby from demons. They bother children more than adults.

Of the various diseases inflicted upon man by the demons, the most common is kata , or fright, which may be sent by any evil supernatural, but most frequently by the wak'a qala (31, 39, 43, 66). 1 An alternative name for this disease may be kat'u usu . The symptoms of kata are so clearly and generally recognized that they can be said (in Chucuito) to constitute a syndrome. All agreed that it attacked the extremities, produced granules, particularly on the hands, and finally resulted in partial paralysis of the limbs (31, 39, 43, 66). Informants 39 and 43 claimed that, in addition, the victim went out of his mind. 2 The Mestizo inhabitants of coastal Moche also appear to suffer from “fright” or “ susto ,” but here both the symptoms and the etiology of the disease are totally different. Gillin, 1947, 130-133. Elsewhere Gillin has discussed “magical fright” as manifested in several regions of Latin America. Gillin, 1948, 387-400.
Springs, puxu , in addition to sending kata , may kidnap the victim's soul, and Informant 45 related the following case in point:

One time Antonio Ascensio of Chucuito sent for me. His son fell into a spring when he was playing and took sick. A demon lived in that spring and this demon had taken the boy's soul so that he was sick. I knew this because I looked at the coca. Then I made an offering near the spring at night. In return for the offering the demon returned the boy's soul and now he is all right. It is like paying the evil one for the child's soul.
On occasion the demon actually possesses the victim's body, and in such an event it must be driven out by a special smoking treatment before the soul can be induced to return (45, 66).

Regardless of the identity of such supernaturals, however, all of the above informants agreed on the nature and symptoms of cupa usu , the disease contracted by those who disturb ruins or the objects found within them. This sickness is thought to be caused by one or more splinters of human bone that have intruded into the patient's body (usually the extremities) and that can be cured by the removal of the foreign object. 1 Paredes, 1936, 202-204; La Barre, 1948, 225.
In regard to this disease, Informant 64 cited the following cases:

Once a man named Mariano Roscado went into a chullpa to look for silver. 2 The ancient chullpa burials often contained ornaments and offerings of silver, and not infrequently of gold. He is dead now. He got the bones of the heathens in his hand and in his foot. The piece of bone came out of his finger all by itself from the swollen place, but the piece in his foot killed him. No one could cure him.
Again:

There is a man in Chinchera named Andrés kispe . One time he picked up some old bones near a chullpa and his knee became injured. One of those bones entered it. Then his knee swelled up and he couldn't walk.

In addition, Informant 43 believed that hunchbacks suffered from what might be termed a chronic from of chullpa sickness. Informant 11 added that if a pregnant woman were to approach a chullpa or to handle bones of the dead, she would bear a deformed baby.

Sorcerers are reputed to make offerings to the demons (or ghosts) inhabiting chullpas or other ruins in order to bewitch their victims (87). Although no occurrences were recorded in Chucuito, such practices appear to be not uncommon among the Bolivian Aymara, and there seems to be no reason to doubt their existence in Peru. Forbes wrote of certain ancient ruins in Bolivia:

In one or two of the houses little rude effigies of men, made of clay, hung up by a string round the neck, or pierced through the body with a thorn were met with--evidently remnants of witchcraft. 3 Forbes, 1870, 260. Similarly, Bandelier describes having found in an ancient rock-shelter a skull in which pieces of a calico dress had been stuffed for purposes of sorcery. Bandelier, MS.
More recently, La Barre has written:
Any of the bodily exuviae, if introduced into a chullpa, will cause the original owner to get the dread disease of cupa usu .... 4 La Barre, 1948, 220.

Like children, adults, although apparently to a lesser extent, are susceptible to soul loss induced by sudden fright or shock. The resulting infirmity is called anim saraqata , soul lost or fallen.” 1 This disease, although designated by a different term, would appear to be closely related to kat'a , described above (see p. 202).
When this happens, the man is like he is crazy; he is out of his head, and can't help himself (66).
Informant 64 relates:

There was a man named Merijildo aski . One time he fell into a deep spring when he was a little drunk. Then he lost his soul and now he is crazy. They did everything for him, but nothing did any good.

It is unquestionably true that the Aymara deeply fear the dead and the circumstances surrounding death. Paredes' belief that these attitudes result from missionary teaching is almost certainly incorrect. 3 Paredes, 1936, 228-229. Far from being so uncomplicated, the explanation of this fear of the dead is complex, and several component beliefs must be considered independently. First, the corpse itself, as well as associated objects, is thought to be a potential source of a certain disease, orixa , to which children are particularly susceptible. Second, all ghosts of adults, irrespective of the dispositions of their former earthly counterparts, are naturally malevolent, and may send disease or, according to folk tales, cause death in other ways. 4 Informants were undecided as to whether or not children produced ghosts; at any rate, the ghosts of children (if they exist) are not feared (11, 43). Finally, the souls of the dead, either out of sheer jealousy of the living, or because of loneliness, frequently attempt to drag relatives and friends along with them to the hereafter. 1 As is shown below, it is close relatives who are most apt to be harmed by the dead. Similarly, it should be noted, in cases of sorcery the first suspicion of guilt falls upon close relatives. Indeed, as lias been demonstrated, the Aymara today is forced to compete for his very livelihood with his close relatives. It seems possible, therefore, to regard this fear of corpses, ghosts, and souls in part as a projection of repressed hostility towards parents and near relatives into the realm of the dead. This is especially true of the souls of children, and many omens are interpreted to mean that the deceased child desires the death of a sibling. 2 Perhaps this belief is to be understood as a projection of sibling rivalry, a phenomenon of which the Aymara themselves are well aware. There is, on the contrary, no evidence whatever from Chucuito to indicate that the dead ever seek to benefit the living (except to warn them of impending disaster) or that souls are regarded as guardians or protectors. 3 Paredes writes that the souls of the dead are believed to watch over and protect their relatives and the community as a whole; while they never abandon their kinsmen, these souls may punish the living if they deserve it. Paredes, 1946, 211-212. Indeed, the return of the souls during All Saints fiesta in November is believed to prevent rain when it is most meeded and the exposed bones of the dead are thought to cause drought (2). It is also desirable to slaughter livestock for meat before All Souls day, since the returning souls are said to steal the fat of these animals (43).

It is also necessary to protect the living against sickness and other possible misfortunes. From the moment that a death occurs every effort is made to prevent the young children of the household from touching or even viewing the corpse, or anything that has been in contact with it, lest they take sick with orixa . 1 See Kuczynski-Godard, 1945b, 26. Bandelier also mentions a disease, larpata , contracted by a child who has seen a corpse. Bandelier, 1910, 125, 342. While the corpse is prepared for burial and during the wake that follows, the children are kept out of sight, often shut up in the kitchen. So liable are children to injury by the dead, that a pregnant woman who has seen a corpse, handled human bones, or been near a cemetery or ruin, will almost certainly bear a child who is either sick with orixa or who is deformed (11, 64).

The nature and etiology of orixa , however, is not clear. Children under five years of age appear to be especially susceptible, and the specific cause of the disease, like kat'a , is said to be fright.
Young children get sick because corpses frighten them. [Question.] No, they do not lose their souls. After a child is older than five, he isn't afraid of corpses, so he doesn't get sick (64).

The preoccupation of the Aymara with disease is very striking. Nearly all laymen have considerable specialized medical knowledge and are constantly doctoring themselves for real or imagined ills. 1 La Barre, 1948, 211. In addition, the variety of professional doctors is so considerable that La Barre was led to observe:
... no other primitive group known to modern ethnology has such a rich specialization among practitioners of native medicine. 2 Ibid ., 217.

But while this elaboration of specialization has been generally recognized (indeed, it is inescapable), it would appear that etiology of disease according to Aymara theory has been highly over-simplified. Paredes states flatly that “witches” directly, or demons acting at the behest of “witches,” are responsible for all diseases. 3 Paredes, 1936, 180-181. Taking a similar position, La Barre writes that disease is inevitably caused either by “witchcraft” or by evil spirits. 4 La Barre, 1948, 219-220. Either these views are over-simple, or the disease theory of the Bolivian Aymara is considerably less complex than is true of the Aymara of Peru. In Chucuito, as has been shown, some diseases are clearly due to sorcery, either directly or indirectly. Others, however, are sent by spirits of their own volition (because they have been angered or slighted), or by permanent and naturally malevolent demons. Still others are contracted from souls and ghosts. Some ailments stem from accidental soul loss, while in others soul kidnapping is the cause. Still others, chullpa sickness, for example, result from the intrusion of a foreign object, either through carelessness or through the evil machinations of humans or demons. In addition, some diseases are unquestionably attributed by the Aymara of Chucuito to natural causes. 5 At least, they are blamed neither upon malevolent supernaturals nor upon the evil intentions of other humana. Among these are various ailments that are (or are thought to be) attendant upon childbirth; fractures, sprains, and dislocations (including the “dislocation” of internal organs); and such common and frequent complaints as p'eqe usu , “headache,” t'uku usu , “common cold,” and c'aka usu , “rheumatism.”

a. Meaning: (1) In connection with shapes, GODAN means “curved” or “stooped.” (2) In connection with land formation, Godan means “low,” “hollow,” or “depressed.” b. Stars: There are three. The main one is SHARTAN (Ar.) in the Aries constellation. c. Weather: It is a prosperious GOD, for if the Daydo /season/ of the Gu begins with it, the ensuing rains will be heavy and beneficial. The saying goes: GODAN BUU KU BISHEE MEEL GODAN OO DHAN KA KURUG, “The (GU rain) began with the GODAN, so remain far from all patches of low land”; that is, make your camp on a hill, or else it will be flooded. Normally, the beginning of the GU falls in the season DAYDO DIRIR, which should be on the 15th of the lunar month occuring in April of the Gregorian Calendar. This lunar month begins either with the station GODAN, or with the following one, LISTAN. The latter means “mid-position.” d. Astrology: In the astrology of marriage, GODAN is unfavourable, for any girl who is born on the night of this station will not be marriageable. NAAG GODAN DHALATAY AMA GAAJO LA GODNAYD AMA CUDUR--which means that a woman who has been born on this station shall be stooped either with hunger or with chronic illness.

made of cow, elephant, or rhinoceros hide, is held in a man’s left hand. Slightly convex and covered with decoration of a simple sort, this shield has a diameter of 30 to 60 centimeters, is brown in color (the smaller, very 28 common kind (Plate 12) is colored dark red), and is very durable. The Somâli often uses it as a parasol, especially when he is roaming idly through the treeless savanna. Usually, however, he keeps his shield in a cotton cover, and when on the march, he likes to hang it on his back. On his hip we find a sword-like bowie knife 45 to 65 centimeters long, with an iron cutting edge ( gulhát, sejf, or bilaúa ) five centimeters wide usually, in a simple leather sheath. The handle is decorated with a tin covering and is made of wood or ivory. This knife is designed for defense in hand-to-hand fighting, but it is used for all the tasks in everyday life that require the use of a knife, especially woodworking, skinning animals, hut construction, and so forth. The Danâkil manufacture especially attractive knives, beautifully hooked at the tip and unusually well decorated with a brass mounting. Many of these knives are to be found in Êjssa country. A small dagger or stiletto (míndi) is also used. The cutting edges are equal to the best European ones. In addition to the spear, everyone as a rule carries a powerful, long, club-like stick (úsa) . This is being adopted more and more, especially in the towns of Berbera and Zeila which have very recently barred the entry of Somâl with weapons in their hands. Furthermore, cudgels a meter in length and richly carved (wêger) are found on the coast. Two spears are carried by the men in the vicinity of the Galla region. No Somâli is seen without a spear, even when he is performing household tasks. When he walks, he usually carries it on the left shoulder or leans on it. The Mídgan carries a bow (gánso) and arrows (nisâb) . The bow is one and a half meters long and unadorned by carving or other decoration. The quiver (gubâjo), however, is adorned with an indented leather lid or leather tassels. The poison for the arrow (gedulâjo) is prepared from the roots of various poison trees, particularly the Cararo . It is deep black and adheres below the arrowhead (filâr) . The poison acts rapidly, and the Somâl regard the falling out or shedding of hair as the first and most definite indication of the onset of complete poisoning. Members of the female sex carry no weapons. In battle, the spear is thrown only in the most extreme situations when one can then immediately hurl himself on the enemy with a knife. As a rule the Somâli carries out an attack by lying in ambush for the enemy and then knocking him down with the spear. The instrument of assassination otherwise is the bowie knife. The natives are not very skilled in the use of their weapons, especially the spears, which are thrown without verve. At the same time the men generally are experts at a series of spectacular juggling tricks with weapons.

In the towns one finds Arabs who fill the office of muéddsin [Ed., muezzin ?] and qudhât . Special priests (wodadín) roam through the countryside, usually traveling through a region with a number of other priests, performing the functions of their office and lining their pockets in the process. They have no influence whatever on the people. Superstition flourishes in the most luxuriant forms, but I would say that even this has no significance whatever, because the natives content themselves entirely with copied amulets and the like. Belief in sorceresses ( komâju, sorceress) is to be encountered here and there since, after all, every old woman is surrounded by the aura of being able to perform sorcery. The Somâli swears an oath (dâr) on the Koran, and the Ogadên on the head of his children and wives. Breach of promise with respect to the Whites or the enemy, however, is no crime. The prayer times are those of all Islamites (9:30, súbbeh; noon, dóhur; 3:30, ássur; 6:30, mágrib; and eight o’clock, asâ ); they are observed only by the most pious. Attempts to convert the Somâl to the Christian religion have never been seriously undertaken. In Zeila, to be sure, a magnificent house has been built for the French Mission, but not in the hope of being able to win the Somâl for Christendom. The building is supposed to serve merely as a way station for missionaries going off to Galla country. The universal complaint is that the Somâli curtly turns away the European apostle of the faith and that, in view of the people’s nomadic way of life, the latter is unable to step in to civilize the natives by getting them in the habit of working regularly. None of the religious ideas of the Galla has been incorporated by the Somâl. Except to celebrate Ramadan there are no festive periods. I heard nothing about divine judgments among the western Somâl tribes. The times of year are mostly distinguished according to the rainy seasons in the manner already indicated, but between these there are also shorter periods ( bil, month) by which time is occasionally reckoned. Their names are not generally known ( 73 . The names of the months given by Haggenmacher, op. cit., p. 28, are not all known to the Ejssa, so I must assume that they are perhaps valid for only a small group of coastal inhabitants. The Êjssa and Hábr Auál use the following designations for the months: dúggo (November), bil dúrroh hôra (December), bil dúrroh dámba (January), rajâl hôra (February), rajâl dáha (March), rajâl dámba (April), sáboh (May), wa báris (June), sunkât (July), sunfûr (August), sid atâl (September), aráfo (October). ).

All the other examples that I have seen are obviously worn primarily as amulets. They are often made of glass beads, shells (whole or fragments, especially from the Conus) ( 1 . See U. Ferrandi, Lugh, cit., p. 365, and G. Révoil, La vallée du Darror, cit., illustrated on p. 234 and described on p. 307. ), stones, or balls of amber ( 2 . See L. Robecchi-Bricchetti, Somalia e Benadir, cit., p, 357, and G. Révoil, La vallée du Darror cit., p. 344. ). These are unquestionably types of stones and shells which have the virtue of protecting their wearers from the evil eye and from diseases and misfortunes. I have had occasion to test their attachment to these talismans. On one occasion at Bur Calli (near Tiglieglo) I noticed a Rahanuin native wearing a small, round stone pendant around his neck. I was unable to buy it at any price since it was a stone which had the power to ward off nosebleed ( ghersa nun ). I had a similar experience, and, I believe, for the same reason rather than because of any vanity on the part of the owner, when I tried to buy a fine amber ball that was worn as a necklace by a Sciaveli Bed-bedan of Baidoa.

In the Gastaldi collection (Inv. No. 7478) there is a rather interesting amulet which, even though it is identified merely as a bracelet, may nevertheless be considered as closely related to the amulets described above. Mochi ( 3 . A. Mochi, Gli oggetti etnografici . . ., cit., p. 158, No. 86. ) has described it as consisting of a blue cotton cord on which are strung “two roughly-rounded, yellow amber balls measuring 21 millimeters in diameter. To the cord is attached a rectangular silver box measuring 9 by 27 by 34 millimeters and decorated on both sides with a carved rosette. The box contains two small pieces of paper, rolled and tied with a bit of red string, on which verses from the Koran are written.” The characters are Arabic and are not written in the usual Somali script (Plate 10, No. 8).

Moslem beads ( tusbah ) are also regarded as amulets, and they are usually worn around the neck for use during devotions. Purely secular objects often hang from them, such as tweezers for removing hair or extracting thorns and, very often, combs ( 4 . See V. Bottego, Il Giuba esplorato cit., p. 399, Fig. 98. ). We acquired a specimen which had been worn by Mohammed Nur, Hauia Illivi, No. 14 in my anthropometric study ( 5 . N. Puccioni, Antropologia e etnografia delle genti della Somalia [Anthropology and Ethnography of the Peoples of Somalia], Vol. 1, Antropometria [Anthropometrics] (Bologna, 1931), Plate 18. ). The necklace is 622 millimeters long and is made of brown wooden disks, terminating in a large, white glass bead from which hangs a cylindrical wooden pendant. The pendant is narrow at the bottom and attached to it are iron tweezers and a small wooden comb for the beard. The comb has five teeth, a pointed handle, and decorations consisting of oblique, parallel and quadrate lines.
I acquired simpler small rosary (Inv. No. 19062) at Mogadishu. It is made of about 100 small black wooden beads and has a more or less prismatic wooden pendant.

What has been said of the necklaces also holds true for the belts which the 51 women wear under the futa next to the skin. They serve as amulets rather than as ornaments and usually have some sort of silver pendant which, according to Zoli ( 1 . C. Zoli, Notizie sul territorio . . ., cit., p. 302. ), “preserves them from malign influences which might affect their fertility.” It is, however, a fact that all the prostitutes also wear these belts, and I feel sure that they are not overly interested in ensuring their fertility. The belt (Inv. No. 19064) worn next to the skin by Salada Dibin (Sciaveli Bed Bedan), No. 157 in my anthropometric notes ( 2 . See N. Puccioni, Antropologia e Etnografia . . ., cit., Vol. 1, Plate 40. ), is 826 millimeters long and is made of variously alternated white, red, and black beads, with which a few tiny silver beads are intermingled.

Rings are not often worn, although silver ones are sometimes seen on the fingers of the more elegant natives, both men and women. They are not of native workmanship and are sometimes set with stones, some of which naturally are regarded as amulets. I had occasion to observe this at Il Behla in the ex-Sultanate of Obbia, where, on one of the many occasions when I assumed the role of a doctor for the benefit of the natives, I treated a nosebleed by putting an effective tampon on one of the sultan’s askari . He had been bleeding for two days, and when the natives saw that the bleeding had stopped, they lauded to the skies the magic powers of a silver ring set with a blue stone which the patient was wearing suspended from his neck.

Apart from the Midgan, who may be said to constitute the class of professional physicians, some priests are highly regarded as doctors because of the fact that their supposed medical knowledge is reinforced by their knowledge of the sacred books and hence of all of the formulas suitable for exorcizing every kind of ailment. Robecchi-Bricchetti ( 3 . L. Robecchi-Bricchetti, Nel paese degli aromi, cit., p. 418. ) encountered a mullah at Bender Gedid, between Handa and Cape Guardafui, who was considered the most famous physician in the area and who was especially admired for his surgical skill. His entire equipment consisted of two cupping-glasses for bleeding, an iron spike for cauterizing wounds, and an ordinary knife that did not even have a very good edge, At Meraia, Révoil ( 4 . G. Révoil, Voyage au Cap des Aromates, cit., p. 132. ) watched a native surgeon extract a bullet from the leg of a war casualty. The patient was securely lashed to four sticks, and using an ordinary knife, the surgeon made an enormous incision in the depths of which he probed for the bullet and then poured boiling fat into the open wound. The wounded man died, however, within forty-eight hours after this treatment.

This is the remedy most often used, especially for ailments involving the chest, for which it seems to be an effective substitute for the blistering agents formerly used by European doctors. Cauterization is done with red-hot irons, and it leaves large, deep scars; when the burns are made on the thorax to treat chest ailments, they are usually applied along the ribarches, 96 and at first glance they may be mistaken for ornamental scars ( 1 . See N. Puccioni, Antropologia e Etnografia . . ., cit., Vol. 1, Plates 9, 12, and 14. ). A more careful examination, however, reveals at once that they are burn scars. In the vicinity of Uarandi we saw a native who had just undergone such treatment. His thorax and back were covered with open sores which made it necessary for him to sit upright in the middle of his hut, since the wounds prevented him from lying down; at first glance one would have taken him for a leper.

This remedy, too, which was formerly popular in European medical treatment, is used a good deal by the Somali, who believe that it is advisable to be bled at least once a month. According to the description provided by Bottego ( 2 . V. Bottego, Il Giuba esplorato, cit., p. 414. ), the “doctor” places a horn, pierced at both ends, against the patient’s skin at the spot from which he wants to draw the blood. Then he draws a sharp breath through the horn, thus raising the skin, and makes several cuts to start the bleeding. When the operation is completed, the patient is given broth made with a large amount of butter.

The amulets which the natives wear around their necks or arms are used not only for protection against spells and thus against evil spirits, but also for snakebite and as a preventive measure for certain diseases. The Midgan and the priests often make use of magic formulas which they intone while treating the patient or which, scrawled on a piece of paper and enclosed in a leather bag, they apply to the affected part or hang around the patient’s neck. A treatment regarded as particularly efficacious involves writing magic formulas in soot or ink on a plate or on the inside 97 of a bowl. The writing is then washed off with water or with a vegetal concoction, and the liquid is drunk by the patient ( 1 . C. Zoli, Notizie sul territorio ..., cit., p. 294. ).

The Somali know that malaria is transmitted by mosquitoes, and they take certain precautionary measures. They avoid setting up camp near stagnant water, cover their heads with their garments when they sleep, and discourage the insects by using smudges from burning resin or aromatic wood. According to Zoli ( 2 . C. Zoli, Notizie sul territorio..., cit., p. 306. ), the disease is treated with amulets and purgatives. However, Paoli ( 3 . Stefanini, G., and G. Paoli, Ricerche ..., cit., pp. 249 and 250. ) says that there is a remedy used for fevers in general: a concoction made of the seeds and leaves of the Cissus stefaniniana Chiov. or of the flowers and fruit of the Vitex negundo L.

Although no prophylactic measures are used against smallpox, the victims are isolated, and after an epidemic their effects and the huts are burned ( 4 . C. Zoli, Notizie sul territorio ..., cit., p. 306. ). Creignou notes ( 5 . G. Creignou, Ethnographie des Somalis: la variole et son traitement [Ethnography of the Somali: smallpox and its treatment], Bordeaux, 1912. ) that a special type of fumigation is used. Aromatic plants are burned under the patient’s bed, and then he is buried in sun-warmed sand, with only his head exposed.

Ailments of the pharynx and of the larynx are treated by applying a red-hot poker to the throat and also by partially severing the uvula which has first been tied off by means of a hair from a giraffe’s tail. The wound is treated with ground pepper, and the patient is kept on a liquid diet for three days. This operation is also used as a preventive measure for diseases of the upper respiratory tract ( 11 . C. Zoli, Notizie sul territorio ..., cit., p. 305. ).

The natives believe that the best way to deal with snakebites or scorpion stings 99 is to entrust themselves to those experts who are privileged by Allah to nourish a serpent in their own entrails. The saliva of these privileged beings, mixed with butter and then applied to the previously opened wounds, is thought to render the poison harmless ( 1 . C. Zoli, Notizie sul territorio ..., cit., p. 305. ), but the natives also recommend ueirag ( Andropogon caesius Vatke) ( 2 . E. Chiovenda, Flora somala, cit., p. 73. ).

Finally, the wounds so often sustained by the natives are said to be treated with the pulverized bark of mergag ( Boscia minimifolia Chiov.) ( 3 . E. Chiovenda, Flora somala cit., p. 81. ), or by administering large quantities of mutton or camel meat, applications of the warm blood of sheep, a mixture of animal dung and rancid butter ( 4 . C. Zoli, Notizie sul territorio ..., cit., p. 305. ), poultices made of myrrh, and a mixture of the pollen of the Acacia fistula boiled with mutton fat and twigs of gobbò, which we were told is the plant called aberà ( Euphorbia inaequispina N. E. Brown) ( 5 . E. Chiovenda, Flora somala, cit., pp. 301-302. ). The formation of scars is encouraged by using the green fruit of the Avicennia marina Forsk ( 6 . G. Stefanini and G. Paoli, Ricerche ..., p. 250. ).

If a serpent of this species that was dead or had been killed by others was found, the old Migiurtini buried it, wrapping it in a shroud, like a human being. Still in 1929 at‘Eli Qoran, on the boundary between Rahan-wen and Ugaden, some Habar Gidir killed a mas . The Migiurtini present intervened, and, after a long dispute, they buried it precisely with the ritual shroud, as if it were a human being. The mas, tradition says, does not bite the Mahmud Saleman Migiurtini; and, if it bites them, it does not poison them (although it is poisonous for the others). Reciprocally, 157 the Mahmud Saleman Migiurtini do not kill the mas; on the contrary, they defend it, and, as was seen, they take care of -- if it is killed by others -- the interment.

When in 1929 a serpent bit a Migiurtina woman and her daughter, the daughter of the Islan of the ‘Umar Mahmud, Dahabo Islan, intervened and pronounced this formula, addressed to the serpent: haddad abougay tahay dadkan wah gari mayo abou ad no ahayde hilibkay harân bu ka ahây nô ma dili girín annáguná ku ma dillan Mahmud Salemân haddád taháy dadkán wah gâri mâyo haddád tĝ taháy wah hún ba lo gu gú arkáya ‘If you are my grandfather, nothing (bad) will happen to them. You were grandfather for us. My flesh was illicit for you. You did not bite us and we did not strike you. If you are a Mahmud Saleman, nothing (bad) will happen to them. If you are a thief, ugly things will be seen in you.’

“Among us the head of the butchered animal is not eaten. Only if one is suffering from blennorrhagia, three times a head is boiled for him. Then he recovers. It is our medicine. Of the livestock, illicit are: the lungs, bladder, pancreas, duodenum ( 1 . The translation that I give here -- according to what at the time seemed clear to me from the explanation of my informant -- of ‘ argau as ‘pancreas’ and barmad as ‘duodenum’ is not certain. ). These parts of the livestock are illicit. The bladder is the one in which there is urine and from which the beasts urinate. The bile too is illicit. The bile is that ugly thing which is in the liver and is like water. The ‘ argau (pancreas) is under the sternum. The heart, on the contrary, is eaten. There is one who was born for the heart and eats it. There is one who was born for the liver and eats it. There is one who was born for the kidneys and eats them. The one who was born to govern eats the liver. One who is not able to spit against the scorpion eats the kidneys. One who is not able to spit against the sickness called sebbad eats the heart. It is our medicine. ‘Heart is for me!’ says the one who spits against the sebbad sickness and will not eat heart. Our Molkal people is thus. Our women do not eat the heart either. What thing is the scorpion? It is an animal that bites you while you walk on the ground. If that animal bites you, that man who does not eat the kidneys spits on you. And the discomfort (of the scorpion’s bite) leaves you. For another the liver is illicit. What thing is the sebbad? It is a sickness that on some comes out of the cheek, and on others out of the sides and is fatal. It is a sore that does not heal. It comes out and then pus comes out. When this pus flows, if it is spat upon, the wound heals. If one who knows how to spit on this sore is not found, it is rubbed with the menstrual blood of a woman. And that one recovers. Thus is our medicine.

All savage races have their medicine men, and the Somali is no exception. Among the members of most of the tribes will be recognized surgical experts whose methods, although somewhat rough and ready, are often most ingenious.

It is well-nigh impossible to witness a Somali surgeon operating, so one can only judge by the results, which, after all is said and done, are the workman’s best test, and these are very frequently highly creditable, if not excellent.

Deep wounds, where there has been a considerable loss of tissue, are washed with water, which is usually dirty, and then plugged with herbs, roots, and bark, chopped up as finely as possible, and well mixed together by the native “leech.”
Once, and sometimes twice a day, are wounds dressed in this manner, little or no attention being paid to the agony of the unfortunate patient.
They are fully alive to the beneficial effects of absolute rest to the highly-inflamed area, always putting the injured part into splints when feasible.
The formation and adaptation of the splints is often most ingenious. I have frequently seen splints on which our surgical instrument makers with all their skill would find it difficult to improve.

In cases where there is severe hmorrhage, due to bullet or spear wounds, the Somali doctor retires to the bush, while the friends of the wounded man kill a sheep; on his return he brings a small collection of roots, usually of one or other of the acacias, which he ties up into a small package, not more than two or three inches in length and about the thickness of a finger, with broad strips of the tough green underbark (maidah) of the same tree from which the tender roots have been taken. This finger-shaped package is first stuffed into the wound, and later suspended from the neck or arm of the patient. The fee for this fetish is one rupee, or more, according to the wealth of the individual.

In cases of depressed fractures of the skull, the Somali surgeon, whose instruments are of the crudest pattern, fashioned by a Tomal, has, in the place of trephining, to resort to the more ancient and rougher operation of chipping away the depressed portion of bone with a strong iron knife.
Having once removed the depressed fragment, he sometimes covers over the opening with a thin piece of bone neatly cut out of the skull of a freshly killed sheep or goat.

In comminuted fractures of the long bones of the limbs, after removing all the fractured bits of bone he pieces them together, and then gets hold of a fragment of a bone, preferably of the camel, and pares it down to the size and shape of the removed pieces, and inserts this in the existing gap. The wound is then plugged up with various herbs, roots, etc., which are chiefly chosen for their styptic properties, and chopped up very fine. Finally, the limb is placed in a splint in which a small window has been cut over the wound, so as to enable the surgeon to dress it without disturbing the fracture. The wound is usually freshly cleaned and plugged once or even twice a day, according to the amount of discharge.

The splints commonly consist of several pieces of stick cut the required length, and bound round with bits of cloth; but, occasionally, in the coast towns or among the larger communities in the interior where there are Midgans, the splints may be made of leather, which is stiffened with a few sticks and adjusted when wet so as to model it to the shape of the limb.

After half an hour’s visit I was led by the Hajj through the streets of Zayla ** Zayla, called Audal or Auzal by the Somal, is a town about the size of Suez, built for 3000 or 4000 inhabitants, and containing a dozen large whitewashed stone houses, and upwards of 200 Arish or thatched huts, each surrounded by a fence of wattle and matting. The situation is a low and level spit of sand, which high tides make almost an island. There is no harbour: a vessel of 250 tons cannot approach within a mile of the landing-place; the open roadstead is exposed to the terrible north wind, and when gales blow from the west and south, it is almost unapproachable. Every ebb leaves a sandy flat, extending half a mile seaward from the town; the reefy anchorage is difficult of entrance after sunset, and the coralline bottom renders wading painful. The shape of this once celebrated town is a tolerably regular parallelogram, of which the long sides run from east to west. The walls, without guns or embrasures, are built, like the houses, of coralline rubble and mud, in places dilapidated. There are five gates. The Bab el Sahil and the Bab el Jadd (a new postern) open upon the sea from the northern wall. At the Ashurbara, in the southern part of the enceinte, the Bedouins encamp, and above it the governor holds his Durbar. The Bab Abd el Kadir derives its name from a saint buried outside and eastward of the city, and the Bab el Saghir is pierced in the western wall. The public edifices are six mosques, including the Jami, or cathedral, for Friday prayer: these buildings have queer little crenelles on whitewashed walls, and a kind of elevated summer-house to represent the minaret. Near one of them are remains of a circular Turkish Munar, manifestly of modern construction. There is no Mahkamah or Kazi’s court: that dignitary transacts business at his own house, and the Festival prayers are recited near the Saint’s Tomb outside the eastern gate. The northeast angle of the town is occupied by a large graveyard with the usual deleterious consequences. The climate of Zayla is cooler than that of Aden, and, the site being open all around, it is not so unhealthy. Much spare room is enclosed by the town walls: evaporation and Nature’s scavengers act succedanea for sewerage. Zayla commands the adjacent harbour of Tajurrah, and is by position the northern port of Aussa (the ancient capital of Adel), of Harar, and of southern Abyssinia: the feuds of the rulers have, however, transferred the main trade to Berberah. It sends caravans northwards to the Dankali, and south-west-wards, through the Eesa and Gudabirsi tribes as far as Efat and Gurague. It is visited by Cafilas from Abyssinia, and the different races of Bedouins, extending from the hills to the seaboard. The exports are valuable—slaves, ivory, hides, honey, antelope horns, clarified butter, and gums: the coast abounds in sponge, coral, and small pearls, which Arab divers collect in the fair season. In the harbour I found about twenty native craft, large and small: of these, ten belonged to the governor. They trade with Berberah, Arabia, and Western India, and are navigated by “Rajput” or Hindu pilots. Provisions at Zayla are cheap; a family of six persons live well for about 30 l. per annum. The general food is mutton: a large sheep costs one dollar, a small one half the price; camels; meat, beef, and in winter kid, abound. Fish is rare, and fowls are not commonly eaten. Holcus, when dear, sells at forty pounds per dollar, at seventy pounds when cheap. It is usually levigated with slab and roller, and made into sour cakes. Some, however, prefer the Arab form “balilah,” boiled and mixed with ghee. Wheat and rice are imported: the price varies from forty to sixty pounds the Riyal or dollar. Of the former grain the people make a sweet cake called Sabaya, resembling the Fatirah of Egypt: a favourite dish also is “harisah”—flesh, rice flour, and boiled wheat, all finely pounded and mixed together. Milk is not procurable during the hot weather; after rain every house is full of it; the Bedouins bring it in skins and sell it for a nominal sum. Besides a large floating population, Zayla contains about 1500 souls. They are comparatively a fine race of people, and suffer from little but fever and an occasional ophthalmia. Their greatest hardship is the want of the pure element: the Hissi or well, is about four miles distant from the town, and all the pits within the walls supply brackish or bitter water, fit only for external use. This is probably the reason why vegetables are unknown, and why a horse, a mule, or even a dog, is not to be found in the place. to one of his substantial houses of coralline and mud plastered over with glaring whitewash. The ground floor is a kind of warehouse full of bales and boxes, scales and buyers. A flight of steep steps leads into a long room with shutters to exclude the light, floored with tamped earth, full of “evening flyers” * “Fid-mer,” or the evening flyer, is the Somali name for a bat. These little animals are not disturbed in houses, because they keep off flies and mosquitoes, the plagues of the Somali country. Flies abound in the very jungles wherever cows have been, and settle in swarms upon the traveller. Before the monsoon their bite is painful, especially that of the small green species; and there is a red variety called “Diksi as,” whose venom, according to the people, causes them to vomit. The latter abounds in Gulays and the hill ranges of the Berberah country: it is innocuous during the cold season. The mosquito bites bring on, according to the same authority, deadly fevers: the superstition probably arises from the fact that mosquitoes and fevers become formidable about the same time. , and destitute of furniture. Parallel to it are three smaller apartments; and above is a terraced roof, where they who fear not the dew and the land-breeze sleep. * Such a building at Zayla would cost at most 500 dollars. At Aden, 2000 rupees, or nearly double the sum, would be paid for a matted shed, which excludes neither sun, nor wind, nor rain. I found a room duly prepared; the ground was spread with mats, and cushions against the walls denoted the Divan: for me was placed a Kursi or cot, covered with fine Persian rugs and gaudy silk and satin pillows. The Hajj installed us with ceremony, and insisted, despite my remonstrances, upon occupying the floor whilst I sat on the raised seat. After ushering in supper, he considerately remarked that travelling is fatiguing, and left us to sleep.

Anwar (the Book of Lights) the tale of Abu Jahl, that Judas of El Islam made ridiculous. Sometimes comes the Sayyid Mohammed el Barr, a stout personage, formerly governor of Zayla, and still highly respected by the people on acount of his pure pedigree. With him is the Fakih Adan, a savan of ignoble origin. * The system of caste, which prevails in El Yemen, though not in the northern parts of Arabia, is general throughout the Somali country. The principal families of outcasts are the following. The Yebir correspond with the Dushan of Southern Arabia: the males are usually jesters to the chiefs, and both sexes take certain parts at festivals, marriages, and circumcisions. The number is said to be small, amounting to about 100 families in the northern Somali country. The Tomal or Handad, the blacksmiths, originally of Aydur race, have become vile by intermarriage with serviles. They must now wed maidens of their own class, and live apart from the community: their magical practices are feared by the people, —the connection of wits and witchcraft is obvious,—and all private quarrels are traced to them. It has been observed that the blacksmith has ever been looked upon with awe by barbarians on the same principle that made Vulcan a deity. In Abyssinia all artisans are Budah, sorcerers, especially the blacksmith, and he is a social outcast as among the Somal; even in El Hejaz, a land, unlike Yemen, opposed to distinctions amongst Moslems, the Khalawiyah, who work in metal, are considered vile. Throughout the rest of El Islam the blacksmith is respected as treading in the path of David, the father of the craft. The word “Tomal,” opposed to Somal, is indigenous. “Handad” is palpably a corruption of the Arabic “Haddad,” iron-worker. . The Midgan, “one-hand,” corresponds with the Khadim of Yemen: he is called Rami or “archer” by the Arabs. There are three distinct tribes of this people, who are numerous in the Somali country: the best genealogists cannot trace their origin, though some are silly enough to derive them, like the Akhdam, from Shimr. All, however, agree in expelling the Midgan from the gentle blood of Somali land, and his position has been compared to that of Freedman amongst the Romans. These people take service under the different chiefs, who sometimes entertain great numbers to aid in forays and frays; they do not, however, confine themselves to one craft. Many Midgans employ themselves in hunting and agriculture. Instead of spear and shield, they carry bows and a quiver full of diminutive arrows, barbed and poisoned with the Waba,—a weapon used from Faizoghli to the Cape of Good Hope. Like the Veddah of Ceylon, the Midgan is a poor shot, and scarcely strong enough to draw his stiff bow. He is accused of maliciousness; and the twanging of his string will put to flight a whole village. The poison is greatly feared: it causes, say the people, the hair and nails to drop off, and kills a man in half an hour. The only treatment known is instant excision of the part; and this is done the more frequently, because here, as in other parts of Africa, such stigmates are deemed ornamental. In appearance the Midgan is dark and somewhat stunted; he is known to the people by peculiarities of countenance and accent. When they appear the conversation becomes intensely intellectual: sometimes we dispute religion, sometimes politics, at others history and other humanities. Yet it is not easy to talk history with a people who con-

On our return home we met a party of Eesa girls, who derided my colour and doubted the fact of my being a Moslem. The Arabs declared me to be a Shaykh of Shaykhs, and translated to the prettiest of the party an impromptu proposal of marriage. She showed but little coyness, and stated her price to be an Audulli or necklace * Men wear for ornament round the neck a bright red leather thong, upon which are strung in front two square bits of true or imitation amber or honey stone: this “Mekkawi,” however, is seldom seen amongst the Bedouins. The Audulli or woman’s necklace is a more elaborate affair of amber, glass beads, generally coloured, and coral: every matron who can afford it, possesses at least one of these ornaments. Both sexes carry round the necks or hang above the right elbow, a talisman against danger and disease, either in a silver box or more generally sewn up in a small case of red morocco. The Bedouins are fond of attaching a tooth-stick to the neck thong. * Beads are useful in the Somali country as presents, and to pay for trifling purchases: like tobacco they serve for small change. The kind preferred by women and children is the “binnur,” large and small white porcelain: the others are the red, white, green, and spotted twisted beads, round and oblong. Before entering a district the traveller should ascertain what may be the especial variety. Some kind are greedily sought for in one place, and in another rejected with disdain. , a couple of Tobes, — she asked one too many — a few handfuls of beads, and a small present for her papa. She promised, naively enough, to call next day and inspect the goods: the publicity of the town did not deter her, but the shamefacedness of my two companions prevented our meeting again. Arrived at Zayla after a sunny walk, the Arab escort loaded their guns, formed a line for me to pass along, fired a salute, and entered to coffee and sweetmeats.

The life led by these wild people is necessarily monotonous. They rest but little — from 11 P.M. till dawn — and never sleep in the bush, for fear of plundering parties. Few begin the day with prayer as Moslems should: for the most part they apply themselves to counting and milking their cattle. The animals, all of which have namest ** For instance, Anfarr, the “Spotted;” Tarren, “Wheatflour;” &c. &c. , come when called to the pail, and supply the family with a morning meal. Then the warriors, grasping their spears, and sometimes the young women armed only with staves, drive their herds to pasture: the matrons and children, spinning or rope-making, tend the flocks, and the kraal is abandoned to the very young, the old, and the sick. The herdsmen wander about, watching the cattle and tasting nothing but the pure element or a pinch of coarse tobacco. Sometimes they play at Shahh, Shantarah, and other games, of which they are passionately fond: with a board formed of lines traced in the sand, and bits of dry wood or camel’s earth acting pieces, they spend hour after hour, every looker-on vociferating his opinion, and catching at the men, till apparently the two players are those least interested in the game. Or, to drive off sleep, they sit whistling to their flocks, or they perform upon the Forimo, a reed pipe generally made at Harar, which has a plaintive sound uncommonly pleasing. * It is used by the northern people, the Abyssinians, Gallas, Adail, Eesa and Gudabirsi; the southern Somal ignore it. In the evening, the kraal again resounds with lowing and bleating: the camel’s milk is all drunk, the cow’s and goat’s reserved for butter and ghee, which the women prepare; the numbers are once more counted, and the animals are carefully penned up for the night. This simple life is varied by an occasional birth and marriage, dance and foray, disease and murder. Their maladies are few and simple ** The most dangerous disease is small-pox, which history traces to Eastern Abyssinia, where it still becomes at times a violent epidemic, sweeping off its thousands. The patient, if a man of note, is placed upon the sand, and fed with rice or millet bread till he recovers or dies. The chicken-pox kills many infants; they are treated by bathing in the fresh blood of a sheep, covered with the skin, and exposed to the sun. Smoke and glare, dirt and flies, cold winds and naked extremities, cause ophthalmia, especially in the hills; this disease rarely blinds any save the citizens, and no remedy is known. Dysentery is cured by rice and sour milk, patients also drink clarified cow’s butter; and in bad cases the stomach is cauterized, fire and disease, according to the Somal, never coexisting. Haemorroids, when dry, are reduced by a stick used as a bougie and allowed to remain in loco all night. Sometimes the part affected is cupped with a horn and knife, or a leech performs excision. The diet is camels’ or goats’ flesh and milk; clarified butter and Bussorah dates — rice and mutton are carefully avoided. For a certain local disease, they use senna or colocynth, anoint the body with sulphur boiled in ghee, and expose it to the sun,M41:P41 or they leave the patient all night in the dew; — abstinence and perspiration generally effect a cure. For the minor form, the afflicted drink the melted fat of a sheep’s tail. Consumption is a family complaint, and therefore considered incurable; to use the Somali expression, they address the patient with “Allah, have mercy upon thee!” not with “Allah cure thee!” There are leeches who have secret simples for curing wounds. Generally the blood is squeezed out, the place is washed with water, the lips are sewn up and a dressing of astringent leaves is applied. They have splints for fractures, and they can reduce dislocations. A medical friend at Aden partially dislocated his knee, which half-a-dozen of the faculty insisted upon treating as a sprain. Of all his tortures none was more severe than that inflicted by my Somali visitors. They would look at him, distinguish the complaint, ask him how long he had been invalided, and hearing the reply — four months — would break into exclamations of wonder. “In our country,” they cried, “when a man falls, two pull his body and two his legs, then they tie sticks round it, give him plenty of camel’s milk, and he is well in a month;” a speech which made friend S. groan in spirit. Firing and clarified butter are the farrier’s panaceas. Camels are cured by sheep’s head broth, asses by chopping one ear, mules by cutting off the tail, and horses by ghee or a drench of melted fat. parrot. The name Cacatoes, is given by the Cape Boers, according to Delegorgue, to the Coliphymus Concolor. The Gobiyan resembles in shape and flight our magpie, it has a crest and a brown coat with patches of white, and a noisy note like a frog. It is very cunning and seldom affords a second shot. ; death generally comes by the spear, and the Bedouin is naturally long-lived. I have seen Macrobians hale and strong, preserving their powers and faculties in spite of eighty and ninety years.

God then in Somali eyes is remote, all-powerful, judging, and just. Men turn to Him in sorrow and distress as well as in joy and thanksgiving. He is the ultimate focus of causation, the ultimate source of life: men, for instance, ‘beget’ children, but God ‘creates’ them. Sickness and health, ill-fortune and good, exist only with His consent and are ultimately in his control to withhold or bestow. Luck ( nassiib ) is in the gift of God; and although magico-religious procedures are resorted to to remove sickness or to palliate it, misfortune and illness are rarely ascribed to the action of sorcery or witchcraft. These themes indeed emerge only in a few special contexts and are relatively unimportant in Somali life as a whole.

In the Kalíl season, the intense heat just before the rains, I have registered 118° Fahrenheit under the shade of a double “Cabul” tent at mid-day, in my camp at Malgui in the maritime mountains. As we marched to the camp where this heat was registered, several of the men were bleeding from the nose, and on my asking them the reason, they said cheerfully, “Oh, Allah makes our noses bleed to cool our heads.” The Somális do not wear anything on their heads, and the close-shaven skulls of the older men are entirely exposed to the hot sun.

Although the subject cannot be gone into fully here, it is necessary first to say something of Somali ideas of causation. The ultimate focus of causation is God ( Allaah ), conceived of as a largely impersonal power before whom man is impotent and helpless. Sickness and ill-health, good and ill-fortune, all exist with His consent and are ultimately in His control to withold or bestow. Although magico-religious procedures are applied in the treatment of disease in man and beast, illness is very rarely ascribed to magical causes. Nor is it necessarily a direct and specific reflection of the wrath of God. Awards and punishments do not automatically fall due in this life but may be received after death. Man is in any case held to be by nature sinful so that God’s disfavour is regarded rather as a constant condition than as an immediate punishment for some transgression. It is indeed because man is known to be far removed from the ideals of religion in his normal behaviour that saints are valued as intercessors. I was often told specifically that because saints have exhibited in their lives special virtue they can the more effectively approach God through the Prophet to seek favours where others less favoured would be likely to fail.

Thus, one interpretation of the long-drawn-out illness of a former and distinguished Chief Government Kadi in the Protectorate who was receiving treatment for tuberculosis, was that a curse ( habaar ) had been laid upon him by rivals for his position. The Kadi consulted sheikhs expert in the treatment of sorcery ( sihir ) and eventually recovered. Another less charitable explanation of his illness was that he had sinned against religion and was being punished by one of his ancestors, a famous saint in northern Somaliland. For, as was stated earlier, generally wadaads and sheikhs are expected to adhere much more strictly to the precepts of Islam than are ‘warriors’; although exceptions are sometimes made on the assumption that a sheikh, with great powers of charisma and devotion to God, may have a special pattern of conduct revealed to him even when this conflicts to some extent with the accepted precepts of the Shariah.

While the blessing of a wadaad is respected and his curse feared, the occasions when wadaads are believed to resort to sorcery except in legitimately protecting their property are rare. Yet there is a spirit-possession disease known as wadaaddo (plural of wadaad ) particularly prevalent in the north-east of Somaliland. The disease is sometimes diagnosed in people suffering from tuberculosis or pneumonia and the general symptoms are coughing, sneezing, and vomiting with occasional lapses into unconsciousness. This ailment is treated by wadaads, particularly those who have previously suffered from it, who adjure the spirit to quit the patient by reading potent verses of the Quran and bathing him with perfume. Perfume in Somaliland has a ritual significance and is associated with religious celebrations. Frequently on Fridays when men are holding a religious ceremony perfume is poured liberally over the hands of those taking part.  These wadaads of the spirit world were, it is believed, formerly the familiars of Boqor ‘Ismaan, Sultan of the Majeerteen ‘Ismaan Mahamuud; and when he died are said to have been released to trouble people. The disease appears to have spread westwards only within the last fifteen years or so and is not very common. That these spirits should attack people is attributed to the belief that at the death of Boqor ‘Ismaan his descendants refused to care for his attendant spirits and sent them away.

Wadaaddo -spirits are generally regarded as jinns, devils, malignant forces of evil. While everyone knows that there is scriptural warrant for the existence of jinns, and many believe that they come out at night to trouble man, many of the most conservative Somali do not believe in wadaaddo -spirits and regard the whole thing as a superstition of the gullible. This scepticism is even more pronounced in the case of a similar spirit-possession illness called saar which afflicts women rather than men. I mention this disease because to some extent it appears to act as a sanction for the good treatment of a wife by her husband. It is certainly considered by men as a foible of women, and is generally dismissed by them as ‘women’s nonsense’. Married women too, concede that it is a complaint which afflicts them usually when they have a grievance against their husbands. But as far as women are concerned it is nevertheless a serious affliction.

Saar -spirit possession is extremely common in Ethiopia where it appears to have originated and amounts almost to a spirit-cult. 1 See Cerulli, Encyclopaedia of Islam, vol. iv, p. 1217; Cerulli, 1923, pp. 178-81; Leiris, 1934 (a), (b); Lewis, 1956; Leiris, 1958. Other sources on the spread of the saar cult outside the Horn of Africa are cited in Lewis, 1956, p. 147. One explanation which I was given for the introduction of the disease into Somaliland, where, in one form it is known as Abyssinian saar ( saar Habaashi ), was that the Ethiopians had sent it in retaliation for the many past acts of aggression of Somali against them. In Somaliland there is a fairly well-developed ritual of exorcism conducted mainly by women who have previously suffered from the disease who are considered to have ‘authority’ over the spirit. Such a woman is called alaqa . The exorcism of the spirit—which may not be permanent—and the treatment of the disease are usually conducted by these women who charge very considerable fees. The saar spirit is held to like all good things; all luxuries, perfumes, fine clothes, dates, coffee etc., and livestock are sometimes also killed so that blood may be given to appease the spirit. While the alaqa takes the majority of these as her reward the patient has also to be given presents, these being given in the name of the spirit possessing her.

Men tend to regard the complaint as a means whereby wives susceptible to the malicious insinuations of old women (who are considered to be ill-disposed) obtain luxuries from their husbands. bands. One man even suggested that a woman might purposely seek to waste her husband’s substance in the treatment of the disease to prevent his having sufficient wealth to marry another wife. It is important to note, however, that I never encountered or even heard of saar possession being directly attributed to jealousy between co-wives. Friction between a man’s several wives, which is proverbial, is resolved by other means. But to some degree saar possession seems to provide a woman with a grievance against her husband with a means of expression for her hostility without recourse to open quarrelling. Yet in the end the instances with which I am familiar show that husbands tend to tire of what they regard as little more than malingering and may seek divorce. Further discussion of saar would be outside the scope of this chapter, indeed of this book, and I merely record here that saar possession is generally looked at askance by the majority of sheikhs and wadaads, the consensus of opinion being that it is unorthodox. In fact cathartic saar dances have been banned by public agitation in many districts, both in northern Somaliland and Somalia.

A variety of spiritual beings are believed to inhabit the world. The JINNY, the only category of spirits that Islam recognizes, are generally harmless if they are left undisturbed. Other categories of spirits, such as AYAAMO, MINGIS and ROHAAN, are more capricious and may bring illness by possessing their victims. Groups of those who are possessed often form cults seeking to soothe the possessing spirit.

Illnesses are attributed both to abstract entities and emotions and to tangible causes. Somali nomads discovered the role of mosquitoes in the spread of malaria long before this connection was scientifically proven. The medical system is a plural one: patients have a free choice between herbal, religious, and Western medicines.

It is important to establish individual relations with people that one interacts with. Where no such relations exist, there is always a fear that one may be struck by disease and misfortune. For instance, the il-dad or isha (lit. “eye of people”, “the eye”), or evil eye is nearly always the suspected agent behind sudden disease of any kind, and it is thought to be the only cause of widespread diseases like qaaxo (tuberculosis). It is from unknown persons (or for that matter distant relatives) who envy one’s possessions that the evil eye can strike. For that reason it is important, for instance, that whatever small item one has purchased from a shop, it must be properly wrapped up so as not to ignite the desire of others.

In southern Somali medicine - as elsewhere in Africa (Ademuwagun 1979; Augé 1985:10; Feierman 1985:110ff; Imperato 1977:54; Janzen 1979) - diseases in general are not held to come from one single source, nor can they be cured with one type of treatment alone. Although both health (caafimaad) and disease (cudur) are seen as ultimately caused by God, Ilaahi (cf. Brotmacher 1955:207; Haakonsen 1983:106; Thomas 1982:33), a number of different specific sources of disease are also identified and a large variety of different forms of treatment are available.

I will limit my discussion to three separate types of treatment. They are: treatment based on geed, which are trees, bushes and herbs, treatment derived from diin, which is the Islamic religion, and treatment which relies on daawo, pills and injections. These three areas of medical knowledge are not to be thought of as separate cognitive systems. Nor will I be concerned exclusively with cognitive aspects. I shall talk about them here as therapeutic forms. They are construed with reference to specific concepts and assumptions and have developed their own forms of practice. Within each one of them there are also named experts and degrees of professionalism. In brief, each type of therapy represents a distinct way of thinking and talking about, and of acting upon, illness.

Despite the obvious differences between these three forms of therapy, people do not generally experience contradictions between them (see Yusuf et al. 1984). Nor can one find any pronounced rivalry even among the different types of experts. It actually happens that one specialist will refer a difficult patient to some other kind of expert in cases where his own therapy has failed. Compatibility between the different forms of medical practice and theory is therefore a marked feature. As it was once expressed to me: “when they are ill, some people rely on the book [the Qur’an] and others on the trees”. One reason for the similar attitudes to different therapeutic forms relates to what it is that gives to medicine and treatment their healing powers. As I will show there are some very central points of connection between the different therapeutic forms; the treatments which they offer all relate to different cultural concepts of the unknown and strange.

Therefore, this exploration into the power of Somali medicines is coupled with an analysis of Hubeer conceptions of the category of the strange and the unknown.
