Since similar explanations were offered by the old men in my Alice Springs camp whenever other leading informants from time to time took ill without any apparent cause, the reader will be able to infer for himself the full strength of this deeply-rooted belief in the omnipresence of the powerful Great Father at each of the spots which were once lit up by his presence; and this, in turn, will render more easily intelligible the interesting fact that the Northern native believes in the presence of his revered and dreaded ancestor wherever and whenever ceremonies are being given in his honour and in his remembrance.”
“The women sing this hopping round the fire. We shall now proceed to investigate the elements of this song.

‘Young women’ is followed by an enumeration of objects used by women, such as the yamstick and various kinds of pitchi . They ‘sing’ these, including their own arm, to fill them with arunkulta and kill the man. The second part deals with various kinds of bushes and with the magpie, which is ‘sitting down.’ My informants did not tell me what this meant. But it is easy to guess from other texts. The bushes are seen by some mythical beings during their wanderings, and as this is an ilpindja, we may add, during their lovesick wanderings. Usually it is the women who rush to the men in this fashion, but as the women are the charmers in this case, it is probably the young men who put the witchetty bush on their heads ( maliara tantana ) and rush to the women. The magpie is either one of the things seen on the way, or perhaps indicates the totemic cycle to which the ilpindja belongs. With the line lunpurgnula manyinila we have a different set of ideas. They are ‘singing’ the bones deposited beside the fire. They are lirinchiri flowing with the life blood extracted from the victim. The word lurpmanjurmankur, translated here as arunkulta , really means the marks of decoration on the bone. When the bone enters the flesh of the victim, these engraved marks stick in his flesh like the barbs of a spear or harpoon, making it difficult for the sorcerer to extract the bone.

But this is love magic; why should they wish to bone the maliara whom they desire? He will be boned, feel hot till he comes to the women, who can cure him by greasing his body ( manchurkanchurka laranapana ) or by removing the bones from the flames and greasing them ( manda randa-ranala laranapana ). There is an underlying parallelism between the state of being sick and being lovesick, of being cured of disease, and of desire that is gratified. Under the heading of woman's magic with the pointing bone we found an incantation that started as black magic, and went on as an ilpindja . Here we have the opposite case.”

“Another curious link between the two types of magic is contained in the word linchirinchiri. In the typical ilpindja it is the menstruation of the women which is flowing. If we remember the significance of the vagina as a wound and as the place where the penis dies, it would seem that the link between the two concepts is the unconscious desire of the female to castrate her lover and victim in the act of cohabitation. The lines Tunta arilichili, Naiuku (ngaiuku) tunta rilichili are especially suggestive, as the ‘leg’ probably means both the bone (derived from the leg of the kangaroo) and the leg of the woman where the blood flows down when she menstruates.

I have used the ordinary word kulakula in translating the ‘song-word’ kulara-kulkara because it can only be rendered with a whole phrase. Kulakula means to run after the women and have intercourse with them. When the song is nearly finished one woman puts her leg close to the vagina of the other woman and they kulakula with each other (‘thigh stands up, thigh, moving upwards’). Then they tell the bell-bird as the harbinger of love ‘Go run and fetch the young men whom we love.’ Konja means pity, sorrow, desire, and tenderness. ‘ Konja Laddie,’ they said when we left. Laddie was my dog and they really did not mean to pity him but expressed their love for him, their sorrow to lose him. [220]
The strong Aranda influence in the song (miniara, larunkulta, konja) shows its Matunara origin, for the Matuntara are the immediate neighbours of the Finke Aranda.”

Infanticide is undoubtedly practised, but, except on rare occasions, the child is killed immediately on birth, and then only when the mother is, or thinks she is, unable to rear it, owing to there being a young child whom she is still feeding, and with them suckling is continued for it may be several years. They believe that the spirit part of the child goes back at once to the particular spot from whence it came, and can be born again at some subsequent time even of the same woman. Twins, which are of extremely rare occurrence, are usually killed immediately as something which is unnatural; but there is no ill-treatment of the mother, who is not thought any the less of. We cannot find out what, exactly, lies at the root of this dislike of twins in the case of the Arunta and other tribes. Possibly it is to be explained on the simple ground that the parent feels a not altogether unrighteous anger that two spirit individuals should think of entering the body of the woman at one and the same time, when they know well that the mother could not possibly rear them both, added to which the advent of twins is a very infrequent event, and the native always has a dread of anything which appears strange and out of the common. In connection with this it may be noted that on the very rare occasions on which the child is born at a very premature stage as the result of an accident, nothing will persuade them that it is an undeveloped human being; they are perfectly convinced that it is the young of some other animal, such as a kangaroo, which has by mistake got inside the woman. 1 Sterility is of frequent occurrence at the present day amongst the native women. The greatest fertility is amongst the strong stout women, the thin and weaker ones rarely having children. Possibly sterility in many cases is associated with injury received during the initiation rite of Ariltakuma. The natives believe that it may be brought about by a girl in her youth playfully or thoughtlessly tying on a man's hair waist-band. The latter so used, if only for a moment or two, has the effect of cramping her internal organs and making them incapable of the necessary expansion, and this is the most frequent explanation of sterility given by the natives.

After the operation of Lutna, the foreskin, amongst the Finke River groups of natives, is handed over to the eldest Kullia of the boy who is present, and he also takes charge of the shield in the haft of which the blood from the wound was collected. He greases the piece of skin and then gives it to a boy who is the younger brother of the Arakurta, and tells him to swallow it, the idea at the present day being that is will strengthen him and cause him to grow tall and strong. The shield is taken by the Kullia to his camp, where he hands it over to his Anua, or wife, and she then rubs the blood over the breasts and foreheads of women who are Mia alkulla, that is, elder sisters of the boy's actual Mia and Ungaraitcha, or elder sisters of the boy.
These women must not on any account touch the blood themselves, and after rubbing it on, the woman adds a coat of red ochre. The actual Mia is never allowed to see the blood.

A [wandering lizard people in the Alchera--Analyst] At Irulchirtna they made quabara undattha, carrying Churinga on their heads, as shown during one of the Engwura ceremonies which represented one of those performed during this march. Here it was that some men of the Thippa-thippa (a bird totem) came and danced round them as they performed, and were afterwards changed into birds, which still hover over the Echunpa lizards and show the natives where they are to be found. Leaving Irulchirtna, they still carried their Churinga on their heads, and the Thippa-thippa ran round looking at them. At a place on the Todd River in the Emily Plain they stayed some time performing Tapurta --that is, a long series of lizard ceremonies--and then, moving on a little further, the party was divided into two by the Illunja man. One lot went away south to somewhere in the region of Erldunda, and the other kept on a westerly course till Illaba, not far from the Heavitree Gap near Alice Springs, was reached. Here it is said that a Purula man who had a stumpy tail left the party, intending to go away, but changed his mind and returned. Then they went to what is now a large clay-pan, called Conlon's lagoon, where Tapurta were again performed. Here a thin, emaciated man was left, and where he died a stone arose, the rubbing of which can cause emaciation in other people. This stone is charged with Arungquilta, or evil influence.

So far as his functions are concerned, the medicine man may be regarded as partly, perhaps in the main, what this name implies, and at the same time as a wizard. His chief function is undoubtedly that of curing the natives; but as all ailments of every kind, from the simplest to the most serious, are without exception attributed to the malign influence of an enemy in either human or spirit shape, the method of curing takes the form of an exhibition of what is really sleight of hand, the object being to remove from the body of the patient something, such as a pointing-stick or the broken pieces of a Churinga, which have been placed in it by the enemy. In many Australian tribes the equivalent of the medicine man amongst the Arunta is the one individual who can hold intercourse with the spirits; but in this tribe this is by no means the case, as there are men who, without being medicine men, are especially favoured in this respect. In many tribes also it is only the medicine men or their equivalents who have the power of, for example, securing by means of special incantations the illness or death of the individual whom it is desired to harm, and therefore, to secure this end, recourse must be had to a medicine man. In the Arunta, Ilpirra and other of the Central Australian tribes this does not hold true; every man may have recóurse to what is usually spoken of as sorcery, by means of which he may work harm of some kind to an enemy, and this power is not in any way confined to the medicine men, though, on the other hand, they are the only men who can counteract the evil influence of an enemy. At the same time, there are certain of the very old medicine men who are supposed to be endowed by the Ivuntarinia with the special power of bringing disease down upon not only individuals, but whole groups of men and women.

In cases of sickness the natives have implicit faith in the medicine man, and in serious cases two or three, if they be available, are called in, in consultation. 1 In connection with medicine men restrictions such as those applying to Mura are laid on one side during the actual exercise of their profession. No reward of any kind is given, or expected, nor is any blame attached in case of non-success, the latter being attributed to the malignant action of superior magic on the part of some hostile spirit or individual, though it is sometimes said, as we have heard on different occasions, that if a particular medicine man had been present he would have been able to counteract the influence of the enemy when the individual who was present was unable to do so and the patient died. Just as amongst ourselves, certain medicine men are regarded as better qualified and more able than others.

In ordinary cases the patient lies down on the ground while the medicine man bends over, rubs and sucks vigorously at the affected part of the body, spitting out every now and then supposed pieces of wood, bone or stone, the presence of which is believed to be causing the injury and pain. This suction is one of the most characteristic features of native medical treatment, as pain in any part of the body is always supposed to be due to the presence of some foreign body, which must be removed. Amongst especially the Western Arunta the medicine man, in addition to the Atnongara stones, is supposed to have a particular kind of lizard distributed through his body, which endows him with great suctorial power, such as the natives attribute to the lizard itself. In serious cases the action is more dramatic, and the medicine man needs a clear space in which to perform. The patient, perhaps too ill to sit up, is supported by some individual, while the medicine man who has been called in, and may have come a long distance, gravely examines him and consults with other practirioners who may be present, and with the more immediate relatives of the patient, as to the nature of the illness. The diagnosis may occupy some time, during which everyone maintains a very solemn appearance, all conversation being carried on in whispers. As a result the medicine man will perhaps pronounce that the sick man is suffering from a charmed bone inserted by a magic individual, such as a Kurdaitcha; or perhaps, worse still, the verdict is that one of the Iruntarinia has placed in his body an Ullinka or short barbed stick attached to an invisible string, the pulling of which by the malicious spirit causes great pain (Fig. 119 nos. 10, 11). If the latter be the case it requires the greatest skill of a renowned medicine man to effect a cure. While the patient is supported in a half-sitting attitude, the medicine man will first of all stand close by, gazing down upon him in the most intent way. Then suddenly he will go some yards off, and looking fiercely at him, bends slightly forwards and repeatedly jerks his arm outwards at full length, with the hand outstretched, the object being thereby to project some of the Atnongara stones into the patient's body, the object of this being to counteract the evil influence at work within the latter. Going rapidly and with a characteristic high knee action from one end of the cleared space to the other, he repeats the movement with dramatic action. Finally, he comes close again, and, after much mysterious searching, finds and cuts the string, which is invisible to everyone except himself. There is not a doubt amongst the onlookers as to his having really done this. Then once more the projecting of the Ainongara stones takes place, and crouching down over the sick man he places his mouth upon the afiected part and sucks, until at last the Ullinka is extracted, either in fragments or, very rarely, and only if he be a very distinguished medicine man, whole, and is shown to the wondering onlookers, the Atnongara stones returning, unseen, once more into his own body. When this is over, unless it is simply a case of senile decay-on the part of the patient, in which case the medicine man is too acute to take so much trouble, when he knows pretty well that there is no possibility of effecting a cure, the chances are strongly in favour of the latter, but if death ensues FIG. 120.--POSITION ASSUMED WHEN USING THE UNGAKURA POINTING APPARATUS. ARUNTA TRIBE. FIG. 121.--POSITION ASSUMED WHEN POINTING THE IRNA. ARUNTA TRIBE. it is simply because the magic stick has been inserted in some vital part, or because the aid of the medicine man had not been called in early enough, or because his efforts had been maliciously thwarted by some Iruntarinia.

Any bone, stick, spear. etc., which has thus been “sung” is supposed to be endowed with what the natives call Arungquilia --that is, magical poisonous properties--and any native who believes that he has been struck by, say, a charmed spear is almost sure to die, whether the wound be slight or severe, unless he be saved by the counier magie of a medicine man. There is no doubt whatever that a native will die aiter the infliction of even a most superficial wound if only he believes the weapon which inflieted the wound had been “sung” over and thus endowed with Arungquilta. He simply lies down, refuses food and pines away. Not long ago a man from Barrow Creek received a slight wound in the groin. Though there was apparently nothing serious the matter with him, still he persisted in saying that the spear had been charmed and that he must die, which accordingly he did in the course of a few days. Another man coming down to the Alice Springs from the Tennant Creek contracted a slight cold, but the local men told him that the members of a group about twelve miles away to the east had taken his heart out, and believing this to be so, he simply laid himself down and wasted away. In a similar way a man at Charlotte Waters came to us with a slight spear wound in his back. He was assured that the wound was not serious, and it was dressed in the usual way, but he persisted in saying that the spear had been “sung,” and that though it could not be seen, yet in reality it had broken his back and he was going to die, which accordingly he did. As a result of this a party was organised among the members of his group to avenge his death, and the man who was supposed to have wounded him with the charmed weapon was killed.

Instances of occurrences such as these could be multiplied, and though, of course, it is impossible to prove that death would not have followed under any circumstances--that is, whether the native had or had not imagined the weapon to have been “sung”--yet, with a knowledge of what wounds and injuries he will survive if he does not suspect the intervention of magio, it is not possible to explain death under such circumstances except as associated directly with the firm belief of the injured man that Arungquilta has entered his body, and that therefore he must die.

A [Made from the hair of a dead man. ---- Analyst] In the central and northern groups of the Arunta tribe this special form of necklet is made of perhaps four or five circles of hair-string, each about half an inch in diameter, but in the Western Arunta there is but one circle, or rather horse-shoeshaped structure forming a coil about an inch and a half in diameter, the two ends of which are tied together by strands of opossum fur-string.

Amongst the Arunta tribe, women, while not dealing with magic as a general rule, or at any rate not to anything like the extent that the men do, are still supposed to be able to exercise peculiar powers in regard to the sexual organs. 1 As a peneral rule women are not supposed to be able to exercise much magic, except in regard to the sexual organs, but we have known of a woman being speared to death by the brother of her husband, who accused her of having killed the latter by means of a pointing-stick. To bring on a painful affection in those of men, a woman will procure the spear-like seed of a long grass ( Inturkirra ),and having charmed it by singing some magic chant over it, she awaits an opportunity to point and throw it towards the man whom she desires to mjure. Shortly after this has been done the man experiences pain, as if he had been stung by ants, his parts become swollen, and he at once attributes his sufferings to the magic influence of some woman who wishes to injure him. A woman may also charm a handful of dust which she collects while out digging up yams or gathering seeds, and having “sung” it, brings it into camp with her. She takes the opportunity of sprinkling it over a spot where the man whom she wishes to injure is likely to micturate. If he should do so at this spot he would experience a scalding sensation in the urethra and afterwards suffer a great amount of pain. Women may also produce disease in men by singing over and thus charming a finger, which is then inserted in the vulva; the man who subsequently has connection with her will become diseased and may lose his organs altogether, and so when a woman wishes to injure a man she will sometimes, after thus “poisoning” herself, seek an opportunity of soliciting him, though he be not her proper Anua. Syphilitic disease amongst the Arunta is, as a matter of fact, very frequently attributed to this form of magic, for it must be remembered that the native can only understand disease of any form as due to evil magic, and he has to provide what appears to him to be a suitable form of magic to account for each form of disease.

We have already, in the account of Undiara, referred to the old man Ungutnika who plucked boils from his body, each of which turned into one of the group of stones which are still to be seen at Undiara and are called Perta iukira --that is, stone sores. Men who desire to harm others in one particular way make a number of small wooden imitation spears and go to these stones, at which they throw the spears, taking care that the points strike the stones. Then the spears are picked up and thrown one by one from a spear-thrower in the direction of the man whom it is desired to injure. The spears are supposed to carry away with them Arungquilta from the stones, and this produces an eruption of painful boils in the individual or individuals towards whom they are thrown. Sometimes a whole group of people can be afflicted in this way by a skilful magic man.

Anyone wishing to injure another person may perform a simple ceremony here, which consists merely in rubbing the stone with the hands while muttering an exhortation to the evil influence to come forth and afflict the person whom he desires to harm. After this has been done the victim will gradually grow thinner and thinner until he withers away altogether.

Another stone close to a large clay-pan not far from Alice Springs marks the spot where a lizard man died in the Alchera. He also was thin and emaciated, and so the stone is charged with Arungquilta, which by rubbing and muttering, as just described in the case of the emu stone, may be projected into the body of an enemy.

Amongst other forms of magic the following may also be noticed. Just as the stones marking the spot where the thin animals or men died are associated with magic, so we find the same to hold good in the case of other trees and stones that are associated with special individuals of the Alchera. Near to Charlotte Waters, for example, is a tree which sprang up to mark the spot where a blind man died. This tree is called the Apera okilchya --that is, the blind tree--and the spot where it stands the Tmara okilchya, or blind camp. Should this be cut down it is supposed that the men of the locality in which it grows will become blind; or if anyone wishes to produce blindness in an enemy, all that he has to do is to go alone to the tree, and while rubbing it mutter his desire and an exhortation to the Arungquilia to go forth and afflict his enemy. Along by the side of the Hugh River in the Macdonnell Ranges close to Mount Conway is a stone which marks where a blind man of the wild duck totem died; and here again the same ceremony may be performed. Close also to Temple Bar, a gap in the ranges, is another similar stone.

To cause a person to become thin and weak, spittle is put on the tips of the fingers, which are then bunched together and jerked in the direction of the former. This is called Pu uma or spittle-throwing. Amongst the Ilpirra tribe especially, a very simple method consists in merely charming a finger by singing over it, and then pointing it at an enemy, who is supposed to waste away. In the Ilpirra also a form of magic called Ichinperli is practised. A short stick is sharpened at both ends and then a number of little bits of flint are fixed on to it all round with resin. The object thus made is charmed by being “sung,” and is then pointed at the enemy, who either wastes away or becomes blind. The same tribe also brings about death by placing a tiny flake of flint which has been charmed under the finger-nail. In this position it is carried about until the opportunity occurs of dropping it quietly on to the person whom it is desired to kill, very much in the same way in which the Mauia stone is used amongst the Kaitisha.

To produce blindness the Arunta native will sometimes merely point one of the ordinary Injilla or pointing-sticks, or he will charm a Chilara or forehead band, and then present it to his enemy, who after a time loses his sight.

To the native the Iruntarinia is a very real personage, who, as a general rule, is a beneficent being, though at times capable of great cruelty; he is, in fact, a man of the Alchera endowed with all the powers possessed by such an one. If he be offended, then he may place in the body of the offender one of his pointing-sticks, or Ullinka, which as a general rule is a barbed stick a few inches in length and attached to a string, the FIG. I27A.--IRUNTARINIA CEREMONY CONCERNED WITH TWO ERUNCHA OF ATNURTINYA KINYA. malicious pulling of which causes severe pain, and the stick can only be removed by the aid of a very skilled medicine man.

After an hour or two the men went away to their respective camps, but for days to come the Immirinja must not speak of the expedition. They have also to be very careful to paint their bodies black 1 The idea of this is probably to render themselves invisible. The widow of a dead man has to paint her body white, so that the spirit of the dead man can see that she is properly mourning for him. and to continue the wearing of the Eremophila twigs. At night-time they wear alpita --that is, the tailtips of the rabbit-bandicoot--which, being part of a nocturnal animal, is supposed to make the wearer wakeful. The chichurkna keeps flying over the camp hoping to injure his murderers, who have to be very careful not to allow the bird to catch sight of their right arm, else it would become paralysed. The chichurkna sounds like a child crying in the distance, and when once it has been heard by any man it is powerless to do him further harm.

On very rare occasions a woman may, at her own request, be sent out by her husband to avenge somé injury done, or supposed to be done, to one of her own kindred. There is no such thing as any consultation of the old men in connection FIG. 143.--WOMAN DRESSED UP AS AN ILLAPURINJA. Carrying in the right hand a charmed stick and in the left a decorated fighting-club. She is supposed to be in the act of throwing the charmed stick at the enemy. with this; in fact, if they knew of its being prepared they would prevent her going, so that the affair is a secret one, known only to the woman and her husband. It seems as if the Illapurinja has never been a very popular form of avenging an injury, and is very rarely mentioned except when a medicine man discovers that one of his patients, who has been seized with sudden and unaccountable illness, is suffering from the attack of an Illapurinja. As usual, the natives when questioned on the subject said that though they knew all about it, yet it was a custom which they did not practise or, rather, had not practised for many years, but that it was prevalent somewhere else. It is only a few years since a man was out hunting euros near to Alice Springs, and was attacked by an Illapurinja who had come from an outlving group. He was picked up insensible (the day. was a very hot one, and in all probability the case was one of sunstroke), and brought into camp in a dazed condition. Under the treatment of an able medicine man, whose services were fortunately available, he recovered, after the extraction from his body of a number of pieces of a wooden Churinga.
All kinds of parrots and cockatoos; penalty, development of a hollow on the top of the head and of a hole in the chin.
Large quail ( Tulkara ) and its eggs; penalty, non-growth of beard and whiskers and general stoppage of growth.

Eagle-hawk ( Irritcha ), except the legs; penalty, premature age and leanness; the leg is supposed to impart strength and generally to improve the growth of the limb. Boys are often struck on the calf of the leg with the leg-bone of an eaglehawk, as thereby strength passes from the bone into the boy's leg.
Wild-cat ( Achilpa ); penalty, painful and foul-smelling eruption on head and neck. This restriction applies until very old age is reached.
Podargus ( Aurainga ) and its eggs; penalty, an ugly enlargement of the mouth.

The following restrictions and penalties concern girls and young women until after they have had a child, or until their breasts begin to be pendent, in the characteristic way of the native women. They may not eat:
Female bandicoot (Quirra); penalty, continual flow of the menses.

Large lizards; penalty, become Arro-iwama --that is, one with an abnormal craving for sexual intercourse; such a woman would be always tempting men, irrespective of tribal laws with regard to section, and would thus, sooner or later, meet with severe punishment, probably with death.
Large quail and its eggs; penalty, non-development of the breasts.
Wild-cat (Achilpa) ; penalty, the same as in the case of the men.
Kangaroo tail (Arura paira); penalty, premature age, baldness, non-development of the breasts.
Emu fat; penalty, malformation of the vulva.
Cockatoos and parrots of all kinds; penalty, development of a hollow on the top of the head, and of a hole in the chin.
Echidna (Inarlinga); penalty, general malformation of the genital organs.
Brown hawk (Hieracidea orientalis, native name Irkalanja ); penalty, absence of milk from the breasts, which will also swell until they burst.

Young women are only allowed to eat the young nestlings. The customs connected with this particular bird are curious. Not only is it ekeirinja or forbidden to the young women, but, if one of them be suckling a child and she sees one of these birds, she at once makes haste to turn so that her breast cannot be seen by the bird, because, if the bird should catch sight of it, or, worse still, if its shadow were to fall on it, then the milk would fail and the breast would swell and burst. The women also believe that if they eat the old birds their sons will be afflicted with varicose veins (ulurkna) on the forehead, causing much disfigurement.

“The peculiar thing about this society is that while there is but little anxiety connected with menstruation (51) Ibid., p. 76. the opposite taboo, viz., that of women touching the ‘ritual’ blood of men, is very strong. ‘It is believed that this blood, when it is on a man's body as a part of a ceremony, if touched by a woman, will make her ill [174] or produce sores on her body because it has had a totemic name given it and the essence of the totemic spirit has gone inside this blood. The blood of a man who has been hurt in an ordinary accident will not hurt the woman. She can rub against him and be all right. The blood that hurts a woman is the spirit of the Wongar that is inside that blood. It has a big (sacred) name that the leader sang when the men cut their arms. The spirit that is inside that blood is not just the wooden trumpet but another that is more inside (more sacred), and the totemic spirit itself, Yurlunggur. The blood that man gives in the Djungguan is Wongar Derpal (Derpal means magically powerful and strong). That blood the old man gives to the dance people makes them derpal and it makes their feathers and bush cotton derpal. The meaning is like this: suppose you and I have come a long way and we reach a good camp and our people have one house empty and it is a good place for us and they take us and put us in it. We get in that house and have a good sleep and nobody can hurt us because we have friends. That blood is just like that. It makes us good. That derpal is like the head man. We have that derpal from that blood. It is in our body. It goes inside when we put that blood on it. That blood makes a very big thing.’ (52) Ibid., p. 277. ”

“Disease is due to the talio punishment for body destruction fantasies; or, in other words, it is due to introjected bad objects--invisible stones or serpents projected into the body by evil medicine men or demons, i. e., introjected representatives of the hostile object. The medicine man is a professional dealer in all kinds of anxieties connected with body destruction and primal scenes. He has been initiated by having his own corruptible intestines removed, i. e., by having undergone the punishment for his body destruction fantasies, but also by over-compensating this anxiety position. The first formula would be ‘My body contents will be removed, torn out as a punishment for my own body destruction fantasies.’ The second version: ‘What I was afraid of has happened and it cannot happen again; I have received new indestructible body contents.’ The reparation fantasies which always follow body destruction trends, are introverted towards his own body, and then re-extroverted towards his patients, whom he heals by stimulating their own reparation fantasies. In healing them he heals himself, by a permanent series of reparations.
We see therefore that the rainbow serpent myth is closely bound up with the introjection-projection mechanism.”

‘The soul of a man came in the form of an eagle-hawk having wings but also the penis of a man. It caught my soul with this penis and dragged it out by the hair. My soul hung down from the penis and the eagle-hawk man flew about with me, first to the west and then to the east. It was dawn and the eagle-hawk man made a great fire into which he threw my soul. My penis became quite hot and he pulled the skin down. He took me out of the fire and carried me to the camp. Many nankara people were there in a group, they were only skeletons with no flesh. Their bones were like the spikes of a porcupine. The eagle-hawk threw me on these bones and they went into my body.’ (51) Ibid., p. 75. Cf. for further details, p. 76.

What is meant by the flight to the Milky Way? We are told that behind the visible Milky Way there is another Milky Way, and this is the one the sorcerer visits in his dreams. It is like a kuntanka (tjurunga) and the medicine man walks along it. It is beautiful and smooth like the subincision opening. If the subincision opening were not beautiful and smooth the medicine man might stick there and his soul might never go back into his body. (52) Ibid., pp. 69, 70. ”

In conjunction with collateral evidence, this text provides support for the following points. One of the standing beliefs in Aguacatenango is that sickness of god /XCAMEL YUUN TYOS/ is essentially curable. Measles is classified as such a sickness. When the children die in a measles epidemic, some “which” must be laying on further illness components which cause the death. One mode of reducing the witchcraft component in the illness is to kill the witch or witches.
Illness is probably the least well-controlled variable in Aguacatenango planning. As such, it is a recurrent event in the lives of Aguacatenangueros, and its implications are serious.

The household, the most complex and long-enduring organizational effort of Aguacatenangueros, may be destroyed by the death of one of its adult members. Extreme illness may cause a family to close up its house and leave town altogether. Any illness is potentially a severe strain on family resources. Drinking is intimately associated with illness: it figures in the etiology of illness; it is central in the procedures used to reduce illness as a basis for inference and action; and finally, it is an important instrument of expression of mourning should the ill individual die. After a brief description of the “theory of illness” in Aguacatenango we will show how drinking is related to this theory and to its behavioral expression.

(3) Most theories that individuals have about causal relationships in the real world are documented by events which have already taken place. They are of the type: X is true because Y has happened; or, alternatively, since Y, then X. Garfinkel has called this the documentary method (Garfinkel n.d.). It is characteristic of the documentary method that there is hardly ever a set of past events which deny some set of inferences the documentary method provides. 2 This characteristic of the documentary method is explicated in an experiment by Garfinkel ( op. cit .). Subjects were told that they should report by phone to counselors serious problems they were experiencing. Whenever the subject thought of a question to which the counselor could answer yes or no, he was instructed to ask the question. The counselor then answered each question yes or no. The subjects were required to interpret the counselor's response. In every case the subjects were able to “make sense” out of the counselor's response. The counselors' responses were drawn from a table of random numbers. Thus, in Aguacatenango, an epidemic stops because the witch who was causing it has been killed; if, on the other hand, the epidemic does not stop with the killing of a witch, then another witch must be responsible. Again, a sick person gets well because a curing ceremony has been performed; if he does not get well after the ceremony, then his illness must be witchcraft and the witch more powerful than the curer. The documentary method is never wrong. This may be one reason most “primitive” belief systems require so much pressure before they can be brought under our documentary rules.

In order to develop a theory of illness, one must have a way for directing the informant's attention to this domain or focus; or, alternatively, the ethnographer must be able to detect in the set of observables he has available to him, those which are, to some extent, conditioned by the salience of illness in one or another of its forms to the performers. In the present case we depend upon verbal contexts to establish relevance from the informant's point of view, and we use verbal contexts to test non-simulated performances in order to determine the salience of illness in the record of any situation we may be examining. One general measure of relevance is expressed in the Tzeltal question: /TUT LA SPAS/ “What happened to him” literally “What was he doing?” A further probe such as: /TUT+A CAMELIL YA YAI/ “What illness does he feel?” if it can be made relevant, is fairly likely to put the observer into the domain of illness as it is being experienced by some participant. If the illness is a non-simulated performance, further eliciting will produce further reports of states relevant in that domain. If the illness is a simulated performance, further well controlled eliciting will produce further relevant responses to the initial simulated performance. Such material, in conjunction with texts, constitutes the basis for the following survey of beliefs about illness.

The conditions which precede the onset of illness are many and varied. While some of them are known to be antecedent to illness in the sense that if an individual experiences one of these conditions the probability is increased that he will become ill, there are nonetheless many conditions which become diagnostic of the illness only after the individual defines himself and is defined as being ill. Types of experiences which lead the individual to anticipate illness include either becoming angry or being an object of anger; experiencing extreme fright, as when one has had dreams, or has seen the image of some malevolent non-human force (i.e., a ladino dressed in black riding a tall horse); and drinking aguardiente. These and similar experiences carry permanent associations with illness; the individual expects to become ill and often does so. Conditions which are used to explain illness only after-the-fact tend to be more properly theoretical in that they explain at once the necessary and sufficient conditions for some non-hypothetical occurrence of some disease process.

Among the after-the-fact explanations one finds statements such as, “the patient is suffering from soul loss, his soul presently residing in the Owner of the Cave's soul pool.” Or, “the man is suffering from malaria which he got in hot country the last time he went to the fincas.” Or, “the man's spirit is being eaten by a witch, Mr. X, who is angry with him because he did not pay back the money he owed.” Every after-the-fact description of antece dent conditions implies a cause and effect relation such that the cause can be manipulated so as the patient will recover from the illness. After-the-fact descriptions of the sources of disease processes are never final since they are always dependent on (a) the further development of the disease process in the patient and (b) the confirmation in the identification of the source of illness by a successful attempt to reduce the effect of the source. If manipulation of the hypothesized source reduces the illness, the diagnosis of source is concluded to be correct; if not, further source potentials are searched for.

There is relatively little explicit procedural apparatus for adding to the inventory of after-the-fact explanations, and there are relatively few devices for modifying the modes of identification of the cause of the disease process. If a change capability is built into this theory of illness in Aguacatenango, it is not easy to detect wherein it lies. 1 The modes of change that we have observed in Aguacatenangueros' response to illness have involved shifts from known medical practitioners to others, where the theory remains relatively unexplicated and the results of the medical practitioner's progress are used to judge the probability of opting some particular medical practitioner for a cure rather than some other. Response to illness involves the principle of exhaustion of resources. In severe illness, the family of the patient may exhaust all known medical practitioners who are thought to have sufficient knowledge and skill and also may exhaust all means for motivating curers to come and perform the cure. With the diminution of resources and exhaustion of the most proper curers, the family of the patient explores curing sources whose potential for curing may be lower, but still appreciable. Successful curing under such circumstances raises the probability that this family will use some newly successful medical practitioner sooner in the next onset of illness, that is, he will be called upon before they have exhausted their resources. The introduction of INI medical practice into Aguacatenango has been in these terms, namely, that patients and their families have turned to INI medical personnel upon the exhaustion of their resources. INI procedures have maintained a ratio of successes over failures in these curing circumstances such that they have continued to be called upon, in some cases under less extreme conditions. The ratio of successes over failures has not been so great, however, that INI is seen to be a totally satisfactory replacement for the more well established practitioners. Furthermore, INI treats only a small proportion of the total range of “illnesses” that occur in the community. INI will increase the proportion of cases it treats as it modifies the Aguacatenangueros' perception of the success' failure ratio and as it increases the classes of illness that it deals with. It may be the case that INI has at present a maximal investment in time and resources in maintaining its present range and success proportion, so future severe changes may not be expected from them. There is, however, some generalization to other INI type of curers--namely, doctors in San Cristobal. The generalization here may increase the use of doctors over curers. There is the further possibility that curers are incorporating into their theories some of the simpler strategies used by doctors. This is done so crudely that it hardly involves change of beliefs at any detailed level, but rather involves a simple increase of the inventories of medicine by means of which the curer implements his theory.

Informants report experiencing a variety of sensed states as a disease process begins. Among these are depression (mental), cough, dry throat, diarrhea, fever, vomiting, stomach ache, loss of appetite, swelling, headache. At this stage in the disease process, no one, least of all the patient, knows what developments of successive units of time will be like. That is, the patient may have a headache and it will disappear (that is, no longer be reported) in some successive unit of time. On the other hand, the headache may be compounded with a stomach ache in some successive unit of time, resulting in a redefinition of the disease process. Generally speaking, sensed states which occur early in the disease process and which are not divisible into other sensed states are equivalent to symptoms , whereas sensed states which occur later in the disease process and which are a sum of other sensed states may be equivalent to illnesses . Illnesses are unit characterizations of the disease process which are sufficiently contrastive with each other so that alternative strategies for reducing the illness (as a basis of inference and action) are pursued, depending upon which (identified) illness is present in any particular case.

It is at present still unclear to what degree well-defined illnesses such as /SAK OBAL/ “tuberculosis” are defined strictly in terms of combinations of symptoms appearing through the disease process rather than in combination with the manner in which the disease process responds to the sequential curing segments, and the ultimate explanations assigned to the disease process (e.g., witchcraft). It is probably that a more adequate statement would be that the names of illnesses are reflexes of all these pressures.

Curers and doctors differ most obviously in that doctors are ladinos and curers tend to be Indians (although ladino curers are known). In addition, they deal with illnesses in sufficiently contrastive ways so that two role identifying labels must be maintained. They are both recognized to be able to reduce illness (as a basis for further inference and action) by prescribing medicines that can be purchased in the pharmacy. These may be taken orally, injected, or applied as a salve. The doctor further prescribes and may himself perform some minor surgery, X-ray examinations, and other traditional Western-European strategies for diagnosing and reducing illness. The curer does not engage in surgery, nor does he prescribe any of the more complex testing procedures whose results he does not imagine himself to be able to interpret. Instead, he recommends additional substances he purchased from the pharmacy such as tallow, wines, herbs in aguardientes as well as substances which are sometimes found in domesticated state, and more often found wild in the general vicinity of Aguacatenango. These include some kinds of flowers, bark, leaves, roots, stems, flesh of animals and fishes, animal waste products, eggs and so on. These substances are variously taken orally, applied externally, or inhaled as steam. Unlike doctors, curers practice bleeding and cupping; they also administer some medications in the form of steam while the patient is seated on a platform over a fire. They incorporate adornment of the sick-bed into curing ritual. The ritual may also include prayer. Most important, perhaps, the curers undertake to examine the recent life history of the individual who is ill, in terms of the possibility that the individual has encountered some disease producing entity which can explain, in his particular case, the onset of the disease process. There is no illness for which the curer does not have an explanation together with a set of strategies for dealing with it. At present, at least one curer, when confronted with very serious cases, will refer his patient to a doctor, but this does not yet appear to be a popular alternative. Generally, the doctor is the last of all medical practitioners referred to in exhausting the curing options in Aguacatenango, though individuals who have had a successful relationship with the doctor are more likely to pursue that option sooner. The only other major class of medical practitioners is the talking saint. Talking saints are more or less representational images of saints who, in conjunction with their “owners” can actively consult with human beings about their trials and tribulations in the world. The most powerful of this class, San Miguel of Soyaló, is about an eight hour trip and a 200 peso fee from Aguacatenango. Talking saints share more features with the curers than they do with doctors. They, like the curers, are predestined by God to their role, but they more directly represent God's omniscience. The cure of the talking sai it is more powerful as can be measured by the greater expenditure of funds for such a cure, or as can be measured by his greater ability to divine in the life history of the patient the principal sources of illness.

Informants report that drinking may result in illness. One can distinguish, in the case of consequent illness two rather distinct constellations of features which lead to illness. The first involves the enchanting of the aguardiente by some badintentioned person, a substance being inserted in the aguardiente which causes severe illness or death to the person who drinks it. The second state involves interpretation of the supposed results of drunkenness, the universal result of the consumption of aguardiente in substantial amounts.
An example of the first condition appears in a text fragment of Ausencio Espinoza, as follows:

NAL PRIMERA LIHKE YUN LOK' TA PAXEAL HUN AHK'BAL SOK SOTAK. This began when he went out to party with his friends. BAYAL XK'OKIL BA STOHIK SK'INIK SLOK' ESLAN SBILIK TA BOSINA. There were several of them who paid for their music and they announced their names on the loud speaker. PERO SUNUL AHK'BAL PAXYAHIK. They partied all night. TA XCE'BAL K'AHAL LIHK YA'Y K'UX TA SBE YIK' MAK SNA STOHOL TUT AY TE K'UX E. The next day he began to feel a pain in his throat and he didn't understand what it was from. BAHT TA ATEL. He went to work. TE TA YATEL E MA LA X HU YA YAY I TONC LA YA YAY TE MAYUK SPERSE. He went to work and he was not able to do it, for he felt very weak. XCEBAL K'AHAL HA NAX HIC. The next day he felt the same. YOXEBAL K'AHAL HA NAX HIC. On the third day he felt the same. TEBEHTIK UNINOT TONC HA K'UX LI TA SBE YIK' I. Little by little the illness dominated him, what gave him pain was his throat. MA SPAS XWE SOYOK MA SPAS X KO HNUXUK SBAL XC'UHT TONC YAKB YUUN TE ZK'UXUL SNUK' E. He was not able to eat, and he began to grow thin for the pain in his throat. HA HIC LIHK XCAMEL ABI. In this way his illness began. TONC LIHK Z'IN PURA YAAL TIIL LIHK MALMUNEL HONA. Afterwards he was spitting a lot of phlegm. MA X MAHK LIHK IPAHUK LXK. It didn't stop, it got worse. OC TA POXTAYEL WEHT YAHUL LA XPOXTA PURO MANBILIL POX LA YABE. They began to cure him. The curer used only medicines that were purchased. PERO MA TOHOL CAMELUK HA SAK OBAL I. But it was not a simple illness, it was tuberculosis. XOBEINAHE MA X LOK' HAL OBAL I. When he coughed the phlegm did not come up. HA HIC CAM HAL KEREM BONIPASY I. In this manner Bonifacio died. X K'OK TA POXTAYEL TA MUK'UL AKIL PERO MA HNA MAC'A TE POXTAWANEH MA TOHUB YUN YAHCAMEL E. He went to Pinola to cure himself. I don't know who it was that tried to cure him, but he failed. A LA PERSA CAM K'ALAL CAM E, BAYAL X K'OK SMUKEL. Inevitably, he died. Many went to his funeral. HA Z'IN ABI YA YAL SPISIL MAC'ATIK XK'OK TA MUKAHEL I, CIKAN AY MAC'A LAH HAK' HOL CAMEL I, PERO MA SPAS TA HALEL MAC'A LA YAK', TA REPENTA ME LA YABOTIK EHK E. And afterward, all those who went to the funeral said, “We know who caused the illness, but we can't say who did it, for he might quickly make us ill also.”

So, Bonifacio is reported to have been carousing with his friends for the course of an evening. The specific behaviors which are mentioned include: (a) making a party (in a bar) for one night. The specific features of the party-making include: (1) paying the barkeeper to play music over the loudspeaker system; and (2) announcing their names over this same loudspeaker system. While drinking is not mentioned in the text, it is none the less the case well confirmed by informants that it is unlikely that drinking did not go on in this setting.

The next day Bonifacio went to work. In a matter of weeks Bonifacio died of tuberculosis, an illness whose etiology carries a strong witchcraft component. The conclusion apparent in the text is that Bonifacio was subject to this witchcraft contamination the night of the party, a point which informants confirm.

The party context, then, is one which may make the individual particularly susceptible to witchcraft. One reason for this may be that the party-goer becomes drunk and is thus less well aware of potentially threatening performances around him. A second is that he is ingesting substances (like aguardiente) the precise character of which he does not know; they being brought to the party by his companions or bought at the bar. It is a standing belief that a witch can cause trago to accept poisonous material which will kill the man who drinks it. Thus Bonifacio was killed at the party, the method being unknown (but not unlikely by using aguardiente as a medium), the killer being unknown but probably a member of the party group.
A further example from text picks up a few more of the features of the drinking situation which is likely to be associated with witchcraft.

M. HINCA, CAWAH TA HOL. Yeah, I'm crazy in my head. C. HAL LA STIH TRAWO EHK I. The trago brought that on. M. HA MA KAYTIK BA YA KUC'TIK TUT'IL ULEMOTIK I. We lose track of where we are drinking when we are good and drunk. YUN HON MA KAYIX K'OP A, HAWAN LA HTAIX A HATE YUN KUXEBAL E. It's because I didn't obey; perhaps I got it during Holy Week. E LA KAK'HBA TA ILEL TA ORA, MANIX KAK' TA MUK' EHK ABI. I tried to cure myself right away but it didn't do any good. TONC YUN C'ABAL YA KAY TONC STUBI YUN LEK AN YA KAY TUL NIX AYINON A. I hear a lot of silence, and nothing is well with me as I have always been. LIHK KABE XAN Z'IN HAL YUN K'IN E, HUNYO E. I began to drink again in the fiesta in June. YUN TE LA SAPUYONIK XAN A TE MAC'A NIX YA YIL BIHINON A E. He bewitched me again, the same guy who had bothered me before. TE LA POHOL HIL HXANAB A, TE POHOL HIL HPOKO A, PERE MAY XC'ULEL HNUXUK. I left my sandals lying there, my flashlight lying there, I just didn't remember a thing. MA BA C'IN HPAS HAIC. This has never happened to me before. OCON K'OL TA HNA Z'IN TONC BOLBOLTIKIX HBA Z'IN A, TONC YANATIK TUTA KALIX A TO OCON K'OL E. I arrived in my house afterwards half crazy. I saw things wildly strange when I got there.

This informant relates the kind of association between his mental disturbance and the drinking of aguardiente. In this case, the disease did not stem directly from the aguardiente but from the experience he had while drinking the trago; namely that someone bewitched him. Having had the illness cured he began to drink again, which was a mistake since the witch knowing of his drunken condition, was able to cast the same spell on him again. Under this spell, his loss of consciousness was more penetrating than anything he had ever experienced as the result of drinking.

This informant reports that his ability to resist the witchcraft attack was greatly reduced while he was drinking. We speculate that such a loss of control involves the individual's loss of ability to control the alters with whom he associates, the locations he moves into, and the substances he drinks.
A more specific example of the introduction of witchcraft substances into the aguardiente can be found in the text fragment of Josefa Lopez, the relevant parts of which appear in the citation below.

NAL PRIMERE LA HTIKUN KAL TA RESAL. It began when I sent him to Rosary. LA KALBE BAN TA RESAL TATA, BAN AK'A AC'IN LIMXNA ZUNA AC'IN KANTELA XKUT. I told him, “Go to Rosary, my son, take a little candle as an offering.” KO XCI, BAHT Z'IN. “All right,” he said, then he went. LAH RESAL Z'IN LA STA SBA SOK XC'IN HOTAK BAHTIK TA IL K'IN. After the Rosary, he chanced on some of his friends and they went to watch the fiesta. YUN SK'IN METIK PASKO BA YILIK BA AN C'IN NINO TYOS TA SNA MIGUEL MENTES. It was the fiesta of Christ's birth and they went to see the Christ-child at the house of Miguel Mendez. BA YILIK HU AHK'OT I TE LA ABOTIK C'IN HPIS TRAWO A XCOLET LA TAL TE HP'IS TRAWE. They went to watch the dance, and there my son was given a shot of aguardiente along with all of the men as the drink pourer moved around the group. ABOT LA Z'IN EHUK PERO MALA KOK YUUN TA UC'EL. They gave him another but he was not able to drink it. LI LA MAHK HIL LITA SNUK I. It got stuck here in his throat. HUN LA TA C'INIK BAK IXIM K'ATAL HIL TA SNUK I. It seemed as though little grains of corn were stuck in his throat. LAH LA YOBENTA MALA XLOK. He coughed but it did not go away. HA Z'INABI K'OT YALBON ORA ILI LA HTAIX CAMEL. He came home and told me that he had just got sick. MAHNA TYN BON TA RESAL I LA SMONONIK TA IL K'IN HOL HOTAK I. “I don't know why, I went to Rosary and my friends invited me to watch the fiesta.” PERO LA YABONIK KUC' HPIS TRAWO PERO MA KO XCI HULEL TA HNA. “But they gave me a shot of trago and it didn't go down,” he said upon arriving home. MATO AK K'AHAL Z'IN A TUHXA TA CAMEL ABOT K'AHK'. Not many days afterwards he fell sick with fever. E HA Z'INABI K'AX HAL K'AHK' I, TONC MA HAHC LIHK K'UXUBUK SNUHKLEL. After the fever passed, he was unable to get up, his body began to ache. LIHK YAY XTILAHAN SNUHKLEL X HUN LA TA STIAW XANIC MALA XU TAN LA HA YAI. He began to feel pain in his body as though ants were biting him and this was very depressing. LIHK NIKOTUK TA SIK, MAYUK SPERSA YA YAI, TONC IPA HONA. He began to tremble with cold; he felt weak; he got very much worse. BA HK'AN PAWOR SOK HMEHTATIK. I went to ask assistance of the curers. LA KAK'TA PIKEL XC'IC'EL LA YAL Z'IN LA YUC' TRAWO TA BA XK' OK TA IL K'INE. I let them pulse him, and afterward [the curer] said, “He drank aguardiente where he went to the fiesta.” ABOT HPIS TRAWO YUC' XC'IN MAHTAN, PERO AY MA C'A ILOWAN LA SPAS IL OTAN O LA SPAS PUKUHIL. “They gave him a shot of aguardiente as a gift, but there was someone who looked evil or who did the evil thing.” HAHIC LA STA CAMEL C'IN KEREM I XCI. “That is how the boy became sick,” he said. HA C'OHBIL CAMEL I LOM TULAN AY MAXU TA HTUL YAHUL YA SK'AN CATUL YAHUL HA HIC SPAS TA POXTAYEL A XCI HAL HUL I. “This witchcraft is very strong, he won't get well with only one curer. He needs two curers to get well,” he said. OC TA POXTAYEL Z'IN PERO MAYUK HTAKIN A. The curer began to cure him, but I didn't have any money. HAWAL NUHUL LO'ON TA MAHAN TAK'IN YUN POX. I hurried to borrow money in order to buy the medicine. LAH TA POXTAYEL Z'IN, C'IN KALKALTIK TEK HIL. After the cure was over, he was a little better. PERO HA NAX CE OXE K'AHAL I LIHK LA KUXUBUK A YAY LITA SBE YIK I. But only for two or three days, and then began to feel the pain in his throat. MALA SPAS YA SBIK' YAL STI, MA SPAS XKO SWEEL KUXLAHA YAY HONA. He couldn't swallow his saliva, he couldn't swallow his food, it hurt so much. MAHNATIK TULA XBAHT, ME XCOHP O ME MA XCOHP. We don't know whether he is going to get well or not. A YAK'WIL TA TYOS TULA X BAHT E. We'll see what God says.

Many other informants relate having narrowly escaped witchcraft by avoiding drinking from some particular bottle of trago. If the man who is drinking is very much alive to this possibility, he will be able to observe swirling hair-like material in the bottom of the bottle or glass. In a recent instance of this, a bottle with this alleged character was broken and the man who offered it to be drunk was beaten up.

I have not been able to determine any other substance orally ingested by means of which illness can be sent to the drinker. This may be associated with the fact that the membership of the drinking group in Aguacatenango is least well defined and hence the one where enemies are most likely to be encountered. Likewise it is the one in which aggressive performances are most likely to occur. 1 This interpretation would have it that aguardiente becomes a physical medium by means of which the anger of the witch is transmitted to his target. Most aguardiente I have drunk has swirling hair in it; so foreign substance is not uncommon and thus available for potential interpretation. To restate the matter slightly, we may say: there is a language of aguardiente which depends upon the visual cues in examining the liquid. It is a one information bit language. The bit reads: If the aguardiente is clear when one is offered a drink, drink it and thank the drinker. If the aguardiente is “swirling-hairful,” and one is offered a drink, break the glass or bottle and beat the offerer up. One general performance the drink pourer engages in on most occasions I have observed is as follows: He pours the drink into the shot glass, then examines the liquid to see if it is clean or not. If it is not clean, he will attempt to clean it by picking out the foreign substance (sticks, leaves, hair, dirt, etc.). This cleaing response may be conditioned in part by the one bit language mentioned above. (See drinking performance of ayuntamiento where this has been mentioned before.)

Not only does aguardiente in some contexts serve as medium by means of which witchcraft can be communicated, but also it has a certain disease producing potential of its own when it is taken in certain amounts within a certain time period. (The ceremonial drinking plus one or more adjacent informal drinking units.) We will now review a few of the disease processes which are interpreted as beginning immediately adjacent to drinking performances. The most common illness that results from drinking is a state that may be glossed as a “hangover” /GOMA, XCAMEL YUUN TRAWO/. This is a minor illness which involves the symptoms of “headache, loss of appetite, dehydration, vomiting, diarrhea, trembling,” the response to which is selected from the following alternative set. The condition of GOMA is nearly exclusive with the ability to engage in routine agricultural performances. This means that the day after a ceremonial drinking plus informal drinking segment, a man does not work. He has the choice, then, of staying around the house or leaving the house to perform some minor tasks such as gathering poles to support chayote vines, looking at his cattle, or any other task that takes him out of the household setting. This is an important distinction since if a man stays around the house he increases the probability that he will continue drinking by some considerable degree. The confusion of setting with cure for GOMA is further reduced if we consider the specific remedies which are employed. Aguardiente is a “hot” substance. This “heat” causes the illness, and the illness can be reduced by drinking remedies which are “cool” or “cold.” Coca cola is such a remedy. A man may stay around the house and drink coca cola by way of reducing the GOMA. A second remedy for reducing a hangover is to drink as much as onehalf a pint of aguardiente. This is the Tzeltal equivalent to the “hair of the dog” response. Drinking a small amount of aguardiente and staying around the house are the two conditions which make it most likely that the man will continue drinking that day. Drinking coca cola and staying around the house make it slightly less likely that a man will drink on that day. Finally, drinking either aguardiente or coca cola and leaving the house to perform some minor task makes it less and less probable that a man will go on drinking that day. These observations are relevant to an interpretation of the cure for a hangover since they clearly include alternative plans for furth action which either produce further hangovers or do not. In other words, if one wishes to cure a hangover and go on drinkin he drinks aguardiente and stays in his house where his previous day's drinking companions will be sure to find him. If, on the other hand, one wishes to stop drinking, he will drink coca cola and leave the house.

Normally, a cure for a hangover, if it is not followed by more drinking, is successful in a one day time period. The length of a drinking performance can be computed as ceremonial drinking plus informal drinking plus one day. If some symptons of the hangover continue on successive days, or if the hangover has unusual symptoms, individuals are alerted to the fact that the drinking performance is about to cause more serious consequences. There follow some text fragments in which the more serious consequences are displayed and discussed by informants.

M. HA YA HK'AN HTAMTIK RASON TYL LIHK HATE X.HAL IK TA SBAKEL HTATA I. I want to ask the reason why my uncle's backache began. D. AX TA YOXEBAL HAWIL, ME TA XCANEBAL HAWIL HONC HATE LA STA E. It began about three or four years ago. PERE HUN TA TE ...TA K'AXIX ... TA XK'AXEL KUXEBAL YUN IP LEK YAKUB HONAX. It seems that . . . a while ago . . . it was just after Holy Week, because he drank so much. TONC BAZ'IL LAH YAK' HONC HATE HUN U MA BEN E. For one month he couldn't walk, he really had it. HUN LAH TA YUN XIHIL TE A YAY STUK TA YOK I. It was as though there was a splinter in his foot. YA YAK' HONC HUN K'AS YUN TONC YU'N HIC XKOTLAHAN YA X LOK' E. It hurt a lot. He had to crawl to go out. YUNEN TA TRAWO LA HTA XCI. Perhaps I got it from the trago,” he said. YUNEN POX YA SK'AN HONC YUN AK' TAK'IN E XCI. “Perhaps it needs medicine, if only there were some money,” he said. X TAL AWAY Z'IN E, LI LA XBAHT TA SBAKEL I. The next thing he knew, it was here in his back. WOKOL STUK IL TAT TONAX YUN SZ'IKOHONC HEHK STUK TUL TA ATEL I. It's not a little that he suffers, especially as he is now a mayordomo. M. MAYUK YA YAK' SBAH TA POXTAYEL. Isn't he being cured? HAYUN MAK XCOHP. That's why it's not getting better.

In this particular case, the illness being referred to had already lasted three or four years, according to the text. The association of drinking with the onset of this illness was strong enough, then, to be remembered by the sick man's wife after a period of years.
In the following text fragment, we see another example of this reasoning about the relationship between illness and drinking.

M. HA YA HLE HCAMEL YUN EHK YAKBEL I. I looked for my illness in a big drunk. LA KABE LEK. I drank a lot. YAN SOK MAK WAN XLIHK HIC MAK KUC'. It's bad, and it wouldn't begin if I didn't drink. HA HATE YUN MA HUNUK NAX K'AHAL YA KUC' EHK E. It's because I don't drink for only one day. YA YAC' HUN SEMNA HA YUN TONC TE.... I drink for a week, and that's the reason.... MAK XWEON SOK TAK HA YUN ... TRAWO KUXULOH A. I don't eat with it, that's way . . . I live on trago. HA YUN TE STIH HCAMEL Z'IN A. It's for this reason that the illness begins.

In this example, not only do we see evidence for associating drinking with illness, but we also observe the particular type of drinking which caused the illness, namely drinking which goes on for a week. An associated feature of the drinking that caused Mariano to become sick, and that in general is perceived to cause illness, is that drinking and eating are usually mutually exclusive.
In the following remarks of Cirilo Hernandez we see further evidence of the association of illness with drinking.

HIC MO TAXL K'AHAL E, TEMA LAHIX HMA TAT E. A few days ago, my father barely escaped dying. E K'UX C'UHTUL. It was stomach ache. HA BA YIC' TA K'OLAL YUN LA YUC' TRAWI. He got sick because he drank aguardiente. HUN U LA YUC'. He drank for a month. TONAX YUN HA AN EHK SMEL INAM I, TONAX HUN U SMIL SBA YUN TRAWO LII. His wife left him and he killed himself drinking for a whole month. TEMA LAH. He nearly died. E SLA YOTAN WAN. It was from bitter anger and shame. AHTAL OTAN HOLIL I, TEY YIHIX ILI, TEY TRAWO NAX TAK LOM NAHT' LA YABE TRAWI. On the one hand, it was from sadness; besides, he's already an old man, and he drank for a very long time. K'AHAL AHK' BAL, TONC AY TA STI HAL TRAWI XAHC TA SAK K'INAL YUC' XAHC TA SAK K'INAL YUC'. Night and day, all that went into his mouth was trago; he started drinking as soon as he got up. LA STOH LEK HONAX, K'O YAY HONC KUX HONC Z'IN I. He paid plenty for it, he felt the effects a lot, he suffered a lot afterward. KALBAT MA XAWUC'IX A K'A KAY AKOMEL, HA SNAEL TUT KAPAS ILI, XCUT. I told him, “Don't go on drinking so much, you feel so bad because of your drinking,” I said. Again, in a text fragment of Juan Mendez: J. LA IL HA YUN K'IN I, KUC' KAAL. And then I drank during the fiesta. K'AXAN K'IN NAXTAK I, HAL KABE XAN HUN TA KA XAN HUN TA CE XAN K'AHAL KABE XAN K'A XAN K'IN NAXTAK I, YUN MAYUNUK TRAWO STIHBON TAL MA IK' Z'IN I. After the fiesta, it seems to me that I drank for two days more. Don't you suppose that this rheumatism began because of the trago? M. YUN AY LOM K'UN HNUHKLELTIK A HAYUN ORA X TASWAN K'AHK' I. Sometimes our body gets very weak and then we are taken with fever. HTE NAX TEK MA AY BA HMAH HBAHTIK TA IK', K'IXNAHEM HNUHKLELTIK A E. If our body is just a little hot, rheumatism will hit us. [Note: Aguardiente is believed to “heat” the body.]

Aguardiente is illness-producing either directly because of its substance, or symbolically because it is one of the media by means of which a witch causes his victim to ingest poisonous substances. In turn, the drinking of aguardiente is interpreted as a disease process to the extent that individuals take “medicine” to reduce the number of occasions upon which they drink. The text citations which have been inserted above are suggestive of these points. By way of summing up this section, I would like to offer a less easily verifiable interpretation which provides still further context in terms of which the reader can think about the drinking performances in Aguacatenango. The first simple set of observations is as follows: Men drink and women don't. Some men drink more than others but all men must drink some. Some men would prefer to drink less than they do. Drinking settings for some men, especially under the informal drinking rules, are settings in which some considerable hostility is expressed. Suppose we take the case of the man who wishes to drink less. He can achieve this end in the short run by either drinking more or not drinking at all. He knows that he will not be able to completely terminate his drinking performances (the ceremonial drinking performances) until he is an old man. Ceremonial drinking performances are required of all men. He can, however, reduce the number of informal drinking performances. If a man wants to reduce the number of informal drinking performances, then, he can do so by increasing the average length of any particular informal drinking performance. Increasing the length of an informal drinking performance increases the probability that the individual will become ill (as well as exhaust all his resources, anger the members of his household, and so on). Upon the next occasion when some individual invites him to start an informal drinking performance, he can respond by saying, “I am afraid to start an informal drinking performance with you since my style of informal drinking performance results for me in severe illness, alienates my family, causes economic catastrophe to my household.” The person inviting must allow that this is true, in view of the fact that he observed ego engaging in such extended performances within the past year, say. On the other hand, an individual can stop engaging in informal drinking performances by reporting that he has taken medicine for drinking, which medicine will cause his death if he drinks. It is not unusual for a man to take medicine and then become very sick by way of telling the community that it was real medicine with strong disease producing effects. If a man goes on drinking in the informal drinking after he has taken the medicine, it is proof that the medicine did not have the desired effect. The common feature of either response to the desire to reduce amount of drinking: increasing the length of the informal drinking performances or taking medicine puts the individual in that context which allows him to say, “If I drink I will die.” We believe that it is only by citing such severe effects as this that an individual can, over the long run, control his response to the invitation to drink. 1 In the short run, a man can avoid any particular, highly probable informal drinking performance by leaving the field, as was suggested above. That is, by knowing which days informal drinking performances are more likely to occur on than other days (the ten day time zone around some major fiesta, or Sundays, for example), he can arrange to be “away on business.”

Some men prefer to drink more in the informal drinking performances than do most men. These men can increase number and length of informal drinking performances by seeking out the existing informal drinking groups on any particular day. The rule is that anyone may join any informal drinking group at the beginning of an informal drinking performance if, and only if, he can contribute a proportional amount of the aguardiente which is being drunk. It is the case that as an informal drinking group approaches deep drunkenness, it becomes easier for any man to join the informal drinking group without paying his proportional share of the drinking expenses.

It appears to be the case, then, that individuals must get sick in order to reduce their number of informal drinking performances. Individuals also may get sick as the result of drinking under any circumstances. Long informal drinking performances allow individuals to behave as though they were experiencing strong aversive physical effects. It is likely that individuals who wish to reduce the number of informal drinking performances manipulate the informal drinking segment length, because of standing beliefs about the relationship between drinking and illness. The only way a man can get out of his social obligations is to place himself in the special condition of being particularly prone to illness. Procedures for inducing illness are then likely to become strategies in controlling participation in informal drinking performances.

Nevertheless, a wealthy man brings upon himself the antagonism of the other villagers, who, in search of a scapegoat during times of stress (such as a village epidemic) would not hesitate to accuse the rich man of being responsible for bringint the misfortune to the town because of his evil spirit, nor hesitate to kill him. Even if people find a man has a good crop, somebody can assume that, because his own crop failed, the other man has “stolen” the soul of his corn or if a man receives a large inheritance, somebody could accuse him of having killed (by witchcraft) the relative from who he inherited it. It takes a good deal of diplomatic skill and a strong control of the sources of gossip to manage to keep oneself clear of such accusations. On the other hand, villagers are afraid of showing excessive wealth (according to community standards) unless they bring upon themselves the other face of witchcraft: supernatural sickness produced by envy. Even a man in good standing, if he has too many goods or money, may fear witchcraft because he “knows” that he is a good target for the envy of those who, possessing powerful and evil souls ( nahuales ), decide to bewitch him and make him sick or kill his children or ruin his next crop.

One result of this set of beliefs is that the etiology of disease is thought of as being supernatural. Other misfortunes are also explained in metaphysical terms. Sickness is always present in the village, misfortunes do occur which cannot be predicted, and the villager “experiences,” then, the effects of witchcraft in everyday life.

The concept of tener su compañía runs throughout all activity, at all ages. Having company means protection from the supernatural on a long trip, help around the house, harmonious social relations with age mates and kinsmen, and insurance against loneliness. Older women who are left alone in a house for several days will “borrow” a younger girl, a son's daughter for example, to keep them company, and a young wife going to market or to get firewood is usually expected to find company to do so. If not, she can well meet a strange man on the road, and get sick from verguenza (sickness assumed to originate from shame at being placed in an anomalous or embarrassing social situation) or espanto (fear and soul loss).

Even more significant is the house ritual connected with the sickness of a person who lives in it. It is significant because sickness is considered a supernatural expression of disturbed social relations, and this is considered disruptive, not only for the people who inhabit a single dwelling, but also for the building which symbolizes their common residence and interests. As long as the relations of people living in a house are harmonious, the house is kept contented. But if this is not so, both the people and the building have to be ritually cleaned. For example, if a daughter disobeys her mother, she is considered to be suffering from bilis or cólico , and in need of curing. During the curing ceremony, the sick misbehaver has to be instructed about her duties as a good daughter, and is given a speech apropos the misdemeanor. The curing ceremony is not completed if the house is not ritually cured, too. This is done by a curer offering the building some trago , the local brew, asking it to be contented. This offering is then symbolic of both the re-establishment of normal social relations between the individuals living in the house, and between the individuals and their materials projection, their house.

Because of the ever present possibility of losing the foetus, the expectant mother will pray and sometimes fast in an effort to prevent spirit flight or other misfortunes. She may pray every week or as infrequently as every other month, calling on me?tik kaseltik (the earth-mother), me?tiktatik , and a host of saint-deities associated with the native “church”, and seeking their aid in assuring a safe, sure delivery of the child. Prayers are also said to ward off evil influences resulting from the envy of others and from accidental transgressions of prenatal taboos. In addition the expectant mother or a close female relative will pray that the child won't come out to be a stutterer, a thief, harelipped, a drunkard, or with some other negatively valued attribute. Prayers can be made on any day but Monday, which is a foreboding and potentially evil day. Nobody in Tenejapa prays on Monday for any reason.

When the baby drops, the mother shifts to the side and some other woman picks up the child for the new mother is generally too weak. The mother then goes and sits on a chair near the fire and is handed the baby to hold in her arms. She spreads her legs facing the fire to hasten the expulsion of the afterbirth. When this occurs a thread is used to tie the cord close to the baby's stomach. Then the measure of the distance between an outstretched thumb and the middle finger (a hoht ) is applied to the umbilical cord that has been tied. The cord is then cut at this distance, about six inches, from the thread. If the cord is cut short, then when the baby grows up it won't be able to shout very loud, an ability that is important for shouting communications across valleys, on the trail, and between houses. The afterbirth and what remains of the cord are put in the ashes next to the flames of the roaring fire and having dried a little are burnt. If it were not burnt up then the child would be subject to stomach aches throughout its life.

Once the baby has been dressed, the little white core in the center of a chili pepper ( yat ?ic ) is rubbed softly on its lips.
