For rheumatic pains in the muscles one makes use of massage, which is practiced by the women, or one makes poultices with the pulp of the pulverized root of o'remit ( Salvadora persica ), which also finds use otherwise as a “mustard plaster.” Married men have themselves massages by their wives to get rid of pains in the leg muscles after long marches, whereas the warriors scorn this help as unmanly. Furthermore one administers a root decoction, preferably mixed with a broth from steer meat, of o'rarait ( Cissus rotundifolia [Forsk.] Vahl.) or of ol iogi ono ( Pentas zanzibarica [Kl.] Vtke.), or also a decoction of the wood of ol gonj el ( Rhamnus prinoides l'Herit.). For rheumatic pains in the back one drinks a root decoction, sweetened with honey, of ol asasia l os subertai ( Osyris tenuifolia Engl.). To cure articular rheumatism a root decoction of ol og ino ( Boerhavia diffusa L.) is administered. Besides these remedies, those that are regarded as diaphoretic, especially the above-mentioned ol amb oschi ( Momordica cardiospermoides Kl.) and e ng aitetoijai kete ( Aneilema Johnstonii K. Sch.), are also given.

As payment for help rendered, the ol abani receives, according to the difficulty of the case or the amount of work done by him, a head of livestock, from a head of cattle down to a young goat or a lamb. One should also mention the remarkable arrangement that he can make a claim regarding the payment only if his treatment has had the desired result, and the patient 188 need not pay before the resulting complete cure. An established custom determines what falls in the department of the surgeon. The ol abani stays within these prescribed limits under all circumstances. If this is not conducive to progress, it has the result, on the other hand, that every Masai, when necessary, entrusts himself immediately to the surgeon without hesitation. He knows that the latter will not under-take an operation on him which he cannot safely perform, but rather that whatever he does, he has often seen and has done with an older colleague or alone. No narcotic agents are available to the surgeon, but his patients have command over very “strong nerves,” over an enviable mental sturdiness.
The juice of ol giloriti ( Acacia abyssinica ), chewed out and spat into the wound, and the charcoal powder of ol du ngui bark ( Harrisonia abyssinica Oliv.) are used as astringent remedies .

Arteries have ligatures applied, if necessary, and, to be sure, by means of a leather strap placed around the limb, which is tightened by a short stick. The cut ends of the artery are then sewed together as quickly as possible with awl and tendon cord, after they 188 cont. have been grasped with the fingernails and pulled forward.

To the surgeon's department belongs first of all the extraction of teeth . This is done by three different methods. To remove the lower middle incisors, which among children is done for the first time at an early age and is then repeated after the change of teeth, one sticks the thin iron blade of an ax between the teeth and levers them out while tapping moderately hard laterally several times with a stick against the blade. The other front teeth are taken out only when they are already quite loose. One ties a string of cattle tendon around the crown of the tooth and a fist-sized stone at the other end of it. When this is done, the operator, for a very loose tooth, simply lets the stone fall, or, with one resting more firmly, throws it down. To remove a molar, one places a little stick almost finger-thick and approximately 20 centimeters long, with its lower end, notched swallowtail-like, against the tooth, and, to be sure, from inside, at right angles to the dental arch and then directs several vigorous blows against the free end of the stick. An assistant holds the patient's head. Tooth operations, with the exception of the ritual ones of course, are very rare. Among 100 men between the ages of 20 and 30 the author found two who each had a tooth gap. One had had a molar knocked out in the manner just described, the other had lost a front tooth through being butted by a head of cattle.

Abcesses , when they are ripe, are punctured with a small, pointed, double-edged knife and cut open only after the draining of the pus by pressure. Then the wound is washed out with tepid water and cleaned out, using the nail of the index finger, as well as possibly also the aforementioned knife, as a sharp spoon. Finally, one sprinkles on it a caustic powder made from the root of ol gneriandus l en doje ( Plumbago ceylonica ). The surgeon does not apply a bandage.
Abcesses of the mammary gland are merely punctured and emptied.
With panaritium the nail is removed and the wound washed out.
Suppurating lymph glands ( ol gnarnari eti n gimek ) are treated like abcesses, but the lymph gland is cut out before the application of the caustic powder.

An ailment called ol dododoi l en daré = goat ulcers 1 This is most probably a matter of anthrax carbuncle. by the Masai manifests itself in that the person afflicted has one, less frequently two, hard lumps the size of a hazelnut under the skin, tapering into a taillike point at the bottom. I saw these ulcers ( em boroi ) and their scars -- somewhat larger than a mark piece -- on the temples, on the chest, on arms, legs, and on buttocks. As the original cause the people cite the eating of meat of goats or sheep that died of e ng ea nairogua = hot sickness 2 Pulmonary anthrax. . 189 cont. The hard lumps are cut out. During the illness the patient is given a diet of meat roasted on charcoal and, as medicine, a decoction of the roots of ol demellua 190 ( Solanum setaceum ) or ol oki with the addition of honey; a root decoction of e n g ogi ( Lycium cf. arabicum Schweinfurth) mixed with milk or meat broth or such of ol amel oki ( Maerua Johannis Vlks. et Gilg), which, as a rule, is mixed with a little honey or fresh livestock-blood, is also regarded as curative. The patient drinks this liquid when he is thirsty. The illness is supposed to lead to death if this diet is not adhered to and the patient takes in particular cold water or milk, as well as cooked meat. On the other hand, if the prescribed way of life is observed for two or three months, the lump, gradually pushing outwards, is said to fall off. Since, however, the continuous meat diet is too expensive and the herb medicines cannot be obtained without difficulty, the operation is preferred in by far the most cases.

A persistent fever connected with swelling of the three pharyngeal tonsils , accompanied by violent coughing and considerable loss of strength, especially common in youthful age, the Masai call ert el muli = gland sickness. Very probably it is a matter of adenoidal proud flesh in the nasopharyngeal cavity. The patient turns to the surgeon to be cured. The latter, putting his hand into the patient's mouth, scrapes the pharyngeal tonsils with the nail of his index finger, or with a small knife, so strongly that they bleed profusely. A rather large number of people whom I questioned about the success of the cure asserted that they always could count on certain recovery. Two of my boys, Masai youths about 11 to 12 years old, fell ill with the above symptoms. In spite of careful symptomatic treatment, their recovery of strength was so unsatisfactory that, upon their request, I gave them permission to go to a nearby livestock-kraal in the steppe for relief. After eight to fourteen days they returned, healthy and refreshed, and told me, which corresponds to the truth, that the surgeon had treated them in the manner described.

Fresh, simple wounds ( en du noto, n dungot ) are cleaned as was described above for the ulcers, but during this one tries to avoid unnecessary irritation, for fear of greater bleeding. On this account, many surgeons do not proceed with treating the wound until several 190 cont. hours after the wounding. After careful cleaning, the wound is closed by the twined-around suture. The edges of the wound, fitted together, are lifted slightly, as though into a fold, with two fingers of the left hand, whereupon the pointed awl is quickly thrust through the two edges of the wound in such a way that the puncture openings in and out are the same distance from the edge of the wound. Then the awl is drawn out again and in its place is inserted a needle-shaped thorn of ol debbe ( Acacia Merkeri ), ol debessi ( Acacia verrugera ), or ol giloriti ( Acacia abyssinica ). Under the projecting thorn ends a cord twisted out of cattle tendons is led around in a circle in several windings; then the cord ends are knotted 191 and cut off a short distance above the knot. The individual needles are not placed closer than four centimeters apart, so that the pus can drain out between them unhindered. A fresh wound that seems insignificant for making a suture is covered with a paste, which consists of the scraped meat of the fruit ol darboi ( Kigelia aethiopica ), or with the leaf of o' rarait ( Cissus rotundifolia [Forsk.] Vahl.). One also drips the juice of ol dorotua , of ol aisegerai kitok ( Heliotropium Steudneri Vtke.) or of ol aisegerai l e n gare ( Verbena officinalis L.) into the wound.
On the edges of small children's nostrils that have been eaten raw by flies the mother puts a paste of chewed plants of e n gilo no or ekum ( Spilanthus Acmella L.).

For penetrating wounds ( e remoto, e remot ), only the larger of the two openings is sewed up, which, since it is always a matter of spear or sword thrusts, is the thrust-entry opening. If this lies considerably higher than the thrust-exit one, the needles are placed closer than previously; if it lies equally high or lower, what was said above holds. Torn ear-lobes are sewed together like the wounds.

Old wounds ( em bald aga, m baldagani ) that will not heal are burned out with a knife made red-hot and then closed with a cooked and heavily thickened paste made out of water and the sifted earth of a termite hill placed on them. The so-called leg ulcers ( em bald aga ) are first burned out in the same manner. Then one pastes around the wound a border of cow dung a centimeter high, so that the wound itself forms the bottom of a bowl, and finally pours into it boiling sheep fat. For healing burns they are covered with a thick 191 cont. paste of the pounded leaves of a climbing species of asparagus ( em b ere e baba ). The taking of an extract of the root and bark of ol gelai mixed with cattle blood and milk is regarded as beneficial for the healing of suppurating wounds. The decoction of the wood of a Rhus species ( ol mesigi:e kete ) is supposed to have a similar effect, in that taking it “makes the wound dry.”

Sand fleas 1 The sand flea was brought into the Masai region in 1897 from Uganda, In June, 1897, it reached Kilimandscharo. , the females of which in particular eat into the soft skin parts of the feet, are removed as soon as they manifest themselves by an itching pressure resulting from their egg-swollen bodies. By means of a sharp scratch with a long acacia thorn, one pierces the layer of skin, usually only quite thin, lying over the sand flea 2 Here M. is mistaken; The tip of the rear abdomen of the female sand flea juts out into the open, without any skin covering. The Ed. Dr. S. and then squeezes it out by lateral pressure. During this one is careful to avoid injuring the animal, so that healing will not be delayed.

192 For snake bite ( a-tonjo 'l assurai ) one thoroughly squeezes out the hastily ligated wound, around which one has also made a number of punctures with the sharp thorns of ol gurschaschi ( Barleria mucronata ) and then cauterizes it with a red-hot iron wire. At the same time the root of ol asajet is chewed, whereupon vomiting follows. This method, however, is customary only if the one bitten is unable to reach a surgeon. Otherwise one has the ol abani fetched immediately and, until his arrival, burns out the immediately ligated wound several times. Swellings of the lymph glands that may occur are also cauterized. If the ol abani regards the bite as only slightly poisonous, he enlarges it by means of a few incisions and sucks it out vigorously. But if he regards it as dangerous to life, he cuts out around the bitten spot a piece of muscle from the size of a nut to 192 cont. that of an egg or even amputates the member (hand, finger, toe), if this seems to him absolutely necessary. After the operation the patient is given raw sheep kidney to eat and a considerable amount of liquid sheep fat to drink, whereupon severe diarrhea soon sets in. Often one has him go through a sweat cure in that he is set over glowing charcoal on which leaves of Barleria mucronata and sheep hair are thrown.

On a scorpion sting ( a-tonjo e n gol owa ) one has a woman who has given birth to twins or, lacking such, a pregnant woman spit and rubs the saliva over the painful spot. As long as the pain continues, the patient eats only raw goat liver, to which is ascribed some kind of marvelous effect -- as is also shown by the fact that it is the only solid food of the ol oiboni .

Into the wound caused by a poisoned arrow another person urinates as quickly as possible. At the same time the wounded one is given as an emetic a mixture of the juice of the fruit of en dulele ( Solanum campylacanthum ) and the amniotic fluid ( e n g eba ) of a gravid sheep, which is slaughtered for this purpose.

The surgeon removes the remains of a violently destroyed eye , by drawing it out of the eye socket, with an awl bent hook-shaped, far enough so that he can cut it off with the razor. The eye socket is then washed out with warm water and not bandaged afterwards.

A place that has suffered a sprain or bruise the El dor obo rub with the juice of ol g er ig us ( Iatropha spec.). Sometimes they also apply the same drug by the method of rubbing the powder of the charred twigs into small incisions that are made on that place.

193 Dislocated limbs are set again and placed in a splint bandage that is not stiff. For a lower-arm dislocation the surgeon sits on the ground in front of the patient, grasps his lower arm just above the wrist, and sets it again by a gradually stronger pulling exerted in the required direction. He then puts around the affected part, from the middle of the lower arm to that of the upper arm, which are drawn together at an angle of 135°, a padded bandage consisting of a strip of sheep leather that is covered with as much thick and soft hair as possible. The padded bandage is tied with a 193 cont. narrow leather strap around it. Over this is put a second, stiffer bandage of dehaired neat's leather tied around like the first one. Finally, one fastens on the bandage, on both the inner and outer sides, a correspondingly bent wooden splint, with leather straps as before. The wooden splints are splinter-like and are only supposed to support the arm, not to stiffen it. The arm is tied up, in that one carries it in a sling put around the neck. The bandage is left on for about a month. The procedure is similar for other dislocations. A dislocated finger is not put in a splint. To set the lower extremities the patient lies flat on the ground.

For a bone fracture the surgeon investigates first the location and kind of fracture. With one or two bones lying together with a simple fracture, extension and counter-extension are done, as among us, by two assistants, while the surgeon takes care of the setting. Then he puts on the padded bandage and, on that, two flat, but firm splints, before he fastens the upper bandage of hard neat's skin with leather straps. For an arm fracture the bandage is left on for two months; for a leg fracture, longer. After an arm fracture is healed, the surgeon has the patient lift stones, at first light ones, then heavier ones, to strengthen the arm.

On the other hand, if the surgeon determines by contact that a bone of the lower arm or lower leg is badly crushed , he cuts the limb concerned open lengthwise on the outside as far as is necessary for the removal of the individual bone splinters. When these have been taken out, the arm is sewed up again with the bound-around suture. “Such operations are always successful, but it is more difficult with a crushing of the upper-arm or thigh bone; then one never knows whether one will be able to keep the arm or the leg.” This is approximately how a surgeon standing in especially high repute expressed himself to me. Further statements of his revealed that this is far more frequently a matter of compound fractures . If the ol abani comes across such a case, he removes the bone splinters as before and, after he has put the tendons and muscles in order as much as possible, sews up the wound again. If, after eight to ten days, the fracture shows no tendency to heal and the patient suffers from fever, the surgeon proceeds to amputate.

There might be described here a successful operation performed by the aforementioned ol abani: In November, 1901, a boy fractured the right tibia quite close to the knee and, soon after the accident, was carried by his friends to a European settlement several hours away. There they asked the European for his help, but he did not dare undertake the treatment and ordered the people to take the patient to the hospital of the military station of Moschi. Now whether the patient or his bearers did not agree with the plan to embark on a two-day journey is beside the point; in any case, the patient, on the following day, was brought to a rather large livestock-kraal to which the aforementioned surgeon, who, incidentally, lived six hours away, was fetched. He found a large, suppurating wound, out of which the lower end of the tibia projected, the marrow of which was likewise suppurating. The ol abani , proceeding from the wound, now cut open the lower leg on the tibia up to a handbreadth above the ankle and peeled out the lower end of the bone equally far. Then he broke this off about ten centimeters above the lower joint, removed the putrefying marrow from the rest of the tibia, cleaned the wound with warm water and by scraping out the upper part of it, and sewed it up with five thorns. Three months later the boy was already able to walk and to resume his work as herdsman.

Of foreign bodies one finds in wounds arrow points most frequently. Taking them out, is certainly more difficult than to take out other foreign bodies, and it will therefore suffice to discuss the method used for this, since those for the removal of more harmless objects will follow from that. First of all, it leads to an operation, of course, only if -- which is seldom the case -- the arrow is not poisoned or if -- which fortunately often occurs -- the poison has become ineffective through decomposition. Since in battle the torso as a rule is protected by shield and beside the leather cape also often deflects the arrow or at any rate greatly diminishes its force, deeper arrow wounds usually occur occur only on the extremities. If the entire arrow remains stuck in the wound, the operator knows immediately, without a lengthy examination, where the point rests and how it lies. If there are only muscles lying in front of the point in the direction of the shot, he quickly pushes the arrow through and draws out point and tang on the other side, the shaft on the shot-entry side. On the other hand, if bones lie in front of the arrow point, this method is automatically eliminated. Simply pulling out the arrow through the shot-entry 194 cont. opening is, however, impossible because of the barbs. The surgeon now has two methods. Which one he will employ depends upon the individual case. He either twists the arrow around in the wound until the barbs have become so filled and coated with muscle fibers that they are no longer 195 able to offer resistance to a pull backwards, or he treats the arrow like a broken-off one, for which he has the following ways of operating. The point palpable by contact from the outside is removed in such a manner that one makes on the shortest path between it and the skin an incision as wide as is necessary in order to permit drawing it through. Since no forceps are at the disposal of the operator, but rather he must grasp with his fingers the arrow point to be removed, the incision must be quite large. A hidden point is sought in the following manner: the surgeon inserts his finger into the shot-entry channel and cuts through at the end of the fingertips from the outside inward, then sticks his finger into this opening and gropes farther into the shot channel, in order to make a second incision where his fingertip now lies. It goes on in this manner until he has reached the arrow point with his finger. If only muscles now lie in front of it, it is pushed forward with the finger in the direction of the shot, until it emerges. If a bone blocks this path, however, the operator either forces the arrow point away from its direction and toward the outside, or he cuts toward the arrow point from the outside in order, as described above, to remove it by way of this new channel.

An arrow point that penetrated into the abdominal cavity from the front is removed by an operation, although, according to statements of the surgeons, the prognosis is unfavorable. The case is more hopeful, on the other hand, if the arrow point penetrated into the abdominal cavity from the back and thereby has already encountered considerable resistance in the strong back muscles. In any case, an attempt to give relief by means of an operation is always made. The surgeon, with his finger, follows the shot-channel, for which this is often enlarged to an extraordinary extent with the knife, until he feels the point. The operation, of course, is most extensive when the arrow point is lodged in the stomach or in an intestine. After he has then drawn it out with his finger, he sutures the cut 195 cont. stomach or intestine with tendon cord and awl, then the inner and finally the outer wound-edges of the enlarged shot-entry opening. An arrow point that has penetrated into the lungs is taken out in a similar manner.

Spear thrusts in the abdomen are not uncommon in war. One or several intestinal coils are probably always injured by this. Moreover, a more or less large bundle of intestines always wells out from the thrust-entry opening and thus is exposed to the greatest soiling. Against the latter, one proceeds with the general lack of consideration in that a few companions of the wounded man wash the soiled intestinal parts with cold water at the nearest brook. In a cloth -- unclean -- attached around the neck at the top, around the hip strap at the bottom, the patient carries the welling-out intestines to the nearest dressing station. The surgeon then first sews up the intestinal tears with tendon cord and awl, then washes the intestine with warmed water, and then stuffs it through the thrust-entry opening back into the abdominal 196 cavity. After that he sews up the outer wound-edges of the abdominal covering with the twined-around suture.

The newborn child is cleaned by a rubbing with liquid fat. According to statements of the people, this treatment, however, is supposed to represent not so much a cleaning as a strengthening and comfort. Then the child is laid beside its mother on a soft leather skin freshly greased. As soon as the latter has recovered from the birth act, she chews four grains of ol odoa ( Maesa lanceolata ) and gives the child an extract of these as a purgative. On the following day the newborn child is given its first bath, consisting of a tepid extract of the twigs of e n gairetuai ( Physalis minima L.) and the stalks of e ng aitetoijai ( Commelina spec.), to which is ascribed the action of a protective magic against sickness. Cold baths, say, for the purpose of hardening, are unknown. The child remains unclothed.

One of the most frequent supplication feasts ( ol og or = the supplication feast) is the ol ogor l ol geretti , which during some periods and in some regions is celebrated almost every month, in others at considerably greater intervals, by the married men and the boys together, in order to supplicate God for the preservation of the health of human beings and livestock. In the kraal a large fire is kindled with dry wood (from the ol oirien tree), upon which green wood with leaves (from the os segi tree) 1 Cordia quarensis Gürke. is tossed, so that a strong development of smoke comes about. A powder made from the wood and bark of the ol mogo ngora liana, which smells like incense, is sprinkled in the fire. The thick column of smoke climbs toward the sky and takes the fragrance to God. Now one leads up a large black ram, washes it carefully with honey beer, and sprinkles it with the powder of the e mata nguju tree. Then it is suffocated, drawn, and cut up. 209 Each of the 209 cont. participants eats a small piece of the meat, after he has roasted it in the ashes. Furthermore he is given a strip of the skin, from which he then fashions amulet rings, one for himself, the others for his relatives. The ring protects the wearer from sicknesses of every kind. Men wear it on the right middle finger, women wear it on the large spiral-shaped neck ornament of iron wire. During the feast the participants constantly sing:

If a person brings misfortune, illness, or death to another through sorcery ( es s et an ), this is merely the effect of a power inherent in the magic medicine, which is based on the composition of the medicine and is effective through the recitation of certain formulas and the execution of special gestures. The aforementioned amulet ring ( ol geretti ) protects one against the effect of magic made by another Masai. Women who go into the neighboring areas of foreign tribes to buy vegetables especially protect themselves from their sorcery. They smear their foreheads and cheeks with cattle dung or wear around their necks a cord on which are strung small, split sticks. Other amulets that I found contained, sewed in leather, a mixture of plant powder (from wood, 211 roots, barks), after which they are named, and a secret medicine of the ol goiatiki , who alone is able to prepare the whole in such a way that it is effective. The legumojig amulet is worn by women around their necks and is regarded as prompting conception. We have become acquainted with another remedy prized by the women barren up to then in connection with the boys' e n geb ata feast. The e n goguroi is tied around the ankle and protects one from ailments of the legs. The ol durgeï is worn by warriors around the neck or wrist for protection against sorcery. In hand-to-hand combat the powder contained in it is also scattered toward the enemy, whereupon the latter is supposed to be forced to give up his resistance. The en jorré protects the husband from the anger of his wife when he has committed some folly, for example, has gone beyond the customary limits on 211 cont. amatory adventures. The powder also serves as love magic, in that the woman sprinkles herself and the man with it, through which his love for her is heightened. If a woman loses her first child soon after birth, she hangs in the doorway of her hut during her next pregnancy an amulet that consists of a few cowrie shells sewed on a small piece of leather and a little bag, made by the ol goiatiki , containing sawdust to protect the expected child from sickness and death. The plants preferred by the ol goiatiki for the manufacture of his magic medicines are: en gaitetojai ( Commelina Merkeri K. Sch.), ol kioge (Courbonia virgata), en gujene (Cyathula Merkeri Gilg), ol assassiai (Osyris tenuifolia), os segi (Cordia quarensis), ol debbe ( Acacia Merkeri Harms), en gadardar (Ochna Merkeri Gilg).

Only in rainy weather do they bring the things into the kraal and keep them there in the hut of an old woman who herself, in their view, can no longer come into consideration in the above respect. They even make themselves responsible, relative to the intensity of the sexual intercourse, for the slow dying of the animal struck by the poisoned arrow. The poison is smeared on the arrow point with a wooden spatula, and, in order to protect the dried substance from crumbling or from dissolving in damp weather (since it is very hygroscopic), it is wrapped with a strip of thin antelope skin that is dehaired and made soft by being rubbed with fat. The poison acts very quickly, and, to be sure, by suddenly stopping the heart activity. In the case of a genet shot in the abdomen, breathing difficulty set in after five minutes, along with rapid movements of the nostrils and violent, cramplike muscle twitchings of the body and limbs. With brief interruptions of a quarter to a third of a minute the symptoms were repeated and increased in intensity. The pupils dilated to a circle. Nine minutes and 18 seconds after the shot the pupils, up to then blue-black, suddenly became sea-green, and, with violent twitching, death came. With quite fresh poison death is supposed to come in even a shorter time. In the steppe the poison is tested by shooting an antelope with an arrow newly poisoned. If on the trail of the fleeing animal one finds fresh urine and excrement, teh poison is regarded as acting too weakly. Good poison put in the foot of a live turtle must lead to its death before it has crawled five or six steps away. Neither the Asa nor the Wandorobo are acquainted with a physiological anecdote. For smaller, simple, and penetrating flesh wounds immediate washing with fresh urine is supposed to help. Aged Wandorobo often showed me scars on their own bodies, especially on arms and legs, which are supposed to have been caused by shots with poisoned arrows two to four centimeters deep. Both the appearance of the scars and the corresponding statements of people, which were separated in time and place from the former, corroborate this information.

For illnesses the Wandor obo use the same medicines as the Masai and also prepare them in corresponding fashion. Those medicaments that the latter take mixed with milk or blood, the former mix only with water or game bouillon. The Wandorobo are also familiar with the nerve-stimulating agents taken so much by the Masai warriors, but they do not use them in such extensive measure and never in such quantities that fits of rage appear among them. Their designations for the principal illnesses are the following: Headache = sogog ag ema = sick head; toothache = ligá agema = sick tooth; cough, ohotu or ahotu ; chest pain, liba agema = sick chest; stomach-ache = waia agema = sick stomach; diarrhea, waia katidji , constipation, waia gischu ngurgue ; dysentery allegedly is not supposed to occur. Smallpox, ol maschuggu or aj og ; chickenpox, simir eg . Gonorrheas, dam og ; lues, en ebitiro . Elephantiasis, as well as E. scroti , is said not to occur. Fever, kaësegomo ; bilious fever, ol odoa . Taeniae, pinib eg ; ascarids, menána . Injured blood vessels are ligated, bone fractures splinted. On burns one puts the soft, plushlike covering of the roots of the ol dungui bush. Excess fingers and toes are not amputated; they are not regarded as particularly unsightly.
151. ol eg is ik on (Cissampelos Pareira L.). Pieces of root are worn as amulets, mostly on the neck ring, for all possible illnesses, and, to be sure, both to prevent them and to cure them.
202. e n g er ig us (Jatropha spec.). On bruises or sprains the El dor obo make incisions and drip into these the juice or rub in a powder of the charred twigs of the plant.

210. e n g il oil o (Pterolobium lacerans R. Br.). Secret medicine of the ol oiboni . He makes an amulet out of the powder of various parts of the plant, which is supposed to protect one against all kinds of illnesses.
266. e ng ischo ng a . From the plant the ol oiboni makes an amulet against fever.
293. ol legemojik l os soito (Actinopteris radiata Link). From the root the ol oiboni makes an amulet against all kinds of sickness.
328. 'mta nguju (Maerua rigida Oliv.). From the powdered root the ol oiboni makes an amulet that is supposed to protect one against colds and fever.
452. os sinande . Secret medicine of the ol oiboni ; ingredient of amulets that are supposed to protect one against wounds, sickness, and accidents.

M-bwat. | The extraction of teeth. N eji en-d oki naji em-bwata, naa 'l-ala aare eitauni li-abori. | The extraction of teeth. There is something called em-bwata, which means the extracting of the two middle incisors of the lower jaw. Neitauni te-'ng-alem. | A knife is used with which to perform the operation. Eisho 'l-Maasae: nebwa 'n-gera enye kat'-are. Ten e ini en-gerai, pe ebaya 'l-a païtin isyet, etubulutua 'l-ala pôkin, nebwai. Netonii. | The Masai extract their children's two middle teeth twice. They extract them first of all when the child is about eight months old, and all its teeth have grown. Then they wait. Ne pwo'l-ala pôkin, neiñgwari 'l-opa-ootubulutua. Ore p' eit oki aabulu 'l-ala pôkin, nebaya en-gerai anaa en-oo-'l-arin tomon o aare, nebwai em-bwata e-kitoo, nemeit oki aabulu. | After the child has lost all its milk teeth and obtained the permanent set, i. e. when it is about twelve years old, the teeth are extracted a second time, and never grow again. Ore p' eidi p aat obwa engerai, nesirieki eng-omom il-mur loo-'sirkon, n eji: ‘I'r obija.’ | When a child has had its teeth extracted, donkey's dung is put on its face in order to cool it. Ore opa p' eiteruaki aabwa 'l-tuñganak eji, pe ten emweiyu ol-tuñgani, p' eitere, neony il-ala, neimyeki eng-are innabwata nat obwaki opa. | The origin of this custom of extracting teeth was to enable people, in the event of a man falling ill or being on the point of death, when his teeth would pain him, to pour water, through the orifice 1 Hinde ( The Last of the Masai, p. 42) writes: ‘The origin of this custom is supposed to date back to a time when tetanus was a great scourge amongst the Masai, and they discovered that it was a comparatively simple matter to feed a man suffering from lockjaw if two of his front teeth were missing.’ Sir H. Johnston, in commenting upon this, says ( The Uganda Protectorats, p. 803): ‘It may be this explanation has been invented recently to explain a very ancient custom inherited by the Masai from the Nilotic stock, which was their origin; for amongst these people the removal of the lower incisor teeth is a very common practice.’ Hinde's explanation, however, appears to be very widely spread. . Naa, ten eata opa 'l-tuñganak pôkin in-jilalo oo-'l-ala le-ke per mme ana'-'ata eiy ouni naleñg im-bwat. Ore taata etamooki em-bwata. | Had people formerly extracted the upper teeth, they would not have required the hole in the lower jaw. But now they have become accustomed to the latter. Ten edol il-Maasae ol-tuñgani lemebwa, nekwenikye aajo: ‘Eñgárie 'sirkon en-daa.’ | When the Masai see a man who has not had the two middle incisors extracted, they laugh at him, and say: ‘He eats his food like a donkey.’

Ng-amulak. | Spitting. Enotari 'ng-amulak kat'-are too-'l-Maasae; en-e-'menata oo 'n-oo-'n-d okitin naadoli neiñgasyai. Nenotari sii 'ng-amulak too-'l-oibonok, ten eiy ouni neishiu 'l-tuñganak. | The Masai have two ways of spitting; one is used to show contempt, and the other astonishment. Besides this the medicine-men spit when they wish to heal people 1 Amongst the Dinkas it is also customary for the medicine-men to spit on their patients (Kaufmann, Schilderungen, p. 128). . Ten emen ol-Maasani likae-tuñgani, neisikaki 'ng-amulak eng-omom, n ejo: ‘Ira ol-dia.’ | If a Masai wishes to show his contempt for another man, he expectorates a small stream of saliva forcibly through the hole in his teeth into the man's face, and says at the same time: ‘You are a dog.’ Ore pe edol il-Maasae 'l-Ashumba opa, neisikaa, n ejo: ‘Eñgu 'l-Orida 2 The name by which the Swahili were formerly known. anaa 'l-lukunguni.’ Nemeiy ou nenyikaki áis eye. | Formerly when the Masai saw Swahilis, they used to spit on the ground and say: ‘These coast people stink like fowls.’ They never went near them or touched them if they could help it. Ten edol ol-Maasani en-gerai kiti neitu ae-oloñg edol, nenotaki 'ng-amulak, n ejo: ‘Tubulu, tamoo 'ng-onyek o-'l-orere.’ | When a Masai sees a baby that he has never seen before, he spits on it slightly several times and says: ‘Grow, become accustomed to the eyes of people.’ Naa, ten edol en-gerai neitu ae-oloñg edol, nenotaki 'ng-amulak, n ejo: ‘Torono enna-kerai’; kake ejo to-'l-tau lenye: ‘Sidai enna-kerai’; amu eji, ten ej oki ol-tuñgani en-gerai: ‘Sidai enna-kerai,’ nemweiyu. | When he sees a child that he has never before beheld, he also spits on it slightly, and says: ‘This child is bad.’ To himself, however, he says: ‘This child is good.’ It is believed that if he praises a child it will fall ill. Ten eñgasaki 'n-gera kutiti 'l-tuñganak tasati naleñg, nenotaki 'ng-amulak il-tasati, n ej oki: ‘Mikitaja pa eng-Aï.’ | If small children salute very old men 1 Vide p. 287. , the latter spit on them, and say: ‘May God give you long life and grey hairs like mine 2 It is customary amongst the Bari people for old men (fathers or grand-fathers) to take children's heads between their knees and spit alightly on them to bless them (Mitterrutzner, Dis Sprachs der Bari, p. xvi). .’ Naa, ten eñgasaki 'l-muran il-tuñganak kituak, nenotaki kulikae-kituak ing-amulak ing-aik. | Then, when warriors greet old men 3 Vide p. 284. , the latter frequently spit in their hands before allowing the young men to grasp them. Naa, ten edol ol-Maasani en-d oki neitu ae-oloñg edol, anaa ol-akira od oyo, nenotaa 'ng-amulak, n ejo: ‘I'usho! im bira 'l-mañgati!’ n ejo sii: ‘Telekwaki.’ | If a Masai sees something phenomenal, such as a shooting star, he spits several times and says: ‘Be lost! go in the direction of the enemy!’ after which he says: ‘Stay away from me.’ Ore sii ten erik ino, nei pot il-meneñga araki eng-arna o-'l-tuñgani otua, nenotaa 'ng-amulak. Ore sii ten eniñg il-omon torok injere etua ol-tuñgani oje, nenotaa 'ng-amulak, n ejo: ‘I'usho, eng-Aï, mikiatá 'n-giyaa.’ | Again, should he forget, and call somebody who is dead, or mention the name of a deceased person, he spits. Should he hear any bad news, such as the death of some person, he spits, and says: ‘Be lost, O God, we have no ears.’ Ore p' eiter aa pw onu 'l-Aisungun kunna-kwa pi, pe edol il-Maasae, nenotaa 'ng-amulak, amu et ejo: ‘Eitu kidól il-tuñganak anaa kullo.’ N eji sii: ‘'L-oibonok kituak kullo-tuñganak.’ Ore pe e pik ol-Aisungui ol-tuñgani ol-chani, n ej oki ol-tuñgani: ‘Tonotakaki 'ng-amulak p' aishiu.’ N eji eng-arna 'l- Ojuju amu eata 'l- pa pit kumok. | When the Europeans came to these countries and the Masai saw them for the first time, they used to spit, for they said: ‘We have never seen people like these.’ They also called them medicine-men, and if a European gave a Masai medicine, the latter asked him to spit on him to heal him. Europeans were formerly called 'L-Ojuju owing to their being hairy.

L-oibonok. | The medicine-men. Eata 'l-oibonok in-d okitin oñgwan naadolye 'l-limot naa p-w onu. | Medicine-men have four methods of divining future events. N ejien-naiteru na en-gidoñg, neiy ol ou 'njere el otu en-d oki naje te-'n-gikenata oo-'so ito. | The first is by means of a buffalo or ox horn. A handful of stones 1 Vids note on p. 328. is thrown in, and they know what is going to happen by the number which fall out when the horn is shaken. Ore eng-ae, ten eyeñg en-gine, neiñgor i-monyit, neiy ol ou 'n-d okitin naa pw onu, anaa en-gäa, araki kulye-t okitin. | The second is by examining the entrails of a goat which they slaughter. From what they see there they are able to predict that certain things will come to pass, such as epidemics, &c. Ore eng-ae, ten eok in-aishi ore pe emerayu, neliki 'l-tuñganak in-d okitin naaaku akenya. | The third method is when they drink honey-wine and get drunk. They are then able to prophesy what will take place. Ore eng-ae, ten eirura p' eidetidet, neliki ol-orere 'njere: ‘Atadua en-d oki naje te-'n-gidetidet.’ Neiruk ol-orere, na ten emuta 'l-arin kumok, meidim ol-orere aat ejo el-lejare, eanyu ake aajo eaku en-net ejo ol-oiboni. | The fourth method is by dreams. They tell people what they saw in their dreams, and it is believed to be a prophecy. Should the dream not come true after an interval of some years, people cannot say it is not correct: they must wait until the medicine-man tells them that the event is about to happen. Ore ten eosh ol-oiboni en-gidoñg, pe etii 'l-tuñganak oo pw onu te-'ng-oitoi, n ej oki 'l-tuñganak: ‘Añgas a pal, amu meishoru 'n-gejek oo-'l-tuñganak oo pw onu aaosh.’ Eiy olo sii ten e pw onu 'l-tuñganak te-'n-nelakwa. | If the medicine-man is going to prophesy by means of the buffalo or ox horn, and there are people on the road, he tells those present that he will wait, as their feet will spoil his prophecy. They always know when people are coming, even if they are afar off. Naa, ten ebonu ol-oiboni en-d oki, nemera meibalaki 'l-tuñganak; eranyu too-'n-gitan-yanyukot, neiruk il-tuñganak. | When a medicine-man makes medicine, he gets drunk before he prophesies. He sings in parables, and the people reply. Anaa ol-oiboni opa oji Menye-Ñgu pe, neibon oki 'l-muran le-Kile po ooiy ou ne pwo en-jore, nerany, ejo: | For instance, when the medicineman named The father of Ngupe made medicine for the warriors of Kilepo before they went on a raiding expedition, he sang: ‘ Pur puri 'l-oiñgok, | ‘The bulls that cannot move because they are so fat, Kile po earaki. | They will be beaten by Kilepo.  Pur puri 'l-oiñgok, | The bulls that cannot move because they are so fat, Naataara ite en-duñgoti.’ | Half of them have been captured.’ Ne pwo 'l-muran le-Kile po en-jore, n ear il-Akaen, netum e-matwa oo-'n-g ishu, nelau 'l-kulikae. | The warriors of Kilepo went on their projected raid against the people of Kahe 1 A small state near Kilima Njaro. , and captured half of their cattle. N ejo: ‘Etabaiya en-opa-nat ejo ol-oiboni.’ | They said: ‘Thus prophesied the medicine-man.’ Ore 'l-oibonok pôkin il-Aiser, le-'ng-aji oo-'n-Gidoñgi, naji en-o-'l-Oimooja araki en-e-'Sigiriaishi. Ore Ol-Oimooja o E-Sigiriaishi 'n-gera o-'l-Ie-Mweiya. | All medicine-men belong to the Kidongi family of the Aiser clan, and they are the descendants of Ol-Oimooja or of E-Sigiriaishi 2 The Somali. , the sons of Ol-le-Mweiya 3 The son of sickness(?). . Ore too-'l-oibonok pôkin Ol- Onana ol-kitok lenye. Ninye egel il-Maasae pôkin, n ejo ol-aitoriani lenye. | Of all the medicine-men Lenana is the greatest. All Masai acknowledge him as their lord and pay tribute to him. N eji Ol- Onana en-gerai e-'M-Batyany, o 'M-Batyany en-gerai e-Su peet, o Su peet engerai e-Sitonik, o Sitonik en-gerai e-Ki pe pete, o-Ki pe pete en-gerai e- Parinyombe, o Pari-nyombe en-gerai e-Kidoñgoi, o Kidoñgoi en-geraie-'Sigiriaishi. | It is said that Lenana is the son of Mbatian, who was the son of Supeet, who was the son of Sitonik, who was the son of Kipepete, who was the son of Parinyombe, who was the son of Kidongoi, who was the son of E-Sigiriaishi, the son of Ol-le-Mweiya. Ore en-giterunoto oo-'l-oibonok n eji enot oki Ol-le-Mweiya eton te-'n-ge per o-'l-doinyo loo-'l-Aiser otad ouo te-'ng-aï. Netum il-Aiser, n ejo en-gerai amu oti naleñg, nerik añg, nenyoriki ol-oiboni, neiyamisho, ne iu 'n-gera. | The story of the origin of the medicine-men is said to be as follows: Ol-le-Mweiya came down from heaven and was found by the Aiser clan sitting on the top of their mountain 1 Commonly known to Europeans as Ngong or Donyo Lamuyu. The Masai have three names for this mountain--Eng-oñgu e-'m-bagasi (the eye or source of the Athi River), Ol-doinyo loo-'l-Aiser, and Ol-doinyo lo-'l-le-Mweiya. . He was such a small person that he was first of all believed to be a child. He was taken by the Aiser clan to their kraal, where it was discovered that he was a medicine-man. He married and had issue. Ore etaa en-n eä, n ej oki 'n-gera enyena: ‘Emindur te-'nne.’ Ti-araki naa n eja pe melam il-Aiser illo-doinyo. | When he was dying he said to his children: ‘Do not move from this spot.’ On account of this the Aiser clan do not go far from their mountain. Ore too-'l-oibonok pôkin li-opa 'M-Batyany ol-kitok. | Now, of all the medicine-men who lived in olden days Mbatian was the greatest. N eji opa eton eitu e pw onu 'l-Aisungun kunna-kwa pi, etiaka 'l-tuñganak: ‘E pw onu akenya 'l-tuñganak ooibor kullo-oshon.’ | It is said that formerly, before Europeans ever came to these countries, he prophesied that white people would arrive. Ore sii inna-kata eton eitu  eä, n ej oki 'l-tuñganak: ‘Endura, amu emuta 'n-g ishu. Ore en-d oki ninderitere aadol naa 'l-ojoñga ooän in-gäk anaa 'l- otorok. Neiter sii 'l-chañgit aaä, neit oki taa 'n-g ishu.’ | Again, before he died he told the people to move their grazing grounds, ‘for,’ he said, ‘all the cattle will die. You will first of all see flies which make hives like bees, then the wild beasts will die, and afterwards the cattle.’ Nesi payu nenna pokirare: ne pw onu 'l-Aisungun, n eä 'n-g ishu. | Both of these prophesies have come true: the Europeans have arrived, and the cattle died. Ore eä 'n-g ishu, n eä sii ninye 'M-Batyany. | Mbatian himself died while the cattle plague was raging (circa 1890). Ore etaa en-n eä, nei pot il- paiyani le-Mata pato, a ol-osho otamanya, n ej oki: ‘Emindur to-'l-osho linyi, amu alo aä; nairiwaki 'ndae 'n-g ishu te-'ng-aï. Naa, tini induruduru, niää te-'mweiyan o-'l-minjaloi, nemuta 'n-g ishu pôkin, niara-rere 'l-mañgati oogol, n eari 'ndae. Ore en-gerai ai naisho 'n-d okitin o-'l-oiboni, ninye ol-oiboni linyi. Endaas im-baa naaj oki 'ndae.’ | When on the point of death, he called the elders of Matapato, the sub-district in which he lived, and said to them: ‘Do not move from your country for I am about to die, and I will send you cattle from heaven. If you move, you will die of smallpox, your cattle will all perish, you will have to fight with a powerful enemy, and you will be beaten. I wish my successor to be the son to whom I give the medicine-man's insignia. Obey him.’ N ej oki 'l- paiyani pôkin: ‘Aïya,’ ne pwo. | The elders said: ‘Very well,’ and left. Ore p' eidi p aashom, nei pot 'M-Batyany en-gerai enye kitok oji Send eu, n ej oki: ‘Tay oku amu aiy ou náisho 'n-d okitin o-'l-oiboni.’ | When they had gone, Mbatian called his eldest son Sendeyo 1 Lenana is sometimes said to be the eldest son of Mbatian. , and said to him: ‘Come to-morrow morning for I wish to give you the medicine-man's insignia.’ N ejo Send eu: ‘Aïya,’ nelo airura. | Sendeyo replied: ‘Very well,’ and went to lie down. Ore ej okïno kunna, neniñg Ol- Onana oisudori ti-atwa ol-ale loo-'l-asho, neiny ot oto tad ekenya, nelo eng-aji e-menye, n ejo: ‘Papa, a euo.’ | While this was taking place, Lenana, who had hidden himself in the calf-shed, overheard the conversation. He arose early in the morning and went to his father's hut. On his arrival he said: ‘Father I have come.’ Ore 'M-Batyany na ol-móruo kitok eata eng-oñgn nabo ake, nemedol en-gerai enye, neisho 'n-d okitin o-'l-oiboni, aa ol-kuma le-'seghengei, o en-gidoñg, o ol-tulet, o em-bene, o 'n-doto e-'n-aibon, n ejo: ‘Iye oitore 'l-alashera lin ono o ol-orere pôkin.’ | Now Mbatian was very aged and he had only one eye. He therefore did not see which of his sons was before him and gave to Lenana the insignia of the medicine-man (the iron club and the medicine horn, the gourd, the stones 1 It is possible that these stones, which according to tradition were brought many years ago from the north, may prove to be of some interest. It is asserted that no European has ever been allowed to behold them. , and the bag), at the same time saying: ‘Thou shalt be great amongst thy brothers and amongst all the people.’ Ne'ya Ol- Onana 'n-d okitin o-'l-oiboni, nelo. | Lenana took the medicine-man's insignia and went away. Ore p' eidi p ash omo, nejiñg Send eu eng-aji e-menye, n ej ok ini: ‘Ol-alashe lino o'yawa 'n-d okitin o-'l-oiboni.’ Ne-goro naleñg Send eu, n ejo: ‘Maitore ol-alashe lai, aarare oo metua.’ | Sendeyo then went to his father, but was told that his brother had already been there and been given the medicine-man's insignia. When he heard this, he was very angry and said: ‘I will not be subject to my brother; I will fight with him till I kill him.’  Onaa n eä 'M-Batyany, nenu-kari to-'l-Doinyo Orok. | Mbatian died and was buried near Donyo Erok. Ore p' eidi p atua, n ejo kulikae-tuñganak: ‘Ol- Onana ol-oiboni lañg, amu etiaka 'yook 'M-Batyany, “Aisho 'n-d okitin o-'l-oiboni en-gerai ai nara ol-oiboni linyi.”’ Netoni te-idye aaboitare Ol- Onana. | When he was dead, some of the people proclaimed Lenana principal medicine-man, ‘for,’ they said, ‘Mbatian told us that he would give the insignia of his office to whichever of his sons he wished should succeed him.’ They therefore remained with Lenana. Kake ejo kulikae: ‘Mme ol-oiboni lañg elle, amu etelejishe.’ Ne pwo ninje aasuj Send eu. | But others said: ‘We will not acknowledge this man for he is a cheat,’ and they threw in their lot with Sendeyo 2 This is the story as told by the Masai. The official version is that Lenana was chosen by the elders of most of the clans and districts on his father's death, but that Sendeyo refused to acknowledge him, and was supported by the 'L-oitai (i. e. the Masai of the 'L-oita sub-district, near Kilima Njaro), with whom he lived for many years. The warriors of the two parties frequently met in deadly strife, and raided each other's cattle. In 1902 Sendeyo gave up the hopeless conflict, and agreed to acknowledge his brother as chief. He now lives not far from Naivasha. Lenana himself says that he and his three brothers Sendeyo, Neliang, and Tolito were examined by their father a short time before the latter's death, and as he possessed a better knowledge of the work of the medicine-men than his brothers, he was given the iron club, &c., and chosen by the elders as Mbatian's successor. . Ore kuldo oosh omo aaboitare Send eu, nemweiyu, n eä 'l-kumok, nemuta 'n-g ishu enye, n ear sii 'l-Dachi. Ore kuldo oototonío aaboitare Ol- Onana, neitu emweiyu, netum in-g ishu, anaa en-net ejo 'M-Batyany. | Now disease broke out amongst Sendeyo's people, many of whom died, their cattle all perished, and they were defeated by the Germans; whilst those people who remained with Lenana did not fall ill, and they obtained cattle, as Mbatian had predicted. N eara Ol- Onana o Send eu 'l-arin kumok, n eari Send eu, nel otu te-'lle-ari le-ñgole asai ol-alashe, neishori eton aaboita, neitayu o-s otwa. | The two rivals waged war for many years, and eventually Sendeyo was beaten. He came in 1902 to beg his brother to allow him to live with him, and peace was concluded between the two parties. Ore ten etaa en-n eä Ol- Onana, negelu en-gerai enye naiy ol ou en-aibon. | Before Lenana dies he will select whichever of his sons is acquainted with the work of the medicine-men to succeed him. Ore en-d oki kitok to-'l-oiboni naa ol-kuma le-'s*eg-hengei. Ore ten eiriwaa ol-oiboni ol-kilikwai pe ej oki 'l-tuñganak t oki, neiriwaa ol-kuma lenye pe eniñg il-tuñganak o-rorei lenye. | The principal badge of the medicine-man's office is the iron club 1 On one occasion the iron club was lost. A messenger was sent by Lenana to the Government authorities at Nairobi, and when crossing the Uganda Railway he was overtaken by a train. He jumped on one side and saved his life, but dropped the club, which was never found again. Its place was taken for some years by a small iron poker, but another club has now been made. . If the medicine-man sends a messenger to tell his people anything, he also sends his club so that it may be known that the message comes from him. Naa, ten eosh ol-oiboni ol-tuñgani to-'l-kuma le-'seg-hengei,

N-alimen, o en-gi oget o en-dasing, oo 'mweiyani. | Yawning, hiccoughs, sneezing, and illnesses. Ten enya 'l-tuñganak oo-'l-Maasae 'n-alimen, n eji eata 'n-jo. Naa, ten enya en-gerai kiti, neibuñg ñgotonye too-'l-kim ojik en-gutuk enye, amu eure mebaari aaku kitok anaa 'l-meek. | When the Masai yawn, they are said to be sleepy. If a small child yawns, his mother grasps his mouth between her fingers to prevent it from stretching and becoming big like the savages' mouths. Ore ten eata 'l-tuñganak en-gi oget, n eji einos in-giri. | If a person has hiccoughs, it is believed that he will eat some meat. Ten easing ol-tuñgani, n ejo o peny: ‘Ol-tuñgani lái poto.’ N ejo kulikae-tuñganak ootii: ‘Mikitagolo (eng-Aï) el-lu-ghunya,’ araki: ‘I'risha.’ | When a person sneezes, he says to himself: ‘Somebody is calling me.’ If other people are present, they say to him: ‘May God make your head hard,’ or: ‘Have good health.’ Ten emweiyu 'l-tuñganak loo-'l-Maasae, n eji e-mweiyan e-'ng-Aï. Eiy olokulikae-tuñga-nak áishoo 'l-käk, p' eishiu. | When a Masai falls ill, it is said to be God's sickness. Some people know of medicines, which they give to sick people to cure them.

Il-baa oo 'l-abaak. | Wounds and Surgeons. Ten eñgori ol-murani loo-'l-Maasae, aagil ol-oïto le-'ng-aina araki le-'n-geju, netii 'l-abaak ooiy olo aatabak. | If a Masai warrior is shot, and an arm or leg broken, the surgeons are able to mend it. Neduñg in-giri; ore p' eidi p, neitau 'rarat, neiruburub il-oik, neri p too-'n-o pin, n eän naleñg. | They cut through the flesh, take out the splinters and bring the edges of the bone together, after which they stitch up the wound with the sinew from the back of an ox, and bind the limb securely. Ore en-daa e-illo-tuñgani naa 'n-giri naa pejo ake enya, ore ol-chani ook naa ol-kiloriti aitaa eng-are. | The only food that is given to a man with a broken limb is roast meat and the thirst-quenching medicine obtained from A cacia abyssinica. Ore ten eñgori ol-tuñgani eng-oshoghe, ne puku 'monyit, nebaki áitau nekwa-naarumisho, neisuji, neriny ok ini eng-oshoghe, nebuk ok ini e-ilata e-'n-gerr, neri pi. | Should a man be shot in the belly so that the intestines protrude, the wound is washed and the intestines returned to their place; sheep's fat (a quart or more) is poured into the wound, which is then stitched up. Ore ten eñgori ol-tuñgani, negili ol-arasi, n eyeñgi inne-w eji, ne piki ol-arasi le-'n-gerr, nebuk ok ini e-ilata e-'n-gerr, neri pi. | Again, if a man is shot and a rib broken, the flesh is skinned from the wound, and a sheep's rib is inserted in place of the broken one. Sheep's fat is then poured into the wound, after which it is sewn up. M eok ol-tuñgani oñgoro kulle, 'n-giri ake einos. | The wounded man is not allowed to drink milk, and may only eat meat. Naa, ten eñgori ol-murani te-'m-bae naata e-saiyet, n eyeñgi en-giteñg naitayu e-nyawa, neitauni 'n-gi pa, neishori lido-oñgoro metooko pe egurumu e-saiyet, neishiu. | If a man is shot with a poisoned arrow, a pregnant cow is slaughtered, and he is given the caul fat to drink. This causes him to vomit and he recovers. Ore ten edol il-abaak ol-tuñgani lemeruburubayu ol-oïto, n eän 'ñgonyo pe etum áitírie inne-w eji netigile. | If the surgeons see that a man's bone cannot be mended, they fasten a ligature round the limb and amputate it. Neiy ol ou sii 'l-abaak aategelem araki áidoñgo 'l-oiñgok, oo 'l-merigeshi, oo 'l-oroi. Ore ten egelem il-oiñgok, negor te-'n-gäne ol-gos, pe etum aatañgor ten eitashe e-ñgony, amu ejo teni meñgor, neij eyu 'sa po. | The surgeons are also able to castrate bulls, rams, and he-goats by either removing or crushing the testicles. When bulls are castrated, a cord is fastened tightly round their necks and blood is extracted from the jugular veins to prevent inflammation of the injured parts 1 A description of the operation was given in The Veterinarian (Stordy), October, 1900. .

Grass tufts on the floor are just left to dry up and get trampled out of existence. Repairs are done by the women of the house, and consist in filling up cracks with wet cow-dung. Fleas, bugs and rats are uncommon in Masai huts. Dried puff-balls and dry cow-dung are sometimes burnt as an insectifuge. The young people are not infested with body lice; but these abound on the aged, taking refuge in bead necklaces and other ornaments.

Masai also sometimes abandon a boma, or at least the house involved, if a person dies in it. People who are very seriously ill are removed from the boma at least during the day, often to a small thorn boma with a shelter constructed nearby. They may remain there at night also. It was difficult to learn much definite about this practice. A disabled person spending the night outside a boma is very likely to end up inside a hyaena. The administration frowns on this efficient method of disposal and consequently the Masai have become reticent to talk about it. The sick persons' bomas that we saw looked to have been occupied nights as well as days.

There are two interpretations of the healthy appearance of Maasai. The popular view is to note the excellence of their diet and way of life by normal African standards (Orr and Gilks 1931). The more sombre view is to accept that only the most robust children have a chance of survival and natural selection is a major factor in the level of health (Merker 1904:334). The true balance between these is hard to assess. The Matapato are reluctant to discuss family tragedies and they dispose of dead children unobtrusively. The general absence of congenital disabilities inevitably raises questions regarding the fate of defective babies. 3 The term en-tomononi refers most commonly to a young mother whose hair reveals her ritual state, but it also applies to certain other ritualised roles including the infant itself. Apart from emphasising the weakness of her condition, informants offered no derivation of this term. In the related language Bari, however, a phonetically similar term, tomunyan , is translated as ’tenderness, feebleness, weakness’ (Spagnolo 1960:300). In its male form, ol-tomononi may refer to a generally propitious elder with children, who is especially suitable for a prominent role in any ceremony. It is held that any deformity could indicate some past sin dogging either parent, but God condoned this birth and God alone should choose the moment of death. As children are progressively exposed to the outside world, those that are maladapted are less likely to survive, but still a few may do so and even live to raise healthy families of their own. It is God's will, they say.

As the time for moving from their temporary villages to the eunoto site draws near, the manyat are joined by non-manyata moran and they migrate as a whole age-group. The apprehensiveness of sorcery surrounding this move helps to build up a sense of occasion. The eunoto site itself is kept secret so that it cannot be tampered with beforehand. A protective line of chalky ‘medicine’ provided by the Prophet is traced on every forehead from ear to ear for the move. There is also a false start to divert misfortune from the migration proper that follows. This is a theme that is repeated later that day with the installation of the ritual leader, for he too is thought to divert misfortune from his age mates who follow him to elderhood. This concern with threats from sinister forces coincides with the transformation that the age-group of moran undergo through eunoto . It marks an implicit shift in the distribution of power with age more generally. The juxtaposition of large numbers of older men and younger men sharply differentiated by age highlights their differences. The maturation of the moran is a fact of life that arouses ambivalence, clearly expressed in Episode 2 and other incidents of the kind. Even the firestick patrons, whose future is ritually linked with that of their moran wards, have a vested interest in delaying the reality of the present. This is to suggest that the kind of insight offered by some informants, that the danger from ‘eyes’ emanates from society at large, could logically be extended to interpreting the dangers that are felt to surround eunoto . Episode 4 . Seizing the ritual leaders . The migration to the eunoto site had to take place on the fifth day of a Maasai lunar month, reckoned from the morning when the old moon was no longer visible (24th April 1977). When the time came, moran feasting in the forest nearby were summoned and the number in the villages increased overnight from about 100 moran to perhaps 450. This was the first time that the whole age-group had ever been assembled in one spot. Forty-nine of the moran were selected to lead the procession. Singing emosiroi , they were followed by a herd of forty-eight white heifers and a young black bull, and then by all the other moran. They were blessed by a manyata-mother, who dipped a handful of grass into a milk gourd and flicked milk at them as they passed through her gateway and out of the larger village. This was the false start, and when all the moran had passed out, the patrons ordered them to disband. (Coining the metaphor, the ritual rebirth had been aborted.) The procession proper had to wait until the manyata-mothers packed their donkeys and had left to be at the eunoto site before the moran. During this lull, the patrons directed the moran to process between the villages performing their lion dance. Some patrons, who were trying to slow down the tempo, were visibly moved, two with tears down their cheeks. It was the lion dance, I was told, that stirred their memories - and it was being performed too fast. In other respects, the patrons clearly showed that they had total control and were determined to dominate this occasion. Throughout the day they marshalled the moran for instruction, for dancing, and for the chores of moving, and one or two lashed out with their long whips on impulse. The moran seemed drained of their earlier confidence, for the migration was a prelude to the evening climax when the identities of the ritual leader and his deputy would be revealed. Later, several moran described to me their feelings of apprehension on this day: a dread of the approach of evening and of the awful possibility that they themselves or perhaps one of their close friends might be seized as a ritual leader. One moran whose ancestry made him ineligible expressed his own vicarious fears. Whoever they were, two of his age mates were to be plucked away, violating the manyata bond of sharing in everything including a common destiny. The ritual leaders were to be condemned to an uncertain future, even an early death, and he felt as though a part of his own self was condemned. Eventually all was packed for the migration. The procession was led by a few firestick patrons who knew the secret location, a spot about four miles further south. Then came the manyata-mothers with their laden donkeys, some straggled from time to time, and others stopped to readjust their loads, halting the procession that followed. Then came the remaining patrons, and at their rear a few with whips to control the pace of the moran, so that they did not overtake the straggling women. Then came the moran in four files, two for Maparasha and one each for Meto and Silale, wearing such lionskin trophies and ostrich feather headdresses as they had. They carried their shields, held high their manyata flags, and raised their spears to the rhythm of their lion dance. Each time the procession was halted by the patrons, the dancing would intensify and minor epidemics of shaking broke out: a yelp, some shaking, and then more yelps and more shaking. Possibly thirty of the moran shook, while many more were shivering. Finally at the tailend of the procession, came a file of about thirty girls, escorted by four moran. By the time that the body of the procession arrived at the eunoto site, the women had already been directed by the leading firestick patrons to build their huts in a large circle. This was the point, incidentally at which the violent eunoto affray had erupted in Purko in 1945 when rival manyat competed for the prime position in the village. In Matapato, there was no prime position to be fought over; and here in any event, manyata rivalries appeared to have dissipated before the migration. When the moran arrived, they were directed to fetch logs for the fire and to cut thorn branches for the village fence. In a matter of hours an unremarkable stretch of open bushland overshadowed by the mountain was transformed into a joint manyata village. Meanwhile, the patrons blessed the forty-nine young cattle in the centre of the village; and then holding down the young black bull, they kindled the manyata fire on his back. The manner of lighting this fire is popularly related to the misfortune that dogs the ritual leader. According to one version, it is the unpropitiousness of lighting it on a living bull that has the effect of a firestick patrons' curse. According to another it is ‘medicine’ provided by the Prophet which they put in the flames that has the effect of sorcery. 3 The fracas concerned respectively the Ngorisho R among the Loodokilani, the Meruturud L and the Nyankusi R among the Purko. The Annual Report for 1945 (AR/Kaj-Nar/1945:3) presumably refers obliquely to this last incident. Various moran looked on, aware that their patrons were performing an essential preliminary to installing the two incumbents in a matter of hours. As the shadows lengthened and the new moon was just visible, all the huts had been erected and the moran were called to the village. Most of them were quickly rounded up, but some were found lurking in the bush nearby, apparently hoping that their absence would not be noticed. There were rumours that several had already run away. Once assembled, the moran were mustered round the patrons' fire, singing emosiroi and facing inwards in a double circle, about thirty yards in diameter with a pathway between the outer and inner rings. Then further delays prolonged the suspense when it was discovered that some of the manyata-mothers had not yet taken a flame from the patrons' fire to kindle their own hearths. This prompted a routine check on all huts. Eventually the patrons were satisfied that the procedure for seizing the two ritual leaders could continue. A posse wearing capes and consisting of the three moran spokesmen and four strong aides ambled round the pathway between the two rings. They glanced over the moran as they passed, and were poised at any moment to seize the ritual leader. In the gathering twilight, they continued to circumambulate for perhaps twenty minutes while the other moran continued the slow measured tones of emosiroi with tense shivery expressions. One or two yelped and started to shake from time to time. As darkness closed in, it only became clear that the posse had seized the ritual leader when there was a cry and a scuffle. Other moran near the spot joined in to hold him, while a woman's apron was forced over his shoulders. Shivering, screaming, and throwing his limbs violently in all directions, he was half dragged and half carried to his mother's hut and forced to sit beside her fire opposite three firestick patrons. For a time he continued to scream and seemed almost delirious, while his mother and his young brother, who was a manyata herdboy, were also overcome with grief. About fifteen of his closer moran friends gathered, singing to comfort him, and a cow with male calf was tethered in front of the hut as a gift from his age-group. The commotion eventually subsided and the moran were again assembled into their rings to sing emosiroi ; and the same procedure was followed to seize and instal the deputy ritual leader. Once this too had been completed, the circle was finally broken. With a sense of general relief there was dancing and high spirits in various parts of the village, by groups of moran with their girls, and also by manyata-mothers in their own groups. For the first time that day, the festive atmosphere returned and continued into the night. The Pleiades star cluster was by now barely visible in the evening sky, and the eunoto sacrifice, which formed the next climax, could not be performed until the cluster had reappeared in the early morning in two months time. The sheer size of the gathering in these hard times could not be sustained for more than a day. Next morning, there was a general exodus by both elders and moran, seeking food elsewhere. Some moran made their way back to their forest camps. The parting gift for elders was one mug of tea to be shared among every four men, and it was accepted that there was no point in remonstrating for more. There was no more. Those that remained in the vicinity were primarily the manyata moran and their mothers.

A review of the list of these taboos which follows will disclose much over-lapping. One such taboo, that against burning the pawpaw tree, is indeed almost universal and was stated by one informant to be characteristic of the pagan Hausa as a whole. This prohibition is not quite universal, since it was explicitly stated for several clans that they did burn the pawpaw. The belief is always held that violation of the taboos will lead to skin disorders or leprosy. In the case of animals, ill effects are supposed to follow not only from killing or eating the animal, but also from stepping on the spot where it has passed. On the other hand, the clans which have the bída snake as their kân gídá believe that if it passes a compound and is seen by one of its members, the compound will be increased in membership, either by the acquisition of a wife or the birth of a child.

Another rite de passage of critical importance takes place on the occasion of a woman’s first childbirth. After the Muslim naming ceremony on the seventh day, the mother returns to her parents’ home with her baby, and remains there for a period of six months or longer, during which she performs the prescribed post-natal ablutions daily for five months. This custom, known as bangwalle, has many different variations, but its performance for the first birth is normative. On completion of bangwalle the mother returns to her husband’s compound loaded with gifts from her kin, and for the first time in her husband’s home will suckle her infant without any pressure or compulsion being necessary. But throughout their lives, a parent of either sex and the first-born child observe a rigorous avoidance-relation, which is hardly relaxed even in private and when the child is fully grown. As the very full acount in the text illustrates (pp. 1 sqq.), social sanctions compel conformity to this behaviour, both during the period of ablutions and thereafter. The entire complex is best understood as a rite de passage, marking the transition in status to parenthood and full social maturity, and the lifelong avoidance-relation, which is extended by Fulani to the second and third child, and by Hausa-speaking Habe and Fulani to the next-born in greater or less degree, if the first child dies in infancy, gives a permanent expression to this new status. Similarly the post-natal ablutions, which are carried out for successive births, are probably best understood as extensions of ritual activity on the first childbirth rather than as measures of preventive hygiene (which the Hausa declare them to be), since such ablutions are not performed for stillbirths or miscarriages, and may be brought to an early conclusion if the mother is unable to bear the washing with nearly boiling water; if this happens, alternative ‘medicines’, herbal and Islamic, are employed.

When I was two years old and it was time to wean me from my mother, Zetanku my father’s old slave took me to live with her until I forgot about the breast. She said I cried a lot, I was with her for three months. She liked her master’s baby and when it was time to wean me she came and said she wanted to take me. Father said ‘Yes, you may take her’. Then she took me to her compound in the rinji where she lived with her husband Dankurama. She vaccinated ( 19 () Kurama are one of the tribes of eastern Zaria Province who traditionally practised a form of vaccination for smallpox. In 1950 they were still using these traditional techniques. ) me for smallpox; they used to scratch your arm until the blood came, then they got the fluid from someone who had smallpox and rubbed it in. It all swelled up and you covered it until it healed. Some children used to die; your way of doing it is better. After three months Zetanku took me back to my mother.

Dantambai became pregnant eight months after the first child was born; for seven months he drank milk, then he drank ‘pregnant milk’ until when she was near to her time they weaned him. When Dantambai knew she was pregnant they sent for her mother, but she was angry and said she would not come. Dantambai and her husband were delighted, but their parents were angry. They said they would give her medicine so that the pregnancy should lie down but he refused, he said ‘Here is one child, let’s have the other one too!’ If you go back to your husband’s hut, what do you expect? The second child was born after a year, there was already a child on her back, then there was the infant, they were both being suckled. They sent for me and I said the elder child must be taken to the market in the very early morning, and when the butchers killed a bull they must get the stomach of the bull while it was still warm and rub the child’s whole body with it, then the woman who took him must tie him on her back and bring him back to the compound at once. Then she must wash him all over with warm water, and get some butter and rub him with it. Every market-day at Zarewa for two weeks, that is seven market-days, they did this. Then he was all right; he ate food—gruel and tuwo and fura and sour milk, he was weaned after a year. He grew strong and well, the children are both alive and healthy now. The new pregnancy spoils the milk and the child ails. But when his body was rubbed with the bull’s stomach, then he passed a lot of urine, then his body became strong. ( 174 The point of this tale is that intercourse occurred during the period of the post natal ablutions. ) Those two brothers are young men now, they have both been married recently. She went back to her husband because he desired her very much and she desired him; she was his head wife, he had three others, but she was the one he preferred.

We have a fable about the madness caused by jealousy between a man’s wives. There was a wife who went to a malam . She asked him to give her medicine so that her co-wife would go mad and leave her in the compound alone. He said ‘Here it is. If you call her and she doesn’t answer, you will go mad. If she answers, she will go mad. Do you understand?’ She said she understood. The next day she returned to him and he gave her the medicine. He said ‘It is not my responsibility’. She said ‘I will find her’. She returned home and called her co-wife. Silence. Then she began to dance in the open space of the compound, then madness seized her. The co-wife’s father was a malam also, and he had told her ‘Don’t take anything she gives you, don’t reply if she calls you’. When she heard the other wife calling her name she remained quite quiet. When the jealous wife went mad she went off into the bush. That is a tale of long ago; they still do that sort of thing, but not in the same way as they did in the past; nowadays women get charms, but only to drive out their co-wives. They don’t use medicine for madness now, they are afraid of you—they don’t want to be caught and taken before the Christians and killed. ( 184 The season of the harmattan, the north wind which blows from the Sahara in the dry season. Epidemics of cerebro-spinal meningitis occur at this season annually, and these may be one reason why it is connected with madness. Hausa distinguish two types of madness, violence (mania) and muttering, which may be of a schizoid character. Both are explained in terms of spirits ( bori, iskoki, aljannu ). ) It is the same with all the bad things of the past—they are finished, people are afraid to do them. Now life is peaceful.

It wasn’t any kind of medicine, it was just them—the spirits that one doesn’t see. They are here in the compound, they are here in the town. But they liked Ahmadu, he always gave them alms; every Friday and Sunday he caused rams to be killed for them and kids, he gave them chickens and porridge; they were taken outside the door of his compound, and anyone could come and eat. The alms were given to the people and they, the ones we don’t see, they felt good when they saw it, they knew it was meant for them. All village chiefs, too, ought to do this—they ought to give the spirits the things that they like, and all will be well with the people. When this one came he was much too clever, he refused to give them what they should have, he didn’t give them alms. Then he saw something terrifying in his compound—only he saw—but he refused to give them alms and he ran away. He appealed to the king, he appealed to the Europeans, he said he wanted to build a new town. When we moved here to New Giwa the spirits filled the town, the European spirits began to come too. The malams advised that it would be right to give these strangers alms so that they should dwell at peace in the town. Whether he gave it to them in secret, I don’t know; but he never gave them alms at the front of his compound. Now you see there is illness, there is meningitis there is trouble. This is the cause of it. ‘They’ have been here since the creation of the world, at every birthday they are here but we can’t see them. ( 262 Baba lived for some time with her younger brother Kadiri before remarrying; her fourth husband Ibrahim was also known as Dantsoho or Danauta, presumably because he was the son of his parents’ old age (see next section). CHAPTER XV )
() Kurama are one of the tribes of eastern Zaria Province who traditionally practised a form of vaccination for smallpox. In 1950 they were still using these traditional techniques.
Presumably Baba’s treatment was intended to cause the child to pass all the ‘pregnant milk’ out of his system. The bull is symbolic of strength and sexual vigour.

Members of a sib have in common the name, a verse of praise recited at the marriage ceremony of one of its female members, an obligation not to marry within it, and a number of taboos against burning certain kinds of wood and killing or eating the flesh of certain animals. The idea of kinship between the forbidden animal and the members of the clan is not held; rather it is simply believed that if the taboo is broken, a series of swellings will break out over the entire body.

The spirits are usually classified as white or good, and black or evil. In the main, the black spirits are held to be pagan and live in the bush, while the white spirits are thought of as Moslem and live in the city. At times, however, other criteria are brought into play as when Massak'i, “the weaver,” is declared to be a white spirit because he weaves white cloth; or Ba'awzini, “the Touareg,” is called white because the Touareg are a light-skinned people. It is also said that a spirit may be white for the man who worships him, while he is black for everyone else. Classification, however, is not a major consideration, and there consequently is some doubt regarding the category to which many of the spirits should be assigned. 5 The division of spirits into white and Moslem on the one hand, and black and pagan on the other, is of Mohammedan origin. The present confusion in the classification of the spirits is thus largely due to the fact that these categories have been superimposed on a native division of the spirits into those of town and bush.
