An exhaustive treatise on the Santal attitude to disease has been published, and shows conclusively that, as with ghosts so with sickness, the ideas of the Santals are common to all the lower strata of society in North India. 1 P. O. Bodding, Studies in Santal Medicine and Connected Folklore, Memoirs of the Royal Asiatic Society of Bengal, Vol. X. These ideas are not simple but complex, and range from the realm of the rational to the fantastic. Disease is sometimes ascribed to natural causes, particularly when the chain of causation is fairly obvious and can be repeated in a series of experiments; there is a whole class of food described as batol, which means that it is unwholesome. There are hundreds of remedies that require no supernatural aid to make them effective. Some remedies are the property of all, while others are the property of individuals and the knowledge of their ingredients is a closely guarded secret. Chaitan of Churimara began his career as a physician in response to a specific need. When he was a young man a friend had come to him in great distress and said that his boy was vomiting blood. He turned to Chaitan and asked him if he knew of any medicine that would be good for the boy. Chaitan was so sorry for his friend that he promised to do something, although when he said this he had no notion what he should do. As he was setting out for his friend’s house he prayed to Cando and asked that he might be shown what he ought to do; at the same time he shut his eyes and kicked at the soil. As he opened his eyes again he saw a plant, which he immediately dug up. He ground the roots to make a medicine, and the boy recovered from his sickness. Since then he has applied the same remedy to many other cases. One of his patients had been extremely ill, he said, but was now the father of four or five children! He has been in great demand as a physician, and claims that Cando subsequently revealed many remedies to him. Sometimes it is claimed that remedies are made known in dreams. The plant that was first revealed to Chaitan was the upel tandi plant, which has a red flower.

When the Santal ojha is called in about a case of sickness or of sudden death, his first function is to try to determine the type to which the particular misfortune belongs. He consults the oracles in order to discover whether natural causes are to blame, in which case it is called plain rua, or sickness, or whether it is necessary to lay the responsibility on a witch, a bonga or a displeased ancestor. He sits down in the courtyard and waits until two sarjom leaves and some mustard oil in a leaf cup are brought to him. Holding one of the leaves in his left hand, he dips his right index finger in the oil and sprinkles some drops on the ground as an offering to the spirits. While doing so he asks for guidance in determining the correct cause of the illness or fatality. He then puts a drop of oil into each of the compartments of the leaf that he is holding, one drop representing one possible agency of evil. There is one for natural causes, three or four for different bongas, and other drops represent households in which there may be a witch, including the sick man’s house, his father-in-law’s house, the houses on the other side of the village street, and so on. When the drops are in position the ojha rubs the two leaves together and then holds the first leaf up to the light to discern the shapes that have been taken by the oil. He pronounces the cause of the disease in accordance with the pattern that he sees. If he decides that the bongas are displeased, he performs the ceremony known as bul mayam in much the same manner as the village co-priest does during the festivals. The blood which he draws from his arm, chest or thigh is mixed with some sundried rice until the whole is saturated. The ojha then proceeds to scatter the rice on the ground and prays to the spirits to spare the sick man from further interference. He confirms his diagnosis by oracle by examining the patient and in particular by feeling his pulse, and apart from his power with the spirits he has a stock-in-trade that includes many remedies, spells, and also powers of exorcism. This is resorted to at once in certain cases such as snake bite. The ojha squats down beside the sick person and takes in his left hand a peacock feather or sometimes one or two twigs from an old broom, and these he passes along the patient’s body without touching it, moving from the head to the feet and chanting the correct spells as he does so.

The magician always warns his clients that there is a possibility of error in his diagnosis, for it is the common belief that witches can interfere with the process of divination in order to draw attention away from themselves. Sometimes at an early stage, but usually when the illness persists in spite of all attempts at a cure, the suspicion of witchcraft arises, and a second divination reveals that a witch is at work. Once the suspicion has been voiced the whole village is concerned in the consultation, and the headman walks through the village exclaiming in a loud voice near each house: “Beware, for if the sick man does not get well we shall deal with thee!” More ojhas are consulted, and once agreement has been reached that witchcraft is operating, then steps have to be taken to locate the witch. The villagers are as a rule reluctant to proceed to this step and only do so when other measures have failed, for no one can tell in advance whether the witch will be found in his own house or not. At times frivolous accusations of witchcraft are made in order to pay off an old grudge, but the fear of the real thing is very strong. The oil divination has to be confirmed by some other means, one of which is the ordeal of placing twigs in water. Some freshly cut twigs are placed in the mud at the water’s edge of a pond and vermilion is placed on them. The twigs represent the various households and spirits, as the drops of oil do in the oil and leaf method. The twig that withers first helps to fix the direction in which the villagers must look for the answer to their suspicions. Another method of divination is to place some rice wrapped in a leaf in a white-ant hill; if the ants attack the rice immediately, then witchcraft is involved.

The same truth is evident in all the Santal’s dealings with things that he cannot understand. The attitudes summed up in the terms “magic” and “religion” are both in evidence. It is not usual in these days to distinguish sharply between them. 3 Cf. G. and M. Wilson, The Analysis of Social Change, Cambridge University Press, 1945, p. 72: “Magic for us, though it may not postulate any transcendent reality, is an integral part of primitive religion.” Magic is used by the Santal as a tool to accomplish many and varied ends. It is not absent from his dealings with the spirits, and it can be used for social as well as antisocial ends. It does consequently overlap the sphere of “religion”, which, however, covers experiences where the arts of magic do not reach, while magic also works independently in some situations. For the most part, the various approaches to the problems of living are simultaneously pursued, by individuals as well as by society. “Charms” are in almost universal use as a precaution against sickness; one finds the shell of a land tortoise hung in the cowshed to ward off smallpox, or cowrie shells worn as a protection against the evil eye, and amulets worn round the arm as a matter of routine and called ran, or medicine. A double attitude is most apparent in efforts to control the weather that plays so great a rôle in their life. In a period of great drought the Santals probably arrange for a special festival to be held, with sacrifices offered to the “Five”. At the same time they busy themselves in other ways which are quite independent of the sacrifice. Unmarried girls plaster the dancing floor with cowdung, while the married women do the same to their own courtyards. An investigation is made as to whether any woman has tied a rope on any roof. It is taboo for women to climb on roofs in the ordinary way, but some of the cowsheds and outbuildings have low roofs on which it would be possible to tie the straw to a rafter without climbing up. If it transpires that any woman has done so, she is made to climb up on to the roof and undo her work, first removing her clothing. Other investigations are made too. It may be that someone has stored dried matkom on the floor in her house instead of placing it on a plank or on stones; or it may be that oil has been stored in a sealed pot, in which case the covering must be removed. Underlying all these activities is the conviction that the welfare of society and of the individual depends on establishing a balance between man, nature and the spirit world, and they witness to a faith that such a balance is possible of achievement.

The remaining festivals of the Santal year do not make the same stir throughout the countryside. Mokor is the name used in the area by Santals and non-Santals alike for the festival which takes place in mid-January. In some places it is called the Sakrat . At this time offerings are made to the ancestors in each house, and the celebration is accompanied by a display of stick dancing, which has replaced the former “sword and shield” dance. At the end of the following month the Mag Sim, the hen at the end of the month of Mag, is offered. In former times the village officials used to resign at this time and could be either replaced or reappointed, but the only relic of the old practice that has survived is that the headman has to treat the whole village to beer. Contracts with servants are renewed during the festival, and they receive the cloth that is always a part of the contract. In connection with rice cultivation there is the Erok’ Sim, the hen that is offered at the time of sowing, and Nãwãi, when the first fruits of the first rice crop are offered in the sacred grove. Before this takes place the new rice must not be eaten. The village priest cuts the first handful of the crop and offers some at the foot of each of the chief trees. A sprig is also tied round the trunk of the trees and remains there. While the prayer is being said, milk is poured on the offering. After the priest has done his part, similar offerings are made in every house to the house spirits and the ancestors, the rice being taken from the crops belonging to the family. In varying degrees the Santals share in some of the festivals and practices of the low-caste cultivators around them. In the early monsoon days, during the period of Rohini, which is an auspicious time for sowing rice, they make a mark round their houses with cowdung as a protection against snakes. The snake goddess festival occurs in late August, and although its observance is not widespread among the Santals there are some local celebrations, especially when there is an ojha in the village. The ojhas all keep this festival, and others go to them at this time to ask for medicines against snakebite. Some Hindu festivals, as we have seen, furnish the occasion for large gatherings of Santals. At Sarenga, in addition to the Lakshmi Puja, a somewhat smaller gathering takes place during the hot weather in connection with the celebration of the Siva Gajon at a local temple. At this time the Charak, or hook-swinging festival, otherwise known as the Pata, takes place. The practice has almost died out within the last fifteen years. It had been prohibited by the government, but as long as the old generation, which was accustomed to the practice, remained it continued with gradually diminishing fervour. The Santals gather now to sing and to dance. They also join the throngs of pilgrims, sightseers and traders who collect at the Bogri mela, or fair, some thirty miles from Sarenga. This fair, which is one of the most famous in Western Bengal, takes place at the time of the Dol Jatra near a temple dedicated to Krishna. The last day of the mela is chiefly renowned for the fact that on that day there is a great concourse of Santals for dancing.

The Santal pantheon includes about 150 deities, generally called BONGAS. These deities include a number of separate classes, which it is impossible to enumerate here. Some relate to the sub-clan, but even here we must distinguish between the BONGA of the place of origin of the clan, and its ancestral BONGA. Each village has a sacred grove, where we find represented the BONGAS common to the Santal tradition. They are generally benevolent. The forest BONGAS, however, are malevolent, and include the souls of people who died an unnatural death. Hindu influence is particularly notable in the appearance of Hindu goddesses as tutelary deities of Santal OJHAS. On the one hand, these goddesses patronize Santal witches and introduce disease; on the other hand, their patronage is necessary to combat the same evils. Hindu symbols, such as the trident, become potent ritual paraphernalia of the Santal OJHA.

Among nature-demons the sun ( mama, mama nui ) has the most extensive influence. He was created by the all-mother Mameumán and was set in the sky by Sintana, who also shows himself superior to him on earth (cf. p. 98). Therefore he is obliged to serve mankind, and one can influence him. The most natural thing that one wants from him is dryness for clearing the fields, and furthermore that the heat will not be too great, in the wider sense rain. He in fact accomplishes all this, induced to do so by the masks representing him or related to him. But he is also capable of other services, since still other things belong to him and start from him. Through his course in the sky he can see to it that the sicknesses do not approach from the four cardinal points and that the directions, that is, the world, do not collapse. Sicknesses particularly, which can be summed up in the term fever-heat, are directly from the nature of the sun’s heat. Therefore they are also called mulbatá, from the stem mul, mun (white, gleaming, hot) ( 1 . Cf. p. 99. ). “Sun-mask ( mama uákai ) sang for 76 dryness..., so that all the Kágaba could prepare their fields... (and) not be hungry. Then the sun mask ( mama uákai ) must be worn” ( 89 ) (Ill. 22 a ). “The great-sun mask ( mama nuikukui uákai ) ( 2 . Nuikukui = great sun, sun at midday ( 39, 1). The demon also has the byname Malkultse, in which mal in nuimala, sun in the afternoon, appears, and kultse = means for curing, offering stone. ) (Ill. 22 b ) collected all the stone powder (magic or offering stones) of the whole village because of the sexual offenses committed and carried everything to all the cardinal points, the intermediate directions, and all the remaining (eight) directions of the compass, so that sickness might not come” ( 62, 1 f.). The mask-demon thus does what the priest or novice who wears the mask does.

In order to feel himself to be a representative of the sun, the demon Zugí-mask ( zugí uákai ) had to have a very strange train of thought. He boasts in front of the priest Sivalukukui that he would be the sun of all peoples ( salinga gúatsi mama ), for he would protect against sickness to the ends of the directions with small offering stones. If any sickness were to come, he would close off the path of the sickness with a fence. But Sivalukukui denies that he could be the sun for all peoples ( 77 ). He could not be this, adds Trinidad Noivita in explanation, for he only attended to warding off sickness, not everything else, for instance, the harvest. According to the laws of sound change, Zugí corresponds to nugi, shell-lime, which is enjoyed with coca leaves. Sugi, the gourd container for the lime, is seemingly the same word. When Híuika brought the shells ( nuksuzua ) ( 4 . The word nugi, lime, is in most of the designations for shells and snails. Cf. nuksei, nukuluva, nukuva . ) from the sea in order to burn them at home in the mountains, he let himself be led astray to sleep with them, for they were girls. -- Such forbidden cohabitation is, in the belief of the Kagaba, always the cause of sickness. -- The shells avenged themselves, and after they were burned, there began the fever heat which the white ( 5 . Or the red ones; cf. 6, 3 /omitted in the translation/. ) shells brought, while the green ones brought the chills of fever. “So Híuika brought all kinds of sickness... Previously... one had begun to bar the path of sickness. But they went out and came in behind Híuika, since they were human beings” ( 6 , 3 ff.). Therefore, in usual fashion, the task of the Zugí mask, as demon of the burned shell-lime, is to influence the “fever heat” of the sicknesses brought into the mountains by the shells as a result of the burning. He is therefore also a kind of fire-demon. Now since one of the main tasks of the sun demons is 79 to ward off sickness approaching from the cardinal points, the Zugí mask wishes to do the same and to represent himself as “the sun of all peoples,” whereupon Priest Sivalukukui rightly told him that he could not possibly be the sun for all peoples, clearly because he had only limited powers over sicknesses coming from the sea, quite apart from the other tasks of the sun.

Those are all the demons relative to the sun. The remaining celestial bodies, for instance, saka (the moon) (or Namsaya) and Hindukana (the morning star), son of the sun and the moon, are admittedly mentioned as demonic creatures ( 3 ), but nothing is known about their activities or about masks. The stars ( zuméia ) are not mentioned as independent beings either. Yet when planting banana shoots, one spits upon each plant “so that the stars of the heavens may not see it and rot it.” On the other hand there is a very instructive sickness and fire demon, Grandmother ( saka ) Suzauban, for whom nonetheless there does not seem to be a mask either. She is the rainbow ( zuzabanka ). Her name means a bifurcation, such as the tips of the rainbow represent, and in its essential parts appears, for example, in the words kaltsusú (forked stick), suzué (elbow), and nuksuzua (shell). Her rainbow form is also indicated in the narrative devoted to her ( 12, 3): “Grand mother Suzauban had, and this was why she was called Suzauban, great claws half a span long (on her fingers), and on her forehead she had a broad horn a span long.” In addition a characteristic trait of hers is that she is always swinging in a hammock ( 12 , 7 ff.), which is all the more striking since the Kágaba women never do this, but only the men. Her older and younger brothers are the sicknesses in human form ( mulbatá kágabakuei, 12, 14); she herself thus actually personifies sickness and as such is a fire creature. But just because of this, in the Kágaba mind, she is precisely the suitable person to destroy, to devour, sickness. She is entrusted with this task by the all-mother Gauteóvan, the mother of fire. Since, however, she eats human beings instead of sicknesses, that is, when sickness destroys the people, she is killed by the younger brother Utsimata, cooked, and devoured by her brothers, the sicknesses, whom Utsimata invites to the feast, in the belief that it was some other meat. Apparently the disappearance of the rainbow and persistence in its original components, the sicknesses, are illustrated through this end. At the time of the new formation the original components, the brothers, are then devoured by the rainbow. In addition the traits mentioned would also fit the lunar crescent.

The narrative about Kasindukua likewise gives information concerning these masks. This one was set up by the all-mother “as older brother and lord of the trees, threads, stones, kinds of earth, streams, and all kinds of straw” ( 10, 3), which is supposed to mean that these things, “the godlike ( alúnakuei ) winds, trees, plants, threads, varieties of straw and soil, rivers, stones, and all things that one sees,” provided him with information in the battle with Namsiku ( 10, 18, 20). Likewise they formed for him the missiles for the traps in which it was hoped to catch him. But since they were of his kind, they fell as puma jaws ( nabkakai ), as little pumas ( nabi vúlukuei ), which Priest Namsiku blew on and left behind, so that the puma-jaw mask ( nabkakai uákai be present ( 10 , 27 f., 41) ( 2 . In the battle Kaviukukui tears from Seizankua his “headband of hair,” the puma-jaw ( nabkaka salakuka, 2, 52), from which it is seen that the puma jaw is also a mystical war-ornament. ). The tubular beads at the chin of the mask correspond 81 to the tubular beads that were laid out as bait in a pot under the traps and, like the traps, were women themselves ( 10, 21 ff.). Obviously these were to tempt him to sexual excesses, which for the Kágaba count as the mystical causes of sickness and thus are closely bound up with a sickness-demon such as Kasindukua. It is probably also on account of this sickness-nature that a strange means is used to overcome him, pouring melted wax into his mouth, “whereupon all kinds of sicknesses, toothaches, and many (other) pains plagued him” ( 10, 34). Therefore not only do sicknesses come from a sickness-demon; he personifies not only these themselves, but also the human beings plagued by the sicknesses ( 1 . The name Kasindukua probably comes from kasikuama, the yellow blossom of a vine from which the yellow color of the same name is obtained, and tsukua, small, thus in all = the small yellow. Cf. the chapter “Sound Changes” in the section on the grammar/omitted in the translation/. ). That moreover the stones, trees, etc. are sickness-demons and at the same time pumademons is proved at least for the stones by the song 133: “Upon the (mountain) Gonduzué a dance was danced with reference to all stones ( salyinga hárlula hiúngulan ); a dance of the stones was danced ( hárlulatsi kala ), so that no sickness might arise. Dances are danced against all kinds of sickness ...”

We have already become familiar with demonic animals, the puma, frogs, and snakes. The puma Kasindukua personifies fire and sicknesses, the snakes represent the evil lakes, and the frog calls the rain. A variety of monkey, guiví, does the same when it cries. The bird nuksasa, 86 evidently because of its orange legs and its similarly colored beak, influences the leaves so that they do not wither, since it belongs to the sun. On the other hand, the same color assures for it a sexual influence (cf. Ch. V), and one therefore sings to it at a christening. Other animals are demonic in nature, because they [unavailable]oretell misfortune or death. The Mukurito, “a magic bird who plays his game with you ( hurluvá ) 1 . Actually game-bird (from hurleesi and nuva ), translation brujo (sorcerer). He is the size of an arara, with white breast and black wings with white stripes. , is given to calling you so that you become sick or a jaguar appears, since he precedes this animal” ( 48 ). “When the guivuka 2 . A small, reddish bird. , the bird of the mountains, sits on the tip of the temple and sings, he frightens you and gives you the news: ‘Older brother, you will die’ ” ( 73 ). Whoever hears the owl ( sunhui ) cry late at night must die. The little bird kakseisei, who sings very rarely, thereby announces serious sickness, and the white bird suikala, who sings in the night, announces death. Whoever sees the rare fish otter ( naui or nauikala, Sp. perro de agua ) swim downstream knows that someone in his family will die. Likewise the big toad ( maukuí teima ) announces death when it croaks in the hut or by leaving its excrement on one of the low stools (cf. p. 41).

The best proof of the consistency with which the Kágaba have developed their view of the mastery of the demons is given by the existence of the Hiséi mask, that is, the mask-demon of the dead. Without knowing the activity of this mask, one would have to assume, according to previous information, that here the dead or death-demon would be used in order to save people from death. To be sure, that is not given directly from the tasks of the mask, but from the remarkable name hiséi huvéi for all kinds of the magical stone powder wrapped in maize leaves 2 . Ahuba = covering. , which is used for the most varied protective purposes, but especially as a means against sickness and to drive away death. A means against death is at the same time a means of death, just as a song against a demon is a song of the mask-demon concerned. Now the Hiséi mask is a demon who has to look after all the preparations for festivals, in particular the festive foods. Among these, moreover, the food for christenings is mentioned in particular ( 27, 2), which, like the complete act of christening, is intended for keeping the newborn child alive. Furthermore, the hut for the first cohabitation of newlywed couples is called hiséi huvéi, like the stone powder in its wrapper, for here, as at the christening, it is used to preserve future life. And finally it is one of the foremost tasks at any festival to protect the dancers and the whole village from sickness. We must assume that the festive foods also serve this purpose more than would appear at first glance. A particular concern of the Hiséi mask is therefore a concern about the canchi fruit, which is used as festive food, to which there belongs a special two-day dance so that the fruit may not be eaten by animals. If one recalls the heavenly origin of this fruit and the detailed narrative about its spread across the land of the Kágaba ( 5, 23 ff.), one may deduce from that its importance as a festive food, and, to be sure, its importance for health, because it is the “death mask” which has assumed concern for it. Among other things the Hiséi mask says: “Sweep in front of the temple, sweep the rubbish together well, so that no puma and no snake may eat me, (for) I fear them” ( 31, 5). That means, speaking from the developmental history of this demon: The sweeping in front of the temple 91 must be done so that no sickness may come, for the puma personifies these. And in connection with the snake, one can probably think immediately of the deadly bite of the poisonous snakes, which are quite common there. Since his mask with the snout-like jaw and the big teeth in it is supposed to represent the puma and on both sides it bears a carved snake (Ill. 31), this clearly expresses the fact that the snake is part of his character, just as sickness is. Since the all-mother herself attends to all ceremonies (p. 97), he comes here from her for the festival and then returns to her in his temple-mountain ( 31, 7). He lives with her, as does the priestly demon Muluku, who is related to him (p. 136). And just as the latter formerly lived on earth, the Hiséi mask was already taking care of the canchi fruit “when he was still a man,” that is, when he was still alive ( 27, 2). This mask too thus belongs among the activity-demons, as did the preceding beings, because it personifies the human means against sickness and death, but it no longer rests on nature. The new foundation is an abstract one: death or the dead.

The means of achieving ritual purity and strength include, besides the rules for sexual activity, certain food prohibitions, and withdrawal into the temple, confession, which consists of an acknowledgment of sins. It takes place only when one is sick or otherwise has misfortune. It is not because sin in itself oppresses the Kágaba and he wishes to be freed from it that he confesses, in order to be able to live as a pure man, but because otherwise it would go ill with him. The most important sins known to him are forbidden cohabitation, especially unnatural sexual satisfaction with close relatives or with animals ( sagá sagá ), as is given as the cause of the great flood, and adultery. Another expression for “to sin” is zinkuali . The fact that precisely sexual excesses are regarded as sins and the cause of sickness and evil undoubtedly lies in a basic view of the Kágaba which is also to be found among other tribes, namely, that cohabitation and intercourse with a woman weaken the strength of a man and endanger the success of every undertaking. This accounts for the magical strength of the novices, as long as they have not yet had intercourse with a woman.

But that it was necessary to acknowledge the sins in order to be spared the consequences is likewise to be regarded as a religious idea, not, say, as a social measure of the priests in order to keep the people disciplined and to increase their influence. Confession perhaps corresponds to the widespread idea of getting rid of a sickness through transference, which is also found among the Kágaba. On the way from the coast to Pueblo Viejo there is a place on this side of La Cueva where those who pass by, even the Colombians, throw leaves. It is the grave of Tumú . If someone, for instance, has a wound and throws there, say, a leaf which he had put on the wound, 96 then the dead man would devour the sickness. Likewise -- one must conclude -- the first step in ridding oneself of the evil consequences of a sin is to admit it openly, so that it will leave one. Confession does not exist among the Kágaba alone. There is something similar, for instance, among the Eskimo and the ancient Mexicans 1 . Boas, Bull. of the Amer. Museum of Nat. Hist ., XV, New York, 1907, pp. 120 f. -- Preuss, Globus, Vol. 83, 1903, pp. 254, 271 f. About the introduction of confession through Christian influence, see, on the other hand, for example, Morris Wolf, Iroquois Religion, New York, 1919, p. 58. . After the confession, among the Kágaba, the priest undertakes, among other things, ceremonies with certain stones for curing or for protection against sickness and other evils. But even the punishment, insofar as it follows in addition or alone, is to be viewed as originally a protection (cf. Ch. VI), even though it too has in view little by little more the social effects of a warning and education.

One has to be astonished at the latitude confession has reached among the Kágaba. It was customary that every adult sick person had to confess before he would be cured, and likewise anyone who, in fear of sickness or misfortune, wished to avoid these by means of punishment or a protective ceremony of the priest. Furthermore, before festivals every individual in the whole village had to confess, upon which protection from sickness followed as one of the acts of the festival. The following assertion in a song ( 56, 6) refers to this: “Then the Colombians came. . . and the four-day and the nine-day dances and confessions ( alunezguaka ) disappeared.” This is to say that confession was part of the ceremony, but the numbers refer to each individual one. That the confession before a festival also continued for many days was confirmed to me. Unusual events, such as eclipses of the sun ( gesubuku ) and moon ( sulabuku ) 2 . The words do not express the translation in themselves, but probably consist of ge, which means fire in Marokasa (cf. gei ahuisi [to blow on firewood = to kindle a fire]), su (moon), and bauku (female), which here perhaps has the sense of weak. or earthquakes ( kaksata ), offered other occasions for confession. It was believed that then a puma ate the sun or the moon and the world might come to an end. The expression for confession ( aluna izguasi ) means “to say the inner” and is also used in the more general sense of “to speak one’s thoughts,” just as aluna izguasihi is used for persuading someone to speak his thoughts ( 2, 22).

The third religious means of expression, besides song and dance, is the stone offering or stone magic, through which one can likewise obtain help and protection in many ways, but particularly against sickness and death. How this has been arrived at can best be understood from the expression hiséi huvá (covering of the dead) for the stone powder wrapped in maize leaves. What comes from the dead protects against death and the dead, just as the demon masks influence the demons. And the stones have many connections to the dead. The ancient forebears were once stone people or changed themselves into stones after death, so the little stones and stone beads used for this mostly come then from the old graves of the coast, from which the Kágaba themselves get them, if they do not perhaps buy them from the Colombians. My whole supply of these magic stones came from the Colombians; the Kágaba, however, had specific names for all of them, and for them themselves their own were not for sale. Finally, the stones were also puma-like creatures and as such brought sicknesses (see pp. 121 ff.). But the little magic stones could do much more than just cure sickness and give protection from it. They are able to do that by means of their various colors, which corresponded so closely to the appearance of certain nature-demons, e.g., the sun, fire, from which again, among other things, sicknesses also came forth and were obstructed.

Since all the strength of the priests consists in taking into service the sun demon and even the passes with the little stones in part imply an imitation of the movement of the sun, e.g., to the four cardinal points, so also the activity of curing, protecting, and helping with stones is called mamalesi (literally, “to become the sun”). The stones used ( hagi ) are differentiated according to whether they are unbored or pierced, that is, beads as asévakai (boys, that is, male) ( 1 . Sp. doncella /virgin/, because of their intactness. ) and päukué (with hole, that is, female) ( 2 . Cf. also kuizi abunzi (female cane-flute with a hole) and sigi (male one with five holes). ), and accordingly, when it is a matter of using the whole stones for the well-being of either sex, the former are used for the male sex, the latter kind for the female sex. If the beads are oblong, they are called hul-a, -e ( 3 . Sp. tuma. ), and it is explicable also from the female 101 nature of these hula that they are women in the narrative about Kasindukua ( 10 , 21). The unbored stones, asévakai , for the most part also show elaboration and likewise come from old graves of the coast. Usually the little stones are used pounded into a coarse powder. For this a small bit of the stone is sufficient; it is wrapped in maize leaves and later strewn in the air with the fingers, either in the vicinity of the persons or domestic animals to be protected or in the planting to be consecrated, upon the grave of the dead who is to be kept away, etc. The maize leaves, on the other hand, are thrown away or gathered together on large stones. One frequently finds these leaves in the vicinity of settlements or even on the stones along the way. With the little whole stone or with the little packet of crushed stone, the main part of the ceremony consists of passing it three times to the right and three times to the left around the head of the person or the domestic animal that is sick or that is to be protected, or one goes three times to the right and to the left around the house, village, or planting concerned. A separate packet is made for each particular kind of stone, even when several stones are used for one person, with the result that countless little packets are assembled for all the persons of a village. These are then tied together into a bundle in order to perform the ceremony with it. Every woman gives the priest as many maize leaves as there are persons in her household to be protected, and he makes the little packets. The powder is called hiséi (dead man) or hárvulu (little stone), and the packet is called hiséi huvá (covering of the dead), or ábukai , from musi (to beat someone, to beat the drum) and ibusi (to hurl, to throw), which occurs, for instance, in seibuká (the whizzer stick) ( 1 . Used only by boys. ), sibuká (the one spinning a thread). Abukai thus means “the little packet that throws, or scatters, the powder.” To prepare the packet is called guasi, ikuasi , but this is also bound up with the things to be benefited, for instance, kualama guasi (to consecrate the field crops, actually to prepare the stone powder for the field crops). More general than ábukai or hiséi huvá is teizáua , which can also designate other kinds of magic remedies. More frequently such stone powder of any kind is hung in a little bag ( noamata ) in the temple for protection against any possible wrong and to further the general well-being. Four of them were hanging in the cansamaria of Chief Arregocé of San Miguel, one on each side of the two doors. The content is then called salingale , that is, all together, and the same name is also used if by way of exception several kinds of stone are joined together in one packet. In one song ( 94 ) the expression zukavaku is mentioned for the little bag of stones of the women, which probably stems from suka (tip, small) and bauku (female): the same as “the female small (stones).” There it is said: “So sang Mother Túrliue to her little bag of stones and to the little bags of stones of all four women’s lineages.” This means that whoever represents Mother Túrliue , the source lake of the Rio Surivaka, sings so that her little bag of stones, as well as those of the four women’s lineages to which the women of the settlement belong, may be efficacious for the field crops and other things.

102 There now follows an enumeration of the magic stones and their uses in alphabetical order ( 1 . Usually several stones are used at the same time. That is why each kind of stone is first presented by itself. The stones, with the exception of guikuitsi , are all in my possession. ):

1. aseihi, asenhi ; reddish; see 2 to 7 of the following enumeration. 2. aseihi, haktasi, nóakuitsi, sivalukuitsi ; used crushed; against sickness of all the village inhabitants; in connection with festivals. 3. aseihi, haktasi, sukuitsi ; crushed, all three in one packet ( salingale ); against sickness of the dancers; in connection with festivals. 4. aseihi, haktasi, sukuitsi ; crushed; at the beginning of the apprenticeship of the temple novices. 5. aseihi, kulzakuitsi, nóakuitsi, sívalukuitsi ; crushed; when the youth for the first time cohabits with the girl whom the later intends to marry. 6. aseihi, kulzakuitsi ; crushed; for the increase of cattle. 7. aseihi, haktasi, mukuhaktasi ; crushed; for the thriving of the coca planting. 8. avikuitsi , from avi (blood); red; see 9. 9. avikuitsi, gaulkuitsi, kulzakuitsi ; crushed; in connection with the first menstruation of a girl. 10. gaulkuitsi , from gaulí , hut in connection with the christening, where the priest prepares the little packets of stone powder, act of baptism; cf. gaulhuvé , hut for the cohabitation of the newlywed couple; red; see 9. 11. 11. gaulkuitsi, guikuitsi, kálguakuitsi, kulzakuitsi, nikuitsi ; crushed; in connection with the christening for the newborn; gaulkuitsi and kulzakuitsi for the graves of the grandparents, kálguakuítsi and níkuitsi for the grave of the great-grandfather, the latter two kinds of stones along with guikuitsi for the grave of the great-grandmother, after the packets for the other forebears named have been touched by it. The powder is strewn on the graves concerned. 12. guikuitsi , from gúi (to make) in gaulí gúi (to christen). Color unknown; see 11. 13. haktasi = hagi tasi , green stone; greenish; see 2, 3, 4, 7. 14. kágabakuitsi , from kágaba (human being), probably because this stone is mostly worn in the necklace (of the women); reddish-white; see 15. 15. kágabakuitsi, mamaukue, seúke ; crushed; for the curing of sickness, especially fever ( 2 . In the case of a minor illness, only the latter two stones are used. ). 16. kálguakuitsi ; blackish, oblong; about ten stones are stuck separately into the ground practically in the middle of the temple, for protection against fire in particular; see 11, 17. 17. kálguakuitsi, kulzakuitsi ; crushed; for the thriving of the fruit trees. 18. karsúukue ; gleaming grey-green; crushed; for the curing of the heat and chills of fever. 19. kuidbaulu ; reddish-white; for a wife, a tubular bead is put in the grave of her father or her mother, so that she may not become sick. 103 20. kuizizi ; reddish-grey; for a little grandson, put into the grave of his grandfather or grandmother, so that he may not become sick. 21. kulzakuitsi , from kultsa (seed); reddish-yellow; see 5, 6, 9, 11, 17. 22. mámakuitsi , from mama (sun); red; a) crushed, in order to obtain dryness; b) crushed, strewn on the sugar-cane planting or in the temple for protection against burning by the sun or fire. 23. mamaukue , from mama (sun); reddish-green; see 15. 24. mukuhaktasi , from abauku (female?) and hagi tasi (green stone); brownish-gray; see 7. 25. mulkuakuitsi , from mulkua (white); white, crushed; the usual passes are made with the packet at the place where cattle were, in order to find again lost cattle or a runaway pig. 26. níkuitsi , from ni (water); white; to make post smooth and strong. The pots are rubbed outside and inside with the little stones. 27. nikuma , from ni (water?); white; to make pots smooth and strong. The pots are rubbed outside and inside with the little stones. 28. nóakuitsi ; dark red; crushed; for the thriving of the coca planting; see 2, 5. 29. nuizuakala ; reddish-grey; is stuck in the grave of the grandfather or grandmother for the protection of the granddaughter. 30. núikuitsi , from nui (sun); pink, crushed; for the protection of the sugar-cane planting against burning by the sun and being eaten by the worms. 31. seikuitsi , from sei (night); black, charcoal, crushed; strewn on the grave of the dead, so that he may not return and will go far away, and so that no one else in his family will become sick. 32. seúkue ; blackish-grey; see 15. 33. sukuizi , from su (light, white?); light grey, somewhat greenish; two longish studs, one narrower, male one ( sévakai ) and one broader, female one ( abauku ), are always tied together and put on a distant stone; against sickness, probably in the case of married persons ( 1 . The female stud in this case, however, is not pierced, as is otherwise done in connection with women. ). 34. súmulu , from the stem su (light) and vulu (small); white; about ten of them are stuck in the floor in the hut of the man and in the hut of the woman, for the protection of the hut, probably especially against fire. 35. sunni, from the stem su (light); white; used like súmulu ; see 34. 36. sivalukuitsi ; pink; see 2, 5. 37. ukuitsi ; light red, crushed; to protect the temple against burning and other damage; see 3, 4. 38. zalakuitsi , from zala (outward, coming from somewhere else); gray, stuck completely in the ground where the pigs feed, also crushed; so that the little pigs may not die, but thrive.

In connection with the smaller stones there is the stone ax ( seikuí ), with which dancing allegedly was done formerly, and, to be sure, with a red stone-ax ( seikuí tsusi ) in order to bring about dryness and with a green one ( seikuí tasi ) for rain ( 20 , 2). Unfortunately in the case of most of the stones the native designations cannot be translated. Nevertheless the basis for their effect comes out from the few which are understandable and in part also from the color. It is no different from what we have already observed in the case of the demons. The stones named with the word for sun ( mama, nui ), mámakuitsi, núikuitsi, mamaukue , are for dryness, against sun-buming, fire, or sickness (the heat of fever); the names of stones combined /104 cont./ with light, white ( su, mulkua ), sukuizi, súmulu, sunni, mulkuakuitsi, are likewise related to protection against sickness, against fire, or to finding (the appearance) of cattle. The red stone-ax ( seikuí tsusi ) calls for dryness. Likewise, the light red sukuitsi is aimed at protection of the temple against fire and for the health of the dancers, the reddish aseihi no less than four times for protection against sickness, and for the same thing the dark red nóakuitsi . The reddish-yellow stone kuizakuitsi, from Kultsa (seed, has a strong sexual meaning and operates in connection with the first cohabitation, in connection with a girl’s first menstruation, for the increase of cattle, and as a means of fertility for the newborn child at the christening ( gaulí ), just like the red stone ( gaulkuitsi ), which is also useful at the first menses. And this word gaulí is evidently found in a sexual sense in the name of the wedding hut, gaulhuvé, Furthermore the red nóakuitsi is suitable for the first cohabitation, just like the reddish aseihi, which also helps for the increase of the cattle. The red avikuitsi, from avi (blood), again is one of the efficacious stones in connection with a girl’s first menstruation. So we see that with the color red, which in this case gets its efficacy from the female menstrual flow, is characterized the sexual act, but also protection against sickness, just as in the case of the red sun. The sickness demon Kasindukua, after all, also arose from the first menses of the all-mother. The meaning of blood and red for the sexual act now also explains the rule that temple novices may only eat animals that have no blood (cf. p. 85).

105 The gleaming gray-green karsúukue serves to heal the chills and heat of fever; the “green stone” (haktasi) is presented three times against sickness and therefore is also related to the chills of fever, corresponding to the chills of fever that come from the green (blue) shells (cf. p. 120), but it also works for the coca planting, just like the red stone nóakuitsi and the reddish aseihi. The gray-greenish sukuizzi also helps against sickness. The “green (blue) stone-ax” ( seikui tasi ) calls the rain; the stone níkuítsi from ni (water), which also calls the rain, is white, because there is white, red, and green (blue) rain (cf. p. 127). The latter is also used at christenings. Finally it is understandable that the black stone seikuitsi, from sei (night), is for driving away the dead, when one recalls that formerly they came upon the earth at the beginning of twilight and ate people ( 15, 6).

The question now arises: In what way are these religious performances, songs, dances, and magic ceremonies organized in the general festivals and what are the festive times? To determine this is extremely difficult, because I only saw one festival, which nevertheless must be regarded as an especially favorable event, and otherwise we must refer to isolated statements; also many acts are not limited to a festival, and statements about time may easily be subject to error. In addition some songs stem from unfamiliar villages, whose festivals the informant could not have known in detail; others again are no longer celebrated, and formerly there was surely a much greater number of festivals. If we first exclude the family festivals, which are to be dealt with in the next chapter, it appears merely from the content of many 107 songs and the statements given in connection with them, as well as from the purposes of many of the little magic stones, that they were used only for events in the life of an individual and for sporadic occasions not bound to any specific time, such as, for example, the curing of sickness. We must think of all such religious acts as most insignificant and performed without any festive adornment. For the curing of sickness there is no song or dance at all; the magic stones suffice. All the sickness songs are rather protective measures for the community and are danced at the festivals.

The three festive times in Palomino and Noavaka, March, September, and November-December, are sharply distinguished, but have no special names. All are called nuvakala, because there is dancing with the feather adornment of the birds ( nuva ), or kuiza (dance), while the church festivals are called pita, pitei, from the Spanish pitar (to pipe), or suziuan, from suzú (the stranger). The 110 March festival is to get from the sun protection against sickness for the coming rainy season and in addition a brief continuation of the dry season in order to finish the field work. It is therefore concerned exclusively with health, whereas that occurs only incidentally in connection with the two other festivals ( 40, 62, 77 ). In the September festival there is expressed the endeavor to call forth rain or to lessen its abundance, to moderate the winds, to keep all kinds of animals away from the crops, and in every way to care for the thriving of the crops. The December festival is concerned with the restoration of the dry season, with the harvest itself, and with all the tasks of the dry season, such as housebuilding and the making of pots. Common to all the festivals, besides the above-mentioned concern for health, are: at the beginning, songs for the birds whose feathers are worn at festivals ( 49 to 51 ); occasional songs for the animals who make up the festive foods ( 52 to 55, 63 ); at the end, songs for the eating of salt ( 29, 30, 64, 65 ), and after that the women’s dances, which are almost exclusively directed against animals that pursue the chickens ( 1 . The fox song ( 42 )is also sung at the end. ) or damage the crops ( 68 to 74 ). Some of these, for instance, the dance of the lizard ( 75 ) and of the pasaroyo /Sp. pasarríos, “lizard, basilisk”/ ( 76, are also performed at church festivals, but then without the feather adornment. At these feasts of the saints the women are said to dance in a circle, without holding on to one another, while one who has a little drum hanging down and beats it with two sticks moves in the middle. The flute is not blown in connection with this. The salt dance too is actually a dance of the women, that is, originally of the girls trained in the temple, like the novices, as their future wives. Such general songs and dances, however, are not absolutely necessary. Only the salt dance seems never to be omitted.

During the night the Hiséi mask dances with the great head-dress, and indeed every two hours it alternates with the other mask in the dance, while the other four dancers are relieved every four hours. So it went from eight o’clock at night until four o’clock in the morning, whereupon all the participants slept for two hours. Later a fifth dancer joined the four. The priest Jacinto Garavito of Palomino, who arranged the whole festival, often moved for a long time at the head of the dancers. Yet he wore no special clothing, only the rattle, like the four young novices. He kept a sharp eye on the precision of the dance and also danced himself with knees more deeply bent and more in time than did the novices, whose efforts in fact left much to be desired. A few times I was a witness as he struck one of them in punishment with the hard stick of the lime calabash. Priest Miguel Nolavita was also occasionally active. He owned the two masks which he had loaned for the festival.

With sunrise of the first festive day, at about six o’clock, it was the turn of the Sun- Surlí mask, and, to be sure, for the whole day. For the aim was to perform the dances in the four directions, in order to prevent sicknesses from reaching the Kágaba from there ( 26 ). For this the dancers stood for a few minutes turned in each direction, beginning with the west then turning to the east, south, and north, both within and outside the temple. This demon was very fundamentally different from the other masks. His mask was completely black; a crack in the nose, covered with wax, was explained as the result of a quarrel between him and Grandmother Munkulú , with whom he had in his time pursued Seizankua (2, 9). A cap with the reddish feathers of the flamingo ( sinungela ) adorned the head. Like the Hiséi mask, instead of men’s trousers and shirt, he wore the woman’s garment ( zakua teima ), which formerly was the dress of both men and women, 115 except that in the dance both shoulders remain free, whereas among the women one shoulder is always covered. Around the hips he wore a colored woven belt with resounding snail shells at the back, just like the Hiséi mask, but, as something special, he had a little plaited penis in front and in the left hand the little basket and the club decorated with a snake scratched on it. He Iacked the palm-leaf apron ( huká ) which the Hiséi mask wears over the woman’s dress, and he also did not have its white cloth hanging far down the back and the pointed collar over it (Ill. 34), and he was indisputably not as adorned with stone beads and golden bracelets as the Hiséi mask demon, so that the latter, who in relation to the Surlí mask was designated as younger brother and as subordinate to him, yet outwardly and in the whole course of the dance had some advantages over him. Although on the same day maize leaf packets were prepared with the four stones, aseihi, haktasi, nóakuitsi , and silvalukuitsi , for the health of the whole village and the powder was strewn in the air, the dances had nothing to do with this, according to the content of the accompanying songs ( 26 ). But in the similar case of the Great-sun mask ( Nuikukui uakai 62 ) the little packets, tied together, are carried by the dancers to all four directions, and in doing so they hold them in front of the mouth, with the thought that they are thus going to the ends of the horizon. The song of the Zugí mask also expresses the same thought ( 77 ).

Gaulí is a form similar to saulí (the male member), which is derived from zahi (to eat). For the view of the Kágaba is that in cohabitation the male organ devours the secretion of the female. “Now the member (kalguákala) of Matuna devoured (arzá) the sexual organ (hakulue) ( 2 . Literally: female hill = mound of Venus. ) of the wife of Songela ” runs the description of a cohabitation ( 11, 10). 121 But the general designation gazahi, gaitsahi (to practice cohabitation), expresses the process more clearly, for the literal translation says: to eat excrement, from gai, ga (excrement) and zahi (to eat). Cf. also gai-misi, ga-misi (to make excrement) and huízi misi (to make urine). That is why the female sex organ is also called gaimiskuí (that which makes excrement) or sotá (= sautá ) [the eating, the food]). Gahi and zahi (to eat), however, are synonomous words, so that gaulí = saulí is the male member, and gaulí gúi, to make into a male member or to make procreative or fruitful. Thus one says of a christened Kágaba in a personal construction, gaulí agakuane (he is christened), or, in the contrary case, gauli agakuagele (he is not yet christened). Now it is also explicable that one of the five stones that are used for the newborn child is called guikuitsi (stone to make [procreative]) and that each of the other packets must be touched with the packet of powder from this stone. When all the stone powder is strewn onto the graves of the grandparents and great-grandparents, it is likewise desired to prevent sickness with this, just as in other cases other stone powder on the graves of the grandparents is supposed to ward off sickness.

For both sexes the hair is allowed to grow from childhood on, without ever cutting it. Long hair hanging down is thus common to both. As early as nine to twelve years of age the boys receive from the father the lime container (sugi), with which the men occupy themselves at any time, but especially during their spare time, by wiping off the stick all around the upper edge of the container (cf. p. 39). The all-mother gauteóvan gave the container as a spouse (seua), so that one might eat lime out of it from youth to old age (128) . Except for the singing of the appropriate song, however, no celebration takes place in connection with it. But narratives report on the procurement of the shells for it from the coast and on the sicknesses that arose from this ( 5, 5 ff., 6, 2 ff.). The partaking of lime is no remedy against sicknesses, however, as one might expect, or else the very superstitious Kágaba Silvestre and Trinidad would not have given up taking it. But it is important as a supplement to the 124 taking of coca, insofar as coca is used, along with the container ( tami ) of liquid tobacco ( noái ), for the greeting. The one arriving does not give his hand, but hands to the other his tobacco container with the words hai tami (here is the container) or merely haiga (here), whereupon the latter puts his finger on the opening and lifts it to his mouth up to ten times, usually without the finger being moistened. The one greeted does the same with his container, and both mutually thrust a handful of coca leaves into each others hand or shoulder bag. At the most one might first ask hántsiga itei? (is it going well?), whereupon the one greeted likewise repliès manki hántsiga? (with you [is it going] well too?). At departure one only says nei or neinigukú (I am going). The exchange of coca and tobacco juice has a binding force for friendly feeling, for from the fact that the novice hands him these two things Kasíndukua recognizes his good intentions and the warnings of his sister in regard to this novice as lies ( 10, 15 f.). Two songs are also devoted to the preparation of the tobacco juice, one of which says that one must die if one does not sing ( 107 . 119 ). It is thus a very dangerous pleasure. There is also a narrative about the bringing of coca by the deer Bunkuéi, the daughter of Gauteóvan (cf. p. 99), which fits in with the custom that only the women may pick the coca leaves, whereas the men undertake the seeding and transplanting of the young bushes. At bottom, however, that is only the usual division of labor, according to which the women take care of the growing plants and the daily gathering of the produce, while the men do the clearing and planting. The women eat neither coca nor lime nor tobacco juice. Correspondingly, they have no greeting. Even when I greeted them, they never answered.

The horizontal cross-stick closing the semicircle of arara feathers at the bottom of the headdress of the Hiséi mask is also called (a)kulzakala, because at its two ends are hung tufts of the yellow tailfeathers of the oriole ( nuluka ), which “are supposed to dance in the wind.” They are called anuíbuka, from avi (blood), because of their golden color, and musi (to beat), ibusi (to throw), which refers to the movement of the feathers, and clearly are supposed to work against sickness, corresponding to the character of the Hiséi mask. In this way it is explicable that the two-stick ornament originally belonged to the huts of the men, as the support of all religious performances. Later we shall also deal with the meaning of the single sticks on the women’s huts.

The punishments for the man consisted of fasting for four or five days and partial continence in drinking, which was interrupted only by eating a few potatoes at midnight, and, in addition, lengthy kneeling and holding heavy stones with out-stretched arms and beatings on the elbow with the lime stick if the arms sank down (cf. p. 85). After the punishment the good-for-nothings were also sent into exile to Surivaka to the priest Felix Daza, until they had improved. In more recent times they were put in the cepo /Sp. “stocks”/. The punishment of putting a bar both over and under the legs and tying together the projecting ends ( cepo huvu ) is also to be traced back to Spanish influence. For the woman there was only one kind of punishment: to sit for about two hours on a pointed stone ( harsukale, from hagi [stone] and asuka [pointed]), which was considered a severe punishment. Since this measure was not used for men, it doubtless came about through consideration of the meaning of gai, ga, excrement, as secretion from the anus and, on the other hand, from the genital organs during cohabitation, and it is shown by this kind of punishment 129 that it was supposed to be not only a physical torment, but a magical influence on the suppression of sexual offenses or the consequences proceeding from them, such as sickness, etc., just as the fasting of the men and the interruption at midnight, as at the festivities, are already to be thought of as a magico-religious influence of the same kind. Now I believe that the pointed stick ( husukala ) at the tip of the womens’ huts is to be explained as a symbol of the harsukale, the stone used in the punishment. But in reality it is not a symbol, but rather again a means of warding off and influencing, like the double sticks with the cross-stick, the suspended bats, the potsherds, and the sun’s rays on the huts or temples.

That nothing good could be expected from the dead we have already seen from the stone powders and the stone beads that are strewn on the graves or buried there in order to avoid sickness. When the sun went down from the middle ( 15, 6), the dead person came to the huts in order to devour the survivors, that is, to make them sick, and that is why he is buried on the first afternoon after his death; thus, if he died in the afternoon, he would be buried immediately. This was the time of the dead, when they were active and also could most easily be driven away. That is also why cohabitation with the widow occurred during this first night. Hiséi keihi (to make free, or to remove, the dead) was also the name of the last act of the burial ceremony, the strewing of the black stone powder seikuitsi over the grave (cf. Ch. V: “Stone Magic”). The deceased is put in a crouching position with the knees drawn up; the hands are put, palms together, against the left cheek; and he is wrapped in a woman’s garment, since this was formerly also the garb of the men. In this position he is put in a hammock, which is hung on a pole, and carried to the grave-yard in the vicinity of the village. The relatives follow, in part weeping, but not shrieking. The round grave is approximately one and a half meters deep. The deceased in placed in this with his face toward the south, toward the snow-capped mountain Takindúe -- as I was told -- to which the soul goes. The hammock is taken back again. Even today sêveral things are still given to the deceased in the grave, but now there is no longer any rule governing this. Priest Miguel says that his father Narciso gave his golden festival adornment to a friend to keep during a trip, but the latter’s son later said that he had put the things in the grave with his father, who had died in the meantime, which was believed and respected. The place of the grave can also still be distinguished later. Merely the 131 later strewing of stone powder and planting of stone beads calls for that. But for the uninitiated no distinguishing marks are present. Some said that one laid a stone slab on it. And in fact in the cemetery of Noavaka, as my boy Telesforo Gutierrez reported to me, there were two of the characteristic stone installations which one also finds elsewhere in the land of the Kágaba, especially in the neighborhood of the temples. and which to the uninformed look like stone seats, since they consist of a thin slab of stone lying on the ground and another set upright against it like the back of a chair. Moreover three and two of these respectively stand in a row in front of the door of the two temples in Nabuvakai (Ill. 36), one behind the temple of the Kasikiál, others near the temple in Noavaka. They are called hakuktú (stone slab), also haksinkana, perhaps from sinika (striped, striped stone), and were also in these cases explained as seats of the priests. On the other hand, the row of stones close to Takina on the north consisted of similar stone-installations, which were explained as field crops (of. p. 105). Still others about ten minutes above and below Takina on the way to Makotama and San Miguel were explained as helpers ( háñguakukui ) of the temple of Takina, which are supposed to inform the priest of the arrival of sicknesses and other dangers. There were none in the region of Palomino, only one stone installation in the valley of the Rio Kavikongui not far from Santa Rosa, and seven more below Noavaka, in addition to those already listed from there previously. That is also why my informants from Palomino were unable to say anything about them. /The remainder of the text, pp. 132-414, is omitted in the translation. The index, pp. 415-423, is likewise omitted in the translation, but is included with the foreign text. Ills. 1-35, which follow here as they appear in the original source, are not in numerical order./

Minor Kogi priests, who occupy the lower status of healers, have a good knowledge of herbal medicine. Many diseases, however, are attributed to malevolent spirit beings, vindictive ancestors, or social dysfunction; in these cases the priests, elders or family members prescribe adequate offerings or confession.

The relationship of the individual to the Children of the Mother, or the Fathers and Masters, is the same that exists among relatives, brothers, uncles, cousins, or other closer or more distant relatives. They do not play as definite a part in the life of the individual as the Mother, and it is not expected that they will give something or that they will protect or aid. But they “possess” something because they are “Masters.” One possesses yuca, another, rain, another, sickness, another, the mask. Thus, in order to be able to plant yuca, one must ask for permission from the Father of the Yuca: in order that it not rain any more, one must ask for permission from the Mother of the Rain-shower. A man cannot plant yuca without having this permission. The Father of the Yuca would say: “I am the Master of the yuca; to plant yuca is in my power. If anyone plants yuca without my permission, I shall damage the seed.” Another would say: “The fox / zorro / is mine. Anyone who kills foxes without my permission will be punished. I shall send sickness to him.” Thus it is necessary to procure permission for everything, because otherwise Fathers, Mothers, and 84 Masters will punish with illness, damage the crops, and cause the death of children. Fathers and Mothers are always hungry. (Who is not hungry in the Kogi world?) Thus permission is obtained by giving them food. But food and sexuality are the same thing. Then it is necessary to perform the sexual act with them. It is necessary to cohabit with the Mother of the Yuca so that yuca will be born.

In addition to the Mother and the Masters, there is another group of supernatural beings, who are the nearest ancestors. The grandfather who died a few years ago, the mother-in-law who died a few months ago, all of these are now united in the other world, and they expect that the surviving members of their family will give them “food.” They do not grant permissions because they are not Masters or Fathers or Mothers; they are simply the “dead,” the heiséi, and are personified in the collective concept of “Death” (Heiséi) . They intervene directly in the destiny of the living, whether it be by sending illness, hunger, or death. If nobody gives them “food,” they send sickness or “claim” a child to serve them. “That is why so many children die.”

“The devil is death”; “After death we are all devils”; “Sicknesses are the dead.” These three phrases of the Kogi show very clearly what the concept of Heiséi, Death, means to them. Of course, the word “devil” does not exist in their language, but heiséi -- dead person or death -- is always translated in this way, since it is the force opposed to the principle of the good, of life. Heiséi ( 3 . The etymology of the word is unknown to us. Preuss writes: hiséi . ) is spoken of as a collectivity, just as sometimes “the Mother” and “the Mothers” are confused; and this concept includes all the dead, that is to say, all of the ancestors of the tribe who are not expressly designated as immortals such as the Fathers, Mothers, or Masters. Heiséi is a man, and they imagine him with “the face of a tigre.” In fact, the mask which represents him has a long muzzle and great projecting teeth, and during the dance which is performed with it the movements and growls of this wild animal are imitated. Heiséi is the Master of Sickness and it is he who sends it to earth to punish those persons who have committed offenses or who have been negligent about the rites and offerings. Just like the Mother, Heiséi is omnipresent, but his symbols are male symbols: the snake, the arrow, the crab ( 4 . The crab is a “worm.” The big blue crabs of the coast are called heiséi husso -- crab of death. ). The mast of Heiséi shows a snake coiled around the face. The color of Death is blue, and the sky is blue because “the dead live there” ( 5 . It is not always very clear where the dead live, in the sky or in the snow. Cf. “Religion, The Beyond.” ). Archeological sites are places where “Death lives” ( 6 . Cf. “Economy, the System of Horticulture” /see 1: Reichel-Dolmatoff in this file/. Ancient osseous remains are called heiséinita . ), and archeological objects are “things of the dead,” and therefore full of contagion and sickness. Such objects must be reburied or handed over to the Máma . Heiséi has a marked sexual character ( 7 . Perhaps the name heiséi is related to sé sei -- penis. ) and controls the sexual life, especially of the men. 91 In fact, he is sometimes designated as Father of Homosexuality. The Kogi believe that there is almost no place on the surface of the earth where there has not been cohabitation some time, that is to say, where human beings who today are heiséi have not cohabited. The earth is imagined to be literally impregnated with the sperm of the dead, and contact between this and the sperm of the living “opens a door” through which sickness may enter the land. If a person performs the sexual act again in one place, Heiséi “will do harm” to the sexuality of the man, will send sicknesses to him, and will cause the death of the children. These sites are designated as “traps” (katú) into which the sperm falls; and above all graveyards or places where it is believed that dead persons are buried are called this ( 8 . Compare with this concept of “trap” the uterine symbolism which burial has. Cf. “Life Cycle; Death and Burial.” ). Since the land itself is a female element and symbolizes the Mother, coitus on this land always implies the danger of incest, and Heiséi is closely related to the incestuous instinct. The ritual of coitus is considered essentially a means of defense to counteract the malign influence of Heiséi and to avoid this incest.

Occasional offerings are made in innumerable places along roads where the genii loci live, where there is a cave, a rock of extraordinary shape, or a spring of water. Approximately in the middle of the road between two towns, two cultivated fields, two rivers, hills, or lakes, there is always a stone in the road, sometimes literally covered with these offerings made by those who walk along these paths. Often the small bundles of maize leaves do not contain anything but the alúna of the offering which the traveler made when he passed through the place. Near these places they sometimes pull up green leaves and touch their thighs with them for a moment in order to absorb the fatigue. Then the leaf is placed upon the rock, and with it all of the tiredness of the traveler. Little piles of natural stones from 1 to 15 pounds in weight were explained to us as offerings “in order not to get tired” or for the fertility of the plantings of coca, which must be deposited on the ancient cultivation terraces ( 35 . If a man plants coca without having the appropriate sewá or without making the prescribed offerings, his family will become sick and his children “will have toothache.” ).

We shall now see how these annual ceremonies of the dances of the masks are performed. Once the day for the beginning of the ceremony has been determined by divination, the whole town is cleaned, and the road which leads from it to the nearby stream or river, where those attending will take their ritual baths, is repaired. Then the Máma lights a fire in the ceremonial house by means of a drill, afterwards feeding the flames with certain woods which have been brought exclusively for this purpose. 142 In the meantime the fire is extinguished in all of the houses and is then lighted again with embers which each man brings from the ceremonial house to his dwelling. In the afternoon the Máma and his assistants, as well as the men of status who will take an active part in the dance, leave the town and go to a nearby house, to the one belonging to the Máma or to one belonging to some Elder, where the masks and other ritual objects have been deposited beforehand. There they put on the costumes, ornaments, and masks, and at nightfall they come back to the town. Some men play large gourd trumpets announcing the arrival of the masks, but otherwise the participants proceed silently in single file. Upon arriving in the town, they then pass through its plaza and all enter the ceremonial house, walking first toward the east, then toward the west, south, and north, respectively, all with short steps, the knees bent, and making bows toward the “four corners of the world.” Meanwhile only the trumpets are played. This entrance of the masks is interpreted as a ceremonial greeting. Halting in the middle of the house, the masks pronounce the ritual greetings and commence a song accompanied by a slow dance, during which the dancers scarcely move from their places, but only rock the body from side to side or abruptly move the head from side to side. In the accompanying song the masks say that they were sent by the Universal Mother to visit the Kogi and to see if “all is in accord.” They ask if there are food and firewood, if all have confessed and fasted, and if the town has been cleaned. After a short time the participants remove the masks and place them on large tripods of stakes, which have been placed along the walls in the interior of the ceremonial house for this purpose. Then the gathering sits down on little benches and hammocks, and periods of conversation, singing and dancing performed by individuals and more of the nature of practicing, follow. Occasionally the Máma intervenes and directs the dancing, inviting all of the men to participate in it. They go on dancing this way through the night, sometimes with the masks, sometimes without them. Now maracas, trumpets, drums, and flutes accompany the songs, and the dancers stop facing in this direction, perhaps just turning their faces and maracas to this side. Thus “the masks speak with the directions” and “keep the bad at a distance and bring the good.” At the same time the Máma receives from the 143 men, dancers or observers, the bundles of mineral dust, opens them, and blows their contents toward the four directions. Many times the men themselves do this and the Máma does not personally intervene. According to the time of year or the special object of the ceremony, they next repeat certain dances and songs, say, the dance of Kandjí, the dance of Namsíku, the dance of the rain, or the many dances which are performed in order to “be in accord” with the animals which damage the crops. In the festivals of the solstices and equinoxes, the next day is devoted to the dance of the mask of Surlí or the one of Nuikukúi (the Master of the East). At dawn the tripods with the masks are placed outside the ceremonial house with the faces turned toward the east “to greet the sun.” In the afternoon, or sometimes even in the morning, the mask of Surlí dances outside or inside the ceremonial house, his dance being accompanied by songs and the sound of the trumpets. At night the masks are brought in again, and the dances and songs continue until dawn, together with the offerings of mineral powder. In the free hours, however, the men devote themselves to small household tasks, eat from time to time, or toast coca leaves in the ceremonial house. No matter what the immediate object of the ceremony may be, whether “to turn the sun around” or “to arrange a rain-shower” (that is to say, to make it rain), the prime concern is always to keep sicknesses away. In the songs they speak of “making fences on the roads of sickness” or of “closing the doors to sickness,” and on occasion the dancers manipulate a small broom of leaves in each hand for the purpose of “sweeping away sickness” and “cleaning the pueblo.”

In speaking of the collective ceremonies, we have already said that they have as one of their principal objects the driving out of “sickness” and keeping it away from the town. We shall deal here then only with sickness as an isolated phenomenon relating to a single individual. As we have also said in another place, sicknesses are conceived of as “seeds” brought by the wind and are classified according to “color,” only those sicknesses of “light colors” (white and red) being regarded as curable. The Kogi almost never use medicinal plants and regard them as “belonging” to the Colombians. “To cure sickness, the Mother gave us stones,” they say, and only in rare cases, when dealing with minor ailments, are infusions of herbs used. The medicinal plants thus used are the following: manzanilla (Matricaria chamomilla), rosemary (Rosmarinus officinalis L.), thyme (Thymus vulgaris D.), viravira (Gnaphalium spp.), and sometimes quina bark (Cinchona spp.) ( 100 . With the exception of viravira (Anaphallum spp.) / sic/, which is called hályi-buchi -- white herb, the Kogi do not have names for designating these herbs. ). Some dry leaves of 159 these herbs are cooked in a little water, which the sick person who is suffering from stomache-ache, a cold, or “headache” then drinks. But no ritual is connected with the preparation of these remedies, which in any case are regarded as “civilized medicine.” They are plants which “do not have a Mother,” at least in the world of the Kogi.

During the entire gaulí ceremony, the Máma “works,” of course, in every phase, first with his left hand and to the “left side,” and then with his right hand and to the “right side.” It is said that during the first two days the ceremonial is performed only “to take out the bad,” and then for two days “to bring the good.” On the last day the Máma places bindings of cotton thread on the baby’s wrists by means of 177 which he transmits “strength” ( káma ) to him and protects him against illness. At times these bindings contain little black beads, and the Máma also gives the father some little dry seeds which are pierced so that they may later be put around the baby’s neck in the form of a small necklace. The baby is given a small totuma /vessel made out of the fruit of Crescentia cujete / containing sugar-cane water to drink, and with this act the “baptism” is considered ended. From now on the baby is included in the life on this earth and in that of the universe. He has been made a link in the long chain of his ancestors.

The cleanliness of the baby in this period is very dubious, and they, like their pouches, are dirty and malodorous. The head, ears, hands, and feet are covered with filth, and no effort is made to keep them clean. The idea of sickness is never connected with a lack of cleanliness, but rather, with regard to children, with exposure to air, sun, and water. Newborn babies are bathed during the first months inside the house with tepid water, an operation which the babies like because of the warmth of the water and the caresses which they possibly receive at the same time, but these baths become less frequent as the baby approaches five or six months of age.

Weaning is done when the baby is about one year old or somewhat less, but long before this he is beginning to get solid food occasionally. Alternating at first between the breast and small quantities of masticated food, the former is withdrawn more and more.
