It was added proof that Eskimo indifference to physical pain is more than legendary; it's real! Therefore, I assumed that Iktutok had enough native stoicism in him to take that kind of treatment without crying or yelling. In all likelihood he merely said, “It's painful indeed!” and ground his teeth.

Soon after we adjourned to the living room, an Eskimo woman came in to do the dishes. She worked quiety and efficiently, using hot water from a large, aluminum pot in a generous-sized dishpan. When she finished washing the dishes, aoyak, the seagull. Manerathiak. Father Raymond de Coccola, on the Mackenzie River en route north in 1937. This is some of the barren land in the Central Arctic. The land of the midnight sun: Arctic midnight sun along the 70th parallel. Only four dogs can pull sled, with peat runners, along the ice pack. “I was visiting my trap line, when the uyaluk --the all-powerful storm--struck. I didn't have time to build an igloo. I quickly buried myself in the snow with all my dogs around me. The uyaluk lasted three days, but I didn't want to wait it out. I was young and strong then; also foolish and impatient. So with my dogs I left our shelter on the second day and returned to my camp where I had left my wife. As soon as I entered my igloo, I could not feel my feet anymore. They were hard like soapstone and just as lifeless. I asked my wife to cut off my toes. She did. They fell like chips of dry wood. My feet were so badly frozen, I had to let her continue. So she cut to the heels. When the blood began to trickle, I started to yell because it hurt so much.”
“But how did she stop the blood from running out?” I asked Iharoitok.

“She tied the vessels with caribou sinew and wrapped the stumps in small fur bags. She bound them very tight. It was all very painful. And for a long time I lay uselessly on the iglek --I, who had once been a great hunter!”
“Can you show me where she cut off your feet?”

I clipped Nokadlak's extraneous hair with my scissors, then bathed and dressed his wound as well as I knew how. Finding no needles or catgut in my medicine bag, I put the torn pieces still attached to the scalp where they originally belonged. The multiple lacerations gave the impression of severe injury, but fortunately the damage was superficial. I was about to bandage his head when Angivrana interrupted me, “ Fala, put this hare skin on first. The wound will heal faster.”
I didn't take the silky fur from her, but suggested that she could do that herself. This she did skillfully, and I applied the bandage.

In addition to attempts to combat sickness through supernatural means, shamans also used some practical medical skills, such as setting and splinting broken or dislocated bones, lancing swellings and amputating frozen limbs. Headaches were treated by bleeding.

“We did not have to go over eight miles till we came to a camp of five houses, pitched on the ice about ten or twenty yards from shore, at the northeast corner of Simpson Bay. We were engaged with the help of some of the local men in pitching our tent about two hundred yards from the village when we noticed a man, evidently stone blind, come walking towards us, feeling about with a long cane as a blind man does. Two or three children stood watching him and kept warning him of the tide cracks, which were numerous here in the ice as they are everywhere near shore. The children kept shouting to him: ‘Turn to the right! Turn to the left! Again to the left! Now watch out for a tide crack!’ These cracks are dangerous to a man [272] who walks carelessly, for they are often covered with snow so as to be invisible and are wide enough for a man's foot to slip in, with considerable danger not only of a bad fall but of breaking a bone. With skill acquired through long blindness he avoided the tide cracks dexterously and walked straight up to where the children's voices told him that I was standing beside our sled, unloading it.

When he got hear he told me that he knew already who I was, and that very likely I knew who he was, for he was a man so much more unfortunate than other men that the story of his misfortune had traveled to distant places. No doubt I had heard the story, he said, but nevertheless he would tell it to me himself so that I might know it from his own lips and take warning from it and tell my friends to do the same.

Many years ago his house had been standing by itself some distance from the village, but from where he stood beside the seal-hole watching for the seal to come up he could see several other hunters out sealing. The seal, when it came, proved to be a bearded one, but being a strong man he had been able to hold it and to kill it. Without assistance he had with his ice pick enlarged the breathing-hole enough to pull the animal out. (It was no mean feat, seeing that a bearded seal will weigh from six hundred to eight hundred pounds.) Up to this time he had not thought of the other hunters, but now he looked around and saw that they were all far away, and while distinctly visible he felt sure that none of them had any idea what kind of a seal he had caught. (The hunter's law does not require that the hunters within sight be summoned to share at the cutting up of a common small seal.) When a bearded seal is killed all the hunters within view must be called in to share the prize.

It had occurred to him that by keeping the thing secret (by pretending this was a common seal), he might keep the animal to himself, and especially the skin, for he knew that he could sell pieces of it to a neighboring tribe who seldom catch bearded seals, for numerous articles of value. Accordingly he secretly cut the animal up, gave out the story that he had killed only a small seal, and pledged his wife to secrecy; but the story leaked out as such stories will. People came to him and took away from him both the skin and the [273] meat and reproached him bitterly. He now repented his act and felt crushed by the disapproval of his people, but his punishment was to be made even heavier, for within a year he began to lose his eyesight and in another year he was stone blind. Since then he, poor miserable man, had been blind and a charge upon the community. Thus it was sure to go with those who did wicked things; and while he felt sure that I was a good man, nevertheless to know his story would do me no harm, and he wished I would pass it on to others, warning them to avoid selfish ways.”

Eskimos believe that all sickness and death are the work of a supernatural spirit, an evil spirit, known in the Perry Island dialect as the agiuqtuq. When someone dies, his name must be passed on, preferably to his own newborn child, but at least to a newborn child of a relative in the region. If there is no newborn child available, then the name will be passed on to a newborn pup. If this is not done within one winter of the death, then that name turns into an agiuqtuq, and will cause sickness or death among humans and dogs alike. Illness is attributed to an agiuqtuq from one of the victim's relatives who perhaps unknowingly has broken a taboo.
Eskimos say that the best way to fight frostbite is to put the affected part in cold water, but that was scarcely practical in our position--we had too many ‘affected parts’.

Eskimo health is poor by southern Canadian standards, and the basic causes are three-fold. They are poor housing, malnutrition, and almost total ignorance of elementary hygienic practices and sanitation.

has been broken, or that the patient has committed some action which offended a certain dead person's shade. The latter was the interpretation given to the illness of the Noahognik Eskimo Hitkok, who killed his dog in a fit of anger because it refused to follow him to the sealing ground; in this case the resentful shade was the dead relative after whom the dog was named.” 1 “There was no conception of the dead man's soul residing in the dog; Hitkok had merely shown disrespect to him by killing his namesake.”

“For the forerunners of death, accidents and sickness, the Eskimo knows of only one cause, the malignant activities of evil spirits or of the shades of the dead. Many of Higilak's seances in Victoria island were held for the purpose of propitiating or intimidating these shades and dispelling their influence. The natives have no knowledge whatever of medicine, and very little of surgery. A head-ache is sometimes cured by bleeding, broken limbs are set in splints and frozen members are amputated. Aksiatak, for example, disloc ated his ankle while wrestling in the dance-house; he pulled it back into place, covered it with a long deerskin sock and laid three splints around it, one on each side and one at the back, keeping them firmly in place by means of a raw-hide lashing; a second cord running from his hand to the sole of his foot enabled him to raise his leg without bending it. A year later his son Nakitok fell from the roof and broke his thigh; the Eskimos set his leg in splints also. Both accidents were ascribed to the machinations of evil spirits and the shamans were asked to appease them. A painful swelling on the arm of the old shaman Ilatsiak was cured by lancing. For snow-blind-ness the natives use counter-irritants, flooding the eyes with the smoke of burning heather or of the Dryas integrifolia, or tying a louse to a thread and letting it scratch the sclerotis. Complaints that are considered magical in their origin, however, find their surest remedies in counter-magic, so a shaman is usually called in at once to diagnose the cause and prescribe a cure. In most cases he discovers that some taboo

Both Sr. Lista ( b, 130) and Dr. Segers (65) mention an evil spirit who enters the body and sends illness; he also sends wind, rain, etc. Some good and evil spirits are believed in by both the men and the women (Dabbene, a, 76; b, 270; Beauvoir, b, 218; Cojazzi, 38). The dead are feared (C. Gallardo, 321), especially dead witch-doctors, who have power even after their death (Cojazzi, 38, 71-72; C. Gallardo, 299, 341). Many natural objects, as mountains, sun, moon, stars, etc., are believed to have once been men, and mountains at least are feared and respected. Finally we may mention the initiation spirits believed in only by the women and children (cf. infra, under Initiations), and the mythological beings, especially the mythhero Kuanip (cf. infra, under Mythology).

A. Yahgans. --The Kachpikh or malevolent spirits of the woodland caves are avoided lest they inflict illness or death (Hyades, q, 255). The Yahgan has a dread of Cushpeec and is loath to hear his name mentioned (Despard, b, 717; cf. also Furlong, b, 137). It is dangerous to name the dead (Th. Bridges, a, Fr. tr., 177). B. Onas. --The Onas fear the mountains (Gunn, 326), who are deceased men, and who send storms on trespassers (Cojazzi, 90-91). The Onas respect and fear such natural objects as the mountains, the sun, moon and stars, lakes, woods, and do not speak badly of them nor stare at them too long; if you speak badly of a mountain in its presence, it will send rains and winds (C. Gallardo, 339-340).

Facial and body painting (fig. 34) they practised both on ceremonial occasions and in everyday life. Red and orange paint was obtained by burning suitable earth, found apparently in many places. For white paint they employed pure white clay. Ground charcoal supplíed black paint. These colors were applied with the hand or finger after mixing the pigment with saliva or grease. The patterns, simple in character, may be studied in the series of portraits published by Gallardo. Among the Ona we noted the widespread New World belief that paint gives protection against the weather and wards off sickness. The Tehuelche told Captain Musters (1871, p. 163) that they painted their faces to “keep off the wind.”

Sickness, said the Ona, was the result of some foreign object lodged in the body through the machinations of the moon or of some malevolent shaman. To effect a cure this must be removed. When summoned to attend a patient, the doctor painted himself in style and put on a kelp-goose down diadem (fig. 11). After an examination of the sufferer he informed the relatives of the nature of the illness and who had inflicted it. Next the sick man was stripped and seated on a guanaco-skin. Around him for some time walked the shaman, chanting incantations to break the spell of the disease. Then grasping his patient the doctor violently massaged the affected part. Finally the point of pain was lustily sucked, and then the shaman vomited forth the ostensible cause of the disorder--an arrowpoint, a pebble, a bit of wood, or some such object.

The evening before, when I sat with these Indians for the last time at the fire and informed them of my definite departure, their sincere affection toward me finally broke through, and they begged me emphatically to visit them again the next year. Then they would tell me much and show me many things that they had not yet been able to confide to me this time. I was also supposed to bring along many medicines and strings of beads, indeed, stay with them forever if possible, for at the present time first this one and then that one of their children would become ill, and since these maladies stem from the whites, only a white could remedy them. From the third day of my being here, when I had scarcely dispensed the first medicines, I was generally called nkol t = European medicine-man; from then on I retained this name among the northern group for the following 83 cont. years. To be sure, casual wishes and promises on the lips of an Indian do not mean much, but their statements sufficed for me to be able to conclude favorably that I had adopted the right tone in my intercourse with them and that, in this way, we would later probably come closer to each other. This hope encouraged me; for now, in parting, I was under the grievous impression that the thought of the sad fate of this handful of survivors of the once numerous Selk'nam people aroused in me! With anxious care I tore myself away from this camp, as though I were never again to see many of its dear occupants; there vigorously throbbed in me the wish to sit once more in their midst, in order to understand them better and become more closely acquainted with them! When P. Zenone gave me his hand in farewell, he did not hold back his impressions and told me openly: “So many travelers have already passed by here and gaped at our Indians; but none has come as frankly close to them 84 as you. Even some taciturn old men have liked your visit and confided to me that they want to see you again next year. You will be welcome to all of us and then the outcome of your work will be successful!” ... It may have been more of a natural disposition that introduced me so favorably to these human beings who are so difficult to approach. From the outset it is always doubtful what reception the investigator will find among the unpredictable children of nature; but the first introduction usually remains decisive for the course of his work and for the final success.

Social contrasts, however, separated the south people from their northern neighbors more effectively than did the natural conditions mentioned. There was always a certain tension and lurking irritability between the two. Though, to be sure, outward sociableness prevailed at times, serious hostility not infrequently broke out. This opposition arose rather unconsciously from economic causes. The north people subsisted primarily on the meat of the cururos and used the soft skins of these animals for cloaks. This prompted the south people to make fun of their northern neighbors and look down on them as “cururo eaters.” A transitory penetration of individual south-people into the north country never occurred for hunting purposes, much less, as Tonelli:9 believes, for the stealing of women, though a medicine man from the other region was not infrequently held responsible for sicknesses or cases of accidents and death. There is no reliable clue for guessing at the frequency of such disputes or hostilities. For all this was hidden from the eyes of the but recently arrived whites, and thereafter earlier conditions changed. Nevertheless, the missionaries felt this ancient hostility. They established their first settlements in the territory of the north people, who continued to prevent their southern neighbors from visiting the mission; as Beauvoir (BS: XX, 37; 1896) complains, “non si presentarona più in corpo di tribù intera, perchè quelli del Nord imposero loro con minaccie la partenza, e passato il Rio Grande, pare si siano scambiate alcune frecciate, lasciandovi alcuni anche la vita” /they no longer appeared in a body of the entire tribe, because those of the North forced departure on them with threats, and, having crossed the Rio Grande, it seems some arrows were exchanged, some persons even losing their lives/.

In intense and persistent cold the Indians resort to a special remedy, which they say is most efficacious. Burned, red colored-earth is well kneaded with guanaco fat and smeared in a thick layer all over the body. This is their true protection against cold, not, however, the fur cloak (cf. Del Turco in SN:X, 145; 1905). (9) Borgatello's assumption that the Indians, “in order to imitate the Czortu (= Kloketen spirit), preferred to go naked and painted red, like him” (SN:XIV, 255; 1908), is almost amusing.

215 One who lacked these coverings, which were used only in the winter, smeared a thick layer of guanaco fat on the lower legs. The hard-frozen snow then bothered the skin less. In order not to sink into very loose, deep, fresh snow one temporarily tied a small bunch of thick twigs on the sandals and called this e k  ámni = snowshoes. (11) Concerning the footgear, cf. what Cojazzi:42, Dabbene (b):224, Gallardo:155, Lothrop:53, and others have written.
He also lets human beings feel his unrestricted ability and boundless power: “ T má kel sends prolonged sicknesses. -- If he wants to punish an entire group, he lets a general sickness come.”

On the course of development of earthly events T má kel does not exert any demonstrable influence. Just as little did he interfere in the fate of the ancestors or the outstanding personalities of ancient times. It is only with respect to actual human beings that the Supreme Being's manifestation of power comes to light through the fact that he caused a sickness and death for an individual person or an epidemic for the generality.

5. The medicine men : They also stand, in their professional work, without any connection to T má kel and even show a strong contrariness to him. Since the medicine man can produce not only sickness for other people, but even death, the n enters into competition to a certain extent with T má kel . Yet how does it correspond with the general principles that the latter calls away the human souls at death if the medicine man too kills human beings and he does not in any case stand on good terms with their deity? One should not confront the Indian with such discrepancies. Noteworthy too are the words of old Tenenesk, the most influential one of that profession: “The souls of the human beings go to T má kel ; but we do not know where the soul of a n dwells after death. It stays 505 cont. somewhere until a candidate for this office makes it his own.” Thus the 506 soul of a medicine man seems removed from the influence of the Supreme Being, since it does not leave this earth. In this area one comes across all kinds of inconsistencies. The Indians contented themselves and me with the explanation: “We ourselves do not understand how the á n practice. If they kill a person, we do not know how they settle it with T má kel, for they never negotiate with him!”

If hostile forces threaten the Indian, if an illness caused by a malevolent n befalls him, if he should become involved with a Y i , he does not lack helping powers upon which he can depend. (37) One should recall the utilization of mighty medicine men, and the Indian's behavior in regions that are favored by these malevolent forest spirits.

These remedies, however, are of restricted effect and limited success. A prolonged illness that cannot be checked because of inadequate skill on the part of the n is causally 511 traced back to T má kel . Illnesses of children are meant almost exclusively, for a serious permanent affliction of an older person “is probably somehow [ = through a lapse with respect to the moral law] deserved,” according to old Keitetowh's cautions manner of expression.

I learned of two kinds of sacrificial practices. Anyone who still wanted to eat something late in the evening, whether man or woman -- children are given nothing more late at night --, was obliged to throw a small piece of meat , raw or roasted, outside the hut; a short distance was sufficient. Turning his thoughts to T má kel , often without speaking his name, he would say softly: “I am going to eat now. This here is for ‘You-up-there’: Be good to us!” Although they expressly emphasize that their god does not eat (p. 715), this fixed formula is retained. This had to be done so that the person in question “would not feel stomach pains during the night!” The next morning, they say further, that piece of meat is no longer to be found; T má kel himself causes it to disappear, although he himself does not eat. But “the eater should remain aware of the fact that ‘The-one-up-there’ sees what every person down here is doing!” 512 cont. It is difficult to determine which, in the interpretation of the Indians, should be more strongly emphasized: The giving of a small portion of the food, say, in the manner of a first-fruits offering, or the thought of the omnipresence of the Supreme Being. The fact that the piece of meat has disappeared the next morning is naturally explained by the many dogs that run around there.

1. One can repeatedly hear: “ T má kel punishes with sickness and with death.” To what extent is sickness regarded as punishment? Naturally those maladies that causally go back to medicine men are eliminated. It is only when the sickness lasts a longer time, when the skill of the n fails, when the latter themselves finally see T má kel behind it, that everyone else also judges it as punishment for some mistake. No one, however, would put it into words -- all our 525 cont. Indians are too sensitive for that -- that the malady was sent by the Supreme Being as a means of correction; but everyone thinks that. Anyone who sees another who has been sick for a long time knows from where it [this being sick] comes!”

Punishment does not immediately follow an offense. Moreover, the outwardly recognizable mistakes are not very frequent, and in most cases those present do not look for the slips that are being punished. But “the sick person himself thinks about all the bad things he has done.” A prolonged illness makes every patient thoughtful.

From all this, however, it becomes clear what grave obscurities occupy the natives' minds. I cannot avoid the impression that a prolonged illness is passed off as a warning for all healthy persons rather than a sanction, since chronic illnesses were formerly rare. The following is also applicable here. Discerning men in olden times would give a mature youth confidential advice not to approach the wife of another, “for ‘The-one-up-there’ is always very close, he hears everything that you whisper to such a woman. He will punish you if you play with the woman, if you let yourself be felt; you will have pains in your hips! Do not have anything to do with the wife of another!” This threat is obviously meant to have a deterrent effect.

2. Death on the occasion of an illness is not interpreted as natural death in the same sense as dying from the weakness of old age, for the kwáke is always derived from the influence of a malevolent medicine man. When the summoned n has exhausted his skill and he must nevertheless predict an unfavorable outcome, the patient comes to terms with his fate without opposition. Usually, as a result of the long duration of his suffering, he already feels so weak that he is scarcely able to acquiesce in the occasional outbursts of rage of those around him against the presumed enemy.
Somewhat earlier, in May, 1923, Toin told me the same story, which contains very valuable references to the general ideas concerning the origin and effect of the illness:

“ Kwá yu lived three generations ago. He is my relative, my grandfather still saw him. (133) Thus, there is approximate agreement with the earlier time-estimate (cf. p. 918). This Kwá yu was a small man. He had a long, full beard. His whole face was so thickly covered with hair that only his eyes were free. He lived in the south. As long as he lived, no one died as a result of kwáke . (134) This morbid matter, according to the belief of the Selk'nam, is imparted to some person by a medicine man and causes the physical affliction. 637 cont. He was a mighty n and helped all the people. In those days people died only because they were very old. (135) The purely natural death from the weakness of old age and wasting away is meant. Some, of course, died by murder or in war or by the nem (136) Means the particularly strong, irresistible power of the medicine man. of a n ; but no one died as the result of an illness. That is, Kwá yu was a good human being. He helped all the people.

“He himself had also already become very old. So he thought he would die now. He wanted to become a mountain. He repeatedly said to his people: ‘If I die a good death, I shall become a mountain. Then it will continue to go well for all the people here; nothing bad will befall them!’ But no one understood what he meant by that.

“Some time later he was roaming through the region near Beagle Channel with a few of his men. They were all unexpectedly attacked by many Yamana men. He himself was wounded during this. Then the enemies cut off his head.

“Soon afterward a great sickness appeared; very many people were afflicted by the kwáke . Almost all died. The foxes came upon the corpse of Kwá yu and ate some of it. They died immediately. It was as though those foxes had eaten only Kwáke . (137) So swift and certain was the effect of this evil morbid matter.

638 “The bones and teeth of Kwá yu , which had been gnawed off and dragged away by the foxes, soon began to move. (138) The same motif is found in other myths (p. 926 and p. 935). 638 cont. These parts individually ran after those people there. While doing so, they spoke as Kwa yu himself had spoken. When such a bone or tooth reached some person, the latter immediately became weak from the kwáke and died very soon.

“Very many Yamana perished at that time. Then the kwáke ran to the Haus people. From them it crossed over to the Selk'nam and hastened along the east coast of Isla Grande, up to the northeast tip, from there along the northern edge farther west and beyond the shores of Bahía Inútil. The kwáke afflicted the people everywhere. Many, many died.
“ Kwá yu himself had sent the kwáke . This was the first kwáke that came to Isla Grande. Before that such did not occur; it appeared only after that mighty n had been killed.

“In olden times no one died at an early age because of illness. Everyone reached an advanced age, so that he was scarcely able to walk. Such an old person would drag himself along, all bent and hunched up, whenever the camp was changed. If such an old person lay down, he would die in a few days; he was simply completely exhausted and wholly without strength. In those days people died only at an advanced age [out of the weakness of old age].

“Since that time, however, the kwáke has remained here in the Selk'nam country up to the present day. Kwá yu sent it here for the first time. That is why people still fall ill even today. The n learned how to seize the kwáke and send it to this or that person. They cause a great deal of harm by it.

“In this way Kwá yu took revenge. Now his people recalled what he had threatened before in plain words.” (139) Tonelli:123 attempted to show an etymological connection between kwake and Kwaiyul , which does not satisfy me. This story chose as its subject the origin of sickness. Here, it seems to me, old ideas from the medicine-man system have been linked with the manifestations of an epidemic appearing for the first time. The disease germs were brought there with European ships, possibly the “Adventure” and the “Beagle,” or with other vessels. Coming from the Yamana, the /this footnote is continued on the next page in the original source/ disaster spread by way of the Haus to the northern Selk'nam. If Kwake is here interpreted as a particularly ravaging epidemic, this story is easily explained in its details and traced back to an actual event, but by this loses its strictly legendary character. In order to avoid ambiguities, I have not included this story in the following group, which describes the activity of the medicine men.

He had already traveled a long time when he met little K't tu . (152) The small, dark burrowing owl, “Pequén,” Speotyto cunicularia (cf. p. 928). This bird was so tame that m es was astonished over it. It was already late at night. He said to himself: “What kind of bird might that be? It is so tame! I shall shoot it; it will make a good roast!” And he shot an arrow. But it did not hit. As he was about to shoot the second arrow, K't tu assumed a human shape before his eyes. Now he said to him: “Do not kill me, I am a Selk'nam and your 644 cont. friend!” The other was speechless with surprise. K't tu addressed him: “What are you doing here?” m es replied: “I am coming from my beloved. Along the way I fell down and injured myself. I hurt my leg, that is why I have to limp!” Then the other said: “Come a little closer and show me your sore leg; I want to cure you!” Immediately m es showed him his sore leg. Then K't tu took a piece of his own skin and healed his wound with it. He was a capable medicine man! Shortly before, when he smelled the wound of that man, he had become a human being again. The other one now thanked him very much for curing him so quickly. Now he went on his way. (153) The following was added by way of explanation: This medicine man lived on the north shore of Lago Fagnano, in the XVIIIth district. He always healed wounds by placing a piece of his own body-skin on the sore spot; then the healing suddenly came about. That is why he was formerly and still is today esteemed by all the people.

Thunderstorms pass over Feuerland /Tierra del Fuego/ extremely rarely and have a somewhat disquieting effect on the Indians. “ ' nhy l we [ = lightning] is always a strong kwáke . This comes from mighty n and overtakes several persons or a whole group”; therefore causes a general illness. “ n is a loud crashing up in the firmament; then very great cold prevails there.” If the thunder rather resembles a rolling noise, one says: “Something is collapsing up there; everything there is tumbling down one on top of another!” 682 cont. Both ideas probably derive from the loud cracking, in the manner of a pistol shot, which, in extreme cold, is caused by the splitting of tree trunks or by the falling of many trees that afterwards roll down the mountains. If the noise of thunder is extraordinarily violent, however, the people creep into their huts. Namely, because “if something now falls down from up there, we are out of danger!” 238 Cojazzi:72 mentions only “un timore superstizioso del tuono /a superstitious fear of thunder/.” Borgatello (c):64, Dabbene (a):76, and Gallardo:319, 343 give very inexact explanations of this.

The Haus /Haush/ greatly esteem the large brownish-black weevil , k' la , as a capable, well-meaning n . They place it on a wound or painful spot, which it now contemplates for a long time. In the case of swellings, it contemplates much longer. Finally, in the manner of the 711 medicine men, it draws a great deal of blood out of the affected limb and, with it, the malady at the same time; after that the beetle goes away again. The Selk'nam know it under the same name and use it in the same way; for them, too, it is regarded as a kind friend who helps everyone without discrimination. Another beetle, by the name of ' m é te -- I was unable to identify it more precisely --, always appears hostile to the Haus. If one holds one's hand up to it, it squirts out a juice that causes a strong burning for some time. It thus expresses its displeasure. A dipteron rare among the Haus, formerly likewise a stubborn n with the name of kokiyá a ka , even today still stays far away from people. This fly does not let itself be seen by anyone and quickly hurries away again when anyone approaches it.

With anxious care men and women burn every little piece of their head hair in the nearest fire. They wish to avoid having a hair fall into alien hands, who might convey it to a n . He could cause that person a physical ailment from it. Even in mythological times the sister of áskels used to “gather the hair of dead human beings” whom this monster had hunted down (Cojazzi:XVII, 303).

Even on my first journey I was introduced to these ideas. I had scarcely arrived in the camp on the Rio del Fuego in January, 1919, when I was faced with the sad spectacle that the children were generally afflicted with severe whooping cough. Without hesitation the Indians told me the name of a European who, in his well-known aversion toward the entire Selk'nam group, had sent their children 722 cont. this kwáke . They declared themselves incapable of warding it off; they asked me for help, with an appeal “that this kwáke came from a k l t , therefore only a k l t can make it disappear again!” I helped insofar as the circumstances permitted me to do this (p. 113).

723 Old Tenenesk's convictions moved in the same direction. On the one hand, he emphasized the absence of general sicknesses in times past; no less did he regret the inability of all the n against the “foreign” kwáke , which is imbued with a special power of resistance. Full of discontent, he complained: “If only we had enough power over the strange kwáke that the Europeans brought here! It must be a very peculiar thing, for none of our n are able to seize it. Otherwise we would soon have driven it away. But now many of our people died because no one knows how to get at it!” There culminates in this the conviction of all the Selk'nam that every n is helpless against the sicknesses brought in by Europeans, and all his preventive efforts are without success.

In connection with the effects felt in his own body, Tenenesk devoted himself to serious contemplation about the way that tablet worked. First he wanted to know from me whether we K l t k n , in the same way as the Sélk'nam k n , sought out the kwáke with the help of the t in or the wá yuwen . Overestimating my ability, he blurted out openly: “I know you are a capable n . I have observed you carefully, you must certainly have a good t in !” I was not prepared for this challenge. But I could not offend the old man and yet wanted to find out the purpose of his question. I replied: “Certainly, we European n also recognize the kwáke that lies in the body of a sufferer, but it is an entirely different one from yours. That 739 cont. is why we must feel and listen, tap and examine, and also use a little tube. (16) I had occasionally used a stethoscope in examining lungs and heart. All this because our strength of vision is so much poorer than yours. Just look: Other European n have glasses, just as I myself do; we need these in addition because we see poorly!” This made the old man laugh and pity our art: “You cannot possibly be capable n if your eyes are so weak! A good Selk'nam n has far-reaching strength of vision, with his ya t ?? he recognizes the kwáke at a great distance!”

The other part of this question still needed an answer. “If a Selk'nam n wants to remove the ailment, he must sing and afterwards draw it out of the body with his mouth. Why do you never sing when a patient comes to you? You only give him that ‘white thing’! (17) Here I should like to confess that I did indeed give these Indians as a cure-all the aspirin to which the old man refers; after all, I could not possibly carry along a large selection of drugs in order to supply others with them. But how can this seize a kwáke !” I was only able to answer: “That ‘white thing’ goes to the painful spot and the pain stops!” The astute old man immediately saw the gap in my reasoning: “So the kwáke does stay in the body of the sick person! Now I know that without singing it is not removed from the body!” ... The Indians, without exception, faithfully cling to their traditional ideas.

Every physical ailment or discomfort, actual pain or over-sensitivity, above all, however, psychic depression and discouragement, states of anxiety and inner agitation, such as result almost exclusively from certain dreams, are collectively and individually caused by the kwáke . The latter is regarded as material , as a small object, as a foreign body, which penetrates into the body of a person and makes itself felt there. Most popular is the comparison of the kwáke with an arrow point. It is said: The malevolent n hurls the evil in the way every Selk'nam shoots off his arrow. In a straight 744 cont. course, but invisibly for ordinary people, it flies at the body and, in the manner of an arrow point, penetrates into a certain spot, which soon begins to be painful.

The kwáke , considered material and corporeal, sometimes manifests itself and acts like a tiny living creature. (20) The descriptions by Cojazzi:87 and Tonelli:117, 123 are inadequate. Now if the n wishes to give the sufferer some relief, he works toward loosening the kwáke sticking fast in the painful spot in the body. Slowly it is drawn out closer to the surface of the body and is finally fetched out through the skin. Since it is drawn out of the body with the mouth, the medicine man spits it out immediately, and, to be sure, always into his own hands. But he spits blood, which he sucks out of “the patient” before or afterward, on the ground beside him or, less often, into the fire. When he has the kwáke lying on the palm of his hand, he rests the inner side of his wrist against his chin, and, with a puffing gust of air, he blows it away; immediately thereafter he turns the palm of his hand and, by suddenly stretching out his arm, sends after it a pushing-away movement. This is always done with the left hand, which is immediately turned forward and the fingers spread out, whereas the right arm hangs down freely.

745 Upon the wish of the bystanders, the n lets the kwáke be viewed . Within the body of the suffering person it has a greater or lesser extension; either it fills only the head or the abdomen or an arm, sometimes the whole interior of the body. Nevertheless its size has no relation to the severity or localization of the pain felt. The patient himself knows nothing precise about this, but the n sees all the details. As soon as he has brought a kwáke , no matter what size, close to the surface of the body by means of the customary treatment, it first of all becomes smaller; for only as a tiny object does it make its way through the skin, in order to attain its previous size quickly again outside the body.

Now it most often resembles a cururo, and in this form almost all the people have already seen it once. Less often it looks like a 745 cont. young bird covered with its first coat of down, still incapable of flight; more rarely, however, like a lizard. Sometimes it is extremely expansible and can be stretched into a very long thread, like a strip of rubber, approximately to the breadth of an arm-span. Occasionally I heard: “The kwáke hurled toward a certain person by a n is like an arrow point. This penetrates into the body. It settles in a certain spot and grows so that the person feels pain. In the body it usually acts like a living animal, like a cururo, rat, or beetle, like a lizard, dog, or young bird. But this type of animal consists of the same substance as the n himself, thus resembles down. This is exactly the way the kwáke sometimes looks when it is removed from the body of the patient. Not infrequently it also emerges as an arrow point.”

Holding the kwáke in his hand, the n holds it out to the people to look at. This is decidedly only a suggestive viewing , however. The n says to the people: “Here in my hand lies the kwáke ; it looks like a cururo!” Now those standing around hold the fixed gaze of their eyes directed at his hand. “That is why they now see the kwáke , although it is not visible at all to the eyes of the ordinary Selk'nam, but only for the t ?? of the n !” Toin one evening summed up in these brief words the upshot of our long conversation. Thus, only on the basis of stimulated imagination and suggestive self-influencing do the people standing around believe they actually see the kwáke in this or that form, which the medicine man names. (21) This settles Gallardo's:300 interpretation, which speaks of a “habilidad extrema de ... verdaderos prestidigitadores / extreme skill of ... true prestidigitators/.” Cf. in this connection too the judgment in Note 14 /p. 1065/.

In a more infrequent form the kwáke appears as will-o -the-wisp. I was once returning to the camp in the late evening after a hunting trip with a small group of men. As we waded through a swamp, a small bright spot shone between the reeds and low brush; we stood still. Involuntarily there flowed from the lips of all the men: “A kwáke ! ... If we only knew from where it comes and to which person it was sent by a n !” Afterwards I heard further: “Now and then a kwáke is seen in the evening as a brighter or dimmer spot of light. It takes a rest if a n sends it a long distance.” The materialization of the sickness principle is clearly expressed in this explanation.

The n makes the kwáke sucked out of the sick person disappear as soon as possible; he blows it far away . Destroying it would be dangerous and is scrupulously avoided. It is said: “If one were to kill a kwáke , a severe general sickness would arise.” The kwáke usually enters into a person through the mouth. It is the task of the n , through his strength of vision, to seek out the place in the body where it is located. When it has been fetched out and sent away, it still consists, as before, of that light, downlike substance and can move most quickly to a great distance. It resides somewhere, but nothing in greater detail is known about it.

Compared to the kwáke , it is regarded as considerably more dangerous and effective. The former manifests itself as discomfort and pain, as a complaint or sickness, therefore some sort of cure is possible in each case. If a nem has entered the body of a human being, however, there is no deliverance from it any more, not even by an ever so powerful n . The rapid death of such a person inevitably follows. It is emphatically stressed precisely with regard to the nem that a n must promptly become aware of its approach in order to protect the people befriended by him and save them from the hostile design. The medicine men test their strength precisely in the use of this dangerous expedient.

It is difficult to avoid going back again here to the precise definition of being sick, in order to make understandable the favorable 755 cont. outcome of the method of treatment carried out by the n . The procedures are not as mysterious as many a one describes them, even though this or that may remain unexplained.

In the strictest sense of the word, kwák tan is the designation for feeling pain, suffering, being indisposed, being sick. But to our Selk'nam a neat separation of the physical from the psychic pain matters very little: all suffering, especially the latter, causes him an unpleasant psychic condition, and he designates predominantly this discomfort, being depressed, being indisposed psychically , with kwák tan or sickness. The more comprehensive term kwáke is more in general use. The latter, however, considered as effect, in the above association of thought 756 means the same as kwák tan . (25) Other Feuerland /Tierra del Fuego/ travelers emphasize this abstract distinction little or not at all. Cf. Beauvoir (b):48, 127 and Tonelli:116. The professional activity of a n quite generally is called ksó m en = extracting the kwáke from a suffering person or inflicting such on someone, sending out a nem or á hmen , etc. Kátmeten , kátme en has a limited meaning = the treatment of a sick person according to the customary procedure of the n , in order to remove the kwáke ; in a carried-over sense, now also the therapeutic procedure of a European physician, along with the dispensation of medicines. On the other hand, k pá en means the use of ordinary remedies for injuries, etc., such as anyone can do.

Accordingly, it is not pathological phenomena, infectious diseases, or accidents that lead people to their n ; rather, it is psychic depression after unpleasant dreams, states of discouragement and temporary ennui, suspicion or fears after threats from certain hostile parties, anxieties following a sharp exchange of words, rumors and gossip such as are carried on by others; general feelings of disappointment, of pessimism, and of misfortune in hunting, disturbed psychic equilibrium, a bad mood. With these the most common cases of kwák tan have been named. In connection with this list, one should 756 cont. by no means think of psychoses or serious nervous disorders; our strongnerved Indians fortunately are not yet acquainted with such. They know very well how to distinguish whether it is only a question of a physical injury or whether the whole frame of mind is upset as a result of a psychic affliction. For example, one does not run to the n for the frequently occurring, temporary stomach disorders. On the other hand, someone who upon awakening in the morning was unable to rouse himself at all to his ordinary love of life and joy in work on account of bad dreams seeks out the n as soon as possible. Before Inxiol went to his father to have himself sung for, he often said to those around him: “I feel so discouraged. I am afraid something will soon happen to me while hunting, I cannot be careful enough ... I almost have to suspect that some whites are lying in wait for me!” (26) In fact he was in danger of attacks by Europeans, because, in defense of his wife, he had killed two drunken Chilean workmen near San Pablo. On migrations his fears would increase to pronounced discouragement.

Here I shall add a few supplemental remarks: Not every physical ailment arises from a malevolent n. It is only when a n sends it 761 cont. that it is generally called kwáke. But some discomfort, suffering, and indisposition can overtake a person “by itself”; such is called p k'e . Where it comes from, what its nature is otherwise, and the like the ordinary people do not concern themselves with in the least. In daily life they for their part just as little make a distinction in the origin of the ailment, for in reality each one of the two manifests itself in the same way. Only the n 's strength of vision is able to separate the two causally. This makes it understandable why the expression p k'e almost never recurs in daily use.

But are the n themselves clear about the cause and origin of their success, which, according to our ideas, is due to purely psychic causes? Certainly not. They emphatically point out that all their work depends on the co-operation of the wá yuwen. They quite inevitably stand under the influence of the prevailing view, inherited from their fathers, about the origin and the disappearance of the ailment.

Finally, how does the medicine man behave when, in spite of appropriate treatment, the complaint sets in again after a certain time? A relapse disturbs neither him himself nor the sufferer. If it is a matter of a complaint “that comes by itself, ” about whose origin no one knows anything, which one just as little ascribes to any special malevolence, then its renewed appearance surprises no one.

If, however, the n believes that a kwáke must be assumed, he states frankly: “That n [whom he mentions by name] sent the kwáke once more!” Of course he designates a person whose dislike of the patient is well known or is suspected from certain clues. Serious complications and enmities arise from this. One need not by any means always presume evil intentions on the part of the n; he acts in fullest agreement with ideas prevailing there, taking advantage of the relations at the moment between the individual persons.

Whereas ordinary people strive for the recovery of a sick child with a sort of prayer to the Supreme Being and expect help from him, a n never resorts to the same expedient. That a n would pray to T má kel . . . , there is simply nothing like that! My informants gaped at me more than astonished when in my questions I expressed this “strange idea,” according to their notions. In the example mentioned it is assumed that T má kel himself sent the illness to that child. Therefore taking away the evil would be expected of him. The illness of an adult is almost without exception caused by a Kwáke , therefore a n must helpfully intervene. But, in addition, there are also cases of illness among the adults, no matter how rare they may be, which, for some reason, are said to be caused by the Supreme Being. The n likewise follows this judgment of the generality. I was even given an example, according to which the medicine man himself frankly expressed this: “This ailment does not come from a kwáke !” and consequently would be derived from T má kel . As in this case, the n always confirms only a negative finding and indirectly reveals the real cause. The n with his art fails altogether when confronted with a case of illness that those closest to the sick person derive from the Supreme Being. Resigned and inactive, he, too, awaits the outcome and would never dare undertake any attempts at a cure according to his otherwise customary methods.

In explaining this dualistic attitude, I should like to state: As a Selk'nam, the medicine man has intercourse with T má kel precisely like any of his fellow tribesmen; as n , he avoids any contact with him.

Conversely, none of our Indians would think of appealing for protection or help from T má kel against the plotting of the n . Everyday observation furnishes the best proof. Anyone who, on the basis of certain indications, believes he is being harmed by some n immediately runs to the n friendly to him; here he seeks protection against the hostile person and asks for relief from the evil.

My informants seemed amazed at my cautious objection: Why does T má kel let every n do as he pleases, without somehow curtailing his activities? Long discussions communicated to me, as a conviction of the Indians, that the n are completely unimpeded in all their activities, as though the Supreme Being were unconcerned about their conduct. I was told: “Certainly, ‘The-one-up-there’ watches what the n do; but [he does] nothing more!”

To the consternation of all, an older girl happened to stumble and fall down in the middle of the meadow. Upon the excited admonition of the rest, she had to turn around as quickly as possible and lie down in the dwelling. (40) This stumbling and falling aroused the worst fears. I was assured that in former times such a person would have breathed his last within a few days, so sinister were the conditions that prevailed at that time during these ceremonies. People thus urgently warned against any falling. Today, however, everything has become more lenient because the malevolent medicine men of those days are no longer alive. That girl had to remain as quiet as possible on her sleeping place and was not permitted to leave it until four days later, when the danger seemed to be past.

The men now remain firmly convinced that the falling over of a mask inevitably results in some disturbance; above all, the person who uses a just overturned mask for the next spirit appearance will fall during this occurrence. Some other accidents further remain to be feared: A bad injury from a fall, a sudden plunge in the forest with a fatal outcome, severe burns from a careless step or slip, and so on. The candidates therefore repeatedly receive admonitions and urgent requests to watch all the masks constantly, to take good care of them, and to handle them cautiously.

While this performance is being readied in the secret hut, a few men prepare an open, blazing fire outside at a distance of 20 meters. They drag up dry wood and large bundles of brush, in order above all to create a strong light. When the glow of the fire seems  fanned sufficiently high, the camp occupants leisurely draw up to it. Here a smaller group of young people voluntarily become separated and stand somewhat apart from the mass of spectators. The procession of the men now appears, first describing a few circles around the large fire. This is followed by a march around the smaller group of younger female persons crowded together in an irregular band. (160) These female Indians stand in no particular order, but crowd very close together. In the Kulpu performance they form an actual longitudinal row (p. 1414). The men move so close to them that this or that girl rushes at the nose of a chap favored by her with a piece of skin in order to dry the blood flowing out. The girls are convinced that it is fresh blood and feel great sympathy. Breathing heavily, the row of men makes several circuits around this group of women. This one or that one repeatedly touches a certain woman with his elbow; usually it is the one who dried his bleeding nose. Sympathetic compensation!

The actual medical knowledge and natural healing methods, insofar as they are a general possession of the Selk'nam, will be discussed here. The special method of practice of the n will not be given consideration and has already been characterized in its peculiarity as chiefly the operation of suggestion (p. 1090).

A person who has been bent down by great age or a physical ailment, who has been tormented by long sickliness, is cared for and treated with the greatest consideration possible. (62) Among the Selk'nam there is a well-developed “social welfare,” which attends to not only orphans and the sick, but also widowed and needy persons. This has already been confirmed (p. 680). For illustration I add an observation by Spegazzini (a):175, who remembers a very old man who was accompanied everywhere by his grandson. The life of the individual person stood and stands in special estimation among those around him, which is why atonement is always demanded for a murder and harsh revenge is taken (p. 629). If an inveterate thief (p. 622) or a person who betrayed the Kloketen secret (p. 1273) was murdered, the generality consented to it, with a view toward warding off greater harm. Suicide seems never to have been practiced (p. 686). (63) Cf. Gallardo:133. Calvi:51 writes very generally: “Gli Ona considerano mancanze gravi l'omicidio volontario, escluso, ben inteso, quello commesso in guerra /The Ona consider voluntary manslaughter a grave offense, except, of course, that committed in war/.” Precisely like life itself, one also prized health and, if necessary, reached for remedies . Feuerland /Tierra del Fuego/ offers only very few of these; true medicinal plants are lacking altogether, (64) The fact that medicinal herbs and minerals are not present at all on the Great Island is shown by a study of the country and its flora and fauna. Dabbene (b):260, Del Turco (BS; 1904), Gallardo: 302, and others expressly confirm this. Only Holmberg (a):59 mistakenly and without specific references speaks of “ramas de plantas medicinales /branches of medicinal plants/.” Just like European pleasures, for “they have a horror of tobacco or other druggs / sic /” /quoted in English/ (Barclay [a]:74), they also reject medicines, which usually taste bitter and for that reason alone do not please them (p. 1068). and the Selk'nam as well as the Haus make do with other things. Fortunately, they are only very rarely ill; on the other hand, mental tension, discontent, states of fear, etc. (p. 1091), which the n must remove, appear more frequently.

Almost every adult is familiar with the remedies mentioned here (67) Borgatello (c):61, Gallardo:292, and Lahille (d):347 give still further information, which I was unable to check on the spot. and knows how to use them himself. For a complicated arm-fracture, m ronam , -- the same applies for a leg-fracture -- an experienced man or a n is consulted. First of all he sucks a great deal of blood out of the wound and removes small bone splinters; then he puts the two parts of bone belonging together into the normal position, waits until coagulated blood covers the wound, places three to four thumb-thick sticks around the arm, and wraps a long leather strip tightly around it. The arm can and must remain motionless in this binding for about a month, until the broken place has ossified. The people could not say whether gangrene had ever arisen. No special treatment for open wounds is known; but sometimes one applies flat flaps of fresh guanaco meat or spongy fatty tissue. An ulcer (ulcus), eruption (impetigo), carbuncle, or eczema had to heal by itself. One first lets large cuts bleed for a considerable time and then tightly binds them with long strips of leather. If an arrow strikes someone, it is immediately pulled out by a neighbor, or the wounded one does this himself if no helper is on the spot. The wound must bleed for a long time afterwards, which is why one kneads around it vigorously. In spite of the greatest pain, the unfortunate one scarcely changes his expression.

The Selk'nam has only a few remedies at his disposal and in many a case he uses them appropriately. Strangely enough, these people, otherwise so brave, intrepid, and even ruthless with themselves, appear as though broken, wholly cast down, and completely despondent when a serious illness or a bad accident strikes them. I am inclined to trace this phenomenon back to their character, which completely and without resistance adapts to every situation of life. (68) This resignation, however, may not, as Gallardo:293 suspects, “atribuirlo al hecho de saber el paciente que será abandonado si se agrava /be ascribed to the fact of the patient's knowing that he would be abandoned if he became worse/”; it was not customary among the Selk'nam to leave a sick person to his fate so that he thereby perished (p. 681). That is, the Indian silently locks his teeth on brief, penetrating pain, hot stinging wounds, a sharp blow, and bears it all with cold-blooded resignation. A person who cannot rise from his sickbed is surrounded by the sympathy of all, even though they cannot help. But with sincere love he is offered everything that pleases him or that is desired by him; in fact, many a sick person has been gravely harmed by excessive tenderness and inappropriate help. (69) Absolutely without justification Gallardo: 293 limits to the slightly ill ones the anxious, readily helpful co-operation of those around them; of course, in reality all are “cuidados con cariño por sus parientes, cariño que en muchas ocasiones les causa la muerte, como sucede en los casos en que convendría la dieta y que por el contrario les dan todo lo que piden /cared for with affection by their relatives, affection that on many occasions caused their death, as happened in the cases in which diet was important and, on the contrary, they gave them all that they asked for/.”

The adults and old people most willingly impart their extensive knowledge and their total experience in all fields to the succeeding generation in frequent instructions and by their personal behavior, so that this valuable treasure will also benefit it and will perish only with this people itself.

Smearing the head and body with grease served protective as well as decorative purposes. Face and body painting was common; besides the three colors, red, black, and white, used by the Yahgan, the Ona used blue, green, yellow, and slate. Body painting was also used for camouflage coloration in the chase.

Herbal curatives were lacking. Massage was a common procedure in minor indispositions. For lung ailments and coughs, a piece of guanaco bezoar (called in Ona “the guanaco's fire-making apparatus”) was ground to powder, put in a mussel shell with water, heated over a fire, and drunk (Gusinde, 1931, pp. 712, 1120). Crude splints were used for broken arms and legs.

In normal times, when no special event was taking place, body paint had a practical as well as an aesthetic and a symbolic function. Ochre mixed with fat was used frequently to protect the skin and cutis against the wind and cold. The Selk'nam took dry baths by rubbing down the body, and rubbing yesterday's paint and grease off, with a lichen ( Usnea campestris or U. magellanica, called ‘the beards of the trees’ in Spanish) or another plant ( Cladonia laevigata ). 92 The director of the Hain ceremony, however, wore his cape with the fur inside. Before setting out to hunt guanaco the men painted their bodies, their bows and their quivers with dark red, yellow or white paint, depending on the season, to blend in with the landscape.

Ochre was a vital item and, as stated above, it was mixed with animal fat to produce ákel. It was used almost daily to decorate the body and to protect the skin against inclement weather as well as to adorn the bags and capes and to preserve and soften the hides of which they were made. Great quantities of ákel were consumed during the Hain ceremony. Different tones of clay and limestone were also used to make paint.

The cultural salience of the link between exposure and vulnerability or weakness is confirmed by the explanatory paradigms that Bedouins use to interpret illness and misfortune. The “evil eye,” magic, and possession—the three most common sources of illness and misfortune—all work through the victim’s exposure to more Young men and clients feel at ease with each other powerful forces. Holymen ( fgih ) tend to diagnose illnesses as caused by being “looked at” ( manzur ). Magic works through the victim’s exposure to a charm or amulet, or merely to water in which a charm was soaked. Bedouins even believe that a new mother’s milk can dry up if she is exposed to the gold coins ( frajallat ) on another woman’s necklace. Serious illnesses are usually caused by solitary encounters in deserted places with jinn (spirits), which, if they get too close, can “ride” the person and possess him or her. The experience of such encounters is always described in terms of fear. Fright also causes other illnesses, such as hepatitis, whose symptoms of yellowness are believed to be caused by the rise of bile accompanying a frightened gasp.

Safety in encounters with powerful forces, supernatural or social, is enhanced by avoiding encounters in the first place or by placing barriers between oneself and the force. The most popular protection against the evil eye, the jinn, and magic is an amulet, one or more pieces of paper on which a holyman has written Koranic verses or, more frequently, scribbles that people mistake for the verses. The word Awlad ‘Ali use for amulet is hjab, meaning a protection, cover, or veil; elsewhere in the Arab world the word refers specifically to women’s veils.

There is a religious basis for the belief that sexual intercourse is polluting. For example, it is forbidden to pray or to enter a mosque in the unclean state following intercourse. Yet to counter this pollution men and women need do no more than observe certain restrictions and perform simple purificatory acts. Awlad ‘Ali explain that intercourse must be followed immediately by bathing to minimize the chance of encountering anyone while still “unclean”; they add that care must be taken to avoid spilling the bath water anywhere people are likely to walk. The soap used in these baths should be kept away from children or those who pray. To appear before children in the clothes worn during intercourse is believed to cause them eye problems. 10 10. Granqvist (1935, 161) notes a similar belief among Palestinian villagers of the late 1920s. She reports that villagers believe an unclean woman can harm others, quoting an informant as saying, “If anyone has bad eyes, and an unclean woman looks steadily at this person, it is not good.” Furthermore, Bedouins said it was forbidden ( haram ) to go with one’s pollution ( wasakha ) to places such as gardens where there was food or any sort of “God’s bounty” ( ni‘ma ).

“When Jawwad went in to see him, he shuddered. He told me, ‘I trembled and something pounded me from head to foot.’... He got sick, Jawwad, and he remained ill after the death. Ill for a year. And then a year after his brother had died, he died. And the old man, their father, died between them in the month of Ashura.

He had stepped on a mine. “Watch out, watch out, they are in front of you!”—that is what Sagr had shouted to his older brother. On the way home they had run across an Englishman whose plane had crashed. The man had bandaged Sagr so the blood would stop flowing. The boy had been hit in three places. In two of these—the thigh and the calf—what had gone in had come out the other side. The third place he had been struck was his heel. That bit was still in. All night long she stayed up with him while he cried out in pain. She massaged his foot until morning, when finally the thing, black and the size of a fly, fell out, “Tack!”—she heard the metal fall to the ground. Then they brought a doctor, who scraped and cut and stuffed the wounds to his screams of pain.

“We used to go out and collect copper,” he began. “I went out with my older brother, Hamid, and two others.... We had some donkeys and bags to carry the stuff out with, to the cars that came into the desert. The four of us went on foot into the desert. We walked separately because we were afraid of the mines. Each person had to be paying attention. I was walking and my thoughts were on the big mines. I was afraid of the big mines. But there is a mine called ‘One with the Little Mustache,’ which has three prongs, even finer than needles, that go into the detonator....

“I was walking along when I found that my shoe wouldn’t go down. Of course, these prongs are very thin, and if you don’t go right up to the mine you don’t see them. And so my shoe... I tried to put my foot down but it wouldn’t go—something stopped my foot, but I couldn’t see anything. So I pulled my foot back. I lifted my foot and looked and then, Duvv! It moved before it exploded. It blasted me twenty-two meters. I had been walking westward, and I was hurled away and found myself facing east. I had been carrying a knapsack with copper in it, and I was wearing a woolen vest under that. It scattered all of this. And my clothes, there was nothing left. All I had left on me was my shredded undershirt. It had blown them up until they ripped. And my shoes—gone. They flew off and I couldn’t find them at all. It was that powerful.

“It was hissing and there was smoke and after that it went ‘Tub Tub Tub Tub.’ I looked and saw my brother shouting and wailing. They couldn’t see me because I was in a low spot. I tried to stand up, but my legs couldn’t. I shouted, ‘Watch out for the mines! Watch out for the mines! The mines!’ They started running, but by then you could see them: every four meters was a mine. I could see them at intervals. One here and one there. ‘Be careful!’

“I told them at the time, ‘I’m safe.’ After I’d felt around my stomach, my chest, my head, and found nothing I told them it wasn’t serious. ‘It’s only something in my legs and it’s not bad. But I can’t stand up.’ So I said to them, ‘Just wrap up what’s here.’ It was really bleeding.... They had to carry me.

“I saw that they were frightened, afraid that I would die. So I said, ‘There’s nothing wrong with me. Let’s just make some tea.’ We had tea, but I only drank a cup. Then I told them to make me a saddle—a donkey’s saddle is not like a horse’s—and rope the saddle on and make me some stirrups in the middle so I could put my legs in. The blood, the blood was flowing and I was getting dizzy. It was a long way, about thirty-five kilometers to Alamein, and I was worried about the blood.

“We got on the donkeys, and when we reached the rise to the north of us we saw someone. He was not an Arab; we could tell from his clothes. There was an asphalt road that the army, the English, had made. And there was a pipeline that brought water, dug in the sand. He had left the road and was walking along the pipeline because the sand there was soft. He couldn’t walk on the hard surface. When we got near him, Hamid whistled at him. He stopped. He stopped and started mumbling. He tried to talk, but he was really tired, completely wiped out. ‘Hey, hey—bomb.’ He’d seen the bomb and had heard it. He’d been close by, but we hadn’t noticed him.

“Then he looked at me and saw the blood. He took off his backpack and took out a box with three pills—one small pill, one grey one, and a third capsule with each half a different color. He opened my mouth and put the medicine in it. Then he got his water flask—there was only a tiny amount in it—and he held me like this and made me swallow the pill with the water. He had hung on to this one last sip, the one I drank. Then he opened his bag and got out some dyed bandages with two ties....He took off all the headcloths and rags they had used to bandage me. The wounds were bleeding, and he rubbed the yellow ointment on and wiped it. It was as if he’d put fire on them, and I let out some screams. He wrapped them with the bandages.

“We looked at this Englishman. He had headphones and was wearing only trousers. He had a sack with an aerial, like a walkie-talkie. And that’s all. His body was burnt. His skin was peeling, exactly like a snakeskin. His shoes had fallen apart, and he had tied the torn tops on with what must have been a strip of his shirt so he could walk on them. His legs looked as if he’d put them over a fire: they were burnt and bleeding. His lips were cracked. And when he looked down you’d see that his eyelids were very white, just as if they had been painted white. He was young, about twenty-eight or twenty-seven years old. He said, ‘Wadiwaant, waadiwij wij blayn. Duvv! Cairo, Cairo.’ His plane had crashed. I don’t know what he said, but we understood that his plane had crashed three hundred kilometers from Cairo. There had been maneuvers where the armies had been and something had gone wrong with his plane. It went down and he had left it....

“He had been walking for seven days. He had with him a little water, which he drank bit by bit. And he had a pill to keep going, something to make him strong. He had gone on like this, walking a lot at night. In the daytime during the heat he sat in the shade—maybe he’d find a tree or he’d find a mountain with rocks to go between. But he was near the end. If he hadn’t come upon us he would have died. He could barely talk—he just kept saying, ‘Blayn.’

Yet when someone like Ngawa would pick up her crying newborn, women watching always said, “Blessings on the Prophet!” They were careful to say this to protect the baby. Gateefa had told me once about her eldest son, now skinny and prone to colds. “You should have seen him when he was small. He was huge and fair. Then one day a neighbor came by and said, ‘I never thought you could have a boy like this!’ Well, the next day he woke up with a huge boil behind his ear. I sent someone to the Sudanese religious healer who used to live nearby to find out what had happened. The woman had entered on the boy and not asked for the Prophet’s blessings. She’d given him the eye. The healer gave me an amulet, sewed something in a pouch, and said I should keep it and put it on each child I had. For forty days.”

“This is what happened. When my son was only one month in my womb, my co-wife’s daughter was with me. One minute she was talking with me—she was so young and beautiful—and the next thing she had fallen in the well. Her father got shocked and went crazy. For a month he could not sit up without hauling himself up with a rope. After that he didn’t have any more children. A healer came and wrote him some amulets, but he took a long time getting better. He was sick for three or four months after the girl died. He didn’t have any more children, at all, after that. And me, I had my only son in my womb, and that was that. I’d had four daughters and then this son and then it ended. From shock.

Fractures . 1 1 Fractures may be considered either as (1) hashima salama “healed fractures”, when repaired without defect. (Such are assessed at 150 dinars of 5 piastres each); or (2) ‘ adam “permanent injuries”. If complete infirmity results, compensation is to be half a diya . Compensation for part of a limb is assessed in proportion to the number of parts in that limb.—A. W. G. —Yahya says that (the Caliph) Mu‘awiya ibn Sufian ordained that if the hand be broken and set again and repaired without defect or injury, 100 dinars should be due.

Yahya also says that if the arm be broken and the bone be set and repaired without injury, 100 dinars shall be due. Also fifty dinars for any bone of the arm or of the thigh, leg, or any projecting limb.

Yahya also says of the collar-bones, that if the two bones situated on the shoulders be broken, but afterwards set and repaired, 100 dinars shall be due, and for either of them separately only fifty dinars.

Dislocations .—Yahya says that if a limb be dislocated or severed, and later recover without defect or injury, fifty dinars shall be due, but if severed or disabled for good or paralysed, the compensation will be 500 dinars.

If the elbow is broken and repaired without damage (the compensation will be) 140 dinars for both (elbows); and fifty dinars for any part of the hips, if dislocated and then set or repaired without damage. Half the diya, that is 500 dinars, for the foot, if it is dislocated and does not recover and become useless; but 100 dinars it it recovers without defect.

Loss of Fingers .—For the fingers of both hands, if cut off, 1,000 dinars, and for the fingers of one hand, 500 dinars, and for each finger amputated 100 dinars. If paralysed, since the fingers of the hands contain three joints but the thumbs only two, then 33 1/3 dinars shall be paid for each joint of the fingers, but fifty dinars for each joint of the thumbs.

We are also told by Yahya that (the Caliph) Mu’awiya ibn Sufian said that a wound on the body should be assessed at half the value of that wound on the head or face. For all bones of the body, great or small, if wounded (and recovered) without defect or damage, seventy-five dinars shall be due.

Loss of Toes .—If all the toes of both feet be cut off, 1,000 dinars, and for each toe-joint, if cut or disabled or paralysed, 33 1/3 dinars. Each of the big toes of the feet has two joints, and for each of these fifty dinars (shall be paid).
Nails .—If a nail be cut off, ten dinars. If the nail be injured so that its colour changes to black, three dinars.

Injuries to the Body .—Yahya says that if the neck be broken with all its bones and only the flesh be left, the full diya (1,000 dinars) shall be due, and if it suffers so that the owner cannot turn (his head) to right or left, 500 dinars only shall be due.
For a munqila injury to the neck, 150 dinars and sixteen dinars, and a half, and a sixth (150 + 16 + 1/2 + 1/6 = 166 2/3) shall be due.
For a hashima injury in the neck, seventy-five dinars.
For a muwadhdhiha injury in the neck, twenty-five dinars.
For a badhi‘a injury in the neck, twelve and a half dinars.
For a damiya injury in the neck, one and a half dinars.

Injuries to the Ears .—If the ears be torn off altogether, with loss of the sense of hearing, the full diya (1,000 dinars) shall be due, and for each ear separately 500 dinars. If the ear be injured and not recover, the wound shall be measured and estimated according to the remaining portion of the ear, or the part lost in proportion to the ear itself. If the ear be split or injured (and recover) without defect or damage, fifty dinars shall be due. But if the ear suffer damage and a little of the hearing remain, then comparison shall be made of the area from which he previously used to catch sounds and that remaining after the injury, and the damage assessed proportionately from the diya . Should the striker suspect that the injured man be pretending, then the injured man shall be detained till he is in need of sleep, when he shall be allowed to sleep. Then when he is asleep, drums are to be beaten above him. If he does not awake or seem to hear, then his hearing is lost. But if he starts up in horror, he is a liar.

The Eye .—Yahya says that if the sight be lost in whole, a full diya of 1,000 dinars shall be due, and if one eye only lose its sight, 520 dinars, and if the sight be lost in part, then the proportionate amount of the 500 dinars shall be paid.

Note .—Yahya says that the method of ascertaining how much sight has been lost is by making lines on an egg of a hen or on a white paper which is to be placed at a distance. When the patient closes his injured eye and looks with the good one, he is to be questioned as to the number of lines he can see on the egg or the paper. The egg or paper is then to be brought nearer to him little by little, until he can tell for certain the true number of the lines. Then he is to be ordered to close his good eye and look with the injured one, and the method repeated, and then the difference is to be measured between the distances.
If the eye be injured so that it lies askew, the slanting is to be measured, and compensation made from the diya by estimation.
The Nose .—Yahya says that if the whole nose be cut off or amputated a full diya of 1,000 dinars will be due, but if the flesh of the nose only be cut off, 100 dinars.

For a nafiza (piercing) of the nostrils in whole, 100 dinars, and for either nostril fifty dinars according to the appearance of the nose. If the bone of the nose be broken, and recover later without defect or damage, 100 dinars; and for a munqila in the nose 100 dinars; but if a big bone be removed from it, 150 dinars.

The Lips .—If the whole two lips be cut off, full diya will be due (1,000 dinars) and for the lips separately, if the upper one is cut off, one-third of the diya; and if the lower one is cut off in whole, two-thirds of the diya will be paid, that is 666 2/3 dinars.

For a nafiza in the lips, if the piercing is visible and its place is evident, fifty dinars according to the appearance of the mouth and lips (equivalent to muwadhdhiha ), but if it be injured or split, then the compensation will be calculated from the diya for cutting off.

The Tongue .—Yahya says that if the tongue suffer and recover without defect or damage, 100 dinars shall be paid; but if it be all cut off, the full diya (1,000 dinars). If hurt be caused to the tongue, so that the owner cannot properly utter the letters, he is to be made to repeat the twenty-nine letters of the alphabet. Then the diya is to be divided according to the alphabet, so that the injured man is compensated for whatever letters he fails to recite or to pronounce properly.
Teeth .—Yahya says that for the whole of the teeth 1,000 dinars shall be due, and for each tooth separately fifty dinars, if it has been injured and fallen out.

For each tooth injured and split and its colour changed, fifty dinars.
