While the Andamanese say that they are liable to be struck by erem-chàugala or juru-win- at any time or in any place, the chôl- strike those only who offend them, and that during the day while they are stationary, this being necessitated by the distance from the earth of their abode, whence they hurl their darts: an invisible spear is the weapon they always use, and this is thrown with unerring aim at the head of their victim, and is invariably fatal. As these demons are considered especially dangerous on the hottest days, they are apparently held accountable for the deaths from sunstroke which happen from time to time.

6. After eating pork or turtle they are also in the habit of smearing og- over their bodies with their fingers, in the belief that it affects their breath, and that evil spirits will be unable to detect, and therefore will not be attracted to, them by the savoury smell of the food of which they have partaken. Again, when heated by travelling, or by hunting or dancing, they have recourse to the same wash, but in these cases it is applied thinly. 5 Vide “Anatomy and Physiology,” paragraph 5.

44. cháuga-tâ -. 5 Vide Plate VIII, fig. 46. Human bone necklaces sometimes ornamented with Dentalium octogonum . These are worn as charms during illness by friends or relatives of the deceased, and may be often seen tied tightly round the part in pain; they are also worn when in health to ward off disease. 6 Vide Part I, “Medicine,” paragraphe 2, 7, 8.

I then asked my friend, ‘But if you desert the god, won't he turn on you?’ He replied, ‘I don't know. Now on a day on which Rakeimaranga (a spirit possessing a medium) will come I shall tell him that I am abandoning the adze on account of my abandonment of the gods--I shall build canoes thenceforth at my own pleasure.’ I asked him if the god had already harmed his family. He replied, ‘I keep on thinking of my children and I say to myself that the god is evil. I have affection too for my grandchildren. My wife and children have been affected. My wife has been bewitched by him severely. She is sore in her ribs and her belly flows. As she descended to the seashore, there came rushing to her the god. He came and his head was split. There were three days on which he rushed at her in the sea. She was afraid and she ran up inland. She threw stones at him but he did not go. Thereupon I sat and sought in my mind among the stories that had been told. Thereupon I abandoned the adze.’ This somewhat cryptic account refers to the Tikopia belief that this feared Taumako deity, incarnate in the reef eel, manifests his hostility towards men by aggressive unusual action. What Nau Nukutapu had seen was apparently a particular reef eel which had approached her on several occasions and which she had remarked because its head had been split by a cut with a knife or other implement. She had never seen this phenomenon before and, taken in conjunction with the approach of the eel to her, regarded it as an evil sign. Her husband said to me, ‘Split in his head he goes in his evil. He is turning evilly. He goes to a person with his head split. It is not certain just what this means, but he is going evilly among us men. He wreaks ill on a man or on a woman.’ At the time of our conversation his wife, who had been obviously ill, probably with some form of influenza which was then common in the island, was feeling much better. I asked if she had dreamed at all of the deity. He said ‘Yes, for two nights or so.’ She dreamed that the deity took on the semblance of the Ariki Taumako. The figure, apparently that of the chief, appeared on the ritual side of the house and asked her for some biscuit for himself. Her husband said he could not remember whether she gave it biscuit or not. He said that this was a custom of the god to take the form either of the Taumako chief or of his brother or of some other member of the chiefly lineage of Taumako with which he was ritually associated. When he took on the form of a man in this way, it was an evil sign. My friend added that the deity was an evil one indeed. By comparison the god of Sa Kafika was good. Their lineage was fortunate.

I now outline the Tikopia theory of spirit relations with the human body. Every individual has when alive a spirit principle called by the Tikopia mauri or ora , which may be termed the soul. This is believed to be separated from the body at death by some rather complicated manoeuvres and may be later spoken of as atua , a term used generically for any external spirit. External spirits are of many kinds and degrees of rank and power. Some, such as ancestors, are clearly benevolent, but may harm people if offended. Others, such as the common wandering spirits known as atua vare , not identified individually, are by nature malevolent to mankind. Types of such spirits are those of the water spout at sea, who cause men to throw away their paddles and attempt to commit suicide, or those of the coconut frond, who are associated with black magic. One of these wandering spirits may take up residence in the body of a person, or may abstract his soul and make him ill. One of the important functions of a spirit medium is to expel the spirit concerned, and/or recover the abstracted soul.

An interesting series of private seances arose in connection with a Tikopia belief that my illness in 1929 had been the result of action by a malevolent spirit. My house was not far from a pool believed to be frequented by a powerful female spirit known as Pufine-i-Vaisiku. She was believed to overcome men and generate children from them in the spirit world, with the result that they fell ill. Some time after I had returned to Tikopia in 1952 I was asked about my former illness and my ‘sons’ in the spirit world. Surprised, I made further enquiry and learnt that this was a widely believed view. Later a neighbour, Pa Ngatotiu, asked me if I wanted to talk to his deceased father, i.e. a spirit, and learn the names of my children in the spirit world. He said it was agreed that I had been ‘overcome’ ( toa; tafina ) in 1929.

The second case is that of a man, Pa Sukuporu, who was a spirit medium but who became a Christian. He used to be possessed by the god Tangaroa, the tutelary of his lineage. But when he became baptized the god departed from him. On his taking this decision for baptism he summoned his kinsfolk and an oven was prepared. This was to be the celebration for parting from his god. He entered into the trance state and the spirits spoke. At first they objected to his decision but finally agreed that they would go and dwell in their own place and not return to him. However, they still really objected to his having deserted them and they made him ill in a sickness from which he was cured by the Mission teachers. Even then one of his gods, the eel god, afflicted his womenfolk by producing miscarriages, and his daughter was seized by the spirits and became ill. Finally he gave orders for another house to be built nearby for the women to sleep in so that they could be free of the spirits’ attention. The eel god, who came to Tikopia with his ancestor, is still under the house, but nowadays is benign.

The third case was the most dramatic of all. In 1929 a son of the Ariki Tafua fell ill and the chief became very disturbed about this. He had been baptized as a Christian, but this had not meant that he had abandoned all belief in the reality of his traditional gods and spirits. He regarded the illness of his son as due to the action of some malicious spirits, and seeing his son get weaker and imagining that he would die he attempted suicide by hanging (p. 138). This was a despairing act given the rationalization of shaming his traditional gods for not looking after his family. When his suicide attempt had been prevented (and it was never quite clear how far the chief had hoped it would be prevented) he addressed his gods, reproaching them for wanting to take the life of a young man while he himself, an old man, still remained. According to Tikopia belief, in response to this reproach the gods allowed his son to recover, but made the chief himself ill. From this illness he was in turn in Tikopia eyes saved by the effort of his peers, the Ariki Kafika and Ariki Taumako, both pagan chiefs, who visited him and laid hands on him. In the course of the rites which accompanied these proceedings the Ariki Tafua, who was a spirit medium, twice entered the trance state, and in spirit form gave utterance to reassuring statements. But the day before he became ill he had also had a trance and in spirit form spoke to the assembled company, saying ‘Who is the man who told the chief that he should hang himself?’ The spirit appeared to be very angry. His eldest son and another senior man crawled across the floor of the house to him, and pressed their noses one to each of his knees in token of obeisance. Then they and all the others present in the house assured the spirit that he was mistaken, that it had been the idea of the chief himself alone that he should commit suicide, that no one else had advised him to do so. At last the spirit appeared to be appeased and the trance ended.

In the second case the man's conversion to Christianity had clearly left him with regrets, doubts and fears relating to his continuing belief in the reality of his traditional gods. The conflict was exemplified in his parting seance (not an unusual Tikopia custom) in which in his trance state the resistant and anxious elements of his mind were able to come to the surface and express themselves freely. They took the form of spirit objections to the man's desertion of his traditional faith. Restatement of his conviction of the rightness of his decision emerged in final spirit statements that they agreed to depart from him and come to him no more. But this reassurance evidently did not carry complete conviction. An ensuing illness was interpreted as due to the traditional influences and only the intervention of the Christian teachers, to whom he had transferred his authority notions, produced a cure.

In saying all this I do not mean to imply that in traditional Tikopia eschatology there is anything of the specific didactic kind which one meets for example in accounts of medieval visions of the Christian afterworld. When the thirteenth-century Essex peasant Thurcill had his vision of the brilliantly lit Cathedral with the foetid smoke of Hell swirling up outside its walls, he was told by his guide (St Julian) that the coughing of unhappy souls in this smoke was caused by the tithes they had unjustly retained. The brilliant light in the Cathedral, on the other hand, was due to the tithes that the just had rendered. When Thurcill unfortunately happened to cough twice from a whiff of the smoke, his saintly guide suggested that he must have been remiss in paying his tithes. Thurcill admitted this, pleading poverty, to which the saint replied that the giving of tithes increases the fertility of the soil, so that it would have been more profitable for him to have paid up. Such didactic details in the visions were used in local medieval sermons, we are told. 1 A.B. Van Os, Religious Visions: The development of the eschatological elements in mediaeval religious literature , Amsterdam, 1932, pp. 3, 75, etc. But little of this plain speaking occurs in pagan Tikopia accounts. The story of the test barrier of the slippery stone has sometimes been given with a moral connotation--those who have not done their duty by the kava rites miss their footing and are precipitated down no-one knows whither. But this story and its implications have no wide currency. 2 In 1929 the Ariki Taumako told me this. He also told me that people who have lived properly and not killed or committed theft go to their heaven without trouble. Those who have slain men or stolen do not. But he said that this information was generally not known, nor did he have any clear idea what happened to such evil-doers. I noted at the time that this was not a current ethical concept, and regard it as a personal gloss due probably to the unconscious effect of Mission teaching, and the desire to represent pagan knowledge as at bottom no less ethical. There was no evidence in other contexts that the chief paid attention to such a belief. What is much more common however is for spirits of the dead to appear in dreams to the living, or in the trances of spirit mediums, and complain that they have not had proper attention paid to them. Here the tone is definitely one of moral application to the survivors, and this is recognized by the living Tikopia who are spurred on by the belief that if they do not do what is asked the spirit will afflict them with illness or death.

What was of great interest here was a modernization of the theory of illness at the same time. In traditional Tikopia belief, most illnesses, especially the graver ones, were the work of spirits. Now the view had changed radically. ‘Formerly when the land became ill, it was greatly because of spirits. Now it is not so, because the land has become different. Sickness is from the vessels that come from the sea, just as in the Solomons. Is this correct, friend?’ The inference from this assumption was of course that since illness was now the product of external influences, not of spirits, it was remedies of an external order, not of a traditional spiritual order, that were required. Here then is another instance of a modification of belief to conform to a more pragmatic interpretation of a situation powerfully affected by external forces.

Two other problems were also dealt with at the same time. One was the question of forces in the personality too strong to be completely inhibited by any external sanction and incapable of being organized by the personality itself. The Tikopia theory of madness continued to be in terms of the notion of spirit possession. But it was possession in a socially non-viable way; the belief that unnamed wandering spirits were responsible did not conflict with the view that the named kinrelated spirits had retired in dignified fashion to their dwelling places. The second problem concerned what may be rather loosely indicated as the psycho-somatic aspects of the illness. Previously these appeared to be catered for fairly effectively by the spirit medium performances; what then could take their place? The Tikopia answer here was clear--the power of prayer. The ‘laying on of hands’ of the Christian priest, and prayers said in church for the sick, seemed in 1966 so far to have met this need, at least in public estimation.

The Tikopia then conventionally conceived of the soul as an immaterial animating principle, separable from the body and to some extent antithetic to it, figuratively and physically, as in dreams or after death. The concept was imprecise and the soul tended to be defined operationally, by actions performed in reference to it--in situations of fainting or illness. As part of a living person the soul was not an integral part of the spirit world, though it could be affected by personalities from that world. But since the owner was mortal, on his death his ora , after certain transmutations, joined the world of the spirits and was known now as an atua .

Unusual events were commonly explained by the assumption of such atua vare ; the events were the tokens ( fakamailonga ) of the spirits. If a person going along a path smelt a pungent scent with no other person nor any fragrant shrub there, that was a sign of the presence of spirits, who had their perfumes just as men had. The sound of a falling stone might betoken a spirit, when no stone is visible. Said Pa Fenuatara: ‘A spirit who is angry with a man takes up a stone and throws it. A stone which a spirit throws at a man is not there.’ The impact of such an immaterial weapon would be not felt directly but through some symptom of discomfort or illness. Animals behaving in an unusual way might be inhabited by spirits ( Tikopia Ritual and Belief , 1969, pp. 235-9 ). Wandering evilly disposed spirits in the undergrowth or abroad in the path were held to come to men like caterpillars and other crawling things; when a man was ill they were attracted and came and bit him, giving him further complaints. These atua fakafua , evil-bringing spirits, were driven off by atua fangai , nourishing spirits, who were a person's guardians, unless the illness proved too severe; even then they could be kept at bay while more compassionate ancestral spirits bore off the man's soul at death. A description given to me by two young men in 1929 illustrates an aspect of the disgusting habits attributed to such evil spirits. ‘After a man has died, the spirits sit and count the nights as they go until the fifth night, that of the ‘scented path’ [a terminal funeral rite] has arrived. The spirits say then that their banana has ripened. That is the body of the man which has rotted in the ground. So the banana of the spirits has become ripe--it is likened to a banana which has ripened. We are living in the house--the men. Our waterbottles are hidden. Thereupon the spirits enter to go and eat their banana--the man who has rotted. When they finish, the spirits come, they come and search, search for the waterbottles of men to drink, to wet their lips. When later we drink from it, we drink and Ugh! it stinks because they have eaten of the dead man.’ Interesting here are the conceptual oppositions--spirits, the antithesis of men, devour men; but what they eat is the antithesis of men--corpses; yet in feeding upon men they illustrate their genesis from men and their dependence upon men.... What is also interesting is the logical embroidery: water which has gone stale in the coconut containers--not unusual considering the heat and the amount of organic matter in it--is neatly accounted for by the notion of spirit intervention.

No shame was shown by Tikopia in admitting fear of atua , though some people alleged they were less afraid than others. I never heard any criticism of a person for admitting to being afraid, though some people took pride in not showing fear. In 1929 Pa Fenuatara said he was not afraid of atua and demonstrated this by going alone at night from one side of the island to the other. In telling me this he said that the night before he actually saw an atua about five yards away and it fled before him; he accelerated its going by waving his firestick at it. Atua , he said, were frightened of fire and of all pungent scents, too, though they had their own. But in 1952 Pa Fenuatara asked to borrow my electric torch one night, saying he was afraid, of atua . The difference was probably due to his age, and to the great number of recent deaths in the epidemic, which had generated many stories of ghosts abroad. Standardized personal differences of response to an experience of atua were recognized. I was told how a man going at night sees an atua standing, is frightened, retreats and yells. But another man sees the atua and calls out to it ‘Wait for me, friend’ or questions it; the atua , seeing this stoutheartedness, disappears. Still another man may see the atua and faint, falling over. Folk come up and grasp him, bear him away and press his limbs, asking, ‘Lad, lad, what is the matter with you?’ He wakes up, and answers, ‘I was overcome by an atua who appeared; I was standing in the path and he overcame me.’ (The term for fainting is puroua , literally, ‘covered over’.)

A third type of specially created spirit, occasionally treated as of major rank, and important in many contexts, was the foetal spirit, product of an abortion or a miscarriage. (A still-born child or one who had perished by infanticide at the time of birth seems to have sometimes been included in this category.) In Tikopia, whereas a child who had lived for some time was buried with due funeral rites even if of minimal character, a foetus or child who had died at the time of birth was simply buried, with no rites at all; it had no social personality. In most cases it was thought that the child's spirit had no part in the religious system thereafter. But occasionally such a spirit might be identified (by a spirit medium) as the cause of the subsequent illness of one of the members of the family, and placated by appeal and offering. Occasionally, too, such a spirit was incorporated into the list of atua worshipped by the group concerned. Structural reasons sometimes accounted for the selection of such foetal spirits, as with a ‘seedling chief’ who might have been a successor in office. But the choice was usually determined only by idiosyncratic dream or spirit medium announcement. As I have pointed out elsewhere ( Essays on Social Organization and Values , 1964, pp. 254-6), belief in these spirits gave a free field to spirit mediums for diagnosis of illness and for building up their own personal cadre of spirit resources outside the standard set recognized as being available in structured form. Defined usually in terms of their kinship to the descent group which invoked them, such spirits seemed to be believed to have a particularly close relation to their officiant. The spirits of such foetuses or dead neonates, described as toto (blood), fanau pariki (born badly) or memea pariki (infant in bad state), according to stage, were regarded as especially powerful. 1 David Schneider once suggested to me that involved here may be an element of guilt at the practice of infanticide, which overtly in traditional Tikopia society bore no moral stigma, but which may well have been associated with emotional disturbance in some people. I think this a very plausible suggestion. Certainly at times there was disagreement about whether a newborn child should be put to death or not. Not many spirits of this category were used in the kava--most were ‘familiars’ of spirit mediums--but those who were so invoked tended to be outstanding in reputation.

In a related family a daughter was born as the result of the mother's ninth pregnancy. The child was buried alive, in a hole dug by its kin, and left unnamed. A name of this child, Terevai, was ‘announced’ by a spirit medium, but the child's spirit did not manifest itself among men thereafter. The discussion of this raised an interesting point about Tikopia spirit theory and social structure. When we were talking about this case the woman's eldest daughter, herself a married woman, asked if her mother had not become ill after the neonate was buried. Her father said no; the babe had plenty of kin among the atua and they took it up and cared for it in the spirit world; it was not allowed to ‘fall down below’ in neglect. The conception was that if the infant had been neglected as a spirit it might have sought vengeance on its living kin--who had been responsible for depriving it of life and had thrust it into the spirit world. If it has become ‘bad of itself’, that is, has been born dead or has been a foetal miscarriage, then it bears no animosity. But if it has been buried alive it may get angry and afflict members of its family with illness. (Here is evidence of fear if not of guilt at the infanticide.) But with this infant no spirit manifestation took place--it was a tama a fenua , a ‘child of the land’, the product of wealthy folk with plenty of spirit kin to care for it, so had no occasion for anger at having been sped unceremoniously to the spirit world. This instance indicates not only a finely adjusted sense of balance in the behavioural field, extended into the spirit dimension, but also a rationalization justifying infanticide as a means of population limitation among the upper social strata of Tikopia!

In Tikopia theory the predisposing factor was human activity, which could be interpreted as human fallibility. A person trod on a place where a spirit lived, had gone to bathe or relieve nature at a pool inhabited by a spirit, slipped on a path or sat upon a stone ordinarily used by a spirit. But the active principle postulated was sex desire, generated by sex difference; the spirit was conceived as being sexually stimulated and having sex intercourse. Since the spirit was invisible, it was held the person had no way of knowing he or she had been interfered with. So the identification was post hoc . Whereas a dreamer had recollections of copulation and, if a man, evidences of semen on his bed mat, someone who was unwittingly seduced at work by a spirit knew only when he became ill, and then usually through a pronouncement by a spirit medium. The expression for this notion of spirit intercourse was toa . The Tikopia would elucidate this only by reiterative examples, but I think the word may be derived from to meaning ‘to fall’, and may be translated as ‘overcome’. The mechanism ordinarily conceived by the Tikopia to account for illness following on being ‘overcome’, and for consequent therapy, was ingenious. It seems to have been thought that a spirit child was generated by the sex congress, and that the illness of its human parent was caused by the child's grieving for his company and summoning him to join it in the spirit world. The means of readjusting the situation was for a spirit medium in trance to assume the role of a tutelary spirit, seek out the spirit child and by blandishment, by threats or by killing the child, induce it to relax its hold upon the sick person. If this move was not successful the person died. In some cases direct intimate contact with a spirit in itself was regarded as leading to illness; in others generation of a spirit child was thought to have resulted in a benevolent relation with its parent. At first sight these conceptualizations of spirit children may seem pointless; why invent these extra entities to complicate the situation? But what this type of elaboration does is to pinpoint the situation in personality terms. A person is stricken with illness, which is identified as the result of intimacy with a spirit. If by location and other circumstances this spirit is identified as one of the regular pantheon, the conceptual mechanism for dealing with it might involve cutting across the purported behaviour of some other spirit and so embroil some other medium or a chief or elder. The creation of a spirit child unique to the situation allows this to be isolated and treated on its own terms, without any danger of appearing to interfere with the relationships of any other human practitioner. So, individual experiences can be related to the general religious framework, but in a way which preserves them from external challenge due to competing demands.

Another mode of spirit action was dependent not so much upon the initiative of a spirit, it was thought, as upon that of men. This was the whole field of tautuku , of sorcery. In this a person was believed to be handed over ( soria ) to spirit powers by means of a formula recited by another person controlling such powers, the result being illness or death for the individual so named. (Another expression, fakasoa , to make a friend of, continued this notion of creation of a linkage between human being and spirit, to the detriment of the former.) A case in 1952 illustrated Tikopia belief in such phenomena. A girl who had accused members of the chiefly family of Kafika of stealing food soon after felt ill--it was a time of influenza epidemic--with dizziness and sore belly. It was said by our attendants that she had been ‘handed over’ by the Kafika people to their deity the Atua Pouri, the Dark God, and that this information was given by her ‘brother’, a spirit resulting from a miscarriage of her mother's, and appearing in her father, who was a spirit medium. On my checking with the medium he said that his ‘son’ hadn't said that the girl had been handed over to the Dark God, but that she had been ensorcelled by the Kafika family by being given to the Bamboo Vessel. This, the Vaka a Kofe , was a kind of ‘death cart’ on the spirit plane. Its material representation was a rough bamboo construction kept in the Kafika temple, known as Te Kaufata , but the invisible counterpart was believed to be used by malevolent spirits as a receptacle for spirits of living people whom they were carrying off ( Work of the Gods , pp. 238-9). Its spiritual use was controlled by the Kafika chief. Now such was the effect of traditional belief that the girl, in her influenzal delirium, had the sensation of being in the Bamboo Vessel. ‘As she lay down, she said she was turning over in the Vessel--she was lying in the bottom of the Vessel.’ According to the usual procedure, the spirit her ‘brother’ went to ‘seek her spirit’ ( sakiri ora ) and having found it, removed it from the Bamboo Vessel, whereupon she lay down peacefully and all was well. The girl's cure was aided by Western pills and cough medicine which we administered, and this was admitted by her father, who explained that the epidemic from abroad and the effects of the Bamboo Vessel had coincided in her case. But realistically, it seemed plausible that the relief given to her by assurance of spirit support helped also in her recovery. Ensorcellment in Tikopia views could be done by means of ancestor spirits or gods. In such contexts both the human agents and the spirits thought to be responsible were stigmatized, whatever be their reputation in other contexts ( Tikopia Ritual and Belief , pp. 199, 211-12).

Evidence for these modes of spirit action was available, in circumstantial detail, for very many instances. Evidence for spirit interference with human beings was supplied by the illness of the person concerned, with specification of the circumstances which by accident or human frailty had given opportunity for the spirit to act. In other words, what was adumbrated by such diagnoses was an implicit theory of responsibility-- a spirit medium, representing external society, imputed what had been observed, the illness, to some earlier action of the afflicted person, who had displayed either carelessness or ignorance. Evidence of interference of spirits with the order of nature was given by concrete signs in the behaviour of vegetation and of fish, which gave results in excess or in shortfall of what had been hoped or expected. Some of these concrete signs did seem of unusual character. Tikopia often spoke to me of the Ariki tautai , the ‘sea-expert chief’, the guardian spirit of canoe and fishing, who with spear or adze would strike a large fish and bring it to the hook of the fisherman. I give a short description of Pa Tearairaki in 1929: ‘I have heard that a spirit decorates himself in his leaf perfumes, bathes his body in oil, binds the decorative fringe round his waist; another spirit hangs an ornament round his neck, sticks a leaf spray at his back--and he goes to strike a fish. He takes his implements, an adze or a spear or a club. He is the “Sea-expert chief”. Now a man speaks words of praise to him, to his “Sea-expert chief”, to go and seek a fish to bring it to his canoe, to bring it for food. For the making of his kava, and for his hunger, that he may feed his children. Then [the spirit] brings the fish, the kava is made, and fish are summoned, whether shark or varu , from the ocean. This land, uniquely, is-great in its sea expertise.’ Now the sign that such a fish has been brought by a spirit is the gash made by spear, adze or club on its head or body; Tikopia have often observed such cuts as the fish is brought alongside, before they have hauled it inboard. For a long time I was of the opinion that the Tikopia were either inventing these stories of gashed and bleeding fish or had built up a few incidents into a mythology. But recently studies of the habits of swordfish suggest that the Tikopia may have been relying on empirical evidence after all. Analysis of the stomachs of 500 swordfish by Canadian biologists has showed that many of the fish swallowed by these swordfish ‘had gashes immediately behind the head’, suggesting that they had been individually marked down by the swordfish rather than fallen victims to an indiscriminate slashing attack on a school. 1 From a note on feeding habits of swordfish, The Times , July 25, 1968. Such instances could easily fit a postulate of sea-spirit activity.

The eldest of the Brethren, Tafito, the Atua i Fangarere, known commonly as the Atua Lasi, the Great God, symbolised both prosperity and disaster. In a variety of unusual ways he was associated with the head . His vegetal symbol, his ‘head’, was the breadfruit, known as mei , but also as te uru fenua , the ‘head of the land’, an indication of its prime place among Tikopia foods ( Primitive Polynesian Economy , 1939, p. 65 ). On the other hand, sprung untimely from the head of his mother, he was cursed as the future bearer of epidemic disease. He was also disaster in another According to Pa Nukutungasau, of Vaisakiri in Fangarere, the rau of the Atua Lasi for the ocean, passed on from his chiefly ancestor Faisangakitetai, who was the founder of the lineage, was Rakaitengaru. This title, ‘Hasten in the Waves’, was a secret one, corresponding to the more well-known one of Tiporokou. Both were ‘evil titles’ ( rau pariki ), his man-eating titles. Under this title the god operated under all the skies known to the Tikopia; he destroyed canoes and ships and crews. From his position in the ocean he would see a vessel above, then rise and stand on the deck, and press it down beneath the waves, after which he would devour the men. The hull did not drift on, as is the usual case with a canoe overwhelmed at sea, but sank down to the bottom. Another method he used to destroy vessels was to part the ocean--‘to separate the path of the vessel’--so that it fell down in a watery cleft and the waves closed over it; he could then eat the crew at leisure. The total loss of craft at sea, with nothing ever heard of them again, was due to him. ‘We think that the canoe has been attacked and destroyed in a foreign land, but no; not slain in another land’ (cf. Work of the Gods , p. 301). So in this transformation the god represents the principle of mysterious disaster at sea, though without any particular ‘head’ referent. But the association between ‘head’ and ‘disaster’, seen already in the bursting out from his mother's head, is carried a step further in a variant of the tale of the killing of Tangaroa (see later.) According to Pae Sao, Tangaroa was not the real victim of the attacker Resa; it was the Atua Lasi, and Tangaroa was the result, the pieces of the shattered head . Tangaroa was ‘the chips of the head of the Atua Lasi’. And a title of the Atua Lasi in Taumako was Te Urupaku, the Dry Head. 1 Paku with short final vowel (ordinarily as pakupaku ) means ‘dry’; paku with stressed long final vowel means to thud with noise, to resound. The latter meaning would seem to fit the attack by Resa, but I think the former was the pronunciation in the name Te Urupaku. Here without much difficulty one can construct a pattern of Lévi-Straussian style: Tafito = original or base bursts through uru = head but without destroying it, and becomes himself uru = head, while incurring further power of bearing destruction; he is himself later destroyed by having his own head burst open, which in turn gives rise to another being; but in one context he is named by a ‘head’ title. Clearly some sense of continuity of theme and of opposed qualities is at work here, though as far as I can see from the data the pattern stops there.
This is thy enemy, Sukutere Writhe your tail in the belly of that person That his liver may be soft. And that he may not hold any food in himself.

As it writhes the man goes to excrete; he excretes water only.’ He added that he kept this knowledge to himself. ‘I leave it in myself, to make known to whomsoever has a good mind. I object to making it known lest people go and ensorcell others. Only our father utters it--Pa Tafua; and only in former days [before accepting Christianity]. Many were the people who died by his agency from the bloody excretion. The man who is killed by it, the blood drips, drips, his belly is not gripped together, and the man dies.’ From other sources it appeared that there had actually been a dysentery epidemic some years before I arrived in 1928, and that it had been attributed to the sorcery of the Ariki Tafua. (Here is a concept that the knowledge of the names and formulae of black magic is a trust, justifiable if used for one's own ends, but not to be used for general bewitching by any casual person--hence the reference to persons ‘of good will’, that is, with a genuine grievance to redress.) I was also told by Kavakiua of Taumako in 1928 that the Ariki Taumako invoked Tuna for black magic in connection with his sacred adzes, under the titles of Matanefu (Eyes Befogged) and Fakaseketaki. These titles were not confirmed by other people, though one similar to the second was said to be used by the Tavi elder in his Somosomo rites. (p. 173).

The association of the eel with the phallus is clearer. In Tikopia mythology the eel was given a phallic origin ( History and Traditions of Tikopia , 1961, p. 22 ). I remember when I first caught sight of a reef eel in Tikopia, when I knew only vaguely of its local religious associations, being struck by the similarity of its head to that of a male organ. Concupiscence towards women was believed to be a quality of all Tikopia male gods, but eel gods in particular were believed to be inflamed by such desires. Hence women were expected to keep away, not so much from places where material eels were found as from places in which eel gods were ritually invoked. This conceptualization of the eel as one of the most vivid symbols of the sex principle may have been an important component in the attribution of evil powers to it. Parallel to the contrast of destructive as well as creative power of the sex principle in social life was the ambivalent Tikopia attitude towards the eel as respected for his power yet feared for the use of it. More than most other gods the eel god was credited with the power of initiative in evil. The sinuousness of the eel and its great muscular power were related by the Tikopia to their interpretation of illness. It was believed that the eel could curl itself up within the human body for the purpose of doing harm, and the distinction between material and spiritual form was here vague. It was not thought that an eel physically entered a person's body, yet the Ariki Taumako told me in 1929 how when he laid hands on the Ariki Tafua to cure him he actually felt the movement of the eel god under his hand in the patient's belly. Most Tikopia manifested a very strong negative affective attitude in regard to the eel. When on one occasion the channel from the lake to the sea was opened to catch fish, people described to me how disgusting was the sight of the eels writhing their way down the dry watercourse; one man said it made him want to vomit. No Tikopia would eat an eel.

Feke did not occupy a very important place in the kava lists of the chiefs other than the Ariki Kafika. By the Ariki Tafua he was invoked under the name of Feke in the kava, in particular for the sacred oven in his canoe yard. As the husband of the Tafua goddess Nau Fiora ( op. cit ., p. 123), he was adjured to furnish a material contribution in the form of a shark or other large fish. The Ariki Tafua identified Feke with the sun and said that he invoked the god also under the title of the Sacred Ray (Kaveitapu). I did not obtain titles of Feke from the kava of the other two chiefs. Pae Sao told me that the title used by the Ariki Fangarere was Black Ray (Kaveiuri), and by Pa Fenumera of Fangarere I was told that Te Urungaru (ordinary term for headache) was a title for Feke used by a former chief of that clan. The Ariki Taumako, who did not invoke Feke in his normal kava, did so, however, when he performed the kava in Niukapu, a lineage offshoot from the chiefly lineage of Taumako, which had settled in Faea long ago. Pa Niukapu explained to me in 1929 that since the autochthonous Nga Faea had been expelled ( History and Traditions of Tikopia , pp. 136 et seq .) their deities were invoked and appeased in the kava of his lineage lest people be devoured by them in revenge: ‘lest we be eaten by the atua , exasperated because of their men who were slain’. By ‘eaten’ he meant afflicted with illness and death. So when the kava formula was recited the deities of Nga Faea were invoked first and those of Taumako subsequently. The first title ‘lifted’ was Feke, then came Taukaveivaru, which he said was a collective term for the rays of Feke. ‘His rays are gathered together and are made his sons, eight rays collectively.’ This explanation reconciled to some extent the discrepancy noted earlier whereby various elders translated titles such as Kaveitoto as being the names of other deities than Feke. Pa Niukapu said that a famous ancestor of his, a noted sea voyager ( Work of the Gods , p. 377), had gone at his death to Nukutureki, a dwelling of Feke beneath the ocean, and that this name formerly had been applied to an open space near his house (where later the church of St Mary stood). More recently this space had been renamed Putafe (Foam Ancestor) which, he said, was still another honorific title of Feke.

While there was disagreement and even confusion about the relationship of some female deities, there was a wide measure of agreement in the recognition of a pair primary to Porima lineage, known generally as A Ruanea, as the same dual entity who assumed different titles and roles over many social groups. A description of them, with a list of titles under which they were invoked (not necessarily complete) was given to me by Pa Porima, in great secrecy and fear, and many other men also gave me information about them, either in interview or in working contexts. On three points all were agreed: that these female deities were invoked very generally--‘they are in all lineages’; that they were essentially a pair, with balanced titles; and that their powers were great, tending towards illness and destruction. As a mythic corollary, they were usually identified as the sisters of the Atua i te Uruao, and one of them (opinion varied as to which) was the wife of Pu Taufiti, usually said to be Rata (cf. op. cit ., p. 90). According to Pae Sao in 1929 the two deities lived in a cave known as Te Rua sa Akitunu on Reani. They were sisters of the Atua i te Uruao, generated like him from two sticks which rubbed together produced fire (the fire-plough). When a man climbed Reani the leaves of plants striking his body as he pushed his way through them snatched away his spirit ( mauri ) which goddesses put in their basket. The man then sickened and died unless action was taken to save him. (Since men often went up Reani this was a selective process.)

Another example of spirit medium behaviour in the domestic field was the consultation of the medium Pa Nukufuti by a member of the chiefly lineage of Taumako, Pa Nukutapu. He was concerned about the health of his wife and children, which he related to his possession of a ritual adze powered by a god of malignant temper whose representation was the reef eel. 3 See Tikopia Ritual and Belief , 1967, pp. 222-5. The woman had had dreams in which she was threatened by the eel, and Pa Nukutapu was anxious to know what the reason was, and if he was responsible. He came to the medium's dwelling one afternoon, having been summoned there by a ‘spirit’ message. I had previously been having a long seance with the medium, who in trance state awaited his visitor. When Pa Nukutapu unexpectedly saw me there he greeted me with surprise, then put on a comic act. He sat up very straight, locked his hands, rattled on the mat, assumed a fierce expression, then relaxed and said, laughing: ‘The Atua i Kafika has come!’ This imitation was treated as a mild joke by those present, including the medium in his trance state, but we then turned to serious things. After some general conversation the medium as spirit leaned forward and said to his visitor: ‘I summoned you, brother, to tell you something’. Then he referred to the adze and accused Pa Nukutapu of having used it improperly, by calling on the god without referring the matter to the control of his chief. Pa Nukutapu listened very seriously but denied that he had acted without due care. He said: ‘Oh! I have not called upon the name of the Atua’. But the medium repeated several times: ‘I am only just telling you; I have sympathy for you; I am saying this to you, brother, because you asked me....’ With the repeated denials of Pa Nukutapu the theme changed and concentrated on the assertion that the children had interfered with the adze. Pa Nukutapu said: ‘I tell the children not to go near the place where I sit, but they won't listen’. Further admonition by the medium in trance state followed, with Pa Nukutapu listening very respectfully. The talk was laconic and allusive to earlier discussion between them, and I did not understand it all, as I listened without interruption; but the medium was clearly searching for a way to identify an explanation which Pa Nukutapu would accept as fitting the facts as he knew them. Then Pa Nukutapu said apologetically, referring to his failure to bring a food gift because of the famine, ‘there's nothing to make it with--you know’. But he extracted from his belt in a fumbling way a short stick of tobacco, which the medium accepted with good grace as recompense for the consultation. It seemed to me that the diagnosis had been rather inconclusive, and had been precautionary rather than explanatory, but it seemed to have given satisfaction. It illustrated an important role of the spirit medium--to act as a recipient of confidences and complaints, to suggest alternative explanations, and to give some advice about conduct and reassurance about the future. This role came to a peak in cases of actual illness.

Simple ailments and injuries were treated by the Tikopia as chance occurrences, curing themselves. But since until recent times the Tikopia have had very little contact with Western medicine, they did not make the sharp distinction made by many other peoples between diseases that could be cured by medicine and those only to be cured by magic. The attribution of spirit causation was left fairly open. But in any persistent illness, or grave sudden illness, diagnosis was usually sought from a spirit medium.

But I had also got Nau Sao's side of the story. She said that she had laid hands upon him, but in vain; he had been cursed by the Ariki Tafua (the former Pa Rangifuri, father of the reigning chief). She said Samuel had been ensorcelled partly for stealing food, and partly because of an incident in a Tafua canoe. And the reason for inviting the present Ariki Tafua to come and try to heal Samuel was because the late Ariki Tafua had ensorcelled him. A crew of three had gone out in the Tafua sacred canoe, Tereiteata. Out at sea they had stood up and urinated over the side (instead of slipping into the water to do so). They had ‘made sport’ of the vessel, which had been dedicated to a former Tafua chief and bore his name (cf. p. 270). So the Ariki Tafua had cursed them--whereupon they all suffered: the heir to the chieftainship from a swollen leg, another young man from a deformed foot, and Samuel from his back injury. The Ariki Tafua, while he later lifted the curse from his own son, did not do so for the others, and so Samuel died. ‘When I went and looked at him, I observed that he would die,’ she said to me.

The father himself corroborated the story of making sport of the canoe, but put the responsibility for it upon the Tafua heir. He said: ‘Indeed, it was the canoe of the spirits--the spirit's name was Tereiteata--it is held to be their canoe.’ But he added: ‘It wasn't sorcery--it's not certain; I just don't know’, and he gave it as his opinion that it was the work of spirits only, and not a result of the action of the Ariki Tafua.

This example illustrates the kind of ambiguities inherent in such a situation for the patient and his kin. There was uncertainty as to the cause of the illness; a belief that it was the work of spirits, but difference of view as to whether they operated of their own volition or were stimulated to act by human agency. And all this in a milieu of longstanding Christianity, with appeal in turn to priest, chief and spirit medium.

But the spirit mediums were usually more assured. When Pa Nukurotoi discussed his patients with me he said in characteristic style: ‘My ancestor entered from the realm of spirits, flew into me to deal with the sick person. Thereupon he dealt with the sickness and there was recovery on the instant. A maro [pile of bark-cloth] was then presented to me.’ He told me of a man whose breast ached, with the pain spreading through his body. He diagnosed spirit affliction; the man had gone to his cultivation to plant taro when he was affected by a female deity who dwelt in a rock face near by, a goddess of the woods living in the ground, daughter of the Eel God of Tafua. The man was then cured. He described also how a married couple became ill with severe headache and body pains; he went to them as a medium and cured them. Then, as was common in the circumstances, the recovered pair returned home with him to confirm the cure. As a service of recompense they assisted him in rebuilding his house. On this occasion the male patient's dead brother Pa Veterei, as a spirit, 1 Tikopia Ritual and Belief , 1967, p. 224; cf. Primitive Polynesian Economy , 1939, p. 120. entered the medium and, so he said, lifted a huge post into position--one which the medium himself would have been incapable of handling. Pa Nukurotoi could not remember an itemized list of his cures; he simply said: ‘Very many people have been handled by me and made well.’ Other mediums gave me accounts of a dozen or so patients they had treated, and one medium listed nearly thirty, and said there were more he could not remember. His wife, who had prompted him a little on details, said proudly: ‘When you look at the list, he has done a great deal of healing’. A medium in 1952 even compared his healing activities to those of medical practitioners, saying: ‘We doctors ...’ using a Tikopia form of the English word.

But at this period the interpretation of the Cross diverged in some cases from its ordinary symbolic Christian meaning. It was used not only as a sacred symbol for the Founder of Christianity and for Christianity itself; it was also used as having power in its own right through its associations. The sign of the cross with the hand, as in many other parts of the Christian world, was not only a symbol of power but also the expression of power. It was believed to exorcise and also to be effective in curing the sick. Physical forms of the cross were also thought to have power in what may be described as a magical way. A cross roughly made of wood might be pushed up in the rafters of a Tikopia dwelling and used to exorcise evil spirits from a sick person. In this it was strictly analogous to pagan Tikopia protective compositions of leaves, and was called by the same term, feao . (The ordinary term for the cross used by Christian Tikopia was the Mota word, ualowolowo .) Similarly, a cross worn on a chain round the neck or on the forehead (Plate VI) of a Christian was his feao , his spiritual protection against physical ills. It was regarded as a sacred object. Crosses were often of wood, but those most admired were of copper or of some white metal such as aluminium or stainless steel. They were often home-made. When ready, they were not taken to be blessed by the priest, but were simply hung round the neck. But when a person went to bathe or to relieve nature, he did not take his cross, but hung it up in his house; it was held that it should not be carried into places of defilement (cf. Tikopia Ritual and Belief , p. 210).

But the maintenance of traditional religious knowledge among former ritual elders was to some degree a function of their belief not simply in its abstract truth but also in its pragmatic value. For them belief in the actuality of their pagan gods and ancestors, and hence in the importance of remembering the titles and roles of these, was kept alive by events such as the occurrence of sickness in their families. In theory it would have been possible for them to have transferred their interpretation of such illness from the field of pagan spirits to that of the operations of the Christian saints, and to the inscrutable will of God. Alternatively and much less probable at the 1952 period, they might have adopted some version of Western beliefs about the physical causation of sickness. For the most part they had done neither of these, but interpreted causation of the illness in terms of their most immediate conceptual experience, the volitional acts of traditional spirit beings. In part it was thought that these spirits beings acted from malevolence owing to their rejection. But the interpretation was usually more neutral; the spirits were regarded as simply behaving in character, as they always were thought to have done. Sometimes the issue was felt to be obscure: the Christian convert sincerely accepted the new faith, with the supremacy of God, but he did not thereby simply cease to believe in his old gods, and was uncertain whether they were still active around him or not. He had a suspicion that they might afflict him or his family, and also a notion that he still could summon their services if he wished to use them against others. So his ritual knowledge had a strong component of belief in its truth, and was tinged with an element of caution, even fear.

Another man, Christian since boyhood, explained to me how a dead brother of his had come and afflicted with sickness another brother, so that he, too, died. The first brother had put off to sea years before and been lost. In the Tikopia expression he was ‘made wet’ because no ritual burial of graveclothes--no symbolic funeral--took place for a long time (cf. my Elements of Social Organization , 1951, pp. 62-3, 71, plate 2a). As the Tikopia put it, ‘his valuables had not been spread’. Hence as a spirit he came and killed his younger brother. The latter had returned from working on Levers plantation with a chest complaint, which was diagnosed by a spirit medium as due to the activities of the spirit, but too late. The illness, already well established in the sick man's body, was being reinforced by the spirit, who would not relinquish his victim. So the sick man died. In the light of the medium's diagnosis preparations had been made to bury ritually the graveclothes of the brother lost at sea, but the symbolic funeral came too late; the ‘valuables’ were spread only on the same day as the funeral of his brother. Here was a demonstration of how among long-established Christians it was believed that the spirits of Christian Tikopia could behave precisely in the way in which traditional pagan Tikopia spirits were thought to have behaved. It also illustrated how among the Christian Tikopia of 1952 spirit beliefs of traditional type still operated as sanction for the enforcement of traditional funeral customs.

But clearly the mental processes involved were not without strain, and the wrench in proposing to abandon his traditional rites became apparent in symbolic form. I asked him did his gods object to his abandoning them? He said they objected. He had a dream, in which his father the deceased chief appeared to him, but would not speak to him. He turned his back upon his son, angry because the kava was being given up. Then the chief fell ill--he was sore in his chest, his eyes became blurred, his head was swimming and his back ached. Finally, he had something like a boil on his back, at the left loin--a pitted scar was still remaining. He recovered without the aid of the priest--there was no priest on Tikopia at that time. Some of his followers pointed out to me that the atua came to the chief in this way because unlike the Ariki Kafika he had made kava continuously for a long period, so they objected to his abandoning it. Empirically, as with spirit mediumship, such dreams and illness followed a fairly regular pattern (cf. Tikopia Ritual and Belief , 1967, pp. 326-8), the ‘conversion syndrome’, as part of the solution process for the stresses involved in the process of religious change.

To facilitate this discussion the Tikopia practices can be classified soughly under the same heads as I used for the classification of Maori economic magic: “ magic” of production; of protection; of destruction 5 Raymond Firth, Primitive Economics of the new Zealand Maori , London, 1929. pp. 242--268. Cf. my analysis of the economic aspects of ritual in Frimitive Polynesian Economy , 1939, Ch. V. For simplicity the rituals of conservation or increase there referred to (p. 170) have been included in this article under the heads of “magic” of protection and production. (This can be done since in a broad sense the aim of all magic is the increase, maintenance or decrease of resources, material or immaterial) Examples of the Tikopia “magic” of production are the formula for inducing plants to grow when they are set in the ground; the formulae for eatching fish. An example of the “magic” of protection is tying on of the ritualised Cordyline leaf necklet to preserve a person in good health. An example of the “magic” of destruction is sorcery directed against persons or food.

The “magic” of protection is much more limited in its practitioners. On the one hand, there are those who have a specific status entitlement -- ritual elders of lineages ( matapure ) and especially chiefs of clans ( ariki ) -- to care for the welfare of their group members. But while Tikopia is rigid in its adherence to the principle of patrilineal descent, it does not confine spiritual benefits so closely, and custom allows help to be obtained by resort to another than one's own lineage or clan head. (This custom has an advantage in that it is part of the mechanism of organization in practice and theory to deal with failure.) On the other hand, “magic” of protection can also be performed by persons of another social category, the spirit mediums ( vaka atua ). For practice in this capacity no particular status is required, only the ability to enter a state of dissociation and give the appropriate social responses. Here is an opportunity for women. No woman can be a chief or a ritual elder, 6 The status of “Female chief” -- Ariki fafine, is a special one, with social functions, and ritual significance, but without the political control and ritual duties of the normal male chief. but it is not uncommon for women, of ordinary as well as chiefly families, to be spirit mediums. Nor is this thought abnormal, or disapproved of, and they attend male as well as female patients. The “magical” procedures of protection and healing are more highly specialized and individualized than those of production. Much of them is common knowledge in the society at large, but the practitioners are regarded as having the special entitlement by status or capacity which secures them from imitation. No-one would use a procedure he had just “picked up”, as he might with some “magic” of production. There is a higher degree of esoteric conten', a greater degree of systematization, a more complete “performance”.

It will have been noted that a decrease in the “magic” of production is associated to some extent with the provision of an alternative, in the form of generalized prayers by mission teachers. This provision of alternative is seen more clearly with the “magic” of protection. In traditional Tikopia ritual the “magic” of protection is epitomised especially by the wearing of an oiled leaf circlet, put round the neck of a person by a chief or ritual elder with a formula for health and welfare. This is still done in pagan circles, and has the sociological function of serving as a demonstration of a ritual relation, and up to a point, a political relation between the person so invested and the man of rank. Practising Christians do not normally have such investment. But a similar function for them is fulfilled by the wearing of the Cross. Both it and the leaf necklet are described by the same general term feao , a ritually protective token. A conversation I had with two Christian lads in 1952 will illustrate the point. The Ariki Taumako, one of the three pagan chiefs, was about to hold an investiture one morning. I asked the lads if the leaf circlet was effective, was it “correct”? They answered that it was -- “the blocking of anything foolish”, i. e. of maleficient influences. “Then why don't you two go and get your circlets?” I asked ironically. “The dark crowd” -- i. e. it's a pagan affair. “Have you got your own protection then?” “Yes! the necklet of the Church.” The Cross on a chain round the neck was their feao , their spiritual protection against physical ills. Such a Cross can be made by anyone, they said, from the appropriate materials -- copper and a white metal such as aluminium or stainless steel. When it is made it does not need to be taken to be blessed by the priest; it is simply hung on the neck. But when the person goes to bathe, or to excrete, it should not be taken, but hung up in the house. If it should be taken to such contaminated places, ill results would occur.

Certain traditional formulae of protective “magic” seem to have practically died out. In 1929 I was given a protective formula known as te pongi by two experts in such matters. In 1952 the brother's son of one of them and successor to the ritual affairs of the lineage, did not know the formula, and did not even know what it was -- he had heard of it rather vaguely, but thought it was something performed at sea. But in another direction, that of spirit mediumship for healing, there seemed to have been some enlargement of role. There were three reasons for this. Firstly, the relatively smaller part played by the rituals of the pagan chiefs in the total Tikopia sphere gave those of the spirit mediums more importance. Secondly, in the loosoned state of Tikopia ritual allegiance, they were relatively freer agents, operating outside the authority of the chiefs to a greater extent than formerly. Thirdly, whereas in 1929 spirit mediums were tolerated within the Church, a sharpening of the doctrinal and political issues of Christianity versus the traditional beliefs had by 1952 made their position more controversial. Another reason too perhaps, was that by 1952 the limitations of Christianity as a means of preservation of bodily health were more clearly realised than in 1929, so that many people, Christian as well as pagan, tended to turn in time of sickness to others than the Christian priest and teachers. In the absence of developed medical facilities on the island, they turned to the spirit mediums. Mediums alleged even that some Christian teachers themselves had done this.

In 1928 9 I heard various accusations of sorcery, levelled on the whole against men of rank, including two chiefs. The Ariki Tafua, in particular, was alleged to have practised sorcery against men of his own clan, in order to secure their lands. In 1952 my impression was that such accusations were at least as common. One spirit medium, a woman, cited three cases of patients of hers who had been made ill by sorcery. Another spirit medium, a man, gave sorcery as the reason why the shoals of fish -- mackerel and another small pelagic fish -- which he claimed to have brought inshore did not always come in over the reef, where they could be caught. He commented “If I knew the man who worked sorcery on the fish, I would tell you his name, that you might write it down, but I do not know. A man who practises sorcery, his mind is evil, he's a bad man.” He was a Christian, as also were his family, who shared his views. Another case concerned a girl in the village where we lived. She fell ill, probably with the influenza which was then beginning to be epidemic. By various village people, including her father, she was said to have been affected by sorcery, because she had accused two men of chiefly family of having stolen some of our food. When she told us this, she said she was afraid of being beaten by these two, her illness, she believed later, was a spiritual affliction from the same source.

It is instructive to compare these two versions of this origins tale. Both mingle the mundane and the marvellous. A woman must be impregnated to conceive, but her impregnator is a gecko-spirit-man. Children are born by the ordinary route, but they converse while being born, and one bursts out from his mother's head. Both versions make casual use of much Tikopia cultural furniture which logically could come only later in the scheme of things--a wooden bowl, a bark-cloth belt, an assembly to determine the man responsible for a woman's pregnancy. Both versions also provide a traditional referent for major sectors of the Tikopia social system. The tale foreshadows the existence of the four clans by using clan names in referring to the deities, and in one case by stating baldly that they produced the modern chiefs. The tale also draws attention to the social importance of primogeniture in Tikopia, which is emphasized by the device whereby Tafito gained primacy over Semoana who would otherwise have been his elder brother. Perhaps here also is an expression in fantasy of sibling hostility, resolved in the tale by the victory of a younger over the eldest brother, though this victory is achieved only at a price--his disease and death endowment. The tale accounts also for the special association of Fangarere clan and chief with epidemic disease. Attributing hurricanes and other natural afflictions to the untimely breach of the birth process by Tafito, the tale implies a requirement of order in nature. It says in effect that disorder in one natural process is likely to be followed by disorder in another. (As another statement put it, illness and death lie with Tafito. As he sprang from the head of his mother, in anger she called out to him that sickness and death should go with him. And Tafito was the major Fangarere god.) In its second part, the incident with Tikarau the usurper, the tale provides a basis for an understanding of the “totemic” ascription of certain major foodstuffs to clan control, with attendant ritual procedures. 7 Firth, 1930-1, b.

The personal name of this man-god was Saku, or as some said, Sako; according to Pa Fenuatara, his descendant, he was known on earth as Pu Siku. He was the son of the Kafika chief Asoaso (see Chap. 4). He was a “sacred child” (nephew) to the people of Nga Faea, since his mother came from that group, and tradition links his name with that of one section of the modern representatives of Nga Faea, the lineage of Siku. 24 Those who look for similarities may note that according to Codrington (1891, 94-9) a chief of Florida named Siko, who afterwards became a ghost, instituted the seasonal Matambala rites. One member of this group, son of Pa Fangatoto, bore in 1929 the personal name Sako. Ordinarily however, the personal name of the mangod was never uttered by Tikopia. He was known instead as Te Atua i Kafika, “the Deity of Kafika”, or more familiarly by the people of the clan merely as “Te Atua”, “The Deity”, no further specification being needed. This is in itself an indication of his supremacy. He bore also several ritual names which were invoked on appropriate occasions by the different clan chiefs. His personal name among the gods, which was consequently that most properly to be invoked in the kava , was Mapusia. By the Ariki Kafika, however, he was called upon often under the honorific title of “Toku Ariki Tapu”, “My Sacred Chief”. The personal name Mapusia was rarely used in the kava on account of its sacredness--“it is not called upon, called upon constantly” said the Ariki in justification of his euphemistic mode of address. Another of these titles was “Te Ariki Fakamataku”, “The Fear-Causing Chief”. He was regarded as principally responsible for storms and thunder, which was caused by the trailing of his staff as he walked through the heavens clattering it from side to side and making the welkin resound. His anger was believed to be terrible. He could overwhelm an offender by striking him or his family with sickness and death. He could blast the whole island with drought, a hurricane or pestilence. Although he was the principal deity of the Kafika clan alone, he was feared by all the people of the island. Pa Vainunu said, “Look at the chiefly houses--they are respected, it is true--but the whole of the land obeys the one Chief, the chief of the Kafika. In this land which stands here the one god is above all others, the Deity of Kafika. No god can come and supplant him; he is high because he is strong.” This was a partisan statement, from a man of Kafika, but it did express the situation as it actually appeared.

The chief of Nga Ravenga had married a daughter of the Ariki Kafika (which daughter is not stated), and to her father she fled when her husband was killed. According to one account she carried with her an infant son; according to another the child was born after she had reached Kafika. The child was protected by his grandfather who named him “Fakaarofatia”, “Orphaned”. Soon after his arrival the portion of flesh was still hanging up outside the house, and from it the fat dripped, making a little pool on the ground. The infant, crawling about, strayed that way. It dabbled its fingers in the liquid, then sucked them. Hence, it is said arose the morbid disease which afflicts the chiefs of Fangarere, owing to the fact that they touched and actually absorbed some of the liquids from their dead father. This is the disease termed te mataora , an ulceration akin to yaws. (In 1929, the Ariki Fangarere was a sufferer from it, his foot being so ulcerated that he tended to travel as much as possible by canoe.)

Because of the almost universal practice of chewing betel it is difficult to pronounce on the state of the teeth of the Tikopia. The juice stains the lips a brilliant red which gives the chewer a most sophisticated appearance to the European eye, but the teeth speedily become covered with black film which renders them practically invisible in the mouth. It is not possible to say whether dental caries is frequent or not, but I gather the latter. Seremata from personal choice often gave up chewing betel for a period, cleaned his teeth, and then presented a beautiful white set in a smile. The state of the teeth is used as an index of age. Pae Sao, in describing his dead brother, said, “Not a tooth had fallen; he was only a young man.” And soft foods are spoken of as “the food of the old people--because they have no teeth.” The common practice of cracking a nut or other hard object with the teeth indicates their healthy state. Toothache appears to be rare. Teeth are not extracted by force, but if one becomes loose it is worked about until it comes out. The native expression is like ours--the tooth “falls.”

A fact is worth noting that may surprise many people--namely, that a brown-skinned folk in a tropical climate can be susceptible to sunburn. In the hottest months the Tikopia not infrequently suffer from this, particularly after a day's fishing in the open sea. The skin of the back becomes a dusky red under the brown and is quite painful; in some cases a crop of small blisters forms. The person has been “sunned,” as the expression is. Incidentally, on days of flat calm fishermen often plait for themselves small eyeshades ( taumata ) from coconut leaf to give some protection from the glare on the water.

One case only was quoted to me of a person having struck his mother. The man was Pa Nukuomanu, who at present suffers from what is apparently a type of framboesia, a pustular affection of the arm and leg which keeps breaking down into large open lesions of angry colouration. He has sought for a cure for years without success. His illness was attributed by the people at large to his wrong conduct, he having taken a stick in a fit of anger and hit his mother with it. She did not die at that time, but wept bitterly. After her death she is conceived as having returned to her son in spirit form, bringing the illness which she presented to him, as one hands over a matcrial object. The procedure employed by the mother is held to have followed a definite form usual in such cases of unfilial conduct. I transcribe from the native account. The mother goes and announces to her ancestors: “My son has not spoken properly to me. I have been struck by him.” Her ancestors grow angry; they speak: “It is good that you return to men to work sickness upon your son.” She does so and the thing is done.

It is important to notice how the sanction for filial conduct is thus ultimately a supernatural one, and that the full weight of the ancestral line is set behind it. The parent does not take action without having consulted the forbears and received their approval. This obviates action from purely personal pique or hard-heartedness, and gives the sanction a universal validity.

An explanation given by Pa Raifuri shows the underlying factors which the natives themselves hold to be responsible for this attitude. He said, “My cross-cousin is weighty indeed. I do not speak evilly to him. He also does not speak evilly to me. Because he is the son of the father's sister. One does not strike the father's sister, one does not speak evilly to her. Good speech only is made to her. The basis of the father's sister is the father. I do not speak evilly to my father, nor do I speak evilly to his sister, my aunt. I again do not speak evilly to the child of my father's sister. It is done in this fashion because she is of weight. Should I speak evilly to my father and my father's sister, when my father's sister dies, and I have spoken evilly to her, then it reacts and I become ill. That is its basis. The oven is fired, and when her oven-firing (final rite for the dead) is finished, the father's sister goes then to her ancestors and returns hither again to bring sickness upon her child who spoke evilly.”

The procedure of bringing illness ( fakafua ) is described as that of personal appeal to the ancestors to avenge the wrong committed; they approve of the punishment, and direct it. This power of calling down a visitation of illness upon an errant child is not, be it noted, the sole prerogative of the father's sister. That power lies also in the hands of a father, and even in that of a mother, through her own ancestors, as exemplified in the case of Pa Nukuomanu quoted above. Naturally the exercise of it is less frequent in the case of parents. (But action in the case of incestuous unions may be noted.)

From time to time epidemics occur, brought, as the natives themselves realize clearly, by foreign vessels. The generic native term for epidemic disease is maki or makimaki , and they distinguish such types as tare , cough or common cold, tiko toto , blood excretion (dysentery). Measles, influenza and other complaints have been introduced in this way, and usually rage with extreme virulence. There is the very strongest possible case for a ship carrying an infection of any kind not to touch at the island. The Tikopia, ignorant of the germ theory of disease, believe that an epidemic is due to the malignancy of those in control of the vessel. They associate it also to some extent with the blowing of the ship's whistle, so that the captain of the Southern Cross , at their request, abstained from the usual practice when weighing anchor. The onset and disappearance of a wave of common colds which followed the visit of the ship when I was set down on the island was a perfect illustration of the spread of an infection. It was gone in about a month, and did not recur again during my whole stay. To the rarity of calls of ships from the outside world is largely due the maintenance of the splendid health of this physically fine people.

The first act in the series of economic transactions now takes place. Immediately the boys enter the house coils of sinnet cord and paddles are pushed out from beneath the caves to the tuatina . Food from the oven of the morning is brought up too and laid outside for them. In this case Pa Niukapu and others protested and ordered a portion to be divided off for the parents of the boys. The paddles and sinnet cord are apportioned by the principal mother's brother--Pa Niukapu in this case. He takes the coils of cord, about twenty in number, with a paddle, a cylinder of turmeric, and some fish-hooks. To the more important relatives he offers a choice; to the more distant he hands out a particular item. He insists that each person shall go away with his or her sinnet cord. Women are frustrated in their efforts to hand over to others coils they have been given. “Each of you speak for a coil of sinnet for herself,” said Nau Niukapu to the women near her. It is intended that each person of the far tuatina shall receive a gift. He or she goes home, observes it closely, and next day returns with a coil of identical type which is handed in to the father of the boy as a return gift. In each case the binding cord of the coil is different--fish-line, hibiscus, a strip of rau fara, rauparon, siri futi , a piece of net or a hank of grass. This enables the authorship of each coil to be known and reciprocity to be made exact by the boy's father, through whose hands the property passes. The sinnet and paddles are the only goods reciprocated. Fish-hooks are given free. At the initiation of Munakina, Seremata, at the instance of the father, the mission teacher, proceeded to give out two fish hooks to each person of the general crowd who had witnessed the ceremony outside. This was liberality to gain a reputation. Sometimes a man will refuse to go outside in order not to increase the liability of the father; those who stay inside get no presents. So Raniata told me that when requested by Pa Paisi to join the fai tuatina , he did not do so. “This man,” he said, “had to give away plenty of things already.”

After partaking of a little food the boy is taken away by the tuatina who performed the operation, into the woods or down by the sea, and instructed how to care for his wound. Leaves of the kamika plant are rubbed in the hands till the juice comes and this is then allowed to drop upon the cut; the tuatina shows the lad how to do this, and how to tie up his penis. The lad dresses the cut himself afterwards for about a month till it is healed--though I was told by one man that the bandage is taken off in about five days. He is told not to go and play in the interval, and is usually too sore to do so for some time.

The theme of this song is the death of the composer at sea. Like so many Tikopia young men, he had made up his mind to set out by canoe to dare the terrors of the ocean, and had been lost. The song is both figurative and elliptical. The expression fakafua , here translated “falls in foam,” refers to the breaking waves in a storm, and is equivalent to the commoner word peau . But it is reminiscent too of another word, fakafua , which refers to the evil that spirits do to the health of human beings, and so here there is an analogy already with death in the image of the foaming waves overwhelming the craft. The head fillet of the young man, a decoration for the dance, is symbolic of his life, thus severed.

Tikopia medical practices were rudimentary, consisting of massage and external application of coconut oil and leaf infusions.
